headline: KOREA DISSIDENT FASTS TO PROTEST NEW ARRESTS
abstract: A leading South Korean Protestant minister has been on a hunger strike in prison since mid-Au@gust to protest the policies of President Chun Doo Hwan, according to Japanese Christian leaders.   The Rev. Moon Ik Hwan, a noted theologian and translator of the Bible into Korean, who is serving a 20-year sentence for sedition, began fasting to protest continuing arrests of students in South Korea and what he charges is President Chun's failure to achieve a promised ''national reconciliation,'' the Japan Emergency Christian Conference on Korean Problems, a Protestant group, announced at a news conference here.   ''There is concern that he plans to continue his fast until at least Sept. 22,'' a spokesman for the group said.  ''Even if he ends his fast then, there are fears that his body may not be able to stand it,'' the spokesman said. Dr. Moon is 63 years old and is said to have lost weight rapidly during his three weeks of not eating. The fast is the second this summer by a political prisoner linked to Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's most prominent dissident, to draw attention to grievances of the opposition.

headline: NU-WEST TO SELL OIL STAKE
abstract: Concern over the vehement opposition mounted by the Cities Service Company apparently helped to convince the Nu-West Group Ltd. to agree to sell its 7.2 percent stake in Cities Service to the American oil company, analysts said yesterday.   The agreement calls for Cities Service, based in Tulsa, Okla., to buy back the 6.02 million shares held by Nu-West, a Canadian real estate and energy company, for $307 million, or $51 a share. Nu-West paid about $45 a share, or a total of $272 million.

headline: HUNGER STRIKE STARTED BY 14 BASQUE INMATES
abstract: Fourteen Basque prisoners in the southern town of Cadiz began a hunger strike today to protest their transfer there from a Madrid jail, Justice Ministry sources said today.

headline: EMORY AYERS DIRECTOR
abstract: George M. Whitmore Jr., former managing director and chief executive officer of Cresap, McCormick & Paget Inc., the management consultant firm, has joined Emory Ayers Associates Inc., a similar but smaller concern, as managing director.   Mr. Whitmore said: ''After 27 years with a big firm, I look forward to taking a more entrepreneurial course, to getting more personally involved in helping build a young and growing firm and simply to have the chance to do more consulting and less managing.

headline: ATTACK ON POPE A CONSPIRACY, COURT SAYS
abstract: An Italian court said today that the attempt on the life of Pope John Paul II was part of a conspiracy and not the work of a single person.   The judges who convicted Mehmed Ali Agca of trying to kill the Pope said that the Turkish terrorist appeared to be the spearhead of a subversive organization but that there was no solid evidence to identify either the promoters of the conspiracy or the motives.   The judges issued their full 51-page opinion tonight three months after they sentenced the assailant to life imprisonment.  ''Agca was only the visible point of a conspiracy which, though impossible to define, was widespread and menacing and devised by shadowy forces which not even the Turkish authorities were able to render intelligible,'' the opinion said.

headline: POEM BY THE LAUREATE
abstract: ''Let's all in love and friendship hither come Whilst the shrill treble calls to thundering Tom, And since bells are for modest recreation Let's rise and ring and fall to admiration.'' Those lines are taken from a ringer's rhyme Composed in Cornwall in the Georgian time From the high parish church of St. Endellion, Loyal to the monarch in the late rebellion, Loyal to King Charles the First and Charles the Second, And through the Georges to our Prince of Wales, A human, friendly line that never fails.

headline: Iranian Prime Minister Asks Foes to Yield Arms
abstract: Iran's new Prime Minister appealed today to opposition groups to lay down their arms as guerrillas struck in two major cities and killed two supporters of the Government.   Teheran newspapers also said 23 people were executed last night.

headline: 5 BIG CANADIAN BANKS GAIN NEW YORK PERMITS
abstract: Ending a three-decade-old ''gentlemen's agreement,'' five major Canadian banks received permanent licenses yesterday to engage in full-service banking in New York.   Until yesterday's action, the agencies and branches of the five Canadian banks had been prohibited from engaging in consumer banking activities in New York.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Agency Rent-A-Car Inc. said it had increased its stake in Spencer Companies to 659,255 shares, or 38.5 percent, through the acquisition of 39,900 shares bought on the American Stock Exchange between Sept. 2 and Sept. 9 at prices ranging from 14 5/8 to 15 1/2 a share.   * Brunswick Corp. said it was negotiating to acquire International Controls Corp., a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., company formerly controlled by Robert L. Vesco, the financier. The company said that a preliminary agreement called for Brunswick to pay $23 a share in cash and stock for each of International Control's 3.74 million shares outstanding.

headline: ROLL-CALL IN HOUSE
abstract: Following is the roll-call vote of 238 to 195 by which the House of Representatives today approved President Reagan's three-year, 25 percent tax-cutting plan, the decisive vote on the legislation. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the President's plan. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 48 Democrats and 190 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 194 Democrats and 1 Republican. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting.  There are no vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, no; Flippo, no; Nichols, yes; Shelby, yes.  Republicans - Dickinson, yes; Edwards, yes; Smith yes.

headline: Bank Robbery in Hong Kong
abstract: Three robbers who threatened tellers with firebombs, pistols and knives stole more than $20,000 from a Hong Kong branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank today, a police spokesman said. The thieves waved bottles of what they said was a flammable liquid and threatened to set the bank on fire. After the robbery, they fled in car, the spokesman said.

headline: WORLD'S WOES AID MAKER OF BANKNOTES
abstract: Political unrest, inflation and toppling governments: These are good tidings for the International Banknote Company, a New York corporation with highly secretive operations that has made a name for itself as a printer of currency for third world nations.   Fighting breaks out and a third world government falls in a coup d'etat. The new government wants the portraits of its leaders on all currency. It does not turn to a new printer; instead it orders a new batch of bills from International Banknote. Following the coup d'etat, inflation surges. That means more bills to be printed by International Banknote.

headline: Time's Film Unit Sold to Columbia
abstract: Time Inc. said it had sold the television production operations and other assets of its Time-Life Films subsidiary to Columbia Pictures Television, a division of Columbia Pictures Industries.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM ENGLISH VERSION OF THE POPE'S ENCYCLICAL 'ON HUMAN WORK'
abstract: Following are excerpts from the official English version of the encyclical of Pope John Paul II ''On Human Work'':   Through work man must earn his daily bread and contribute to the continual advance of science and technology and, above all, to elevating unceasingly the cultural and moral level of the society within which he lives in community with those who belong to the same family.   And work means any activity by man, whether manual or intellectual,whatever its nature or circumstances, it mean s any human activity that can and must be recognized as work, in t he midst of all the manyactivities of which man is capable and to whi ch he is predisposed by his very nature, by virtue of humanity itself . Man is made to be in the visible universe an image and likeness of God Himself, and he is placed in it in order to subdue the earth. Fr om the beginning therefore he is called to work.

headline: New Military Uprising In Bolivia Is Reported
abstract: A new attempt to oust President Luis Garcia Meza was reported under way today, with rebel broadcasts saying that insurgent troops had taken control of the provincial capital of Santa Cruz.

headline: TRANSAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PAKISTAN'S GRIM ISLAMIC LAW IS NOT JUST A THREAT
abstract: An 18-year-old high school student and the 24-year-old school bus driver with whom she eloped were ordered recently to be flogged and then stoned to death for adultery.   It was the first such sentence passed by a religious court here since Pakistan adopted traditional punishments for violations of Koranic law more than three years ago.   The ruling, announced here Sept. 1, is the most dramatic example of the Government-sponsored attempt to foster standards of probity and private behavior that are defined as Islamic.   Most of these efforts center on relations between men and women, and in the last month they have involved decisions to limit or ban female models on television and the cancellation of a foreign trip by a women's field hockey team on the ground that there would be male spectators watching the games. Meanwhile, Government organizations are considering a national standard of dress.

headline: CENTRAL WISCONSIN BANK SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Business Conditions; FARM INCOMES FADE
abstract: Despite the July uptick in food price inflation, developments during the first half of 1980 - weak agricultural commodity prices, rising costs and a strong dollar - have not been appreciated down on the farm.   According to Jeffrey Miller, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, net farm income was running at a $21 billion annual rate, seasonally adjusted, through June.

headline: WEDNESDAY, JULY 22, 1981; Economic Summit Meeting
abstract: The seven major industrial democracies concluded their economic summit meeting with a pledge to revitalize their economies, but no agreement on how to accomplish this. World leaders attending the Ottawa conference vowed to defeat inflation and unemployment, avoid protectionist policies and help poor nations. Grievances, however, remained against President Reagan's economic policies, and the resultant high interest rates. (Page A1.)   The 2,000-word communique by the meeting's leaders papered over differences between the President's priority of getting inflation under control and rising European concern about lagging economic growth. (D18.)

headline: Dutch Premier to Try To Fashion a Cabinet
abstract: Queen Beatrix assigned Prime Minister Andreas A.M. van Agt today to form a coalition of his Christian Democratic Party, Labor and Democrats '66, the Government Information Office said. The party leaders have been negotiating for three months since Mr. van Agt's coalition lost a slim majority in Parliament in the May 26 election.

headline: CBS AND RCA SEEK NEW BROADCASTING: SATELLITE TO HOME
abstract: CBS Inc. and the RCA Corporation filed separate requests yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission to start services that would beam television programs from satellites directly to homes and apartments with small receiving antennas.   The two communications giants and 10 smaller companies met the F.C.C.'s deadline of yesterday afternoon for direct broadcast proposals.   The commission will now have to decide which and how many of the services to approve. It is expected to take into account a multinational conference scheduled for 1983 to divide satellite frequencies among all nations wishing to use them.

headline: Comment; WALL STREET VIEW: WELL, I LIKE REAGAN
abstract: T OO much credence has been given to the view that Wall Street doesn't approve of the Reagan program, or is becoming convinced that it won't work. Many of the critics represent partisan and in my opinion minority views. Just last week in two articles, most of those quoted were prominent Wall Street Democrats who obviously don't agree with President Reagan or any other Republican program.   I have been on Wall Street since 1931 and remember the days when leaders of the financial community such as J.P. Morgan, Thomas Lamont, Bernard Baruch, Sidney Weinberg, Gustave Levy, and the speculators like Joe Kennedy, W.C. Durant and Ben Smith, were vocal spokesmen and in fact influenced Presidents and the economic course of this nation. However, today most of Wall street watches the country find its way through the ups and downs of economic and political history and remains silent.

headline: Judge Delays New Rule On NOW Account Use
abstract: A Federal judge, acting on a request by commercial banks, temporarily blocked savings and loan associations today from offering interest-bearing checking accounts to nonprofit organizations and state and local governments.   United States District Judge Harold Greene issued a 10-day temporary restraining order stopping a new Federal regulation that expands the use of NOW accounts - negotiable orders of withdrawal - from taking effect today, as had been scheduled.

headline: BEGIN DENIES A LINK BETWEEN AWACS AND U.S. STRATEGIC TIES WITH ISRAEL
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that in his talks with President Reagan and other American officials, no hint was given that any link existed between the sale of surveillance aircraft to Saudi Arabia and broad strategic cooperation with Israel.    ''In all my con versations with the President and his advisers,'' Mr. Begin sai d, ''I never heard, not a single hint, nor did my colleagues. T here is no link between these things.''   He was replying to a reporter's question, after the weekly Cabinet meeting, about statements in Washington that Congressional rejection of the sale would disrupt plans to strengthen United States military ties with Israel.

headline: U.S. SEEKS FLEXIBILITY IN ARMS SALES
abstract: The White House today made public a new Presidential policy directive on sales of conventional arms that was said to be aimed at giving the Reagan Administration greater flexibility in using the transfer of weapons as a tool of foreign policy.   The directive, which replaces one issued in May 1977 by President Carter, means, according to a senior Government official, that the human-rights record of potential customers will be a factor but not ''the sole determinant'' in deciding whether to make the sale. It also apparently signals the end of self-imposed ''unilateral restraint'' on American arms deals in view of the Soviet sales program.   ''We will deal with the world as it is, rather than as we would like it to be,'' said the policy directive, which President Reagan signed yesterday.

headline: UNITED FIRE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hunt Coal Tie To Shamrock
abstract: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said it had formed a joint venture with the Hunt Energy Corporation to mine coal in Alaska's Cook Inlet area near Anchorage.   Diamond Shamrock said the 50-50 venture would be managed by its Diamond Alaska Coal Company subsidiary and that about $25 million would be spent on predevelopment costs.

headline: POLISH LIBERALS SEE CONSERVATIVE THREAT
abstract: In a report disseminated today, a group of liberals charges that there is a danger that Poland's Communist Party will be taken over by conservatives who will frustrate the general desire for change.   The report, written yesterday, comes just before the opening of an emergency party congress and clearly reflects concern on the part of radicals that their positions will not prevail.   The report was compiled by an organization that calls itself Experience and the Future. It was founded in November 1978 and included more than 100 journalists, scholars and intellectuals, many of them from the Communist Party itself. The group has produced three other reports, including two published before the strikes last summer that predicted an explosion of social unrest.

headline: CHANGE IS A DU PONT TRADITION
abstract: First, there was Du Pont. And then Du Pont begat gunpowder, and the gunpowder business begat chemicals.  Chemicals begat nylon, and the nylon business begat fibers. Fibers begat diversification, and the diversification begat Conoco. Conoco?   ''I have heard people use the term mishmash,'' said Edward G.  Jefferson, chairman of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, commenting on his corporation's takeover of Conoco Inc. ''Well, you know, that is all good sport for the morning paper, but it really doesn't describe this at all.''   Whether mishmash or synergism, the marriage of the venerable lord of Delaware to a giant wildcatting oil company out of Ponca City, Okla., has left more than a few people wondering about the future of Du Pont.

headline: Japan's Soviet Exports Rise
abstract: The Soviet Union replaced China as Japan's second-largest steel export market after the United States in the first half of this year, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today.   Officials in the statistics bureau of the federation said steel exports to the Soviet Union surged 91.3 percent during the six-month period from a year earlier, to a total of 1.313 million metric tons.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The encyclical letter that Pope John Paul II issued yesterday on the subject of work and human dignity is the Pope's third major statement relating Roman Catholic doctrine to modern problems.   Like the earlier two encyclicals - one on the ''moral disorder'' of the arms race and another on the dangers of materialism - ''Laborem Exercens'' (''On Human Work'') is a nuanced document that reveals both the Pope's scholarly background and his pastoral concern for the way the modern world affects the life of the Christian.   The Polish-born Pope's diplomatic tact is also evident in the balanced critique of both capitalism and Marxism. By stressing the theological aspect of work as humanity's ''specific dignity,'' he gives a spiritual dimension to labor at a time when economic and technological developments tend to downgrade the worker, making him merely a unit of production or operator of machinery.

headline: Ludlow Agrees To Bairnco Bid
abstract: The Ludlow Corporation, after spending two years fighting an on-and-off takeover attempt by Tyco Laboratories Inc., said that it had agreed to merge with the Bairnco Corporation in a takeover valued at about $90 million.   The definitive merger agreement, which has been approved by directors of both companies, provides for Ludlow to become a wholly owned subsidiary of Bairnco following a cash tender offer, beginning this week, of $25 a share for Ludlow's 3.1 million outstanding shares.

headline: Stocks Slip With Dow Off 6.09
abstract: The stock market drifted lower yesterday amid moderate volume. The decline and slower activity, analysts said, were partly attributable the wait-and-see stance of institutional investors in the face of uncertainty about the outlook for interest rates and the shape of the tax bill being debated in Congress. Also, a trading halt in two key takeover-related shares dampened activity somewhat.   The Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.09, to 948.25. The current level is not very far above the low for this year of 931.57 and well below below the 1981 high of 1024.05.

headline: Heavy Storms Hit Britain
abstract: Violent thunderstorms swept across Britain today, setting off widespread flooding but bringing some relief from the hottest weather of the summer. In Manchester, where 3 1/2 inches of rain fell in 24 hours, a landslide damaged a major suburban highway. In London flooding shorted out sections of the subway system, and operations at Heathrow Airport were disrupted.

headline: COFFEE QUOTAS ARE CUT AGAIN
abstract: Falling prices, oversupply and stagnant consumption forced the 70-nation International Coffee Organization today to cut export quotas for the fourth time in the crop year ending Sept. 30.   After two days of discussions, producers and consumers in the organization's executive board agreed to cut the July-September quarter export quota by 1.4 million bags, effective immediately.

headline: People
abstract: * Nicholas Gisonde and Barry Lisee have been elected senior vice presidents of Backer & Spielvogel.

headline: JUNTA TAKES CONTROL IN BOLIVIA
abstract: A three-man military junta has assumed control of the country, but the two rebel generals who forced the resignation last night of President Luis Garcia Meza are holding out for further negotiations.   The commanders of the army, the navy and the air force said they had formed a ruling triumvirate, the 190th Government Bolivia has had in its 156-year history.

headline: Advertising
abstract: Philip H. Dougherty Intermarco Looks Back   A YEAR ago in the light, airy, dignified and sincere surroundings of the Plaza's Palm Court, Ramon G. Gaulke, just getting accustomed to being chairman of Intermarco-America, talked expansively about the newly formed shop and its breakthrough plan.   Imagine an ad agency with no account executives to act as liaison with the client, having the creative teams doing that work themselves.   Well, it seemed like a good idea at the time.  Back in the Palm Court for breakfast yesterday was the same Ramon Gaulke, one-time president of Marsteller, who as before was accompanied by Gerard Pedraglio, vice chairman of the Intermarco-Farner network of the Publicis group that is half owner of Mr. Gaulke's operation.

headline: PHOTOGRAPHIC SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Seiko of America Has New President
abstract: Takayoshi Saito, 48 years old, has been appointed president of the Seiko Corporation of America, the United States subsidiary of K.  Hattori & Company of Japan, which calls itself the world's largest watch manufacturer.   Hattori, which was founded in 1881 as a shop selling imported watches, was the first company to market quartz watches in 1969.

headline: Caracas Oil Output
abstract: Venezuelan oil production for 1981 through Aug. 5 averaged 2 million barrels a day, a decline of 69,000 from average daily output in 1980, the Mines and Energy Ministry said today.

headline: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Fewer 'Boat People' Afloat
abstract: The number of Vietnamese ''boat people'' arriving in East and Southeast Asian countries in August was the lowest in 11 months, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees reported today.

headline: Bethlehem Steel Planning Layoffs
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it will lay off about 300 salaried workers this weekend at its plant in this city just south of Buffalo.

headline: AMERICAN MEDICAL AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A U.S. AWACS ROLE PRESSED ON SAUDIS
abstract: A Saudi prince, the White House national security adviser and a key Democratic Senator today discussed proposals that would permit the United States to share a measure of control over the five Awacs surveillance planes that the Reagan Administraton wants to sell to Saudi Arabia, according to Senate and Administration sources.   Senator John Glenn of Ohio told reporters after a four-hour meeting tonight that he had ''very interesting discussions,'' which he said would continue tomorrow, with Prince Bandar bin Sultan, who is a son of the Saudi Defense Minister and an air force officer, and with Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser to President Reagan. (According to The Associated Press, P rince Bandar also conferred with President Reagan for 15 to 20 minutes.)   Two R epubli can Senators, Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, who is the Republica n leader in the Senate, and Paul Laxalt of Nevada, who is a close fr iend of President Reagan, were present for part of today's meeti ng, an aide to Senator Glenn said.

headline: CHESAPEAKE CORP OF VIRGINIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 14
QADDAFI SAID TO SEEK MEETING ON U.S. 'AGGRESSION'
abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, paid a brief visit to Kuwait today and then flew to Syria in a reported attempt to win support for a discussion by Arab leaders on what to do about United States ''aggression.''   A Qaddafi aide who asked to remain anonymous said that two Persian Gulf nations, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, had agreed that the topic should be taken up at a proposed conference of Arab leaders that the Lebanese have been seeking to discuss the issue of southern Lebanon.   Syria, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia had previously announced support for such a conference, which Lebanese officials said should concentrate on forming a unified Arab strategy against Israeli attacks on Palestinian bases in southern Lebanon.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: * Bank of New York has elected Richard P. Kiernan, Bruce E. Smith, George W. Van Der Ploeg and Mark Wolf vice presidents.   * Central National Bank of New York has elected Jerome D. Twomey executive vice president and chief lending officer.

headline: CABINET IN FRANCE APPROVES TAKEOVERS
abstract: The French Government approved a sweeping nationalization law today that would cost it more than $9 billion - twice as much as expected - to take over five major industrial corporations and 36 French banks.   Ignoring its own advisory body, the Council of State, the Socialist-led coalition Government declined to include foreign banks in its takeover plan.   The legislation, approved at a Cabinet meeting under the chairmanship of President Francois Mitterrand, now goes to the National Assembly for debate. The Socialist majority in Parliament virtually assures the law's passage. However, the Council of State, which advises the Government on the constitutionality of proposed laws, could reject it on constitutional grounds. The council is made up of 23 elder statesmen, most of them hold-overs from the center and right governments of the past 23 years. If it rejected the plan, the Government would presumably revise the plan and submit it again.

headline: Moscow Renews Offer On Nuclear Missiles
abstract: Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Soviet Defense Minister, renewed an offer today to reduce the number of nuclear missiles targeted on Western Europe if the West dropped plans to deploy missiles there aimed at the Soviet Union.   Marshal Ustinov's offer, identical to one made by Leonid I.  Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, in a speech in East Berlin in October 1979, came in a full-page article in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda. Mr. Brezhnev's offer was turned down.   Marshal Ustinov did not say whether the missiles Moscow might pull out would be destroyed or merely moved eastward and he did not specify whether they would be the modern SS-20's or the older SS-4 and SS-5 rockets.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Loan for Philippines MANILA, July 27 (Reuters) - The Bankers Trust Company of New York has been authorized to raise a $100 million 10-year loan for the central bank of the Philippines, officials of the central bank said today. The interest rate is to be 3/4 percentage point over the London interbank rate plus a management fee of 3/4 percentage point.

headline: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Apex Oil said a subsidiary began its previously announced tender offer for shares of Clark Oil and Refining Corp. at $37 net per share. Apex, which owns 9.9 percent of Clark's outstanding shares, recently acquired the right to purchase an additional 53.5 percent of the outstanding shares from certain members of the Clark and Dawes families.

headline: HONEYWELL EARNINGS UP 27.5%
abstract: Honeywell Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income rose 27.5 percent, to $71.4 million, or $3.15 ar share, from $56 million, or $2.51 a share, in the second quarter of 1980.   The company said 4 cents a share of the quarter's earnings resulted from extraordinary gains, compared with 2 cents in the period a year earlier.   Revenues in the second quarter increased 10.2 percent, to $1.30 billion, up from $1.18 billion a year earlier.  Despite the large surge in the latest period, Honeywell's chairman and chief executive officer, Edson W. Spencer, was cautious about the remainder of the year.

headline: Mine Merger Is Approved
abstract: The Sunshine Mining Company, a leading silver producer, announced that its plan to merge with the Silver Dollar Mining Company, Silver Syndicate Inc., Sunshine Consolidated Inc. and the Big Creek Apex Company had been approved by directors of the four companies, all silver-mining concerns based in Wallace, Idaho.   Under the agreement, valued at about $66 million, one share of Sunshine Mining common will be traded for 1.15 shares of Silver Dollar stock, 0.75 share of Silver Syndicate stock, 0.715 share of Big Creek Apex stock and 0.55 share of Sunshine Consolidated stock.  Sunshine Mining said that shareholder meetings on approval of the mergers are expected to be held in November.

headline: Westinghouse, I.T.T. in Pact
abstract: In separate ventures, the Westinghouse Electric Co mpany said it is teaming up with t he world's largest manufacturer of telecommunications equipment on a defense contract and with one of Japan's leading technological concerns on several projects.   The Westinghouse Aerospace Division and the Avionics Division of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced that they will work together on an $81 million defense contract.

headline: NEW SAUDI OIL OUTLET
abstract: The first shipment of oil through the 747-mile trans-Arabia pipeline was loaded aboard a tanker today, opening Saudi Arabia's second major oil export outlet and the first on the Red Sea.

headline: THE TAXMAN RUSHETH TO FILE ON TIME
abstract: Nelson A. Brooke's publications don't have fancy titles but then again, with a guaranteed press run of anywhere from 3.5 million to 92 million copies, there isn't much need for a snappy lead.   Al Brooke is the tanned, mustachioed assistant director of the Internal Revenue Service's tax forms and publications division. As such, he oversees the publication of tax schedules, forms and guides that this year will try valiantly to explain the enormous changes wrought by the passage of the 1981 tax act.   Ranging from the 100-page explainer, ''Your Federal Income Tax'' (once costing $1, now free like the forms), through Circular E's for employers to the 1040 series for all 92 million individual American taxpayers, the publications have been rushing to print since the moment Congress put the final touch on the law Aug. 4.

headline: TEXACO MAY SEEK $5.5 BILLION
abstract: Texaco Inc., which is expected to make a takeover bid for another oil company soon, is negotiating an option to borrow $5.5 billion from a group of American and foreign banks, banking sources disclosed yesterday.   And, in what appeared to be a related move, Conoco Inc., the nation's ninth-largest oil company, said it had arranged to borrow up to $3 billion.   The line of credit for Texaco, the nation's third-largest oil company, would be one of the largest ever granted, far exceeding the credit arranged less than a week ago by E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.   Du Pont arranged to borrow more than $3 billion as part of a $7.3 billion cash-and-stock offer for Conoco that valued the Conoco shares at $87.50. Conoco rejected a secret offer of $85 a share, thought to have come from Texaco, and another of $73 from the Seagram Company, amid continued speculation that one or the other - or both - would raise the bidding for Conoco.

headline: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BARTON BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A West Coast Defense Of Advertising Awards
abstract: Now the West Coast is contributing commentary on the matter of advertising awards.

headline: Earnings; DART AND KRAFT CLIMBS; BANGOR AND PUNTA DOUBLES
abstract: Dart and Kraft Inc., a diversified food, chemicals and consumer products company, said yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1981 rose 15.5 percent, while sales advanced 16 percent.   The Glenville, Ill., concern, formed in September 1980, by the merger of Dart Industries and Kraft Inc., said that net income in the latest three months rose to $116.1 million, or $2.12 a share, from $100.5 million, or $1.84 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales climbed to $2.61 billion, from $2.25 billion.

headline: CAMP IN GREECE A HALFWAY POINT FOR REFUGEES
abstract: Twenty-year-old Teresa, from Gdansk, Poland, has been waiting here for seven months to get clearance to begin a new life in Toronto.   Teresa, who asked that her last name not be used, says she left Poland because of economic hardships and the fears of a Soviet military intervention. She lives in a refugee camp in this dusty coastal town, 40 miles southeast of Athens. With her are more than a hundred other refugees, mostly from Eastern Europe and the Middle East.

headline: BLACK HILLS POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Litco Stockholders Approve Its Sale
abstract: Stockholders of Litco Bancorporation, holding company of the Long Island Trust Company, have overwhelmingly approved a previously announced proposal by Banca Commerciale Italiana to acquire all Litco's outstanding shares for at least $35 a share. The transaction is worth more than $93 million to Litco stockholders.

headline: Advertising; Magazine Renovation Success
abstract: LOUIS OLIVER GROPP says that he's all thumbs with a hammer, but he seems to be a handy fellow when it comes to renovating a homemaking magazine.   In the seven months since he moved in at House & Garden as editorin-chief, he's been polishing up its graphics and refurbishing its editorial content - and H.& G.'s circulation figures have acquired a new luster. Average circulation for this year's first half was 11.2 percent higher than in the same period last year, the Gallagher Report says, using Audit Bureau of Circulation figures. ''Maybe we' re on the right track,'' Mr. Gropp mused in his Madison Avenue office this week. ''We sort of operate on the premise that ourreaders are p retty bright, fairly affluent, kind of young - and that our job is to show them exciting, newsy, trendy material that they can pick and choose from. Where it fits them, they can put it on.  Where it does n't, they can go on to the next thing.''

headline: Philippine Blast Wounds 8
abstract: Eight people were wounded, three of them seriously, by a grenad e that was thrown into arestaurant here tonight, the police said. The identity and motive of the attacker were not immediately known.

headline: I.C.C. Chief Pledges Deregulation Support
abstract: In a wide-ranging talk with reporters here today, Reese H. Taylor Jr., the new chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, disavowed frequently heard suggestions that he would take his marching orders from the large operators in the trucking industry and from the Teamsters.   Even though he expressed concern about the liberal way the commission under Darius Gaskins Jr., his predecessor in the Carter Administration, had been handing out operating rights in line with its pro-competition policies, Mr. Taylor pledged to carry out fully the 1980 law on trucking deregulation.   ''The Congress is my boss,'' he said, ''and it is up to me to see that the agency faithfully carries out the laws. You won't find me trying to put the toothpaste back in tube, and I won't be an obstructionist.''

headline: Ian Smith Charges Mugabe Injures Zimbabwe's Economy
abstract: Ian D. Smith, Prime Minister before Rhodesia became Zimbabwe, said in an interview today that the nation's economy was ''deteriorating rapidly'' after 16 months of black majority rule.

headline: CONSOLIDATED ACCESSORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: China Reports Repelling Vietnamese 'Invaders'
abstract: Chinese soldiers repelled three border attacks by Vietnamese troops and killed a number of the ''invaders,'' the official New China News Agency said today.

headline: DU PONT VICTOR IN COSTLY BATTLE TO BUY CONOCO
abstract: The most expensive corporate takeover battle in history ended yesterday with the Du Pont Company announcing that it had acquired a controlling interest in Conoco Inc., America's ninth-largest oil company.   The chemical company will pay $7.57 billion in stock and cash to acquire Conoco in a deal that will make Du Pont the seventh-largest industrial corporation in the United States, just behind the Ford Motor Company. It is now ranked 15th in the Fortune 500 list.   ''This is so much bigger than anything that has every happened before in mergers,'' said Robert Powers, chairman of Smith Barney Inc., an investment bank. ''With all the lines of credit now being established by other oil companies, this could well be the start of a new wave of mergers and acquisitons in the energy field.''

headline: The U.N. Today; Sept. 30, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: GENE AMDAHL'S NEW COMPUTER VENTURE
abstract: I T would seem enough to scare off all but the most venturesome of investors. ''These securities are speculative and involve a very high degree of risk,'' the hefty prospectus warns in bold black letters. The investment, it says, is suitable only for those ''who have no need for liquidity'' and who have ''adequate means of providing for their current needs and contingencies, even if the investment results in a total loss.''   The prospectus - 133 pages dripping with caveats - covers a tax shelter bearing the name of Trilogy Computer Development Partners Ltd. The name itself reveals little. Its board chairman and founder, however, is Gene M. Amdahl, the 58-year-old computer designer. Mr.  Amdahl, principal architect of the revolutionary I.B.M. 360 computer series, left I.B.M. more than a decade ago to form his own computer company, the Amdahl Corporation, with which he severed ties last year after serving as chairman, consultant and chairman emeritus.

headline: A.T.& T. Plans High-Speed Cable
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced plans for what it said would be the world's longest high-speed digital coaxial cable system.

headline: CENTRAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Molybdenum Find Reported by Exxon
abstract: The Exxon Corporation said its Exxon Minerals Company unit had discovered what it termed a ''substantial'' deposit of molybdenum in central Nevada.

headline: Brezhnev Talks With Karmal
abstract: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, held talks in the Crimea today with Babrak Karmal, head of the Sovietbacked regime in Afghanistan. The Tass press agency said Mr.  Brezhnev had told Mr. Karmal that international tensions had ''considerably worsened recently'' because of actions by ''imperialistic circles, above all the U.S.A.''

headline: CENTRAL CAROLINA BANK & TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Uranium Accord
abstract: The European Economic Community has signed a 30-year agreement with Australia setting conditions for the sale of that country's uranium to the Common Market, the community said today. The accord bans military use of the uranium.

headline: COAL UNIT OF CONOCO IN VENTURE
abstract: The Consolidation Coal Company, a subsidiary of Conoco Inc., announced yesterday that it had agreed to form a joint venture with Rheinische Braunkohlenwerke A.G., a major West German mining company generally known as Rheinbraun, to develop up to five new coal mines in southwestern Pennsylvania. The deal includes a long-term sales agreement.   Consolidation, America's second-largest coal company, said the project could eventually produce 12.5 million tons of coal a year and generate revenues of about $500 million a year (at present coal prices).   Marc D. Cohen, a coal analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company, said the deal, if carried out, would be one of the largest of its kind for steam coal exports and would represent a ''classic'' in terms of how domestic coal companies can go after the booming steam coal export market.

headline: MOURNING IN ULSTER AND PARADING TOO
abstract: Thousands of Protestants today celebrated a 1690 victory over Roman Catholic forces a few hours after a sixth hunger striker died this morning at Maze Prison here.   The death of 26-year-old Martin Hurson at 4:30 A.M. was signaled to Catholic areas by the ritualistic clattering of garbage can lids by women. But perhaps because the death came as a surprise - the other deaths came after hunger strikes that lasted several days more - the violence that followed was far more modest than the reaction to the five other deaths.

headline: LITCO BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tosco to Sell 60% of Oil Unit
abstract: The Tosco Corporation said it was negotiating to sell up to 60 percent of a shale oil facility in Utah whose development plans were announced last month.   Tosco is primarily an independent oil refiner but is involved in the development of two shale oil projects.

headline: Credit Markets; RATES UP DESPITE FED MOVE
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday, despite moves by the Federal Reserve to supply more credit to the banking system temporarily.   According to many analysts, the near-record interest rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market is the main obstacle to lower interest rates in all maturities. In the absence of the long-awaited drop in the funds rate, and because of a heavy supply of new issues, most interest rates have been rising since mid-June.   In the long-term bond market, for example, the bellwether 13 7/8 percent Treasury bonds due 2011 were offered late in the day at 102 7/8 to yield 13.47 percent, compared with 12.55 percent on June 15.

headline: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THE CATHEDRAL WAS A COMPUTER
abstract: In a windowless basement room of the Data General Corporation in Westborough, Mass., engineers worked feverishly to produce a powerful new minicomputer vital to the company's future. Its archrival, the Digital Equipment Corporation of Maynard, Mass., had already introduced such a machine - a super minicomputer -forcing Data General to embark on a crash program in 1979 to design a powerful new mini of its own.   A book, ''The Soul of a New Machine,'' by Tracy Kidder, tells the story of two engineering teams of youthful computer designers - the Microkids and the Hardy Boys - who worked under high stress days, nights and weekends on what the company called project Eagle.   Mr. Kidder was there and his book recounts the pressures, the motivations, the corporate gamesmanship and the formidable technical problems. The project, under Tom West, a tough and individualistic manager, was a free-wheeling, risk-taking cell in the bowels of a structured corporation. ''Data General comes across as one of the few places people coming straight out of college can get in and contribute to a major project,'' said Edson D. De Castro, president and a founder of Data General. ''Of course, there is the other side of the coin. Did the company exploit them? But I think Kidder shows that for the engineers, involvement was a personally satisfying experience.''

headline: POLISH BISHOPS DENOUNCE OFFICIAL NEW MONOPOLY
abstract: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops, in a pastoral letter to be read from church pulpits tomorrow, said that limiting freedom of speech was ''inadmissible'' and that monopolizing the press and broadcasting was ''unacceptable.''   The bishops' statement was made available tonight and appeared to endorse the demands of Solidarity, Poland's independent union, for access to the press and braodcasting, a sore point with the Government here and with the Soviet Union.   Solidarity's leader, Lech Walesa, has vowed to lead an attempt to break the Communist Government's monopoly over the state-run press, radio and TV. He held talks yesterday with Archbishop Jozef Glemp, Poland's Roman Catholic primate, union sources said.

headline: Coat of Arms for Zimbabwe
abstract: The Government today unveiled a new Zimbabwean coat of arms, showing a hoe and a Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifle, with the motto, ''Unity, freedom, work.''

headline: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY UNCHANGED
abstract: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday afternoon that the nation's basic money supply was unchanged in the week ended July 22, a development that analysts said left the Fed with little reason to change monetary policy or short-term interest rates in the near future.   ''By itself the money number does not change anything, but it is part of a trend that, if continued for another half month, would set the stage for lower rates,'' said Maury Harris, an economist at Paine Webber Inc.   William Melton, an economist at the Irving Trust Company, added that the Fed would ''continue to be very cautious'' about encouraging lower rates by making bank reserves more plentiful. Although growth of the adjusted M-1B money supply measure is about $8 billion below the Fed's target of 3 1/2 percent growth this year, growth of M-2, the other closely watched money-supply measure, has been very rapid.  Mr. Melton estimated that M-2 would increase at a 12 or 13 percent annual rate in July, which would put it above the top 9 percent growth rate that the Fed has targeted for 1981.

headline: ARCHEOLOGIST DEFENDS WORK AS ISRAELI RABBIS RAIL
abstract: The stormy season of archeological excavation ended officially today in a potent mixture of history, religion and politics.   As the Chief Rabbinical Council met in solemn session to plan the religious hierarchy's political opposition to excavations on the site of ancient Jerusalem, the dig's chief archeologist, Yigal Shiloh of the Hebrew University, donned his favorite Mexican straw hat and led a gaggle of reporters and television crews through the dusty ruins, trying to interest them in what he had found there this season.   They kept asking him questions about politics and religion. He kept quoting from rulings in his favor by the Supreme Court and the Attorney General, and saying wistfully that he hoped next year he could spend his time on archeology rather than public relations.

headline: TEXT OF THE SOVIET MESSAGE TO POLAND
abstract: Following is the text of the Soviet message to Poland's leaders published in Warsaw today, as translated by the English-language service of the official Polish news agency P.A.P.:   The First Secretary of the P.U.W.P. Central Committee Stanislaw Kania and the Chairman of the Council of Ministers Wojciech Jaruzelski received the Soviet Amabassador Boris Aristov, who on behalf of the supreme party and state authorities of the Soviet Union stated the following:   The Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union and the Soviet Government are compelled to draw the attention of the Central Committee of the P.U.W.P . and of the Polish Government to thegrowing of an ti-Sovietism in Poland and to such an intensification ofit which has reached dangerous limits.   Facts indicate that an acute and unchecked campaign is being waged openly, widely and with impunity in the country against the Soviet Union, its foreign and home policies and that it amounts not to sporadic irresponsible hooligan excesses but to coordinated actions by the enemies of socialism of a clearly defined political line. Its main objective is to vilify and cast aspersions on the world's first socialist state and on the very idea of socialism, to enkindle among Poles hostility and hatred of the Soviet Union and the Soviet people, to break the bonds of the brotherly friendship linking our nations and as a result to wrest Poland out of the socialist commonwealth and to liquidate socialism in Poland herself.

headline: THE ITKINS RIDE THE 'WORK STATION' BOOM
abstract: Almost half a century ago, three brothers from Brooklyn joined forces as office furniture repairmen, pushing dolleys laden with freshly repaired goods along New York city's trolley tracks.  Canvassing skyscrapers floor by floor, the Itkin brothers ventured into sales, and gradually succeeded in unravelling the tight-knit fraternity of office furniture dealers.   Today, ''The Itkins,'' boasts a bustling Madison Avenue showroom, a sprawling warehouse and a fleet of snappy green trucks. It is also the largest retailer of office furniture in the nation.

headline: TWO TOP PARTIES SEEM DEADLOCKED IN ISRAELI RETURNS
abstract: Projections based on partial returns from Israel's general election yesterday showed the two major parties in a close, inconclusive race that appeared to provide Prime Minister Menachem Begin with a chance to form a government based on a slim majority in Parliament.   With nearly half of the vote counted, and on the basis of sample precincts, Israeli television predicted that Mr. Begin's Likud bloc and the opposition Labor Party of Shimon Peres would each win 48 or 49 seats in the 120-member Parliament, with a slight edge for Labor.   Of the votes counted 10 hours after the polls closed, Labor had won 38.3 percent and the Likud 35.8.  But the smaller parties on the left, whose support Labor would need to form a majority coalition, were doing very poorly and were expected to win no more than two or three seats among them. The religious and right-wing parties, potential allies of the Likud, were making a stronger showing, with up to 15 seats predicted for them altogether.

headline: More Soviet Talks Seen
abstract: American negotiators at the trade talks with the Soviet Union held out little hope today that a new grain agreement could be reached before the present pact expired on Sept.  30.   Willliam E. Brock, head of the 10-member United States trade delegation, said that he doubted a new agreement could be completed by tomorrow, when this round of talks is scheduled to end. ''There is a probability of further negotiations in September and October,'' he added.

headline: HAIG REBUFFS POOR NATIONS' PROGRAM FOR MORE AID
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M.  Haig Jr. said today that a third-world plan for a large increase in resources flowing from rich nations to poor ''is simply unrealistic.''   Instead, he urged Asian, African and Latin American countries to rely for development on free markets, private initiative and foreign capital.   Mr. Haig's address at the General Assembly surprised most diplomats because it was devoted almost exclusively to problems of promoting faster economic growth in the third world and touched only briefly on other aspects of international politics. Reaction to Haig Speech   Several third-world delegates, who declined to be named, said they were pleased that Mr. Haig had dealt at such length with a theme they regarded as critical. But most made clear that they were distressed by what they saw as a rejection of their proposal for what they call a new international economic order.

headline: Founder of Clark Oil Prepares for Takeover
abstract: In 1932, Emory T. Clark, built a gasoline service station in the Milwaukee area and later found himself in control of it when the owner ran out of money. Now, if an acquisition proposal of the Clark Oil and Refining Corporation, the huge company created from that station, goes through, the 24 Clark family trusts, established by Mr. Clark in 1965, will gain nearly $200 million for the 41.8 percent share of the company that they own.   Mr. Clark, who is 75 years old, no longer manages the company he founded, but he is still on its board of directors, as is his son, Roger. And his agreement to sell the family stock was an important factor in the decision of the Clark management to accept a $37-ashare tender offer from the Apex Holding Company.

headline: U.S. SAYS DATA SHOW TOXIN USE IN ASIA CONFLICT
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  said today that the United States now had ''physical evidence'' tha t poisonous chemicals have been used in Southea st Asia in apparent violation of international agreements banning their use.   In a wide-ranging speech aimed at bolstering West European morale and Excerpts from Haig speech, page A8. invigorating the alliance, Mr. Haig took note of what he said had been ''continuing reports'' that the Soviet Union and its allies had been using ''lethal chemical agents'' in Southeast Asia and Afghanistan, reports that had not been confirmed before. Now, he said, there was confirmation that three ''potent mycotoxins - poisonous substances not indigenous to the region and which are highly toxic to man and animals'' - had been found there.

headline: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Watt Opposes Stock Limits
abstract: Amid growing hostility to Canadian takeovers of United States companies, Interior Secretary James G.  Watt today expressed reluctance about proposals that revoke the right of Canadians to own stock in corporations that have mineral leases on Federal lands in the United States.   ''It would be inconsistent with U.S. investment policy and send a signal to other countries that the U.S. acknowledges investment limits as a legitimate foreign policy tool,'' Mr. Watt told a House Energy subcommittee.

headline: Technology Sales by U.S.
abstract: The United States would probably pay a higher financial and political price than the Soviet Union if plans to broaden the ban on advanced technology exports to Russia were adopted, according to a Rand Corporation study published today.   The report, prepared for the Defense Department, emphatically supports export controls on technologies with military applications.

headline: Around the World; 120 DIE AS TROPICAL STORM LASHES THE PHILIPPINES
abstract: Tropical storm Kelly, the worst in eight months, pounded the central Philippines with heavy rains today.

headline: A STAKE IN CANADIAN PACIFIC
abstract: When Paul Desmarais was in business school some 30 years ago, he wrote a research paper on how someone could take over Canadian Pacific Ltd., the giant corporate conglomerate so intimately tied to Canada's history.   Today, at the age of 50 and a highly successful French Canadian businessman, Mr. Desmarais may be well on the way to carrying out that research dream. For Mr. Desmarais, the head of and largest shareholder in the Power Corporation, a large holding company, has acquired almost 5 percent of Canadian Pacific with an option to buy another 5.6 percent.   The moves have excited talk in Canadian corporate circles that this country could be on the verge of witnessing the largest corporate takeover in its history, an estimated $3 billion effort to own a sprawling corporate giant with vast North American holdings in ships, planes, trains, trucks, hotels, steel mills, paper plants, mines, forests, oil, agriculture, real estate and even chinaware.

headline: Advertising; ACCOUNTS
abstract: * AM Cable TV Industries Inc., Quakertown, Pa., to Spiro & Associates, Philadelphia.

headline: SLIGHT REPRIEVE AT THE BULLETIN
abstract: The Bulletin has extended for five hours, until 5 P.M. Sunday, the deadline set for its unions to decide if they will accept economic concessions that the newspaper management says will save the 134-year-old publication.   The eight unions have scheduled a membership vote at 1 P.M. Sunday, The Bulletin's vice president of communications, B. Dale Davis, said today in explaining the extension.   The unions are being asked to agree to $4.9 million in contract concessions or face the closing of the newspaper on Sunday.  The unions have said they will hold separate membership meetings to vote on any proposals made and will notify management of the results by 5 P.M.

headline: SALVADOR TRIES TO RALLY SUPPORT FOR 1982 ELECTIONS
abstract: A grieving woman, lighting candles at the four corners of a body covered by a sheet, appeared on the television screen. It might have been her husband, daughter, son, or a friend killed by the political violence. A narrator asked viewers if they wanted the violence to continue. The bereaved woman said, ''El Salvador deserves your vote.''   The public service announcement has been taken off the air, to the relief of many Salvadorans who were troubled by the negative approach of associating elections and democracy with death.

headline: SILENT BUCKLEY LEAVES PAKISTAN
abstract: Under Secretary of State James L. Buckley, who three months ago negotiated a $3 billion military and economic package for Pakistan, left for Washington from a military section of Islamabad airport today after failing to attend a scheduled meeting with reporters.   At the end of his hastily arranged two-day visit there was no official indication of why he came to Pakistan or what he achieved.

headline: Court Supports Topps in Suit
abstract: A Federal appeals court has ruled that Topps Chewing Gum Inc. did not illegally corner the market on baseball trading cards through exclusive contracts with major league players.   In a unanimous opinion issued yesterday, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit said that the contracts between Topps and the Major League Baseball Players Association did not constitute ''an illegal restraint of trade.''

headline: General Motors Sets Dividend
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said today that it is paying a dividend of 60 cents a share on common stock in the third quarter, which ends Sept. 30.   The auto maker announced the dividend following a meeting of the company's board of directors.

headline: 19 SAVED FROM CANADIAN SHIP
abstract: A Canadian Coast Guard ship today rescued 19 survivors who had drifted at sea for two days after a research vessel sank with 32 people aboard.   The survivors of the Arctic Explorer were picked up after a helicopter spotted their inflatable raft in frigid, rough seas off the Newfoundland coast.   The bodies of eight crew members were later discovered close to the spot where the ship sank Friday morning off Newfoundland's northern tip. A search continued for five crew members who were still missing, a rescue official in St. John's, Newfoundland, said.

headline: INTEREST RATES MOVE HIGHER
abstract: Interest rates soared yesterday at the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills. The average rate realized on the three-month issue was 15.705 percent, up from 15.24 percent the week before, while the six-month rate climbed to 15.644 percent from 15.122.   With the addition of the quarter-point to the average six-month bill rate, banks and savings institutions may pay as much as 15.894 percent for their six-month savings certificates for the week starting today. The top rate last week was 15.372 percent.

headline: Firestone Changes
abstract: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said it is combining its corporate development activity and diversified products operations into a new corporate development group.

headline: VOPLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOLIDARITY OPENS THE SECOND PHASE OF GDANSK PARLEY
abstract: The Solidarity union opened the second phase of its national convention here today with invited American labor leaders absent, with Soviet reporters watching like hawks and with moderates and militants clashing over the issue of workers' participation in the management of industries.   Solidarity had invited three representatives of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., including Lane Kirkland, president of the 15-million-member organization, but they were not granted visas by the Polish Government. The Government, which has protested the financial support given to Solidarity by the A.F.L.-C.I.O, wants to discourage such expressions of fraternity from the United States.   A videotape of Mr. Kirkland delivering a speech was in hand but could not be played immediately because proper equipment was lacking. Instead, printed texts of the speech circulated through the cavernous hall of the Olivia Sports Stadium.

headline: COMPANY NEWS; Moody's Lowers Du Pont's Rating
abstract: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, burdened with billions of dollars in debt from its acquisition of Conoco Inc., lost its bluechip credit rating yesterday.   Moody's Investors Service Inc. reduced the rating of Du Pont's senior unsecured debt from Aaa, the top rating that is accorded to only a handful of companies, to Aa, the next level.   A Du Pont spokesman said that officials of the Wilmington, Del., chemical concern would have no immediate comment on the downgrading.  On Monday, Du Pont's chairman, Edward G. Jefferson, told shareholders that the company had borrowed nearly $4 billion to finance the acquisition of Conoco for cash and stock worth $7.7 billion. He said that he will try to reduce that debt over the next several years, possibly by selling some Conoco assets.

headline: PEOPLES EXPRESS AIRLINES reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Option Cash Set On Conoco
abstract: The Options Clearing Corporation, a private company that guarantees the payment of stock option transactions, is ordering that an estimated $50 million in Conoco stock options be settled in cash rather than in stock.   The move - the first time the clearing company has ordered a cash settlement because of a shortage of stock -will save market speculators from large financial losses.   The imbalance in orders came in the wake of an agreement by Joseph E. Seagram & Sons to transfer 28 million Conoco shares to E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. Du Pont's $7.5 billion cash and stock offer for Conoco prevailed over Seagram's rival takeover bid.

headline: Around the World; BRITISH LABOR PANEL FAVORS A UNIFIED IRELAND
abstract: In a major shift, the opposition Labor Party's policy group has recommended support for the eventual reunification of Northern Ireland with the Irish Republic, party officials said today.   Commenting on the recommendation, which must be ratified by the full party, the party's leader, Michael Foot, said that he favors Irish unity but that he remains opposed to the withdrawal of British troops from Northern Ireland at this time.

headline: Around the World; Poland Says Solidarity Is Increasing Tension
abstract: he Polish Government accused Solidarity of increasing tension in the nation today after union bus drivers in Radom struck for one hour.   Drivers in Radom, which is south of Warsaw, were demanding punishment of the Government officials responsible for suppressing a 1976 worker revolt that was sparked by an announcement of higher food prices.

headline: Advertising; Vanity Fair Names Its New Publisher
abstract: Joseph E. Corr Jr., has been named publisher of Vanity Fair, the Conde Nast magazine that resumes publication as a monthly in January 1983.   Previously, Mr. Corr has been vice president, marketing, for Heublein. He has also held a number of positions in advertising and promotion at Time Inc.

headline: JAPANESE CAR MAKERS STUDY EXPORT PLANS
abstract: After more than a decade of spearheading Japan's export drive, car manufacturers here are being forced to reassess their basic strategies because of recent agreements to curb shipments to the United States and several West European countries.   Industry spokesmen say the manufacturers face the problem of deciding whether to hold down production, after years of substantial annual increases, while seeing how far they can penetrate new markets.   Despite recent agreements to cut sales to their major markets against a background of intensified trade friction, the car companies have not reduced this year's production and export goals.  But an indication of their possible future action came this month when Toyota, Japan's largest car maker, announced an 8 percent production cut for July, to 12,600 vehicles a day. Its 1981 target of 3.3 million, however, was unchanged.

headline: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; Analyzing 'Irritation Factor'
abstract: WHAT Rena Bartos, senior vice president at J. Walter Thompson, calls ''the irritation factor'' in today's advertising has left her, if not exactly irritated, at least distinctly worried about its implications for the advertising industry.   ''A lot of advertising is very hard-hitting and very hard-sell,'' she said in a low-keyed, unirritating conversation the other day, ''and it's a lot of this kind of advertising which people find irritating.''   Before a brasher person could press for specifics, Mrs. Bartos gently cited a survey that the Gallup organization carried out some months ago on behalf of the National Advertising Review Board. She has analyzed it, and related research, in the July-August issue of Harvard Business Review.

headline: Patents; New Compounds Help Treat Hypertension
abstract: The National Foundation for Cancer Research, Bethesda, Md., received a patent this week for compounds that are useful in the treatment of hypertension and pain. Patent 4,287,205 was granted to Albert Szent-Gyorgyi, scientific director of the foundation's laboratory in Woods Hole, Mass., and Prof. Gabor B. Fodor of the University of West Virginia, an area director for the foundation.

headline: SOVIET INVITED TO SISCUSS NEW GRAIN PACT
abstract: A running dispute between the Agriculture Secretary and the Secretary of State over who would negotiate with the Soviet Union on a new grain trading pact has been settled, and an invitation for new talks has been sent to Moscow, an Agriculture Department official said today.   In a compromise solution, the State Department announced that Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, would head the American negotiating team.   A State Department spokesman said that no date or place had been set as yet. But it was understood that a message suggesting further talks was sent by the State Department this morning.

headline: U.S. STATEMENT ON NOTE BY REAGAN TO BREZHNEV
abstract: Following is the text of a statement made in New York yesterday by Dean Fischer, State Department spokesman, about the letter sent by President Reagan to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader: Following i s the text of a statement made in New York yesterday by Dean Fischer, State Department spokesman, about the letter sent by President Rea gan to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader:   On Sept. 22, President Reagan sent a letter to Soviet President Brezhnev outlining his views on the future of U.S.-Soviet relations, and describing his desire for a constructive relationship with the Soviet Union that will lead to a free and more peaceful world community.   I cannot give you a copy of the letter. What I can do is give you a sense of its contents and perhaps put it in the genral themes in which the President addressed President Brezhnev.   The general thrust of it is as follows: The United States is vitally interested in the peaceful resolution of international tensions and in a stable and constructive relationship with the Soviet Union.

headline: Conoco Oil Find
abstract: Conoco Inc. reported that a subsidiary had made what it called a ''significant'' oil discovery at a well in the Netherlands North Sea sector and also confirmed an earlier discovery. The unit, the Continental Netherlands Oil Company, which is operating for itself and six other concerns, said the new discovery well tested at a combined flow rate of 8,145 barrels of oil a day from two separate reservoirs. The company said additional drilling would be needed to determine the extent of the field.

headline: Longtime Hanoi Leader Heads New Presidency
abstract: Truong Chinh, a founding member of the Vietnamese Communist Party who was a rival of Ho Chi Minh for its leadership, was elected leader of Vietnam's new collective presidency today.

headline: WEST GERMANY AND ITALY CALL FOR EARLY SOVIET - U.S. PARLEY
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and Prime Minis te r Giovanni Spadolini today called on the superpowers to begin arms co ntrol negotiations and said that Western Europe had a right to be c onsulted by the United States on defense and economic issues.   Mr. Schmidt, who arrived yesterday for a three-day visit, said at a joint news conference: ''Italy and Germany believe negotiations are very important. But just as important are continued consultations with our countries. We intend to take the initiative and speak out on the progress of the negotiations.''

headline: RALLY UNLIKELY, EXPERTS SAY
abstract: Participants in the fixed-income market return today from their Labor Day holiday to face the grim prospect that bond yields - already brushing record highs - are likely to move higher still.   ''The peak in yields still lies ahead,'' said Philip Braverman, a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank.  The Treasury's newest long-term bond, the 13 7/8's of 2011, finished Friday at a price of 94, to yield 14.76 percent. Amid the deep gloom enveloping the bond market, the return on this security actually edged a bit higher during the week. But it never reached what would have been a new, startling plateau at 15 percent.

headline: HUSKY OIL OF CANADA TO SELL ITS U.S. UNIT
abstract: Husky Oil Ltd. of Calgary announced today that it will sell its United States subsidiary -with assets valued at nearly $1 billion - so that it can concentrate on its Canadian operations and on domestic exploration.   Husky's announcement said the company's board ''has decided to approach a selected list of companies in connection with the possible sale'' of the Husky Oil Company, its American subsidiary. It has retained the First Boston Corporation as its adviser.   The subsidiary is an integrated oil and gas company, with headquarters in Cody, Wyo., and listed reserves of 36 million barrels of crude oil and 96 billion cubic feet of natural gas. It owns the equivalent of 1.4 million acres, mostly in the West, and has three refineries, in Cody and Cheyenne, Wyo., and North Salt Lake, Utah, with a combined capacity of 60,000 barrels a day.

headline: Bucyrus-Erie Bids For Western Gear
abstract: The Bucyrus-Erie Company has made a cash offer of $171.2 million for all the shares of the Western Gear Corporation, the two companies said today.   Bucyrus-Erie, based in South Milwaukee, is a leading manufacturer of surface mining and construction equipment.

headline: G.O.P.'S TAX STRATEGY IN HOUSE: ALL OR NOTHING
abstract: President Reagan and Republican leaders in the House of Representatives decided today on a one-vote, all-ornothing strategy in which the House will choose between the Democratic tax bill drafted in the Ways and Means Committee and an Administration bill being sweetened to appeal to as many members as possible.   Signaling that the Republicans would not try to rewrite the Democratic bill with floor amendments, Representative Barber B.  Conable Jr. said upon leaving the White House, ''I think we will have an upand-down vote.'' Mr. Conable, a Republican from upstate New York, is the ranking minority member on Ways and Means.   He, other committee Republicans and the House leaders met with President Reagan for 70 minutes in the Cabinet room. Afterward, Mr.  Conable told reporters that ''there are going to be substantial changes in our bill'' to make it attractive to the largest possible number of Representatives.

headline: BONN DEFENSE AIDE SEES THREAT IN '82 BUDGET
abstract: West Germany's Defense Minister, detailing plans to slow the growth of defense spending, expressed concern today that Bonn's proposed 1982 austerity budget could hurt West German arms development and jeopardize the military's ability to cover its fuel needs.   Speaking on West German television yesterday, the minister, Hans Apel, said that Bonn's austerity plan would make it impossible to finance ''many desirable and or necessary'' defense projects.   Bonn has proposed increasing defense spending next year 4.2 percent to the equivalent of $17.6 billion at the present rate of exchange, prompting concern both in Washington and among opposition leaders here that, calculating inflation, which is running at 5 to 6 percent, defense spending could shrink in real terms and undermine the country's defense ability. But at a ne ws conference today, Mr. Apel rejected the suggestion that West Ger man defense spending would shrink next year.  ''We can sa y with assuredness there will be a plus before the percentage fi gure,'' he said. He indicated that growth after inflation wou ld be about 1 percent, adding that ''only at the year's end, knowing the actual inflation figure, will we know the real growth rate.' ' Plan to Free Funds Outlined

headline: Soviet Tries Rights Activist
abstract: A Soviet activist on human rights, Irina Grivnina, went on trial today on charges of slandering the Soviet state, the press agency Tass reported. Dissident sources said she was arrested in September in a crackdown on an unofficial group looking into alleged abuses of psychiatry.

headline: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CONTINENTAL BANK OF CANADA SHIFTS
abstract: The Continental Bank of Canada announced that its parent company, a finance company called IAC Ltd., will cease to exist on Oct. 31, 1982, as a final step in a five-year legal process by which the finance concern was transformed into a bank.   The bank, ninth-largest of Canada's 11 banks with 70 branches coast to coast and assests at June 30 of $1.6 billion (Canadian), was granted a federal charter in 1977 and began business in June 1979.

headline: PEERLESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DEFENDING THE HONOR OF THE BUBBLE MEMORY
abstract: Richmond B. Clover has spent most of his career developing the bubble memory, a method of storing computer information. So, when the National Semiconductor Corporation said on Monday that it was quitting the business because it lacked potential, Mr. Clover was less than respectful.   ''They are really crying in their beer,'' he said disparagingly.  ''They are simply limiting the market potential because they are unable to deliver.''

headline: SOMBER MOOD AT HYATT HEADQUATERS
abstract: Until tragedy struck in Kansas City last Friday night, the Hyatt Hotels Corporation had enjoyed a 24-year string of good fortune that carried its name and a reputation for fastidious service and plush accommodations to practically every major city in the country.   The chain, which is particularly popular among businessmen and conventioneers, has 61 hotels with 33,000 rooms in 51 cities. Eleven more hotels are under construction and two major additions to existing structures are planned in Long Beach, Calif., and Atlanta.  Revenues for the parent, the Hyatt Corporation, one of several privately owned companies controlled by Chicago's Pritzker family, passed $400 million last year.

headline: RADICALLY NEW COURSE FOR U.S. FISCAL POLICY
abstract: Ronald Reagan's radical change in United States fiscal policy, aimed at cutting back the role of the Federal Government in the United States economy, has come to pass.   The approval of the President's tax program yesterday by the House and the Senate will translate into a tax cut that will amount to $150 billion in three years, by far the biggest tax cut in the nation's history.   That tax cut follows actions by a Senate-House conference committee that will reduce the Government's public expenditures by $36 billion next year and, according to President Reagan, by a cumulative total of $140 billion over the next three years, which Mr. Reagan called ''the most sweeping cutbacks in the history of the budget.''   The tax and budget cuts certainly represent the most striking change of direction since the New Deal in the balance between the public and private sectors of the American economy. A Question of Inflation   The aim of the conservative Republicans who made this fiscal counterrevolution - with the help of Democratic conservatives and even some liberals who were carried along in an effort to maintain their political strength - is to revitalize American capitalism and to bring inflation under control.

headline: Cheese Industry Sets A Fall Campaign
abstract: D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/Chicago is starting a $5 million fall cheese industry promotion campaign for the American Dairy Association, to run for 12 weeks starting in September. The budget is 16 percent larger than it was a year ago for the original ''Cheese adds a slice of life'' campaign.

headline: Steel Output
abstract: Steel production remained virtually unchanged at 2.204 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, compared with the previous week's 2.205 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported today.

headline: WALLACE BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DURABLES ORDERS OFF 0.8% IN JUNE
abstract: Orders for manufacturers' durable goods fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the first decline since January and was viewed by many analysts as another indication that the national economy remained weak.   A sharp drop in transportation equipment - primarily reflecting fewer orders for aircraft and parts -led the June decline, the report said.

headline: Krugerrand Sales Up
abstract: International Krugerrand sales rose to 447,076 ounces in July, more than double the 207,011 ounces sold in June and well above the 255,170 sold in July 1980, the International Gold Corporation, South Africa's marketing agency, said today. The agency said that the July sales total was the highest since December 1979, when 695,030 one-ounce coins were sold.  International Gold said the increase was the result in part of a significant revival of sales in the United States.

headline: ARMCO TO RAISE SPENDING ON STEEL MILLS
abstract: Armco Inc., projecting that the oil and gas drilling boom would continue at least to end of the century, announced yesterday that it would spend $671 million to build new mills and upgrade an old one to increase the production of seamless tubular goods for the industry, which are now in short supply.   Harry Holiday, chief executive of Armco, said in a telephone interview that studies by the company had concluded that even after new pipe mills announced by Armco and other steel producers were ready, the domestic capacity to produce pipe would total about 3.1 million tons by 1986. But projected demand would be about 5.3 million tons, leaving a shortfall of more than two million tons that presumably would be made up by imports.
