Mr. Holiday said in a news conference in Houston yesterday that by the end of 1984 Armco, the nation's sixth-largest steel company, planned to spend $290 million to build a new mill to produce steel blooms at its works in Ashland, Ky., and $343 million to build a finishing mill in Gulfport, Miss.  The two new plants would create about 1,000 jobs.

headline: Personal Finance; ESTATE PLANNING FOR TWO-INCOME HOMES
abstract: T HE conventional marriage, in which the husband works and the wife stays home, is a continuing challenge for estate planners, who worry how to provide for the wife yet minimize estate taxes if the husband dies. But with more and more women pursuing careers, estate planners have turned their sights on two-income couples. While such couples are in many ways better off from an estate-planning standpoint, they, too, have tax problems.   The topic is the subject of an article in the current issue of The Estates, Gifts and Trusts Journal, a publication for tax professionals. The author of the article, Carlie B. Sorensen, a Washington tax lawyer, concludes that while two-income couples are in an ''optimum position'' so far as estate and gift planning are concerned, their advantages can be easily lost if they pool their assets by keeping joint bank accounts and fail to maintain accurate records of their separate incomes and investments during their marriage.

headline: Doctors' Strike Spreads To Miners in Peru
abstract: Copper miners and bank employees went on strike today, joining 13,000 physicians in a campaign for higher pay.

headline: Executives
abstract: * AMCA International, Hanover, N.H., has formed a new marine division and appointed Peter J. Gwyn the division's president.   * American Express Company has appointed James M. Schell vice president-domestic treasury.

headline: SAVINGS UNITS GET LOAN AID
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board put into effect today a program of emergency loans from its discount window to help financially squeezed savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks.   The Fed action, which was welcomed by the thrift industry and its regulators, is intended to provide longer-term credits than the twoto three-day loans now made available chiefly to commercial banks. It is expected that the duration of the new loans will be six to nine months, at interest rates as low as 14 percent.   The longer-term loans are for all financial institutions - including savings and loans, mutual banks and credit unions - suffering a liquidity problem caused by the withdrawal of deposits.  Although commercial banks will have access to the new facility, the program is to be chiefly of benefit to the thrift institutions, because they have been losing deposits as a result of high interest rates.

headline: SUAVE IRAQI AT U.N. HELM
abstract: Ismat Kittani, a sophisticated practitioner of the convoluted diplomacy at the United Nations, grew up as a barefoot boy in a Kurdish mountain village in western Iraq.  He never saw an electric light until he was 12 and recalls that he was awed by his visits as a youth to Baghdad.   Today, the General Assembly's new President is a moon-faced 52-year-old diplomat with a reputation for a suave manner in dress and politics. His victory was due not only to the luck of the draw.  The fact that he gained as many votes, 73, as his chief rival, Khwaja Mohammed Kaiser of Bangladesh, was a triumph of individual labor over long odds. Mr. Kittani had to overcome the handicap of representing a nation that last year invaded its neighbor Iran and still regards itself at war with Israel.

headline: About Real Estate; OFFICE BUILDING, 1981 STYLE, IS COMING TO WHITE PLAINS
abstract: Names have a history. The name Centroplex has come to downtown White Plains as the designation of a new office building, but it turns out that the building was the second choice for the honor.   The first choice was a hotel that was never built. Pappas Enterprises, a diversified family-owned enterprise with headquarters in Boston, hoped years ago to to buy the Improved Risk Mutuals building on North Broadway in White Plains and demolish it for a luxury hotel.

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: * Long Island Lighting to Greenstone & Rabasca, Melville, L.I.   * U.N. Plaza magazine to Waldman/ George Associates.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Amana Refrigeration Inc., Amana, Iowa., has named Jack F. Peppers vice president, sales-major appliances, and Richard H. Pendergast vice president, sales-central air-conditioning and heating products.   * Castle & Cooke Inc., Honolulu, has elected Robert V. Antle, F.  Homer Eaton and William S. Swinford as executive vice presidents, and Robert M. Moore as senior vice president.

headline: MOST MAJOR BANKS LIFT PRIME 1 2 POINT, TO 20 1 2%
abstract: Most of the nation's major banks raised their prime lending rates yesterday by half a percentage point, to 20 1/2 percent, only a percentage point below the record set last December.   Bankers attributed the increase to stringent Federal Reserve policies that, they say, have pushed their own costs of funds higher and higher.   ''The Fed's maintaining a tight grip on the market,'' said Leif Olsen, chairman of Citibank's economic policy committee. Citibank, the nation's second-largest bank after the Bank of America, was the first to raise its rate yesterday. Its move was quickly followed by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and eventually by scores of other banks across the nation.

headline: CONVICTS END TAKEOVER OF A POLISH PRISON AFTER 2 DAYS
abstract: In the latest of a series of prison uprisings throughout the country, 150 inmates barricaded themselves inside the main detention center here for two days, holding out over a list of grievances that ranged from poor shoes to torture.

headline: Need for Budget Cut Is Tied to Wall St.
abstract: Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that failure by Congress to approve the Administration's new round of budget cutting would have a serious effect on the financial markets.   ''I think that would be a discouraging sign,'' Mr. Weidenbaum told the House Budget Committee. He told the committee that approval of the cuts would be the kind of sign the financial markets are looking for before interest rates will fall. So far this year, despite approval of $35 billion in 1982 budget cuts, interest rates have not fallen.

headline: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ANGLICANS TO RELAX CURBS AGAINST REMARRIAGE AFTER DIVORCE
abstract: The Church of England Synod has agreed to modify its rules on marriage so that some divorced persons can be remarried by the church.   At its meeting earlier this month, the Synod approved a resolution submitted by Bishop John Taylor of Winchester that said, ''There are circumstances in which a divorced person may be married in church during the lifetime of a former partner.''   A committee of the Synod, the church's highest decision-making body, will now draft guidelines to aid priests and bishops in deciding whether a divorced person can be remarried in a church ceremony.

headline: NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dome Petroleum I n Japan Gas Pact
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd., an energy producer based in Calgary, Alberta, said it had reached an agreement with the Nissho-Iwai Company, a Japanese trading house, to supply 400 million cubic feet of liquefied natural gas a day to four Japanese utility companies. The value of the accord, to run for 20 years from 1985, was not disclosed.

headline: Around the World; Jewish Activist Loses An Appeal in Soviet
abstract: Viktor Brailovsky, a prominent member of the Soviet Jewish emigration movement, lost an appeal today of a fiveyear term of internal exile for defaming the state, his wife reported.   A Moscow court sentenced the 45-year-old scientist on June 18 for his involvement in an underground journal critical of the Government's handling of Jewish emigration.   His wife, Irina, told a Western correspondent that Mr. Brailovsky appealed the decision and a court upheld the conviction and sentence in a two-hour proceeding.

headline: NATIONAL DISTILLERS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Tenneco Gas Find
abstract: Tenneco Inc. said today that an exploratory well on its Vermilion block 75 in the Gulf of Mexico flowed 2.2 million cubic feet of natural gas and 317 barrels of condensate a day from depths of 15,067 to 15,073 feet.

headline: NEW ORLEANS EXCHANGE ELECTS TOP EXECUTIVE
abstract: About a month after the resignation of Thomas Webber as president and chief executive officer of the New Orleans Commodity Exchange, apparently after a dispute with the board, Robert L. Martin has been elected to the post. Mr. Martin has been a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission since 1975.   ''The three things we want to achieve are responsibility, visibility and credibility,'' Mr. Martin said in a telephone interview. ''I don't mean that we have been irresponsible, invisible and incredible. But we're the youngest commodities exchange and I want this place to become a meaningful institution within the city and within the industry. Then there's the business of developing a good cadre of floor traders.''

headline: Savemart Awards $1 Million Account
abstract: Shapiro/Budrow & Associates has won the $1 million account of Savemart, New York's leading dealer of Zenith television, video and audio products.

headline: BANKS CAUGHT IN RATE SQUEEZE
abstract: Caught in a profit squeeze as the result of high interest rates, the nation's 15 largest banking concerns experienced a difficult second quarter.   Nine announced earnings declines from the levels of the second quarter of 1980, and 12 reported declines in their annual rates of return on total average assets, which indicates their basic profitability.   The main problem was a shrinkage of the difference between the average rate banks paid for their funds and the average yield on their loans and investments. This, they said, reflected the unexpected persistence of high interest rates.

headline: IZVESTIA CONDEMS POLISH UNION
abstract: The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia tonight condemned the wave of protests over food shortages in Poland and said they were playing into the hands of enemies of the Communist state.   In a report from Warsaw, it said the protests were a weapon used by extremists in the Solidarity trade union to aggravate the crisis.

headline: GENERAL TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Admiral Nominated As Maritime Head
abstract: President Reagan has nominated a retired four-star admiral, Harold Shear, to head the Maritime Administration.  The 62-year-old Mr. Shear has spent some 40 years as a naval officer, in a career that was devoted largely to the undersea world of submarines.   Shipping industry officials say little is known about Mr. Shear's ''maritime philosophy,'' but it is widely believed that he was appointed by the Reagan Administration because of its desire to foster closer coordination between the shipping industry and the nation's overall defense planning.

headline: Garrett Receives Boeing Contract
abstract: The Boeing Company said it has awarded the first major subcontracts for its new Boeing 737-300 jetliner program to the Garrett Corporation, a unit of the Signal Companies.   Garrett won two multimillion dollar contracts to supply the first 50 of the new jets, Boeing said. Options for a further 30 aircraft are covered by the agreement, Boeing added.

headline: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FIJIANS BRING NEW FIGHTING STYLE TO MIDEAST
abstract: The small but tough Fijian Army, blooded in Lebanon and now preparing for new peacekeeping duties in Sinai, has brought to the Middle East a style of fighting new to that arid area half a world away from the lush South Pacific islands.   For example, said the army commander, Brig. Ian Thorne of New Zealand, instead of firing their rifles the Fijians would rather swing them like the war clubs of their ancestors.

headline: EAST BERLIN PARADE HONORS WALL
abstract: East Germany celebrated the 20th anniversary of the Berlin wall today with a show of force in which troops, police units and thousands of armed militiamen marched past Erich Honecker, the Communist Party leader, and others in the party hierarchy.   Mr. Honecker said the building of the wall ''saved peace in Europe in 1961,'' but he warned of new tensions and dangers to world peace.  He said that the American decision to build neutron weapons constituted ''a provocation to all peoples struggling for a peaceful future'' and that Europe ''must achieve arms control and disarmament and needs no new arsenals.''

headline: IAC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: China Signs Deere Aid Pact
abstract: China has signed a contract to buy technical aid from Deere & Company, of Moline, Ill., on how to build combine harvesters, the company said. Value of the accord was not disclosed, but Deere said it would provide China with data on quality control, product experimentation, maintenance and management, and would train Chinese technicians, administrative personnel and workers and send experts to China to give technical direction.

headline: UNITED'S PLAN UPSETS J.A.L.
abstract: The Japanese Government is under no obligation to permit United Airlines to serve Japan, Japan Air Lines said today in a statement to the Civil Aeronautics Board of the United States.   United, the world's largest civil airline, called for action last month to suspend the Japanese airline's flights between Tokyo and New York, after Japan rejected a United plan to operate between Japan and the West Coast of the United States.

headline: MOSCOW CALLS UNION SESSION AN 'ANTI-SOVIET ORGY'
abstract: The Soviet Union today accused Solidarity, Poland's independent trade union, of engaging in ''an antisocialist and anti-Soviet orgy'' at its convention in Gdansk and again said that that the union was preparing for a ''a seizure of power.''   A commentary by Tass, the Soviet Government's press agency, said that the union's leaders, in a conspiracy with ''agents of imperialist secret services,'' were planning to use the union as a vehicle with which to challenge the Polish Communist Party's leading role, restore private ownership and subvert the country's ties to the Soviet Union.   ''The convention of Solidarity in Gdansk is, as its participants declared, a review of forces that are preparing for a seizure of power,'' the article said.

headline: Coffee Surplus in Kenya
abstract: Kenya has a coffee surplus of more than one million bags and has exhausted its export quota allocated by the International Coffee Organization, a spokesman for the Coffee Board of Kenya said today.   Originally Kenya's export quota for the coffee year ending Sept. 30 was 1.3 million bags, but in July the organization reduced this by 140,000 bags in an effort to bolster weak prices.

headline: VERSA TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: energywatch
abstract: JULY 10, 1981 Crude oil stocks increased to 402.0 million barrels, while refining output dipped and crude imports climbed to 4.1 million barrels a day.

headline: Marsteller Post
abstract: Marsteller Inc. has announced the election of Bert Rosenberg, 48 years old, as executive vice president. He had been senior vice president and director of marketing.

headline: CONSERVATIONISTS GAIN A VICTORY IN HUNTING BAN ON SPERM WHALES
abstract: The decision by the International Whaling Commission for a virtual ban on the hunting of sperm wales as its annual meeting in Brighton yesterday represented a victory for conservationists.   In addition to a strong stand against sperm whale hunting, the 30-member group approved a total ban, beginning in 1983, on ''cold harpoons,'' which opponents contend cause whales to bleed slowly to death.   ''It was an extraordinary meeting in that I believe we've seen for all intents and purposes the real end to commercial whaling as we've known it over the past 25 years,'' said Patricia Forkan, vice president of the Humane Society of the United States. ''I say that cautiously, but the extraordinary advances in this meeting leave me with no other conclusion.''

headline: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DUPONT GETS THE MARBLES
abstract: Du Pont last week won the titanic battle for Conoco, the nation's ninth largest oil company.

headline: Business Digest; SATURDAY, AUGUST 8, 1981; The Economy
abstract: The nation's airlines reported a loss of revenue of $100 million so far as a result of the air traffic controllers' strike. A spokesman for the Air Transport Association called it ''devastating.'' The airlines' revenue and earnings are normally greatest during the summer months, he said, and 1981 earnings will be sharply below a prestrike estimate of $750 million. (Page 33.) Meanwhile, Federal officials assigned more military personnel to perform the work of the strikers, and the union called for support from other labor organizations in this country and abroad. (1.)   The unemployment rate fell to 7 percent from 7.3 percent in July, the Labor Department said, its lowest level since April 1980. (1.) In New York City, however, the rate rose to 9.4 percent. In New York State it slipped to 7.6 percent and in New Jersey to 6 percent. (7.)

headline: Pennzoil to Supply Naphtha to Kodak
abstract: The Pennzoil Company has signed a 10-year, $1 billion agreement to supply an Eastman Kodak plant with naphtha to be refined into plastics and chemical intermediates, officials of the two companies said.

headline: SHOW TIME AT PIZZA CHAIN
abstract: She leans forward seductively, and in a husky voice reminiscent of another singer, Pearl Bailey, says, ''Hello, handsome, why don't you sing along?''   Then, with a wink and a shrug of a gold-lame-covered shoulder, Dolli Dimples, an enormous hippopotamus with bright orange hair, starts singing ''Yankee Doodle Dandy,'' much to the delight of the small children clustered around her piano bar munching on pizza. The audience appears fascinated by the movement of her satin-lipped jowls and heaving bosom, and even parents seated at nearby tables seem to enjoy hearing songs like ''Hello, Dolly'' and George Gershwin's ''Summertime.''   Miss Dimples appears daily in a caberet-like lounge at local outlets of Pizza Time Theaters, an aggressive, fast-growing chain of restaurants that expects to triple its sales, to almost $30 million, this year.

headline: Thomson, Muir in Talks
abstract: Representatives of Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. met yesterday with John Muir & Company officials to discuss the possiblity of buying some of Muir's retail accounts.   Muir had announced on Monday that it was withdrawing from the retail brokerage business.  Robert W. Smith, a Muir partner, said yesterday that his firm was talking with several other brokerage concerns besides McKinnon and that a decision had not yet been made as to which firm would acquire Muir's 20,000 active accounts.

headline: SANDGATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MAGIC CIRCLE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; MONOGRAM'S FEWER SHARES
abstract: FEW persons have noticed, perhaps, but Monogram Industries has bought back a bigger percentage of its own shares than almost every other New York Stock Exchange company that has not gone private.   As a result, hard times at Monogram and even harder times at its partly owned Craig Corporation have not prevented reasonably good results, from the point of view of Monogram's remaining shareholders.    Monogram, a mini-conglomerate, is a supplier to several hard-hit industries. It sells fasteners to automobile and farm equipment manufacturers and wiring and insulating materials to producers of major appliances. Monogram's business of building single-family homes in California is also depressed.

headline: G.M. Discloses New Plant Plans
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said it planned to build ''an all-new generation'' of front-wheel-drive luxury cars in its two new assembly plants under construction in Detroit and in Orion Township, near Pontiac, Mich.   The plant in Detroit is scheduled to begin producing new luxury coupes and sedans, including Cadillac Eldorados and Sevilles, in mid-1984.

headline: Business Conditions; PLANT CAPACITY STAYS LOW
abstract: In response to weak demand in major sectors, the nation's manufacturers have kept plants operating at levels far below normal capacity. For the first eight months of 1981, Federal Reserve Board statistics show that capacity utilization amo ng manufacturing companies has averaged 79.7 percent, up a min uscule six-tenths of 1 percentage point from 1980 levels.

headline: Soviet Exit Visas for Jews Reported at a 5-Year Low
abstract: The number of exit visas granted to Jews seeking to leave the Soviet Union dropped to a five-year low in August, Western sources reported today. They blamed worsening relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.

headline: IRAN SHOOTS 9 FOES AND OUSTS REUTERS
abstract: Iran today intensified its drive against what it denounced as ''counterrevolutionary'' elements, as it announced the execution of nine more domestic opponents and ordered the British news agency Reuters to close its Teheran bureau.   The Iranian Government also expelled three South Korean diplomats and advised most of the rest of the South Korean Embassy staff to leave within two weeks. No reasons was given for the action, but radio broadcasts said the Iranian Embassy in South Korea had been downgraded to the level of charge d'affaires.

headline: JAPANESE MILITARY OFFICIALS AGREE WITH U.S. ON NEED FOR MORE ARMS
abstract: The United States is not alone in its campaign to persuade Japan to increase its defense spending. The Japanese military establishment is entirely on the American side.   From senior military officials in Tokyo to senior officers on this northern island of Hokkaido, the center of Japan's military deployment facing the Soviet Union, men who were interviewed shared the American view.

headline: ROGERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RADAR DETECTOR ABOARD SR-71 ALERTED PILOT TO MISSILE ATTACK
abstract: The American SR-71 reconnaissance plane that was fired at on Wednesday from a North Korean ground-launched missile site first detected the attack through a radar warning device, an Administration official said today.   The Lockheed-built aircraft has electronic equipment that allows it ''to determine when it comes under radar surveillance,'' the official said.   Yesterday a Pentagon spokesman, Henry Catto, said that the pilot of the SR-71 had seen the contrail of a surface-to-air missile launched from North Korea and the smoke of its explosion.

headline: 26,000 Steelworkers Strike in Canada
abstract: About 26,000 steelworkers demanding higher wages walked off their jobs today, shutting down two companies that together accounted for more than half of Canada's steel production last year.

headline: DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.N. WIDENS INQUIRY ON CHEMICAL ARMS
abstract: A United Nations panel of experts has decided it must visit four Asian countries to determine the accuracy of American charges that the Soviet Union and its allies are using chemical weapons, officials here said today.   The experts' decision to travel to Afghanistan, Laos, Thailand and Pakistan is regarded here as crucial and politically charged. So far the panel has had to rely on second-hand reports, mostly by the United States, and has tentatively decided they are inconclusive.   Only a visit on the spot to interview possible victims and doctors who have examined them can establish the veracity of Washington's accusations, officials said. The panel, however, has received no replies to its month-old letters asking permission to make an inquiry at the reported sites. Its efforts may be frustrated by the refusal of some or all of the four countries to admit the team.

headline: Washington Watch; Soviet Pipeline And the U.S.
abstract: WASHINGTON THE Reagan Administration is considering revoking a license granted in the final weeks of the Carter Administration to Caterpillar Tractor for pipe-laying equipment for the projected 3,000 mile Yamal pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.   The National Security Council, the Cabinet and the President are about to take up the issue as part of the broader review of new East-West trade guidelines that the Administration has promised to release later this month.   There is strong sentiment for continuing the ban on high-technology exports, including computer spare parts, the loss of which, intelligence officials report, has already caused some significant disruptions in Soviet information flows.   The emerging policy on the gas pipeline, which could increase Europe's dependence on Soviet energy and swell Moscow's hard currency earnings, may well be another point of conflict between the United States and its Atlantic partners.

headline: COPING WITH POLISH ECONOMIC PROBLEMS
abstract: Whatever political satisfaction Poland's brush with revolution is bringing its people, in the economic sphere the dramatic events of the past year have only meant falling living standards and increased hardship so far.   Fourteen months after the industrial strikes that gave birth to Poland's independent Solidarity trade union movement, the Polish economy is tottering on the brink of disaster.   Over the past year, the production of industrial goods and food has dropped by about 15 percent, although wages have increased by almost 27 percent. In some key sectors, the fall in output has been much greater. Government statistics disclose a stunning 34 percent drop in meat production, for instance, while coal output is down 21 percent.

headline: Datapoint's Profit Up 45.7%
abstract: The Datapoint Corporation, a leading manufacturer of computer systems and peripherals, announced yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1981 ended July 31 rose 45.7 percent, to $13.4 million, or 66 cents a share, from $9.2 million, or 52 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

headline: EMIR'S VISIT UNDERLINES TURKEY'S TURN TO MIDEAST
abstract: Turkey's military rulers, who seized power a year ago, have intensified the nation's efforts to play a more active r ole in the Middle East.   Their policy, which is described by officials as ''economic realism'' and also apparently has political overtones, was underscored today with the arrival here of the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah, for a two-day state visit. Describing the visit as a historic occasion, the Turkish press said it was the first by an Arab head of state from a Persian Gulf country.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: For an Administration that made the guerrilla war in El Salvador its first, most heralded anti-Communist cause, the Reagan Administration provided a decidedly low-key public reception last week for President Jose Napoleon Duarte, the Salvadoran leader.   In terms of access, the sturdy, dark-haired veteran Salvadoran politician had an open door. He saw President Reagan, Vice President Bush and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, and is scheduled to have a parting visit with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. at the United Nations.   But the White House deliberately refrained from staging a warm official embrace. There were no formal dinners with toasts ringing with political endorsements, no Honor Guard welcome on the south lawn, no joint appearance of President Reagan and Mr. Duarte for informal pictures and answering questions from the White House press corps. Many other leaders have enjoyed such courtesies but the plucky little Salvadoran politician was left to speak for himself in his encounters with reporters.

headline: U.N. VOTES TO ISOLATE SOUTH AFRICA OVER NAMIBIA
abstract: The General Assembly today voted overwhelmingly, 117 to 0 with 25 abstentions, to isolate South Africa and to arm the guerrillas fighting to make South-West Africa the independent nation of Namibia.   The stern resolution has no binding force, however, and most diplomats here saw it as an expression of African frustration over South Africa's refusal to yield Namibia.   The United States was among the large group of Western and other democracies that abstained, largely on the ground that the document would make South Africa more rather than less intractable. With Britain, France, Canada and West Germany, the United States has been trying to persuade South Africa to accept a plan for elections in the territory that would be supervised by the United Nations.

headline: General Dynamics Says No to Airbus
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation said it had decided against joining a consortium of companies setting up the European Airbus Industrie A-320 commercial airlines program.   David S. Lewis, chairman and chief executive officer, said representatives of General Dynamics had been ''impressed'' by planning for development and production of the new 150-passenger airplane. But Mr. Lewis said a decision not to join the consortium had been based on the belief that greater near-term growth potential could be gained by General Dynamics in areas other than commercial transport aircraft.

headline: SENATE ENDORSES U.N. STAND ON TERRORISM WITH HOSTAGES
abstract: The Senate voted today to endorse a United Nations call for tough measures against international terrorists who commit acts in which hostages are taken.

headline: SPARKMAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Conagra Net Up 13.2%
abstract: Conagra Inc., a diversified agricultural products company, said today that it earned a record $7.7 million, or 60 cents a share, in the first fiscal quarter, a 13.2 percent increase from the $6.8 million, or 57 cents a share, earned in the first fiscal quarter a year ago. The company said sales rose 70.8 percent, to $520.1 million, from $304.4 million. Charles M. Harper, president and chief executive officer, said Banquet Foods and Singleton Foods, acquired in the second half of the fiscal year 1981, accounted for much of the first-quarter sales increase and were significant contributors to earnings.

headline: ITALIAN PROSECUTOR RRQUESTS A LIFE SENTENCE FOR THE POPE'S ASSAILANT
abstract: The prosecutor today demanded the mandatory life sentence for Mehmet Ali Agca for attempting to kill Pope John Paul II and for wounding two Americans.   Calling Mr. Agca ''the son of modern-day terrorism, that sinister affliction of our time,'' Nicolo Amato, the prosecutor, said, ''We have looked into the heart of Mehmet Ali Agca for a small sign, an infinitesimal sign of repentance and humanity, but we couldn't find it.''   He asked that the defendant be sentenced to an additional 12 years for the illegal possession of arms and for carrying false identity papers, and he suggested that these 12 years be converted to 12 months in solitary confinement.

headline: ARGENTINE COURT FREES MRS. PERON AFTER FIVE YEARS
abstract: Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron, who has been under house arrest since her overthrow by the military five years ago, was ordered freed on parole today by a federal court.    Lawyers for the 50-year-old Mrs. Peron said that her plans were unclear but that she would likely stay in Argentina for a day or two before leaving for either Panama or Spain. They said she would probably seek court permission tomorrow to leave the country.   Although Mrs. Peron's appearance in the federal court building had not been announced beforehand, word spread quickly and more than a thousand Peronists were outside to greet her as she emerged.

headline: Advertising
abstract: YOUNG & RUBICAM, which has somehow missed having any hightechnology accounts despite being America's largest advertising agency, yesterday corrected that oversight. It has been named the agency for Atari, the personal computer and video games designer and manufacturer that is a subsidiary of Warner Communications.   Y.&R., New York, will be handling the advertising for Atari's personal computer products, formerly handled by SSC&B, Inc., one of the Interpublic Group of companies. It will also handle corporate advertising for Atari, which has its headquarters in Sunnyvale, Calif.

headline: New Chief Chosen At Sears of Mexico
abstract: Guillermo Weidmann, 54 years old, will be running Sears Roebuck de Mexico, the Mexican subsidiary of the giant American retailer. He succeeds Jorge Lemus, who retired from the 43-unit chain at the age of 63, as its president and chief executive officer.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago appointed Karl F. Hoenecke a member of the board.   * Baldwin-United Corporation, a financial services company, elected Virginia A. Dwyer a director.

headline: Datapoint Buys 7 Distributors
abstract: The Datapoint Corporation, a manufacturer of computer systems, said it purchased for $85 million in cash seven international distributors for its products that were previously wholly or jointly owned by TRW Inc. Two more such acquisitions are pending under the agreement, the company said.   The seven distributorships include four that were previously wholly owned by TRW and three that were jointly owned by TRW and non-United States companies, Datapoint said.

headline: ESSEX CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IN UGANDA, HIGH PRICES AND GUNFIRE AT NIGHT
abstract: Along the shore of Lake Victoria near Uganda's international airport, there are tall, stately trees and a rolling countryside of soft green hills.   But in Kampala, the capital, 20 miles away, the setting by contrast is one of shabbiness.  The low buildings along the highway that the airport bus travels are generally unmaintained, and often characterized by rusted corrugated metal roofs. Soldiers in combat uniform at a muddy roadblock are unsmiling and rough in their communication with fellow Ugandans, forced to get off the bus for a check of passes and belongings.

headline: Police Reportedly Use Force To Break Up Polish Crowds
abstract: The police used force to disperse angry crowds in the western Polish city of Konin today as violence flared after clashes between local youths and gypsies, the official Polish press agency said.

headline: THREATS ALTER LIFE OF NOBEL LAUREATE IN ARGENTINA
abstract: Adolfo Perez Esquivel, the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize seven months ago, has been living ever since under repeated threats of violence.   He has been approached by gunmen, the police have found bombs in his office, and he and his family have regularly received death threats by telephone.   The Nobel laureate now puts a chain and lock on what had been his open gate at home. His office door is bolted to open only a crack so visitors can be surveyed before entering.

headline: Taiwan Jailing 27 Fishermen For Trade With the Mainland
abstract: The Taiwan High Court overruled a lower court's verdict today and sentenced 27 fishermen to prison terms ranging from five months to a year on charges of trading with Chinese Communists in the Taiwan Straits.   The Taipei District Court, in a surprise move in March, acquitted the fishermen, who were then charged with trading with mainland fishermen in 1979 in violation of Taiwan's law against smuggling.   Today's High Court verdict said the fishermen had bartered 6,000 Taiwan-made watches bearing bogus foreign brand names for more than 300 ounces of gold and more than 300 silver coins.

headline: TAX RATE CUTS VS. INFLATION
abstract: In just two weeks and a day, the much-heralded cuts in income tax rates begin. Tax advisers caution, however, that people should not expect to see big reductions in their tax bills after the cuts are phased in from Oct. 1, 1981, to July 1, 1983. ''We're not really cutting taxes for most people - we're simply preventing their taxes from going higher,'' said Leon M. Nad, a partner at the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse & Company.   Although tax rates are being reduced, he noted, inflation will push most salaries higher. For most people, therefore, the tax cuts will simply offset the extra taxes they would have had to pay on higher wages. ''If you continued to earn the same amount of taxable income, you would see an actual tax saving,'' Mr. Nad said. Schedule of 3 Reductions   The new law reduces tax rates on individual income by 5 percent on Oct. 1, by 10 percent on July 1, 1982, and by 10 percent again on July 1, 1983. The law also shrinks the maximum tax on individual income to 50 percent on Jan. 1, 1982, from the current ceiling of 70 percent. There is already a 50 percent ceiling on earned income (such as wages, salaries, pensions and bonuses) but not on unearned income (such as interest, dividends and rent).

headline: Texaco Unit Sets Gas Sales
abstract: Texaco Canada announced that its wholly owned subsidiary, Texaco Canada Resources, planned new natural gas sales of up to 30 million cubic feet a day by 1983 to Progas, a Calgary, Alberta, distributor of natural gas to United States customers.   Progas, owned by a group of Canadian gas producers, recently received American Government approval to export 300 million cubic feet daily to the United States.   Texaco Canada said it currently sold about 230 million cubic feet of natural gas a day.

headline: Israel Is Said to Supply U.S. Arms to Iranians
abstract: The Argentine cargo plane that crashed last week over the Soviet Union was returning from the third of a dozen scheduled trips in which Israel was supplying American-made tank parts and ammunition to Iran, it was reported today.   The Sunday Times said Israel had agreed to provide the Moslem Government in Teheran with 360 tons of military equipment worth $15 million.

headline: BRASCAN'S NEW BID FOR NORANDA
abstract: Brascan Ltd., thwarted two years ago in an attempt to take over Noranda Mines Ltd., today announced a renewed assault on Noranda, this time in association with a powerful arm of the Quebec government.   Brascan announced that it and the Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec had agreed to pool their 28 percent Noranda holding in a company called Brascade Resources Inc., 70 percent owned by Brascan and 30 percent by Caisse. Brascade would then make a bid of $921.2 million (Canadian), or about $755.4 million in United States funds, for Noranda shares that, if successful, would bring its holding to 39.2 percent.

headline: Oil and Gas Drilling Rises
abstract: Oil and natural gas drilling activity in the United States has increased rapidly since 1979 despite concerns raised about potential shortages of drilling equipment and personnel, the American Petroleum Institute reported today.   An institute staff study showed that in response to rising crude oil prices, the needs of the industry for supplies, equipment and personnel were not only met but exceeded.

headline: AS H & R BLOCK SEES IT, THE NEW TAX ISN'T MUCH OF A BREAK
abstract: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  T HE new tax law has set H & R Block abuzz. Some 85,000 new students have signed up for Block's tax courses at offices around the country, the familiar yellow Income Tax Workbook is being drastically revised, and an advertising campaign is being hustled together in Chicago by Block's new agency, J. Walter Thompson.   H & R Block Inc., by far the nation's largest tax preparation service, stands to profit from the mass of changes ordered by the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981. Last year, some nine million Americans went to Block for help in filling out tax forms, income rose 17 percent on a 25 percent revenue gain and some 70,000 students took Block's tax preparation course.   Now, gearing up to take advantage of the complex web of new tax rules that will take effect over the next three years, it hopes that the changes will so confuse Americans that they will flock in record numbers to the 8,000 storefront offices that Block operates around the country.

headline: BIDDING WAR IS FEARED FOR RETIREMENT SAVINGS
abstract: Although it may be too soon to tell how high rates will go, spokesmen for commercial banks and thrift institutions assert that last week's decision to remove the interest-rate ceiling on the retirement savings accounts they offer might set off a bidding war for funds. The decision by Federal banking regulators is drawing fire from sa vings banks and savings and loan associations, which fear that a pr ice war would increase their cost of money. The move, however, has be en generally applauded by commercial banks.   Spokesmen for both the commercial banks and the thrift institutions said that higher rates would have to be offered than at present.  ''With banks competing to make these long-term commitments in I.R.A. and Keogh accounts,'' Edmond Shanahan, president of Bell Federal Savings in Chicago, said, ''my fear is that we will see some people who jump too soon and for the next 40 years regret their actions.''

headline: U.S. CANADA FLIGHTS ARE CANCELED IN TURBULENT DAY ON 2 CONTINENTS
abstract: Trans-Atlantic air travel was thrown into confusion yesterday as international airlines and governmental aviation officials reacted to a report that Canadian air traffic controllers would refuse to guide American flights over the western Atlantic.   In addition to the trans-Atlantic disruptions, virtually all flights between the United States and Canada were grounded through the afternoon and evening, and a number of domestic and other international flights were delayed.   In the most troubled day since 13,000 air traffic controllers struck the nation's airways nine days ago, some flights to and from Europe were canceled, others were turned back, and many others were delayed for hours and rerouted to their destinations.   Airline officials noted that many of the disrupted planes yesterday had been connecting flights for passengers going to Africa, the Middle East and the Far East and that a ripple effect had been felt by many of these travelers.   Today's flight schedules were expected to be more near normal, but spillover effects of yesterday's turmoil could not be discounted, according to spokesmen for Kennedy International Airport and various airlines, especially if new job actions by Canadian or European controllers materialize.

headline: U.S. WIDENS EFFORT FOR MIDEAST TRUCE
abstract: The Reagan Administration moved today to broaden diplomatic efforts to achieve a cease-fire in southern Lebanon after drawing encouragement from the initial subdued Israeli reaction to the latest American postponement of shipment of warplanes to Israel.   Richard V. Allen, the President's assistant for national security affairs, said that preliminary reports from Prime Minister Menachem Begin's meeting earlier today with Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy in the Middle East, offered ''some basis for forward movement'' toward a cease-fire.   At the United Nations, the Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution tonight calling for a cease-fire in Lebanon but avoiding any rebuke of Israel or threat of sanctions. (Page A11.)

headline: Around the World; 6 Persian Gulf Nations Assail U.S. on Dogfight
abstract: Six conservative Persian Gulf nations, including Saudi Arabia, accused the United States today of engaging in ''cowboy politics'' in the incident in which two Libyan planes were reportedly shot down over the Gulf of Sidra.   Abdullah Bishara, Secretary General of the Gulf Cooperation Council, called Wednesday's incident ''a provocative trap and medieval piracy on the high seas.''

headline: TYING PENSIONS TO PRICES
abstract: It is an oft-heard complaint - inflation eating away at the standard of living of retirees who are dependent on pensions. Some companies have tried to solve the problem with ad hoc increases in pension benefits, but the costs of such improvements can quickly become prohibitive.   Over the last year, however, three major corporations - the H.J.  Heinz Company, Inco Ltd. and the Xerox Corporation - have taken a different approach. They have begun ''indexing'' pension benefits to inflation. The mechanics differ somewhat as do the indexed increases, but all three have the same goal: to protect retirees from most of the devastating effects of inflation by providing supplemental pension payments. Yet such inflation protection does not come without a cost to the employees.

headline: Investing; HERE A YIELD, THERE A YIELD...
abstract: A currently fashionable timing technique used by investors in choosing between bonds and stocks is to compare bond yields with the dividend yields available on common stocks.   It seems clear at first from the accompanying chart that the yield advantage of bonds over stocks is greater than at any time over the past generation. Had we extended the chart back further in time, we would have seen that stocks actually yielded more than bonds for the 30 preceding years. In fact, the gap between bond and stock yields, as well as the absolute level of bond yields, is at its highest. Some analysts are therefore calling corporate bonds - with their yields in the vicinity of 15 percent - the buys of the century and the best thing available to the public since night baseball (before the strike).   It may well be that bonds are a most attractive investment medium today and that congenital bond market pessimists will finally be proved wrong. There is an old and useful investment adage, however, that asserts markets are reasonably efficient and suggests that if you are calm when the markets around you have collapsed, perhaps you don't understand the problem.

headline: Honda May Start Production Early
abstract: The Honda Motor Company, Japan's third-largest auto exporter, indicated that it may start compact car production at its new plant near Columbus, Ohio, up to six months ahead of schedule.

headline: Regal Report
abstract: To the Business Editor: Being the printer of E.F. Hutton's 1980 annual report, there is one correction I would like to make in your ''E.F. Hutton's Regal Report'' (June 28). The West German paper that was used was not silver, but white, on which we printed a specially formulated silver ink.

headline: Boiler Contract
abstract: Combustion Engineering Inc., based in Stamford, Conn., said it had received a contract from South Africa's Electricity Supply Commission to help design and build six 600,000-kilowatt coal-fired boilers for installation in South Africa.

headline: SNAG DEVELOPS IN SHIFT OF IRAN FUNDS
abstract: Disagreements between Iranian and American negotiators meeting secretly in the Netherlands are likely to stall transfer by the United States of more than $2 billion in once-frozen Iranian bank deposits and have aroused concern among American companies with claims against Iran.   The dispute includes Iran's demand that it receive the interest accruing on a special $1 billion security account designed to cover possible awards against Iran by an international tribunal arbitrating American claims, according to a Washington lawyer who has followed the negotiations closely.   Treasury officials refused to comment on the nature of the disagreements with Iran. It was not clear today how far the United States was willing to go toward meeting the Iranian demands or whether Iran would undermine the elaborate arbitration process laid out in the hostage agreements if it did not get its way.

headline: AT G.M.'S BUICK UNIT, WORKERS AND BOSSES GET AHEAD BY GETTING ALONG
abstract: FLINT, Mich.  A YEAR ago, Eddo Brantley's biggest responsibility was blowing dust off equipment with an air hose. Now, she can shut down one of the principal production lines of an automobile factory whenever she wants.   And she does. On a recent day, the slender, 49-year-old laborer strode assertively to a control panel and pushed a fat maroon button. A rolling line of metallic saucers, destined for a spot in every new front-wheel-drive car produced by the General Motors Corporation, jerked to a halt.   ''I could never do this before,'' said Mrs. Brantley, one of 2,500 Buick workers who has been trained in what are termed ''Quality of Work Life'' principles. ''Now, I stop the line whenever there is a problem.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: Talking Business with Vincent of Columbia Pictures A New Image At Columbia   Six months ago, ending a long battle with Kirk Kerkorian, the film executive, Columbia Pictures bought 2.44 million shares he owned in the company in exchange for a 10-year peace pact. Since then the three networks have accepted Columbia television shows and the RCA Corporation has joined with the company to market video cassettes and videodisks abroad. Last month Columbia reached tentative terms to buy the Outlet Company, owner of five television stations. And by next May, at an estimated cost of $40 million, it will introduce the musical ''Annie.'' The architect of Columbia's new image is Francis T. Vincent Jr., president since 1978 of Columbia Pictures.

headline: Drop in Prime Is Forecast
abstract: The prime lending rate in the United States could fall to between 10 percent and 13 percent by the end of the year if the United States stays on the right track as far as money supply growth is concerned, Beryl Sprinkel, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, told a Swiss newspaper today.   American interest rates will not only fall in the long run when the fight against inflation begins to succeed, but they may also ease before then if the markets are convinced that a disciplined monetary policy will not be softened, Mr. Sprinkel told Finanz Und Wirtschaft in a Washington interview.

headline: Japan Wins Ship Order
abstract: The Sanoyasu Dockyard Company said today that it had won two orders from United States and Norwegian owners to build a total of five bulk carriers worth 28 billion yen, or about $120 million. Mowinckels Rederi of Norway ordered two 60,000-deadweight-ton carriers worth about $55.7 million for delivery in July and September 1983, the company said. Sanoyasu also said it would build three 40,000-deadweight-ton carriers worth about $64.7 million for Lygnos of New York for delivery by August 1983.

headline: Japan Warns Iran on Oil
abstract: Iran has been warned that Japanese oil companies will stop buying Iranian oil by Sept. 1 if prices are not cut, European oil industry sources said here today.   The Japanese companies are demanding that Iran reduce its official price of oil by at least $4 a barrel, from the current level of $37, the sources said.

headline: Radial Tires For U.S. Cars
abstract: All new United States-built cars will have radial tires as standard equipment for the first time in the 1982 model year, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today.    ''This is the first time since the 1968 model year that one tire construction has been standard equipment for all U.S. auto companies,'' said Scott H. Buzby, president of Goodyear Tire.

headline: Israeli Mission in Athens Is Damaged by Bombs
abstract: Two bombs exploded outside the Israeli mission here early today, causing minor damage and no injuries.  An Israeli spokesman said the Palestine Liberation Organization claimed responsibility in two phone calls to the mission.

headline: G.M. OFFERS AUTO BUYERS LOW-INTEREST FINANCING
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said today it would offer below-market interest rates to customers borrowing money to buy a G.M. car in an effort to perk up sluggish sales and to help clear large stocks of unsold cars before the 1982 models reach dealer showrooms.   The corporation said its General Motors Acceptance Corporation subsidiary would offer, starting tomorrow, the ''preferential financing rate'' of 13.8 percent on loans for the purchase of 1981 G.M. cars and 1982 ''J'' cars. The company said the rate would mean a savings of $550 in the financing cost of a typical G.M. car, and would be in effect for several weeks.

headline: WEST CHEMICAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LADY DIANA WON'T VOW TO OBEY CHARLES
abstract: In a break with royal precedent, Lady Diana Spencer has decided that she will not promise, at her wedding four weeks from today, to obey Prince Charles.   Queen Elizabeth II, Princess Margaret, Princess Anne and a long line of royal brides before them have included the word ''obey'' in their wedding vows, as prescribed in the Anglican Book of Common Prayer dating from 1662. But Lady Diana has chosen to follow the new ritual of the Church of England, and she will promise in the ceremony at St. Paul's Cathedral only to ''love him, comfort him, honor and keep him, in sickness and in health.''

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: * Talon Inc., a division of Textron, to the Chester Gore Company.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: President of Bernstein   Lewis A. Sanders, 35, has been named president of Sanford C.  Bernstein & Company, a New York investment research and money management firm. He succeeds Mr. Bernstein, 55, who founded the concern bearing his name in 1967 and who remains chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Express Company has elected to its board Charles W.  Duncan Jr., former Secretary of Energy.   * Bausch & Lomb, Rochester, N.Y., has named Jay T. Holmes vice president, general counsel and secretary.

headline: FRED MEYER INC.
abstract: Fred Meyer Inc., a Portland, Ore., shopping center and department store operator, said it had received inquiries about acquiring the company from an unidentified United States company and a foreign company. Meanwhile, it said its board of directors was still considering a $55-a-share leveraged buyout proposal from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company of New York, an investment firm.

headline: Credit Markets; Oregon Issue at Record Yield
abstract: Record yields were set for double-A rated state bonds yesterday when Oregon brought a $180 million issue to the municipal market. The most-distant maturities fetched a tax-exempt return of 12.60 percent.    Meanwhile, prices edged higher and yields dipped slightly for other tax-exempt issues in the secondary trading market. Despite this token improvement, dealers noted, various pressures upon the municipal sector have sent yields this week to new highs.

headline: WOMAN IN KIBBUTZ KILLED BY ROCKET
abstract: An Israeli woman was killed this morning during a rocket attack on a kibbutz near the Lebanese border. She was the fourth Israeli civilian to be killed in the recent upsurge of fighting.   The woman, 40-year-old Ziporah Yesod, was hit directly by the rocket as she left a building in the Misgav Am kibbutz followed by three of her four children, according to one report.

headline: MONDAY, JULY 6, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Economists are sharply divided over the near-term course for interest rates following the decision last week by two major banks to raise their prime rates by a half-point, to 20 1/2 percent. Some find the action a sign of unexpectedly strong loan demand. But others see rates falling within weeks. (Page D1.)

headline: FINANCIAL MARKETS SHAKEN
abstract: Renewed fears of high interest rates and the prospect of growing Federal budget deficits shook the financial markets yesterday.  In the bond market, interest rates surged to record levels. On the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.46 points to its lowest level in more than a year.   According to credit market analysts, the plunge in bond prices reflected growing skepticism that the Reagan Administration could balance the Federal budget by 1984. They expressed concern that the Treasury would have to borrow large sums of money to cover biggerthan-anticipated deficits. Such Government borrowing tends to create competition for funds with private industry and this competition can push up interest rates.

headline: EGYPT AND ISRAEL SIGN PACT ON SINAI
abstract: Egypt and Israel formally signed an agreement today establishing a 2,500-member international peacekeeping force in the Sinai to police their peace treaty. Nearly half of the force will be composed of United States combat troops and civilian observers.   Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. signed the document as an observer in ceremonies at the State Department with the Ambassadors from Egypt and Israel.   He said formation of the peacekeeping force, originally called for in the 1979 peace treaty between Egypt and Israel, was a ''clear manifestation of the United States' continuing support for a peace process in the Middle East.''

headline: PRINCE'S GUEST LIST EMBRACES KINGS AND CHARWOMEN
abstract: Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer have invited a potpourri of personal friends and people whom they have never met to their wedding Wednesday - kings and gamekeepers, presidents and comedians, generals and charwomen.   Buckingham Palace announced today the names of about 50 of the highest-ranking guests and said no further announcement would be made.   But many people here and abroad have been unable to resist talking to the newspapers about their invitations, so a clear idea has emerged of the makeup of the congregation of 2,500 that will gather to watch the ceremony in the English baroque splendor of St. Paul's Cathedral.   Baudouin, King of the Belgians, Queen Margrethe of Denmark, King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden, Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands, Princess Grace of Monaco and King Olav of Norway (a grandson of Edward VII who stands 34th in the line of succession to the British throne) are among the members of reigning Continental royal houses who will march in the wedding procession.

headline: MRS. THATCHER IS TARGET AT BRITISH UNION CONGRESS
abstract: Embattled and angry unionized workers, facing unemployment of nearly three million, have opened their most determined attack yet on Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her austere economic policies.   As the annual meeting of the Trades Union Congress reached a climax here today, several hundred delegates approved the heart of a position paper that calls for $33 billion in government economic stimulus, unilateral nuclear disarmament and withdrawal from the Common Market. The paper was the group's most radical and overtly political one to date.

headline: ITALY WON'T TALK WITH TERRORISTS
abstract: ROME (AP) - Italy will not barter with the Red Brigades for the lives of three kidnapping victims held by the Marxist terrorists, Interior Minister Virginio Rognoni told the Parliament today.   ''No negotiations are tolerable that would place the terrorists on the level of interlocutors and judges of the democratic system,'' Mr. Rognoni, a Christian Democrat, said in a 20-page speech on the fight against political violence.

headline: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: Kuwait has lowered the premium on oil exported to South Korea to $1 a barrel from $2.75, officials at the Energy and Resources Ministry said yesterday.   The $1 premium, retroactive to Aug. 1, would be added to the official price of $35.50 a barrel, they added. Oil from Kuwait, which totals 10,000 barrels a day, represents about 18 percent of South Korea's total needs, Government sources said.

headline: MOBIL'S MISTAKEN PRICE RISE
abstract: The Mobil Oil Corporation has made its mark in the advertising world as a tough media street fighter that has pioneered an aggressive style of advertising in explaining oil industry profits, pricing and policy decisions.   Public relations experts have generally given Mobil high marks for its techniques. But yesterday, many said Mobil might have overplayed its aggressiveness and embarrassed itself with a series of price reversals this week in response to new state taxes on oil companies.   ''It looked like they were out to gouge the public,'' said an executive vice president at one of the largest public relations firms in New York. ''It was a serious public relations mistake. They ended up going through a lot of grief they didn't have to.''

headline: U.S. LAUDS OIL SALE BY MEXICO
abstract: Government planners today hailed the United States agreement to purchase some 110 million barrels of oil from Mexico for its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, saying it would mean a reliable supply at prices that were likely to be below those of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.   The agreement, announced late last night in Mexico City, covers oil valued at about $3.5 billion, to be supplied by Petroleos Mexicanos, the Mexican state-owned oil company, over a period of five years.   ''This is a delightful thing,'' commented a spokesman for the Department of Energy, noting that in the late 1970's, Mexico had continued to meet previous contract commitments, even as world prices were soaring. No Objection From Saudi Arabia   The agreement, the first purchase by the Energy Department directly from a foreign government agency, calls for Mexico to supply 24 million barrels during the final four months of this year and an additional 85 million barrels from January 1982 through August 1986.

headline: Gain of 56.8% For Dow Jones
abstract: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose by 56.8 percent, to $20 million, or 64 cents a share, from $12.7 million, or 41 cents a share, in the same period in 1980, helped by the continued strong performance of The Wall Street Journal, the company's newspaper.   Revenues for the company, which publishes newspapers, magazines and college textbooks, rose to $160.6 million from $128.4 million.  In evaluating his company's performance, Warren H. Phillips, chairman and chief executive officer, pointed to a second-quarter increase in advertising linage for The Wall Street Journal of 11.9 percent from the same period a year earlier.

headline: ARGENTINE REGIME SEVERELY STRAINED BY ECONOMIC WOES
abstract: The military Government of President Roberto Eduardo Viola, hammered by a worsening economy and internal division, is being severely strained as the military seems to have lost the majority support it once thought it had from Argentina's 28 million people.   Unemployment has doubled, inflation has moved into triple figures and the peso has been devalued by more than two-thirds - all since the beginning of this year.

headline: Rightists Said to Shell A Port in Lebanon
abstract: Israeli-backed Christian militiamen fired three artillery shells into Tyre today, the Palestinian press agency said.

headline: NEW BRADLEY GAME TESTS FICKLE MARKET
abstract: The battle for the electronic game market is beginning to get intense, and Milton Bradley is showing its hand with all the hoopla of a highly orchestrated advertising campaign.   The nation's third-largest toy maker, the Milton Bradley Company has yet to find the formula that guarantees success in what has proved to be a rather fickle market. But with its new entry, a combination computer-board game called Dark Tower, the company is talking as if it has a winner. Dark Tower, which carries a retail price of $55 to $65, has alreadybeen in stores for three or four weeks, and t he results, said George Ditomassi, Milton Bradley's senior vice presi dent for sales, are morethan encouraging.

headline: TAX-EXEMPT CALENDER FULL AMID HIGH YIELDS
abstract: While industrial companies continue to delay long-term financings, utilities and state and local governments tend to go ahead and borrow despite high interest rates.   This week, for example, the calendar of tax-exempt issues is full of general obligation bonds offered by high-grade borrowers. For these borrowers, market conditions are not favorable. Yields rose last week, by one-fourth to one-half percentage point, setting new highs.

headline: TEHERAN APPOINTS PRIME MINISTER AND A PARTY HEAD
abstract: Iran announced the appointment today of a provisional Prime Minister and a new leader for the ruling Islamic Republican Party.   Ayatollah Mohammed Riza Mahdavi-Kani, the Interior Minister, was named provisional Prime Minister to replace Prime Minister Mohammed Javad Bahonar, who died in a bomb explosion Sunday that also killed President Mohammed Ali Rajai.   Dr. Bahonar's other position, as head of the ruling party, was given to Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, the leader of Friday prayers in Teheran.   As the new head of government, Ayatollah Mahdavi-Kani is to join the Speaker of Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, and the Chief Justice, Ayatollah Abdulkarim Moussavi Ardabeli, on the presidency committee. That committee is exercising executive power in Iran until a new chief of state is elected.

headline: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY UP $5.1 BILLION
abstract: A key measure of the nation's money supply rose $5.1 billion in the week ended Aug. 5, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday. Fed officials cautioned, however, that some of the unusually large increase was related to bank loans extended during the Conoco merger battle waged by Du Pont, Mobil and Seagram.   Large loans to businesses can cause a increase in the money supply if some of the loan proceeds are put into a bank deposit counted in the money supply. Analysts said some of the huge $3.7 billion increase in business loans at large banks in the week ended Aug. 5 reflected borrowing for the Conoco takeover battle.

headline: MOBIL IS REORTED TO SEEK $5 BILLION TO BID FOR CONOCO
abstract: The multibillion-dollar takeover battle for Conoco Inc. spread yesterday to the Mobil Corporation, as banking sources disclosed that Mobil was negotiating to borrow some $5 billion to bid for Conoco.   Reports continued on Wall Street, meanwhile, that Texaco Inc., and the Standard Oil Company of California might soon make bids of their own.   Texaco has already lined up loans totaling $5.5 billion, according to banking sources, amid indications that it might make a bid for either Conoco or the Cities Service Company.   Texaco, as it has repeatedly, declined all comment. Standard of California also refused comment.

headline: CESSNA AIRCRAFT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Three Ethnic Albanians Are Jailed in Yugoslavia
abstract: Three ethnic Albanians were sentenced to jail terms ranging from six to eight years today for antis@tate activities in the first of a series of trials stemming from violent Albanian nationalist riots in Yugoslavia's province of Kosovo last spring.   The official press agency Tanyug said the three men formed a clandestine group known as the People's Liberation Movement of Kosovo last year, with the aim of destroying Yugoslavia's social and political system and forcibly annexing the province to neighboring Albania.   The trial resulted in the convictions of Bislim Bajrami, Jakup Redzepi and Ismail Makici.

headline: HOOVER REALIGNING OVERSEAS OPERATION AS PROBLEMS GROW
abstract: During the 1920's it was not unusual for 2,000 or more of the Hoover Company's door-to-door vacuum cleaner salesmen to gather in William H. Hoover's pasture for several days and nights to sing company songs, listen to spirited pep talks from sales managers and hear about the fast-growing young company's latestmodel electric floor sweeper.   But it has been 50 years since ''Boss'' Hoover's salesmen slept in giant canvas tents and serenaded the chairman's livestock. And although Hoover now sells almost as many vacuum cleaners in the United States as all its competitors combined, a saturated domestic market, large foreign losses and a costly restructuring of its European operations have left company officials with little to sing about.   The retrenching in Europe is intended to reduce Hoover's long reliance on Britain as its chief market outside the United States and its European manufacturing and distribution center. The work force at three plants in Britain has been cut to 9,000 from 13,000, export headquarters have been moved from Britain to corporate headquarters in North Canton, Ohio, and a $10 million expansion is under way at Hoover's plant in Dijon, France.

headline: Economic Summit Meeting
abstract: Leaders of the seven major industrial democracies meeting in Ottawa agreed to delay consideration of tightened trade restrictions with the Soviet Union. The group, however, approved an American proposal to hold a conference on limitations of high-technology and miltary exports to Eastern bloc countries. (Page A1.)   Concern over historically high interest rates dominates the summit conference of leaders of the industrial world. The concern stems from a fear that the high rates will choke off employment and depress industrial output. The Reagan Administration blames inherited inflation for the high rates while other nations cite the tight money policy followed by the United States.  (A1.)

headline: A STRIKE AGAINST INFLATION
abstract: I N drygulching the air controllers' union, President Reagan has successfully produced one of the major political coups in recent years. From all appearances, the primary reason for the President's stand was simply his anger at widespread law-breaking. He responded like Marshal Dillon cleaning up the entire gang of rowdies east of the Pecos.   In addition, it may be that the President's antipathy for organized labor prevented him from taking a more moderate stand. There has been no serious suggestion by the Administration, however, that Mr.  Reagan's stand was motivated by economic considerations.

headline: Patents; A Way to Immobilize Microorganisms
abstract: A method of immobilizing microorganisms so they will continue to multiply and serve in the commercial production of such things as alcohol was patented this week for the Department of Energy. Alicia L. Compere and William L. Griffith, employees of the Union Carbide Corporation, which operates the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee, were granted patent 4,287,305.

headline: IRAN PLANS TO SPEED UP EXECUTIONS OF ITS FOES
abstract: Iran, intensifying its crackdown on dissidents, announced new rules today for quicker executions.  The Chief Justice, Ayatollah Abdulkarim Musavi Ardebeli, said in an interview broadcast by the Teheran radio that demonstrators and political dissidents would be tried immediately upon their arrest and would be put to death if two people testified against them.

headline: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 28 IN MEXICO KILLED BY FUMES
abstract: A derailed freight train leaking chemical fumes has killed 28 persons and hospitalized over 1,000 at an isolated mountain village, officials said today. Tank cars carrying hydrochloric acid overturned late Saturday in the village of Montana, 240 miles north of Mexico City.

headline: Harvester Canada
abstract: International Harvester Canada Ltd. said today that it was recalling more than 400 workers to its truck assembly plant here. The recall is in anticipation of a stronger Canadian truck market and will raise production to 90 units a day from 49, the company said. It said the recall would allow for the opening of a second shift and increased the work force to 1,600.

headline: Russians Buy Canada Grain
abstract: The Canadian Wheat Board today announced the sale of just over 2.3 million metric tons of wheat and barley for shipment to the Soviet Union.   It was the first contract to be signed with the Soviet Union under a five-year agreement announced last May.

headline: Advertising; AWARENESS AT CREDIT CONCERN
abstract: WHEN a fellow prepares for an interview by making a flip chart, you know you have got a thorough person for a subject. Such a man is Barton D. Ladd, vice president of the General Electric Credit Corporation, who was well prepared yesterday to talk about the new $2 million ad campaign prepared by Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn.  You might already have seen it, since the ads began running this month in business publications.   All the ads (there are three for this year) are spreads and all run under the same big headline: ''Enterprising Capital.'' They all tell business leaders how anxious General Electric Credit is to lend money, how it hates to say ''no'' when approached.

headline: Lawyer Tied To Stock Data
abstract: A Wall Street securities lawyer has been charged with illegally using inside information concerning impending mergers of his firm's clients to buy and sell stocks at a profit of $450,000.   State Attorney General Robert Abrams disclosed on Sunday that Carlo M. Florentino, 37, who worked for the Wall Street firm of Wachtell Lipton, Rosen & Katz, apparently learned of possible mergers and acquisitions from clients.

headline: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Further budget cuts of $10 billion to $15 billion were authorized by President Reagan. The White House called the reduction a ''hardline'' effort to limit the deficit for fiscal 1982 to the $42.5 billion projected. (Page A1.) Mr. Reagan is expected to propose an innovation to achieve the cuts: an omnibus appropriation bill that would afford a single yes-or-no vote on the whole package of cuts.  (A1.)   The new tax law will cut deeply into the market for tax shelters, specialists say, although the program enhances certain areas, such as housing rehabilitation incentives. (D1.)

headline: HILL BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ABC NEWS PROTESTS
abstract: Roone Arledge, president of ABC News, protested yesterday ''in the strongest possible terms'' the explusion of Chris Harper. The protest came in a letter to Ashraf A. Gorbal, Egypt's Ambassador to the United States.

headline: TAKING AIM AT GRUMMAN
abstract: de-loops in a World War II fighter plane, and he still takes to the slopes although he once broke his leg in 16 places in a skiing accident. In his Dallas office, there is the sword he won as a golfing prize in Scotland, a collection of rifles, and a painting of Mr. Thayer in Ethiopia posing with Cecil, a newly bagged lion. Cecil, now stuffed, sits in a roaring pose in one corner of the room.   Late last week, Mr. Thayer took aim at his biggest quarry yet. LTV made a surprise $450 million takeover bid for 70 percent of the Grumman Cor po ration, the nation's fourth-largest military aircraft manufacturer.

headline: Business People; MOVE AT PAINE WEBBER
abstract: ''Thank you, Paine Webber,'' is heard a lot on Wall Street these days, especially in the company's own offices. In the third promotion to be announced in the last two weeks, Jack L. Rivkin, 40, has been named president and chief executive officer of Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins, the research arm that conducts the firm's institutional equity and investment business.

headline: MOODY'S CUTS FORD UNIT'S RATING
abstract: Moody's Investors Service yesterday lowered its rating on the Ford Motor Credit Company's commercial paper to P-2, its middle rating, from P-1, the highest.   In an unusual move, Goldman, Sachs & Company, Ford's investment banker, criticized Moody's for the rating cut.

headline: SEALED POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Easing Burden Of a Mortgage
abstract: TO paraphrase Simon and Garfunkel, this period of high interest rates demands a bridge over troubled waters - particularly for those who seek housing in an 18 percent mortgage ma rket.   A serviceable but somewhat costly bridge is available to the home buyer who has substantial capital though not enough to hold mortgage payments down to an affordable level.   Make these assumptions: The individual is willing to invade principal to cover current mortgage payments, and future income prospects are bright enough that in a few years the mortgage payments can be paid from current income.   A financial adviser, who asked not to be identified, recalls how he handled such a situation.  His client, a young woman in business, had purchased a co-op apartment. She soon discovered that the high mortgage payments left her short. Although her income was rising, it would be several years before income matched her needs. She also had, as it turns out, a small inheritance.

headline: ABC Seeks to Bar New Satellite TV
abstract: The American Broadcasting Companies asked the Federal Communications Commission to block the introduction of direct broadcast satellite systems, which would transmit programming from satellites directly to consumers' homes.

headline: Business People; Lehman Brothers Aide Promoted to President
abstract: Lewis L. Glucksman was elected president and chief operating officer of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., yesterday, succeeding Peter G. Peterson, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.   ''I'm very pleased,'' said Mr. Glucksman, who has been with Lehman for 18 years of his 55 years and continues as chairman of the operating committee.

headline: ROCOR INTERNATIONAL (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IRAQ CONCEDES PULLBACK, DENIES DEFEAT
abstract: Iraq denounced as ''lies'' today Iran's statement yesterday that Iranian troops had broken the Iraqi siege of Abadan. Iraq conceded, however, that its forces had made a tactical withdrawal in some areas north of the battered oilrefinery city under pressure from Iranian forces.   The Iraqi general command said in a communique that its forces killed 118 Iranians and lost 23 of its own troops in the last 24 hours along the front from Abadan north to Susangird. Actual Situation Is in Doubt   Iran, however, continued to assert that its forces had scored a significant victory over the Iraqis at Abadan. The Teheran radio said that the Iraqi death toll had risen to 1,000 in fighting that started yesterday morning and that Iran had lost 70 of its troops. The radio also said that 1,521 Iraqi prisoners had been evacuated from Abadan and taken to Teheran.

headline: RCA Shifts Executives
abstract: The RCA Corporation announced some executive changes yesterday, the first since Thornton Bradshaw took over as chairman on July 1.  The company announced that William C. Hittinger, who has been executive vice president of research and engineering, will assume additional responsibility for RCA Communications and the company's international operations.

headline: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY UP $80 MILLION
abstract: In what the financial markets regarded as an unpleasant surprise, a key measure of the nation's money supply rose $800 million in the week ended Aug. 15, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.   As a result, prices of some long-term Government bonds fell by a half point or more in late-afternoon trading and yields rose.  Treasury bill yields also moved higher.   Continued investor apprehension over the high interest rates sent the stock market to a low for this year, and the Dow Jones industrial average declined by 7.80 points, to 920.57. (Page 33.)

headline: Japan Coal Liquefaction
