abstract: The Nippon Oil Company said today that it had reached agreement with the Chevron Research Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of California, to introduce the Chevron coal liquefaction process in Japan at an undisclosed cost. Nippon said that it planned to build a pilot plant in Yokohama, southwest of Tokyo, at a cost of about $53 million, based on the Chevron technology, it said, without elaborating. Industry sources said that Nippon Oil would study whether the Chevron-developed bituminous coal liquefaction technology could be applied to low-grade brown coal.

headline: EL SALVADOR'S TURMOIL, U.S. PRESENCE IS POTENT
abstract: More than 300 Salvadoran business, government and military leaders gathered around the swimming pool of the American Ambassador's residence here to celebrate the Fourth of July.   Outside, on a tree-lined street of quarter-million-dollar homes hidden by high brick walls, bodyguards carrying automatic weapons watched over the armor-reinforced station wagons of the guests.   Inside, senior American military officers in brightly shined black shoes and decorated uniforms mingled with casually dressed priests and more formally attired businessmen and diplomats from around the world.   But the United States involvement is more than just inviting residents to join in Independence Day festivities.  Combat troops trained by United States military advisers here are conducting search-and-destroy missions in the densely forested mountains against guerrilla units of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. American-supplied transport trucks ferry troops across rivers where bridges have been blown and helicopters supplied and maintained by the United States allow El Salvador's army to respond more quickly when patrols are attacked, as they have been with increasing frequency in the last few weeks.

headline: Canadian Jobless Down
abstract: Canada's unemployment rate fell slightly in July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.2 percent, compared with 7.3 percent in June and 7.5 percent in July 1980, Statistics Canada reported today. The agency said 835,000 people were unable to find work in July, down from 855,000 in June and 852,000 in July 1980. Canada's unemployment rate reached a five-year low of 7 percent last April.

headline: REAGAN DISPLAYS SKILL AT CRAFTING DEALS
abstract: Representative Glenn English represents a district in western Oklahoma that produces a vast amount of natural gas. Yesterday, Mr. English received a hand-written note from President Reagan, written on Camp David stationery, promising to veto any bill coming to his desk that would impose a special tax on the profits of natural gas producers.   Today, the Democratic lawmaker voted for President Reagan's tax package. Mr. English denies that his vote was directly purchased by the President's pledge, but the incident does reflect the sort of deal-making and influence-trading that helped Mr. Reagan win his sweeping victory today on the tax issue.   In dozens of meetings with wavering Congressmen over recent days, Mr. Reagan has persistently asked the question: ''What can I do to help you make up your mind?'' The answers have been varied. Don't lift the quota on imported peanuts. Keep some form of the minimum Social Security benefit. Promise to review the third year of your tax cut if the economy weakens.

headline: Business Digest; FRIDAY, AUGUST 14, 1981; The Economy
abstract: President Reagan acknowledged that future budget deficits might be wider than he had projected, as he signed his economic package into law. He blamed changes in his program by Congress. (Page A1.) The tax-exempt savings certificates authorized by the tax law could prove a boon to those in 30 percent-plus brackets. (D1.)   The Big Three auto makers reported a 30.8 percent sales increase in the first 10 selling days of August. Analysts pointed out, however, that the increase was compared with the worst sales period of 1980.  The new figure lifted the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for 1981 to 7.4 million domestic units. (D1.)

headline: 2 CONSERVATION GROUPS URGE AN IMMEDIATE END TO WHALING
abstract: Two international conservation groups urged an immediate ban today on commercial whaling to insure the survival of many threatened species.   The World Wildlife Fund and the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources made the call as the International Whaling Commission prepared for its next meeting.

headline: B.P. Stock Issue Termed Success
abstract: The British Petroleum Company, the world's fifth-largest oil company, said it completed a record $1.18 billion new share issue that earlier seemed set for disaster.

headline: Market Place; Utility Stresses Tax Benefits
abstract: FIVE years ago, the Citizens Utilities Company won the right to recapitalize on a tax-sheltered basis. That is, the dividends of only one of the two new classes of common stock were subject to income taxes.   The cash dividends of the series B shares were -and still are - taxable upon receipt. But the stock dividends paid on the series A shares were treated differently. Any gain or loss resulting from the sale of the dividend shares paid on the A shares was treated as a capital gain or loss.

headline: Hatleigh to Study Sale of Oil Stake
abstract: The Hatleigh Corporation, a Torontobased restaurant and race track operator, and its controlling shareholder, 403372 Ontario Ltd., announced jointly that ''they intend to explore'' the possible sale of their combined 47.5 percent interest in North Canadian Oils Ltd.

headline: Market Place; Seagram Role In Du Pont
abstract: In 1802, a year before the Lousiana Purchase, E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company was established in Delaware's Brandywine Valley as the nation's first producer of explosive black powder. For more than a century, it was America's largest explosives manufacturer.   Today, Du Pont, the winner of the Conoco sweepstakes, is the nation's largest chemical company and Delaware's largest employer.  But the company, whose direction has been largely controlled by the duPont family, may now find itself under the influence of the Seagram Company as well, as a result of the Conoco deal.

headline: Great Britain
abstract: Margaret Thatcher ... 55 ... Prime Minister of Britain ... elected with absolute Parliamentary majority in 1979 ... Conservative ...  wants to dismantle much of the welfare state established by previous governments, and return Britain to prominent world role ... is fighting inflation with tight money but has reaped criticism for high unemployment and deep recession ... violence in Northern Ireland and recently in English cities her main concerns ... popularity low because of wilting economy ... will look for support for monetarist policy ... called ''Iron Lady,'' tough-minded, not given to compromise. Japan   Zenko Suzuki ... 70 ... Prime Minister of Japan ... chosen in 1980 by Parliament as a compromise candidate ... belongs to Liberal Democratic Party, a conservative group ... seeks to protect Japan's strong economic position in light of threats to free trade and American demands that   Tokyo increase its military spending ... now rather popular with public, but suffered recent embarrassment over reports of past visits of American ships with nuclear weapons ... could encounter heavy criticism from others at summit meeting about   Japan's huge trade success ...  straightforward, a verbal fencer.  West Germany   Helmut Schmidt ... 62 ... West German Chancellor ... suceeded Willy Brandt, who was forced to resign after a spy scandal in 1974 ... a moderate Social Democrat ... has fostered strong West German economy but social policies have produced budget deficits, inflation and sharp political attacks ... defies Washington in pressing East-West detente ... easily won last election, in October 1980 ...  has joined President   Mitterrand in opposing high American interest rates ... quick intelligence, vast expertise, but sometimes accused of arrogance ... only leader to have attended all six previous conferences.

headline: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RALSTON PURINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS KEEPS UNIT
abstract: The American Express Company, which had been considering the sale of its American Express International Banking Corporation subisidary, said yesterday that it had decided against such a sale and had accepted the resignation of the head of the subsidiary, who opposed the decision.   James D. Robinson 3d, chairman and chief executive officer, said American Express had decided to retain the subsidiary when it could not find a buyer willing to pay its ''high price standard.'' Consequently, American Express concluded that the ''best alternative'' for the subsidiary was ''to integrate it more closely to the American Express family.''

headline: DOW ADVANCES 7.71 TO FINISH AT 945.11
abstract: The stock market greeted President Reagan's tax-bill victory in Congress with a moderate advance yesterday.  For the first time in five sessions, volume exceeded 40 million shares. It expanded to 41.6 million shares from Wednesday's 37.6 million.

headline: NEWMONT SOLICITATION SAID TO WIN OIL INTEREST
abstract: The Newmont Mining Company, quietly extending invitations to a select group of wealthy American corporations to save it from a possible takeover, has received expressions of interest from two big California oil companies, sources close to the discussions said yesterday.   The two - either of which would have to put up about $1 billion for the ''substantial minority interest'' that is being offered - were identified as the Standard Oil Company of California and the Union Oil Company of California.   The invitation was extended by Plato Malozemoff, Newmont's 72-yearold chairman, in a bid to block a possible takeover by Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd. of London. Gold Fields, operating through a local subsidiary known as the Amcon Group, owns 8.1 percent of Newmont and has already said it planned to buy at least 25 percent but less than 50 percent.

headline: Tiger Increases Purolator Stake
abstract: Tiger International Inc., parent of the Flying Tiger Line air cargo carrier, said that it had raised its stake in Purolator Inc. to 13.4 percent.   Tiger International said in an amended filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it now controlled 584,200 common shares of Purolator, a diversified concern with interests in automotive products and specialized courier and security transportation services.

headline: Around the World; Youth Killed in Belfast As British Fire at Sniper
abstract: A 15-year-old boy was shot to death by British troops tonight as they fired back at a sniper, the authorities said. Irish Republican Army spokesman said the boy had been killed when the soldiers ''fired indiscriminately.''    The incident came amid sporadic attacks on security forces tonight by gangs of youths hurling rocks and gasoline bombs in protest against yesterday's death of Joseph McDonnell, an I.R.A. hunger striker in the Maze Prison.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: At the same time that Pakistan formally accepted terms of the United States military sales and aid package yesterday, the Government in Islamabad summoned the Indian Ambassador, Natwar Singh, and presented him with a proposal for talks on troop reduction along the border and on the possibility of a nonaggression agreement.   The two events, obviously related, underscore Pakistan's sensitivity that as the arms supply relationship with the United States is being resumed, India is stepping up bellicose language aimed at its western neighbor. ''There seems to have been a progressive erosion of restraints,'' commented Abdus Sattar, the Pakistani Ambassador here, as he discussed what he regards as the unwarranted fomenting of a war psychosis.   In Islamabad, Mr. Sattar's superiors insist that while they have made every effort to inform India of their defense needs and wishes, the Indian Government has merely brushed aside these gestures and criticized the purchase of F-16 fighter aircraft from the United States as representing a real menace to India and touching off a costly arms race on the subcontinent.

headline: BONANZA INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TRANE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Man in the N ews
abstract: Moments after Belize became independent from Britain at midnight Sunday, Prime Minister George Price found himself surrounded by delegates from Cuba, Nicaragua and Grenada.   He shyly accepted their congratulations, then looked around quickly and almost thrust himself into the arms of a senior American official who was standing nearby.   For the last 30 years, as he has led Belize's struggle for independence, Mr. Price has become a master in the political art of steering a middle course. And now, as leader of a new nation appearing suddenly in the troubled Caribbean basin, he seems equally anxious to avoid any easy political label.

headline: KINDER-CARE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Talking Business with Kanaga of Arthur Young Accountants And Ethics
abstract: The accounting profession has been one of the principal beneficiaries of the wave of government regulation that mounted steadily during the 1960's and 1970's. Such regulatory legislation as the 1974 Employee Retirement Income Security Act and the 1977 Foreign Corrupt Practices Act were sometimes referred to within the profession as ''acountants' full-employment acts.'' These laws and others increased the need of corporations for financial reporting, auditing and other accounting services.   The Reagan Administration is intent upon peeling away as many of the regulatory controls on business as possible. For instance, Administration officials want the accounting provisions of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act to be stricken entirely. They argue that the legislation saddles American companies engaged in international trade with unnecessary costs.

headline: QADDAFI ATTACKS U.S. 'PROVOCATIONS'
abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, has accused the United States of ''persisting in its provocations and terror'' but has remained silent on what action he might take as a result of the air battle Wednesday between American and Libyan jets.   He spoke at a mass rally in Aden, Southern Yemen, hours after the air action, but he did not mention the clash between American Navy jets and two Libyan fighters. Charging that the United States was directing its ''provocations and terror'' against all Arabs, he called on the ''active forces'' in the Arab world to ''declare a state of mobilization to face imperialist-Zionist and reactionary challenges.''   Colonel Qaddafi, who was in Southern Yemen on Wednesday to sign a treaty of friendship and cooperation with both that country and Ethiopia, arrived in Ethiopia yesterday for a four-day visit.

headline: VIACOM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KDT to Close 50 Kings Stores
abstract: KDT Industries Inc. said it will close 50 of its Kings Department stores by the end of the year because of declining unit volume. But the company also said it would continue to operate about 200 stores in 16 Eastern and central states and Puerto Rico with an estimated annual volume of more than $700 million.

headline: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 31% Rise In Mergers
abstract: The corporate merger pace, which rose by 46 percent in the first quarter, continued its resurgence with a 31 percent rise in the second quarter, a company that tabulates nationwide merger activity reported today.   W.T. Grimm & Company, which is based in Chicago, said that net merger-acquisition announcements rose in the second quarter to 585 from 445 in the same period in 1980.

headline: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Mobil Reports Hebron Results
abstract: Mobil Oil of Canada said its Hebron well off the coast of Newfoundland flowed at a rate of 2,322 barrels of oil and 3.2 million cubic feet of natural gas a day from more than two miles below the sea floor.   J. Denis Mote, an analyst at Bache Halsey Stuart Canada Ltd. in Toronto, said the well was ''shaping up right now as being as good or better than Hibernia.''

headline: AMAX SLIDES 32.6.%
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation, the country's largest steel producer, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1981 rose by 50.3 percent, while sales climbed 22.6 percent.   U.S. Steel said that net income in the latest three months rose to $167.6 million, or $1.89 a share, from $111.5 million, or $1.28 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier, which included a $30.8 million extraordinary tax credit. Sales widened to $3.8 billion, from $3.1 billion.   The company, which has derived a significant portion of its pretax profits from nonsteel operations in recent years, stressed that the earnings gain in the latest three months was achieved despite an aftertax cost of more than $50 million resulting from the strike against the soft-coal industry.

headline: 10 GAMBIAN REBELS SEIZED
abstract: Senegalese troops invited into Gambia by President Dawda Jawara continued mopping-up operations against rebels today.  Their commander, Lieut. Col. Abel Ngom, said that 10 armed rebels were arrested yesterday in the forest of Sokutu, near the Senegalese border.  No figures have been given for the total number of arrest since the Senegalese crushed a leftist-led revolt, but military sources said more than 100 rebels had been taken into custody.

headline: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; 14 ARRESTED IN PAKISTAN IN ROUNDUP OF DISSIDENTS
abstract: Pakistan's military authorities have arrested 14 political leaders in the first major roundup of dissidents in about five months, authoritative sources said today.   The arrests were made last night in a police raid on a Lahore home during a meeting of the Movement for the Restoration of Democracy, a grouping of nine political parties.   The 14 leaders were reportedly jailed here after being charged before a military court with breaking martial-law regulations banning political activity.

headline: Paper Says Egypt and Britain Will Build Heavy Arms in '82
abstract: Egypt is to start producing heavy weapons in January as a result of an agreement with Britain for the joint manufacture of 105-millimeter and 122-millimeter artillery, the authoritative newspaper, Al Ahram, said today.

headline: DETROIT'S CLOUDED CRYSTAL BALL
abstract: The product planners of the American Motors Corporation were droning through another meeting, describing the fuelefficient models on their drawing boards when Gerald Meyers, chairman, interrupted.   What, he asked, were they going to do if the current glut of gasoline continued and prices did not increase in accordance with their projections. What would happen if no market developed for the very fuel-efficient, but expensive, cars planned for later in the decade?   Mr. Meyers has since said that his main purpose was to jolt his executives' thinking. But it is also true that the current surplus of gasoline that has stabilized prices at the pump is causing some concern for auto executives who have to decide now what buyers will want in three to four years.

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Effective January, Tennis magazine is increasing advertising rates 14.1 percent. Golf Digest increases its advertising rates 11.9 percent and its circulation rate base by 1.5 percent, to 1,025,000, effective the same date.

headline: Talking Business with Dreman of Dreman, Gray & King; What's Good About Stocks
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average has fallen steadily in recent months, and yesterday it reached its lowest close in more than a year. Yet some money managers remain enthusiastic about the stock market. One of them is David N. Dreman, managing director of Dreman, Gray & King Inc., an investment counseling concern.   Mr. Dreman, the author of ''Contrarian Investment Strategy'' and ''Psychology and the Stock Market,'' concentrates on stock selection rather than market timing. He argues that selecting stocks from those industries that have the lowest price/earnings ratios is the most disciplined approach to sound investment. Here, Mr. Dreman discusses his investment strategy and how it appplies in the currently depressed market.

headline: Penn Central Net Soars 69%
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings surged 69 percent in the second quarter ended June 30 to a record $48 million, or $1.84 a share, from $28.4 million, or 91 cents a share, a year earlier, reflecting the impact of its acquisition of GK Technologies Inc. on March 31.   Sales rose 92.9 percent, to $935.2 million from $484.6 million in the same period a year ago.

headline: MOSCOW'S FORCES LAND NEAR POLAND
abstract: Soviet Navy forces landed in Lithuania today in their biggest amphibious exercise in the Baltic Sea, military analysts here said today.   The American analysts, who have access to highly reliable information, said that the naval forces, the equivalent of United States Marines, went ashore near Baltisk, a small port 15 miles northeast of the Polish border.   A spokesman for the Pentagon reiterated Washington's belief that the maneuver was not related to the continuing unrest in Poland.  But an official said privately, ''It's sure initimidating enough.''

headline: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 14
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Process May Increase Semiconductor Capacity
abstract: A process invented by scientists at Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., is expected to help manufacturers of microelectronic devices, including radio and other communications equipment, as well as computers.

headline: Conoco Votes to Oppose Seagram Takeover Bid
abstract: Conoco's board of directors voted unanimously Tuesday to oppose an offer by the Seagram Company Ltd. for 35 million shares at $73 a share - a 40.7 percent stake in the oil company.   Conoco, the nation's ninth largest oil company, also filed a $1 billion law suit against the Canadian liquor company and its American subsidiaries to block the tender offer, claiming that it violated Federal securities laws and promises by Seagram officials not to pursue a hostile bid.   The suit asked $500 million in actual damages and $500 million in punitive damages for alleged interference by Seagram with Conoco's merger discussions with Cities Service.

headline: SALVADORAN TELLS OF CRACKDOWN IN THE ARMY
abstract: El Salvador's President said today that his Government had dismissed 600 National Guardsmen and imprisoned 64 for crimes against Salvadoran civilians. The statement, made in response to a question from Vice President Bush about reports of violence committed by Government troops, could not be independently confirmed.    President Jose Napoleon Duarte, head of his country's ruling junta, conferred with Mr. Bush after a meeting with President Reagan.  According to aides, Mr. Duarte told the President that the Salvadoran junta would be prepared to negotiate an end to civil war in that country, but only when the guerrilla forces opposing his Government had ceased fighting.

headline: MADRID DEFENDS MOVE TO JOIN NATO
abstract: Widening a debate on the Government's decision to bring Spain rapidly into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Foreign Minister Jose Pedro Perez Llorca said today that alliance membership would be a significant improvement on the long-standing treaty with the United States.   ''With the entry to NATO, the bilateral treaty with the United States will lose its importance,'' Mr. Perez Llorca told a group of foreign journalists here. ''It will lose the political significance that it has had.''   The Foreign Minister's remarks came partly in response to a Socialist Party campaign against NATO entry, which is expected to come before Parliament later this month. The Socialists favor a renewal of the agreement with Washington, which gives the United States access to Spanish naval and air bases. The agreement has been extended for eight months to give the Government of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo time to complete the NATO negotiations. It expires Sept. 21.

headline: ISRAEL VISITORS GIVEN A TASTE OF ARMY LIFE
abstract: The Israeli Army has begun training students from outside Israel to use light weapons as part of a program that is intended to persuade them to remain in the country.   A total of 43 seminary students who normally attend classes in Jerusalem and at Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank are spending part of their summer vacation in an army barracks here at Camp Mirvah, 10 miles from the Lebanese border and in an area of Lower Galilee that is heavily populated by Arabs. Nearly two-thirds of the students, who range in age from 18 to 26, are United States citizens.

headline: Croatian Dissident Jailed
abstract: A Zagreb court today sentenced Marko Veselica, a Croatian dissident, to 11 years in jail after a seven-day trial. Mr. Veselica, 45 years old, was found guilty of spreading hostile propaganda in interviews with Western news organizations and maintaining contacts with emigre groups.

headline: Industry Honor Is Voted for 2
abstract: Loet A. Velmans, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Hill & Knowlton, and Ronald E. Rhody, corporate vice president for public relations and advertising at the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, have been voted the ''public relations professionals'' of 1981 by the subscribers of Public Relations News.   Mr. Velmans, who was born in the Netherlands 58 years ago and is the first foreign-born person to win that title, was praised for his pioneering role in international public relations.

headline: Soviet Sales Of Oil Rise
abstract: High fuel prices worldwide raised the Soviet Union's earnings from oil and gas exports last year by almost a third, to $27.3 billion, according to trade statistics released today.   The earnings contributed to the Soviet Union's trade surplus of $125.6 million with the West and Japan last year, its first with developed non-Communist countries since the mid-1970's.

headline: WARNER ELECTRIC BRAKE & CLUTCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Rise Is Urged In Debt Ceiling
abstract: The national debt will surge nearly $75 billion above the $1,000 billion level in the upcoming fiscal year, the Reagan Administration told Congress today.   The estimate came from Roger W. Mehle, an Assistant Treasury Secretary, who told a Senate Finance subcommittee that the debt ceiling, now at $985 billion, should be raised to $1,080 billion to give the Government leeway for borrowing next year.

headline: AFFABLE HAND AT IRISH HELM
abstract: During the recent parliamentary election campaign, Garret FitzGerald was at a rally one day in the pretty little coastal town of Bray, about to speak to an expectant crowd of supporters. The politician introducing him described him as a man born and bred in Bray and at that point, before the audience had a chance to cheer and clap, Mr. FitzGerald interrupted.   ''I was actually born in Dublin, not Bray,'' he said, ''and I spent only part of my childhood here, and so although I remember it fondly, it is not strictly true to say that I was born and bred here.''   Low-key, self-deprecating and totally honest, the remark was entirely typical of the man who has just become Prime Minister of Ireland. Indeed, one of the most common questions asked about him during the campaign was, as a newspaper headline put it, ''Is Garret simply too nice to do the job?''

headline: Arms-Related Trade Control
abstract: The United States today asked its allies to be more cooperative in stopping the East-bound flow of advanced technology that has the potential to help the Soviet Union improve its war machine.  The Adminis tration called for tighter export controls to avoid the drain of mili tary-related technology to the Soviet Union, while endorsing mor e East-West trade ''if the Soviets act responsibly.''

headline: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for 13 weeks to Aug 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BONN BUDGET CUTS QUESTIONED
abstract: Despite the Government's adoption last week of an austerity program to curtail spending and borrowing - a strategy designed to promote more private borrowing in the capital markets - there is a growing sense of uneasiness in West Germany's financial community.   In a series of conversations, bankers, accountants and business leaders suggested that the current recession was likely to be prolonged and deepened. The austerity program, coupled with a lack of decisive action by the coalition Government in other areas of the economy, could have long-term negative effects, they said.   ''There is a continuing sense of skepticism, a holding back,'' said the chief economist at the Frankfurt branch of a major American bank recently.

headline: New Terrorist Bombings Keep Lebanon on Edge
abstract: A terrorist bombing campaign continued in Lebanon today. The state radio said that an explosive charge rigged inside a gas cylinder went off prematurely in a store that sells bottled gas canisters in a residential neighborhood of Tripoli.

headline: UNION AND THE LONDON TIMES REACH PACT TO END SHUTDOWN
abstract: The shutdown of The Times of London and The Sunday Times ended late tonight when protesting newspaper workers reached agreement with Rupert Murdoch, the papers' owner.   Pickets were to be lifted ''forthwith,'' and although The Times will not appear tomorrow, for the third consecutive day, publication was expected to resume with Thursday's edition.   Details of the agreement wi th the National Graphical Association, which represe nts both printers and pressmen, reached after more than six hours of talks tonight, were not released pending a meeting tomorrow of t he union's 101 members at the Sunday Times.

headline: Credit Markets; DOW PLUNGES 18.36; INTEREST RATES CITED
abstract: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday in trading that was hectic at times, and dominated by the fear that the large $6.9 billion increase in the basic money supply will spur Federal Reserve efforts to prevent a decline in short-term rates, action that may even result in higher rates.   In the Treasury bill market, rates on new bills moved higher at yesterday's auction, where three-month bills averaged 15.56 percent, up from 14.56 percent last week, and six-month bills averaged 15.32 percent, up from 14.23 percent.   After adding one-quarter percentage point to the six-month bill average, banks may pay a top rate of 15.57 percent for new six-month savings certificates starting today, up from 14.48 percent last week.    Although many economists continue to recommend bond purchases because current yields are so high compared with inflation, few investors heeded that advice yesterday. The combination of extremely volatile bond prices, and short-term interest rates that offer higher yields without the risk of a steep price decline, have kept many investors from moving funds into longer maturities.

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 21, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.  Special Committee on Decolonization, subcommittee on petitions, information and assistance - 10:30 A.M.  Special Committee on Decolonization - 11 A.M.

headline: Around the World; Cuban Exile Leader Hopes to Topple Castro
abstract: The leader of an organization of Cuban exiles says he is undeterred by the capture of a group that intended to assassinate President Fidel Castro.

headline: Metropolitan Venture
abstract: Bernard Weissbourd, a 58-year-old Chicago developer, has been named to head a major new commercial real estate development organization that is a joint venture between his company, Metropolitan Structures, and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. The venture, which has a net worth of more than $500 million, plans development projects totaling $2 billion to $3 billion over the next decade, Mr.  Weissbourd said.

headline: Gasoline Futures Trading Approved
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission agreed today to permit trading in futures contracts for gasoline, both leaded and unleaded.   The agency gave the New York Mercantile Exchange permission to trade in the contracts.

headline: BBC's Ankara Reporter Faces Trial on Unspecified Charges
abstract: The Ankara correspondent for The Financial Times of London and the British Broadcasting Corporation said today he would be tried in criminal court next month on unspecified charges.   The correspondent, Metin Munir, said he had learned of the pending legal action in a summons delivered to him today.

headline: OPEC Price Discussions
abstract: Indonesia's oil minister, Subroto, the current president of OPEC, said today that he foresaw a ''50-50 chance'' that the oil cartel would hold a price-setting meeting before its regularly scheduled meeting Dec. 7 in Abu Dhabi.   In the meantime, he said, ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries are holding ''constant consultations'' in hopes of ''arriving at an understanding about the possibility of a unified price.''

headline: MOUNTAIN BANKS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: YAMAHA-SPAIN ACCORD
abstract: The Yamaha Motor Company of Japan said today that it had signed an agreement with Spain's Banesto Group to set up a 50-50 joint venture company in Spain to produce motorcycles for the domestic market.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Israeli Officer Killed By Concealed Bomb
abstract: The Israeli military commander of the Rafah region of occupied Sinai was killed today by a bomb at the southern end of the Gaza Strip. Five other Israelis - two soliders and three policemen - were wounded.

headline: INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PRICES PAID TO FARMER DOWN 2.1%
abstract: Prices paid to farmers for raw products dropped 2.1 percent in August and, for the first time in 14 months, averaged below the levels of a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.   Nevertheless, the department's economists predict that retail food prices will go up an average of 8.6 percent this year, matching last year's gain, which was the smallest annual increase since 1977.   Scott Steele, a staff economist in the Agriculture Department, said this year's prospects for big grain crops (including wheat, rice and corn) along with sharply higher production of cotton and other commodities were the main reasons for a price decline.

headline: RCA to Sell Satcom 5 Unit
abstract: The RCA Corporation said it would sell its planned fifth telecommunications satellite, Satcom 5, to Alascom Inc. of Anchorage, in an agreement worth $180 million.   Alascom, which RCA created and sold to the Pacific Power and Light Company of Seattle in 1979, already leases space on two RCA satellites, according to an RCA spokesman, Henry J. Bechtold.

headline: Prospects
abstract: The Economy Becalmed   Based on recent indicators, the economy gives the impression it is going nowhere. Retail sales, employment and industrial productiof all seem to have flattened. For third quarter, the question confounding analysts is whether the economy will keep treading water, or start to sink.   Wall Street fears a credit crunch and recession during the latter half of 1981 as a result of the Fed's tough monetary policy. But consumers are likely to stave off a precipitous downturn.

headline: Advertising; A Rooster Will Crow For the Putnam Trust
abstract: The Frank Vos Company, specialists in direct-marketing advertising, has landed the Putnam Daily Dividend Trust, a Boston-based moneymanagement company that is part of Marsh & McLennan. And as part of the job, the agency has created a new logo for the company, a rising sun with a rooster in the foreground.   How much advertising money will back the Putnam Rooster in its fight with the lions, bulls, frogs and mountain goats working for other financial institutions is still up in the air, but Frank Vos says he thinks that since Putnam ''is a big company, I don't think they will let the competition outroar, outbleat or outcroak our new rooster for long.''

headline: SOUTH DAKOTA LOVES CITIBANK, BUT THERE'S NO STAMPEDE
abstract: It took nearly two years, but Citibank credit cards have finally taken up official residence in Sioux Falls, S.D., a locale unmarred by usury ceilings. With a ribbon-cutting in June and other proper ceremony, the newcomer professed itself pleased with the Coyote State. The state, flush with new jobs, beamed, and looked for more.

headline: AN AUDIENCE WITH MR. EXXON
abstract: T HE scene is an executive dining room on the 53d, and top, floor of the Exxon Building. Down the hall is the rolltop desk of John D.  Rockefeller, the patriarch. Out the broad window, looking north, the view is Manhattan, then Connecticut, and in a real sense, the entire globe.   Clifton C. Garvin Jr., the 14th chief executive of the Exxon Corporation, is eating a cheeseburger (without bun), and talking about Exxon's place in the world's economic firmament and the nuances of the giant company's conception of the economics, politics, and sociology of our collective energy future.   ''You know, I'm the last guy to be opposed to something because of size,'' Mr. Garvin, 59, said with a laugh in the course of a rambling two-hour conversation.

headline: British Car Output
abstract: Automobile production in Britain rose to 56,000 cars in August from 51,000 a year earlier but was below the 73,000 in July, Industry Department figures show.

headline: Growers Hopeful On California Fruit
abstract: Facing heavy odds, California fruit growers are hopeful that they can win their battle against the Mediterranean fruit fly and save the state's $15 billion agricultural industry.   The difficulty the industry faces was reflected today in a move by Texas to set up roadblocks to inspect and keep out infested fruit.  (Page A12.)   Although several other states have restricted the shipment and sale of more than 200 of California's crops, only a Federally imposed quarantine now under consideration could cripple the industry, the growers believe.

headline: Patents; CHEMICAL IN CANDY TO INHIBIT SMOKING
abstract: A Californian offers a method of inhibiting tobacco smoking without causing physiological symptoms of nicotine withdrawal.

headline: ABC's Profit Climbs 3.4%
abstract: The American Broadcasting Companies announced yesterday that its profit in the second quarter rose 3.4 percent. It thus became the only corporate parent of a broadcasting network to report a gain for the period.

headline: Soviet Says Flood in Far East Left 8,000 Homeless Aug. 3-6
abstract: The Government newspaper Izvestia said today that floods in the Far East earlier this month had caused extensive property damage and left 8,000 people homeless.

headline: Business Forum; WHEN SHAREHOLDERS BECOME THE VICTIMS
abstract: S EVERAL times a month business publications report a familiar ritual. Bidder announces a tender offer for the shares of Target, offering 150 percent or more than the current market price. The management of Target promptly announces that the price is inadequate, that Bidder does not appreciate the time-honored ways in which Target does business, that the market does not appreciate how soon Target's profits will skyrocket if management is just left to do its job. Bidder, the management says, would spoil all this, and shareholders who take the offer are foolish.   Lest the foolishness of shareholders overcome them, Target's management sets out to protect them from themselves. Target files suit against Bidder, asking a court to block the offer on any available grounds - frequently that Bidder has not disclosed to shareholders the very things Target's management announces for all to hear. Target may acquire a competitor of Bidder, seeking to create an antitrust impediment to the offer, or perhaps Target issues new shares, buys back existing ones, or does something else to complicate Bidder's life.

headline: U.S. PROTESTS SOVIET INNUENDO ON SHOOTING OF POPE
abstract: The Vatican, the Italian Government, the office of the American envoy to the Holy See and the Soviet Embassy here have become involved in a four-way diplomatic dispute over an article by a Soviet journalist that implied that the United States was involved in the shooting of Pope John Paul II.   The office of William Wilson, the United States envoy to the Vatican, said yesterday that it had asked the Italian Government ''to take appropriate action'' regarding the article published by the Soviet Embassy. Mr. Wilson's office said the article ''implicates by innuendo'' the American Government and its envoy in the May 13 attack on the Pope.   A spokesman for the Vatican today refused to comment on the incident, but Vatican and diplomatic sources said the office of Agostino Cardinal Casaroli, the Vatican Secretary of State, was informed before the protest on Friday and agreed with the American action.   The article, written by Vladimir Katin, political commentator for the Soviet feature agency Novosti, was printed in the June issue of ''U.R.S.S. Oggi,'' or ''U.S.S.R. Today,'' a magazine published by the Soviet Embassy here.

headline: ANALYSTS READY FOR A PRICE RISE
abstract: The fixed-income market opens today with a ray of hope in the wake of a sharp price drop that lifted yields to record levels last Monday afternoon and Tuesday morning.   Wall Street economists said they were particularly hopeful for favorable developments in short-term maturities - and for a decline soon in the prime lending rate of 20 1/2 percent -while long-term bonds still face the problems of a bulging Federal deficit.   Hopes for improvement on the short-term front were buoyed by two developments last Friday. The Federal funds rate, for overnight loans between banks, sank to 14 1/2 percent during the day. This surprised market participants, since the figure was below the Federal Reserve's current target range of 15 to 21 percent for this key money-market rate.

headline: SUNOHIO SOLVES ENVIRONMENTAL SNAG
abstract: In 1978 Norman E. Jackson faced a serious problem with his company, Sunohio. Operations of the 18-month-old enterprise, in the business of recycling electric transformer oil, were threatened unless the problem could be solved.   The Environmental Protection Agency had recently restricted the use of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, a chemical compound often used as insulation with transformer oil. Now the agency was holding hearings aimed at banning PCB's altogether. But nobody knew how to take PCB's out of the oil.

headline: Soviet Reports Attack By 700 Afghan Rebels
abstract: The Soviet press agency Tass gave a rare insight today into the strength of anti-G@overnment forces in Afghanistan, reporting that a unit of 700 guerrillas had attacked a single border post.

headline: VITRAMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Cabinet Says Premier Is Resigning in Portugal
abstract: Portugal's Cabinet announced today that Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao had resigned. The three parties in his center-right coalition pledged to remain in power.

headline: OFFICE FIRE PUTS MARSHALL ISLES IN 'A REAL MESS'
abstract: The two-year-old government of the Marshall Islands, an American-administered trust territory about 2,000 miles southwest of Hawaii, lost its operational center and irreplaceable financial, legal and other records in a predawn fire Aug. 24, according to the government's liaison office here.   The blaze destroyed the Administration Building, which housed the offices of the chief secretary, the attorney general and the auditor general, the departments of finance, immigration and social security and the Marshall Islands credit union. Also destroyed were two government warehouses containing valuable equipment parts and other materials.

headline: MIXED CAPITAL SPENDING PLANS
abstract: When the Champion International Corporation broke ground last May on a new $483 million pulp mill in Quinnesec, Mich., the goal was to get the mill operating by September 1984.   That is now in question. Construction plans were squeezed by a 10 percent cut this month in Champion's 1982 capital spending budget, a cut that stemmed largely from the persistently high interest rates that threaten to hurt the economy in 1982.   ''If the situation does not improve, a second cut could delay the plant for as much as another year,'' Gerald J. Beiser, Champion's senior vice president for finance, said yesterday. ''We'll have to decide that in a couple of months, based on general business conditions. We're watching the situation very closely.''

headline: Around the World; Bombs in Ulster Injure 7 And Block Key Railway
abstract: Irish guerrillas set off bombs in six cities and towns in Northern Ireland tonight, injuring seven people and causing extensive damage.

headline: HANOI STILL HOLDS THOUSANDS IN CAMPS
abstract: More than six years after the Communist victory, countless thousands of Vietnamese who served the former Saigon Government remain imprisoned in jungle camps, uncharged, untried and unsure whether they will ever be released.   Although the Government in Hanoi announced in response to international criticism that in no case would the imprisonment for ''re-education'' exceed three years, the outflow of refugees continues to bring to other shores men who have only recently been released from such concentration camps.   Pham Van Phu, who was arrested in June 1975 for having been a judge in Saigon Criminal Court, arrived at this island group in the Formosa Strait on a small fishing boat in mid-June. He said he was released last January from a ''re-education'' camp at Xuyen Moc in Dong Nai province, about 200 miles north of the former South Vietnamese capital.

headline: 40 Hurt as Korean Jumbo Jet Veers off a Runway in Manila
abstract: A Korean Air Lines jumbo jet veered off the runway during takeoff tonight and crashed through a fence at the Manila International Airport, injuring at least 40 people, authorities said.   Jesus Singson, director of the Bureau of Air Transportation, said the pilot of the Boeing 747 was taxiing down the runway when he noticed a mechanical failure and pulled the brakes.

headline: I.M.F. Loan to Malaysia
abstract: The International Monetary Fund said today that it had approved a $218 million loan to Malaysia, which has been hurt by a decline in sales of its major exports.  Financing is being made through the I.M.F.'s compensatory financing facility, which makes loans available for countries that suffer export losses because of poor weather and other factors. The I.M.F.  said that, in the 12 months ended June 30, Malaysia's export earnings stagnated because of a 10 percent decline in exports of natural rubber, tin and timber.

headline: FUEL SHORTAGE AFFLICTS LEBANESE
abstract: Lebanon, relieved of fighting between Israeli and Palestinian forces, is in the grip of an acute fuel shortage that has played havoc with daily life and has threatened to cripple its already burdened economy.   The fuel crisis began after the Israelis destroyed part of the Zahrani refinery, on Lebanon's southern Mediterranean coast, in the two weeks of fighting before a cease-fire was arranged by the United States on July 24.   A pipeline that carried crude oil from Saudi Arabia to the refinery, which supplied more than half of Lebanon's fuel needs, was also damaged. Technicians have told the Government that repairs will take two weeks.

headline: Around the World; Strikers in Sierra Leone Protest Economic Policy
abstract: A strike protesting soaring prices and food shortages crippled the capital and other areas today in the biggest challenge ever mounted by unions to the economic policy of President Siaka P. Stevens.

headline: NOW Order Narrows Use
abstract: A Federal judge today nullified regulations that would have allowed all private nonprofit groups and government organizations to own interest-bearing checking accounts in savings and loan associations.   The decision, by United States District Judge John Lewis Smith Jr., was a victory for the nation's commerci al banks, which contended the regulations g ave the thrift industry an unfair advantage.

headline: Business People; KROEHLER REALIGNS TOP MANAGEMENT
abstract: A change in the management of the Kroehler Manufacturing Company has been announced, following the acquisition of the Kroehler family's 37 percent interest in the corporation by an investment group led by Peter B. Harvey and Kenneth L. Kwiatt. Kroehler, established in 1893, is one of the largest manufacturers of upholstered furniture.

headline: RULING AIDS DOME IN ITS ACQUISITION
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd. has cleared the first obstacle to its effort to acquire the remaining shares of the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company over the objections of a key minority stockholder.   The Ontario Securities Commission decided yesterday to exempt Dome from the usual Ontario requirement that Dome make a takeover offer to the minority shareholders of Hudson's Bay Oil as a follow-up to its purchase of the majority of the shares. Hudson's Bay Oil has its headquarters here.

headline: TEXT OF CONFERENCE COMMUNIQUE
abstract: Following is the text of a communique issued today by Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau representing the views of the participants in the economic summit meeting:   Our discussion of international affairs confirmed our unity of view on the main issues that confront us all. We are determined to face them together in a spirit of solidarity, cooperation and resonsibility.   We all view with concern the continuing threats to international security and stability. Lasting peace can only be built on respect for the freedom and dignity of nations and individuals. We appeal to all governments to exercise restraint and responsibility in international affairs and to refrain from exploiting crises and tensions.

headline: Torrijos's Body Flown To Panama's Capital
abstract: A Panamanian Air Force helicopter today brought to Panama City the body of Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, head of the Panamanian National Guard and effective ruler of the nation since 1968.   General Torrijos, who ended United States rule over the Panama Canal, was killed Friday when his light air force plane crashed into the side of a mountain in western Panama.

headline: Lebanon Set To Seize Oil
abstract: Lebanon has requisitioned crude oil in reservoirs of the Trans-Arabian Pipe Line Company, known as Tapline, in southern Lebanon, following Tapline's decision to stop pumping oil from Saudi Arabia to Lebanon, official sources said today.   A decree seizing the oil was issued by Mohammed Yosuf Baydun, the Minister of Industry and Oil.

headline: WARNER PROFITS JUMP 66.4%
abstract: Warner Communications Inc. reported yesterday that profits in the second quarter soared to a record $42.6 million, or 66 cents a share, up 66.4 percent from $25.6 million, or 45 cents a share, in the April-June quarter a year ago.

headline: MCA Inc.'s Net
abstract: MCA Inc., a major film entertainment concern, yesterday reported that net income for the second quarter was $30.9 million, or $1.30 a share.

headline: Hudson's Bay Widens Offer
abstract: The Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company said it would offer $44.25 (Canadian) a share, or about $127 million, for the 2.9 million publicly held shares of the Cyprus Anvil Mining Corporation not covered under a previous purchase agreement. Hudson's Bay said the offer would commence Wednesday.

headline: U.S. STEEL CANCELS RISE IN TIN PRICE
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was withdrawing its price increase on tin mill products, which was to have gone into effect on Sept. 20, after the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation announced Monday night that it would not increase its prices until January.   The 6 percent rise on tin mill products, used primarily to make cans, was initiated by the National Steel Corporation earlier this month.   The increase was followed by the Kaiser Steel Corporation and last week by U.S. Steel and the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation.  Industry sources said, however, that some of the major steel producers were offering price protection to some major consumers, under which their prices would not be increased for several months after the Sept. 20 effective date.

headline: Viletta at Margeotas
abstract: The Viletta China Company, previously only the maker of collector plates, is now going into the tableware field and has hired Margeotas/Fertitta & Weiss to handle a $1.5 million ad campaign.  Previously its ads were done in-house.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Brock Confers in Hong Kong
abstract: Bill Brock, the United States special trade representative, held informal discussions with Hong Kong officials today on matters of mutual interest, a spokesman for the British crown colony said.

headline: 2 Monsanto Holdings Sold
abstract: The Monsanto Company said it had completed the $275 million sale to Conoco Inc. of its interests in their joint ventures in Louisiana and Texas.

headline: CONSUMPTION OF MEAT RISING IN THE DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
abstract: When Lowell Haskins, an American poultry breeder, visited Zambia not long ago, he was invited to lunch at the luxurious home of a Cabinet minister. The official's wife asked if he would like to see her chickens, and then led him outside. There in the back garden were 300 broilers being fattened for the Lusaka market. ''It was like being invited to the home of Alexander Haig and having Mrs. Haig show you her chicken business in the backyard,'' said Mr. Haskins, whose Connecticut company, Arbor Acres, supplies almost one-third of the world's breeding stock for broilers.   All over the developing world, the production and consumption of meat are soaring. In the last five years, for example, the per capita consumption of poultry has risen by 24 percent in the developing countries. Poultry Part of Meat Category   The meat category, as defined by experts, includes poultry in addition to beef, veal, pork and sheep, goat and horse meats.  The trend is the most important change in global eating habits of the last decade, in the view of many food experts. Despite warnings in the early 1970's that the world's food-producing capacity could not sustain an American-style diet, people in Africa and the Middle East, in the rapidly growing countries of Southeast Asia and in Eastern Europe, Mexico and Brazil are using their rising incomes to purchase more meat.

headline: AWACS SAFEGUARDS ARE OF USUAL TYPE
abstract: Some of the limitations on the use of five Airborne Warning and Control System Aircraft that the Reagan Administration wishes to sell to Saudi Arabia are what one senior American official calls ''standard strictures'' common to all sales of military equipment to foreign Governments, rather than special concessions by the Saudi Government.   Such standard restrictions include what are called ''third-country exclusions'' that prevent a buyer of American military equipment from transferring the equipment or technological secrets about it to another country without permission from the United States.   Another standard part of all foreign military sales agreements is a pledge to maintain the security o f secret and sensitive equipment.  Safeguards against use of the planes, known as Awacs, against Israel in a f uture Arab-Israeli conflict are expected to figure prominently i n Congressional debate over the proposed $8.5 billion sale of air c ombat equipment.

headline: LONDON AND TORONTO MARKETS FALL
abstract: Stock and bond prices fell sharply yesterday as investors expressed disappointment with President Reagan's latest economic proposals and concern that his Administration will not be able to bring down interest rates.   On the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 11.13 points, to 824.01, its lowest level since the recession in the spring of 1980, and the American Stock Exchange's key index suffered its second-largest decline on record.   Prices fell quickly when the market opened, reflecting concern that President Reagan's proposals Thursday night will fail to keep the Federal budget deficit within bounds. The markets also reacted to a new forecast from Joseph Granville, a well-known investment adviser whose sometimes dramatic predictions have affected stock prices in the past. Predicts Big Drop Monday   Mr. Granville said in an interview in Paris that stock prices would plunge in New York on Monday.  In the credit markets, the return on long-term Government bonds rose to a record level, exceeding 15 percent, as prices, which move inversely to yields, plunged. Short-term interest rates rose, too.  (Page 29.)

headline: Japan Vehicle Output Up
abstract: Japan's vehicle production last month rose to the second highest on record, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.   It said the 2.4 percent increase over the June figure, the previous second highest, to 1.04 million vehicles followed better than expected exports and increased production of trucks and small cars.

headline: MOSCOW SAYS U.S. IS SPURRING ON POLISH COUNTERREVOULTIONARY DRIVE
abstract: Barely a week after President Reagan urged LeonidI. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, in a letter to exercise restraint on Poland, the K remlin has given new emphasis to charges that the United States is fomenting ''counterrevolutionary'' activities in Poland.   Two commentaries in the official press were devoted to the subject today, one of them making a mocking reference to the Reagan letter.  The commentaries, by the Communist party newspaper Pravda and by the Government's press agency Tass, said American appeals on Poland were a mask for a policy that sought to generate tension by funding and otherwise manipulating the ''counterrevolutionary'' activities of Solidarity, Poland's independent labor union.

headline: People
abstract: * Stephen William Norcia has rejoined SSC&B Inc. as an executive vice president.

headline: Portugal's Social Democrats Ask Backing for Government
abstract: Portugal's Social Democratic Party has called on its Christian Democratic coalition partners to give full backing to a new government led by Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao.   Mr. Balsemao, who resigned on Aug. 10 in the face of growing criticism from the Christian Democrats and the right wing of his own party, has been asked to form a new center-right government by the Social Democratic National Council.

headline: BETHLEHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WHEELABRATOR PONDERS A NEW RAIL UNIT
abstract: Wheelabrator-Frye Inc. announced yesterday that its board of directors was studying a proposal to create a subsidiary to be called the Pullman Transportation Company. Its financial results would no longer be included in Wheelabrator's statements.   The proposal, an analyst said in an interview, is aimed at getting the potentially volatile Pullman Standard division ''off their main financial statements.'' The division has worked off its backlog of orders for railroad cars this year, he said, and now faces uncertainty over future orders.

headline: Soviet Gets Loan
abstract: The First National Bank of Chicago said today it was participating in a $25 million syndicated loan to the Soviet Union. The bank said its London-based First Chicago Investment Banking Group unit was arranging the loan, but declined to give further details.

headline: ANOTHER CAR BOMB EXPLODES IN BEIRUT, KILLING 3
abstract: A car bomb exploded in Beirut today, killing three persons and wounding three others, and an anonymous telephone caller said it had been set off by the same underground group that was responsible for two similar blasts yesterday.   In calls to newspapers and news agencies, a man speaking in Arabic said that his organization, known as the Front for the Liberation of Lebanon From Aliens, would carry on its activities ''until there no longer are any foreigners or plotters alive on the territory of greater Lebanon.'' The front, a little-known organization, has been called a Lebanese-Christian right-wing group, but the different types of targets that the caller said it had attacked led to much speculation here over its identity.

headline: Trial Set Over Thrift Rules
abstract: A dispute over whether nonprofit groups can have interest-bearing checking accounts at thrift institutions - with billions of dollars in deposits at stake -should be settled quickly by a nonjury trial, lawyers for Federal regulators and the American Bankers Association agreed today.   Oral arguments in the case were set for Sept. 11.

headline: SEOUL SAID TO HOLD 15,000 IN CAMPS WITHOUT TRIAL
abstract: The South Korean Government keeps 15,000 people in army detention camps without trial and with no charges brought against them, according to a prisoner's account smuggled out of a camp and published here.   Prisoners, including many common criminals and a few polticial prisoners, were severely kicked and beaten with rifle butts on entry to the camp in August 1980, the account said. It said that there had been five deaths out of 500 people held at one camp.   The account was published in the current issue of Sekai, a Japanese magazine, and is to be carried shortly in English in the Korea Communique, a publication here of the Emergency Christian Conference on Korean Affairs.

headline: DR PEPPER TO ACQUIRE CANADA DRY
abstract: The Dr Pepper Company has agreed in principle to acquire the business and most of the assets of Norton Simon Inc.'s Canada Dry subsidiary, the two companies announced late yesterday.   Analysts said that the transaction would solidify Dr Pepper's nowtenuous market position as the third-largest soft-drink company after Coca-Cola and Pepsico. It is just ahead of the Seven-Up Company, a Philip Morris subsidiary.   The announcement gave no indication of the nature of the transaction or of its estimated value. The brief statement, issued after approval of the sale during an afternoon meeting of Norton Simon's board, said the transaction was subject to the ''preparation and execution of a definitive agreement containing customary conditions.''

headline: Heimann Joining Warburg, Paribas
abstract: John G. Heimann, former United States Comptroller of the Currency, has become chairman of the executive committee and a managing director of Warburg, Paribas Becker-A.G. Becker, the New York-based international investment banking firm. His salary has not been disclosed.

headline: LEISURE CONCEPTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRITAIN'S TRADE SURPLUS SET A RECORD LAST YEAR
abstract: Britain achieved a record balance of payments surp lus in 1980, the Central Statistical Office reported today in its annual report.   The value of Britain's exports of goods last year outstripped imports by the equivalent of $5.88 billion, the first surplus since 1971 and only the fourth since World War II, it added, bringing some cheer to a bleak economic landscape.   The nation has been in recession and unemployment has risen steadily, to almost 11 percent last month.  The trade deficit in 1979 was $1.58 billion.  Visible trade last year swung into surplus by $2.17 billion after a deficit of $6.36 billion in 1979.  Exports held up well as businesses, faced with sagging demand at home, mounted a major overseas sales drive, a Department of Trade official said. At the same time, imports fell as businesses reduced their supplies of raw materials from abroad and drew down stocks.

headline: The U.N. Today; July 9, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Ad Hoc Committee on the World Dis- armament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * AM International Inc., Los Angeles, has elected Terrance J.  Bruggeman vice president, finance and administration.   * American Express Co. has named Joanne Black senior vice president, Travelers Cheque division.

headline: Patents; ELECTRONIC TONE FOR TELEPHONE USER
abstract: An electronic tone ringer was patented this week for the Bell System.

headline: STORAGE BIDS FOR MEMOREX, WHICH IS 'INTERESTED'
abstract: The Storage Technology Corporation said yesterday that it had proposed to acquire the Memorex Corporation, the financially beleaguered manufacturer of data storage equipment and audio tapes.  Kenneth Rowe, a spokesman for Memorex, said that while the offer had not yet been received in writing, ''the general response we want to convey is that we're interested.''   The Colorado computer products company offered to acquire Memorex on the basis of four-tenths of a share of Storage Technology for each Memorex share outstanding.   Based on yesterday's prices, Storage Technology is offering stock worth about $11.90 for each Memorex share, making the total value of the deal approximately $89.25 million for the nearly 7.5 million Memorex shares outstanding.

headline: MOSCOW ASSAILS UNION' AIMS
abstract: The Soviet Government's press agency Tass said today that Solidarity, the independent labor union, had shown at its convention in Gdansk that it was out to seize political power in Poland.   An agency dispatch from Warsaw said reports and speeches at the convention had concentrated on attacking the Communist Party, the political system and Poland's gains since World War II.   Tass said the union had offered no solutions to the nation's problems and was instead formulating new demands that could not be fulfilled.

headline: WARSAW DECLARES UNION JEOPARDIZES NATION'S EXISTENCE
abstract: The Polish Government warned the Solidarity union today that its actions were jeopardizing the ''independent existence'' of the country.   The warning was made at the same time as the authorities released a statement by the Central Committee of the Text of Soviet statement, page 4. Soviet Communist Party telling the Polish leadership that ''anti-Sovietism'' was increasing and that something must be done about it.   The statement from the Polish Cabinet, the Council of Ministers, said the Government was prepared to take ''all means'' at its disposal and ''definite measures that might become necessary for the defense of socialism.'' The language was vague but suggested a readiness to use force in any new confrontation with the independent union.

headline: G.M. to Delay Land Purchase
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said that it would delay indefinitely the purchase of land for a new $500 million car assembly plant in Wyandotte County, Kan., because of a continued slump in car sales.   In April, G.M. postponed construction of a new Wyandotte County plant for at least one year because of low sales, but said it would go ahead with the purchase of the 700 acres of land.   A spokesman said that the decision to postpone the land acquisition would not affect long-term plans to build the plant.

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 17, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.   Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 3 P.M.

headline: PORTUGUESE PREMIER TO RESIGN
abstract: Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao today announced plans to resign after failing to silence his critics in the governing Social Democratic Party.   Mr. Balsemao announced his decision after winning a vote of confidence in his leadership at a meeting of the party's National Council.

headline: TODD SHIPYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FLORIDA GULF REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hudson Bay Seeks Francana Shares
abstract: The Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company said it had begun discussions aimed at acquiring the 42 percent interest in Francana Oil and Gas Ltd. which it does not already own.

headline: NL Industries To Review Units
abstract: NL Industries said that it had begun a ''strategic review'' of its wholly owned metal fabricating units that may lead management to recommend their divestiture.   NL said that the units, which include the Doehler Jarvis, Tool and Engineering, Southern Screw and Magnus divisions, manufacture a variety of castings, fasteners, bearings and tooling and prototype assemblies, primarily for the automotive industry.   NL, a leading manufacturer and supplier of petroleum services and equipment, said the units generated about 15 percent of NL's sales and 3 percent of its operating profit in 1980, and represented $140 million, or 8 percent, of NL's assets at the end of 1980.

headline: Rollei Sells Optics Unit
abstract: The Optics division of Rollei Singapore Ltd. has been sold to United Scientific Holdings Ltd. of Britain, Rollei's receivers said today. The purchase price was not disclosed, but the receivers said United Scientific planned to keep the division operating at current levels. Since Rollei Singapore was placed in receivership on July 2 by its two shareholders, Norddeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale and the Development Bank of Singapore Ltd., more than half of its employees have been dismissed, leaving 1,413 workers and 90 executives.

headline: Quanex to Build Two Steel Plants
abstract: The Quanex Corporation of Houston, a manufacturer of specialty steel tubing, said it would build an $85 million specialty steel plant in Fort Smith, Ark., to produce seam-free bars at a rate of 280,000 tons a year.

headline: British to End Use of M.L.R.
abstract: The Bank of England's minimum lending rate, the benchmark of British interest rates since 1971, will be formally suspended tomorrow, the bank said today.   The central bank said the key rate, called the M.L.R., had been replaced by a flexible system in which market forces play a dominant role.

headline: ABRAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Seoul Buys Mexico Oil
abstract: South Korea has contracted to buy 20,000 barrels of Mexican crude oil a day at current prices of $28.50 to $34 a barrel, the Mexican state petroleum company, Petroleos Mexicanos, announced today. Pemex said the contract was for one year, renewable annually, and called for renegotiation of prices every three months.

headline: Your Money; 2d Mortgages Catching On
abstract: MOST parents are willing to make sacrifices to educate their children, but putting up the family home as collateral for a college loan might strike some people as going too far.   Yet that is just what the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Bank is suggesting in its current advertising campaign promoting the use of second mortgages. ''In the last 10 years, your home has earned a college education,'' say the ads, which urge consumers to borrow against the equity they have accumulated in their homes for a variety of purposes that range from sending children through school to opening up a business. Similar ads have been run by the Chemical Bank, another major New York institution.

headline: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KENAI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BANKERS' HOURS TAKE ON NEW MEANING
abstract: At 2 A.M., it hardly seems like a bank.  Only a handful of desks are occupied in the block-sized room, while during the day 134 people are kept busy there. A motorcyclist's helmet sits atop one desk, and radios quietly hum at one or two others.

headline: GREEN BERETS STEP UP HONDURAS ROLE
abstract: This village's isolated mountain valley, as oppressively muggy by day as it is bleak by night, is nonetheless attracting its share of visitors. They include peasant refugees fleeing from neighboring El Salvador, Salvadoran Government troops and American military advisers.   ''This dump is the center of the world now,'' a United States Army officer said when he was here for three days at the end of July. The officer, Capt. Michael Sheehan, is a member of the Army's elite Special Forces, known popularly as the Green Berets.

headline: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Esso Chemical Order
abstract: Esso Chemical Ltd., a unit of the Exxon Corporation, has ordered three water tube boilers for its planned 500,000-ton-a-year ethylene plant at Mossmorran, Scotland, from Northern Engineering Industries, Northern Engineering said in a statement today. It said site construction is scheduled for completion in 1983.

headline: POLISH CONGRESS, IN SECRET BALLOT, BACKS CENTRISTS
abstract: Voting for the first time by secret ballot, delegates to the emergency congress of the Polish Communist Party elected a new Central Committee today, sending some of the most prominent figures in the leadership down to defeat.   Leaders of both liberal and conservative extremes among the 279 condidates were eliminated in the single-ballot vote for the 200 seats on the committee.   The centrist position of Stanislaw Kania, the centrist position of Stanislaw triumphant, a strong indication that Mr. Kania will be re-elected as First Secretary by the entire congress.   Challenger to Kania Loses   Tadeusz Grabski, a conservative on the Politburo who had undertaken a challenge against Mr. Kania and was planning to oppose him for the party leadership, lost getting 899 votes.

headline: NICHOLS, S E, INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FOR POLES, NEW FREEDOMS DON'T BRING SHORT LINES
abstract: Some people say that if it weren't summer, with fine sunny weather, this city would already have exploded. Others say no, that the freedom Poles have wrested for themselves is so precious that it will temper the growing frustration and anger over the long food lines and the stores whose shelves seem emptier each day.   A dramatic slowdown in production has reduced exports, heightened Poland's indebtedness to the West and forced sharp cutbacks in the import of meat and other foodstuffs. Hoarding and a spreading black market in food have also limited supplies to state stores, which are stocked by an inefficient centralized distribution system.   Lazurowa is a grim collection of 10-story high-rise apartment buildings on the western fringe of Warsaw. It has no telephones, episodic bus service and one kindergarten to serve 30,000 residents.  Most people shop in Warsaw because there is little to buy in Lazurowa.

headline: Advertising; Ad World Is Setting For a Play
abstract: WHEN Madison Avenue comes to Broadway, and the publicist has a name like Fred Hoot, you can be fairly sure that the event will be hard to ignore.   The occasion was a preview of ''Commercial Women,'' a play about six women who act in television commercials, which has been written by a longtime television commercial actress, Fredricka Weber, better known as Freddie. She and the producer, Raymond Homer, need to raise $200,000 to stage the play Off Broadway this autumn, and they invited the rich, the near-rich and the would-be rich, along with some folks from advertising agencies, to see excerpts from the play Wednesday night.

headline: Hunger Striker in Belfast Gives Up His Prison Fast
abstract: Patrick Quinn, the Irish Republican Army hunger striker whose life was saved at the request of his family, has given up his fast, Irish nationalist sources reported today.   Mr. Quinn, 23 years old, who had refused to eat for 47 days, was the 11th jailed guerrilla to go on a hunger strike to back a campaign to be given the status of political detainees in Maze Prison.

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 25, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology for Develop- ment - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: AIRLINES' BID TO WIDEN FARE AUTHORITY DENIED
abstract: The Civil Aeronautics Board by a vote of 3 to 2 rejected today a request by the airlines for greater latitude in raising fares without C.A.B. approval.   The Air Transport Associaton, on behalf of the carriers, had asked for permission to raise the ceilings under which the airlines are permitted to increase or lower fares without petitioning the board.  The association said it would consult with the airlines to decide whether to ask the board to reconsider its vote.

headline: Auto Output Is Reported
abstract: United States automobile production declined for the second consecutive week as some plants remained closed for model changeover, but total production was ahead of last year, according to industry reports released today.   Meanwhile, temporary layoffs at the five major domestic auto makers fell to 77,750 from last week's 90,680.

headline: Briefs
abstract: * Aluminum Co. of America said it planned to discontinue operations at a subsidiary in Sylesbury, England, on Dec. 31 because of depressed demand for ingot.   * Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corp., a subsidiary of Allegheny International Corp., said it would acquire the Madison Steel Co., of Skokie, Ill., for an undisclosed price.   * Cascade Steel Rolling Mills said it had suspended negotiations to acquire Northwest Steel Rolling Mills, a small steel processor based in Seattle.

headline: Market Place; A New Interest In 2d-Tier Oil
abstract: SHARES of some second-tier oil companies have surged during the battle to acquire Conoco. On Tuesday, Getty Oil, Marathon Oil and Superior Oil were standouts, with gains of 5 1/8, 4 and 3 points, respectively, in a largely lackluster stock market. Moreover, Superior Oil's 500,000-share turnover was second only to Conoco's 1.2 million shares.   Yesterday, Getty and Marathon experienced profit-taking, with Getty closing at 77 3/8, down 1 1/4. Marathon dropped 1 3/4 to 74 3/4, partly in reaction to a reduced earnings estimate for the current year. Superior remained strong, closing up 3 1/8 at 47 1/2.

headline: AIDES SAY TOLL MAY BE 4,000
abstract: At least 700 people were killed in an earthquake in southeastern Iran, the second in that region in seven weeks, and the final death toll could be between 3,000 and 4,000, Iranian officials said today.
