First reports listed 700 people dead and 440 injured in the quake that struck Kerman Province last night, and ''efforts to recover the bodies of other victims are continuing,'' the Teheran radio said.   Abolhassan Saveh, governor general of the province, was quoted by Pars, Iran's official press agency, as saying that the final death toll from the quake could reach 3,000 to 4,000. He said that as many as 90 percent of the houses in some villages had been demolished.

headline: REPUBLIC STEEL UP
abstract: American steel companies recorded sharply higher profits during the second quarter of 1981, but analysts cautioned that lower auto, building and machine tool sales presaged a downturn for the remainder of the year.   ''You have to remember when comparing this quarter with 1980 that during the same period last year there was a precipitous decline in industrial orders,'' said Charles Bradford, steel analyst for Merrill Lynch. ''After last year's slump the steel industry streamlined its operations and made significant efficiency gains,'' he added. ''With lower production costs any significant increase volume enables them to make money like bandits.''

headline: Real Estate; A Flurry Of Deals in Manhattan
abstract: A FLURRY of transactions involving investment property in Manhattan suggests a continuing widening of investor pa rticipation in ownershipand financing here.   In one case, the CIT Corporation building at 650 Madison Avenue, on the west blockfront between 59th Street and 60th Street, was sold for $90 million through Eastil Realty Inc. to a pension-front account managed by the Prudential Insurance Company.   In another transaction, the City Investing Company agreed to sell the 59 Maiden Lane building occupied by its Home Insurance group and other subsidiaries to Olympia & York Properties, based in Toronto, for $175 million in cash. City Investing will lease back the space it occupies.

headline: WARNER'S FORMER CHIEF OF DISCO BRANCHES OUT
abstract: Ray Caviano has long been considered a wunderkind in the frenetic record business, an image that was reinforced in 1979 when Warner Brothers Records made him executive director of its dance music department and gave him $6 million to start a disco division. Eight months ago, the 31-year-old Mr. Caviano took what he feels is another step forward when he left Warner to start his own orgnization, the impressively-named RFC Group of Companies.

headline: PUROLATOR GUARDS CARGO-HANDLING NICHE
abstract: The company helicopter connecting the headquarters of Purolator Inc. in Piscataway, N.J., with some of its outlying offices has been busy this week. At a series of meetings, executives have been planning company strategy and discussing the latest earnings figures.    But there has also been talk about Tiger International, the air cargo giant that recently increased its share in Purolator to 13.4 percent in hopes of acquiring its ground courier services.   The idea of such an acquistion roils top exectives at Purolator and the discussion at the meetings has been fierce, ''The last thing we need is a bunch of huge cargo planes,'' said Frederick H. Cook, Purolator's president, in an interview.

headline: The Economy
abstract: The Consumer Price Index jumped 1.2 percent in July, the fastest inflation pace in 16 months, the Labor Department said. For the three previous months the average advance was six-tenths of 1 percent.  Analysts said the surge - 15.2 percent at an annual rate - hurt prospects for lower interest rates. (Page A1.)   New-car sales by the Big 3 rose 20.3 percent in mid-August, helped by rebates and other sales incentives, the auto makers reported. The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate of 7.9 million domestic units was the highest since mid-March. (D1.)

headline: G.M. DELAYS VACATION PAY
abstract: Officials of the United Automobile Workers said today that there was little they could do to prevent the General Motors Corporation from issuing vacation paychecks later than usual to its 376,000 hourly workers.   In the past, General Motors has issued the checks in July.

headline: TROUBLES IN ISRAEL'S DIAMOND TRADE
abstract: Israeli banks, which for years have profited by financing the diamond industry, are now facing large losses on those loans as the nation's biggest industrial export business falls on tough times.   Government and bank officials say that as much as $45 million in loans to the diamond trade may go into default, and many financial institutions are beginning to report lower profits because of the problem.   ''I'm not concerned about the stability of the banks,'' said Oded Messer, an official of the Bank of Israel, referring to the diamond loans. ''But there will be a certain drop in profits this year'' at the banks, he said.

headline: ELIXIR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Japan's Trade Balance Rises
abstract: Japan posted a $739 million trade surplus on a customs clearance basis in August, bringing the January-August trade balance to $3 billion in the black, the Finance Ministry reported today.   The ministry said in a preliminary report that the August surplus compared with a $1.52 billion surplus in July and a $801 million deficit a year ago.

headline: Hewlett Net Up by 15.7%
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the giant electronic instrument producer, reported a 15.7 percent increase in earnings today on a 15.6 percent rise in sales for the third quarter of its fiscal year.   Earnings for the quarter ended July 31 were $81 million, or 66 cents a share, compared with $70 million, or 58 cents a share, a year ago.

headline: Inc. Magazine Names Randolph Publisher
abstract: C.C. Randolph 3d, known in the magazine publishing world as Jim, has surfaced in Boston Harbor as publisher of Inc., the highly successful, two-and-a-half-year-old magazine for small business.   He made a name for himself as publisher of Business Week, magazine for pretty big business, as president of Gruner & Jahr U.S.A. and as the first publisher of Geo.

headline: SHIFTS AT AUTO INSURER
abstract: Paul A. Donald, 52, has been appointed president and general manager of the Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company, the nation's fourth-largest automobile insurer and a major component of the giant Nationwide Insurance organization. The appointment is effective Oct.  1.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: For all the nationally televised debating over the rival Reagan and Democratic tax bills, winning seems to have overtaken substance as the primary objective of both sides in tomorrow's showdown vote in the House of Representatives.   President Reagan and his lieutenants are intent on sustaining the political momentum generated from their earlier budget victories or, failing that, to set up a campaign issue for 1982.   Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and Dan Rostenkowski, the Ways and Means Committee chairman, told the Democratic caucus this morning that the Democrats are scrambling to regain control of the House.  Another Democrat paraphrased their message like this: ''If we win this one, we're still running the show, but if we lose, we might as well turn over the House to the White House.''

headline: Account
abstract: * Taylor Rental Centers of America Inc. to Creamer Inc./New England.

headline: US INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Officers Buy Bigelow Sanford From S.& H.
abstract: A group of senior managers at Bigelow Sanford Inc., the nation's oldest carpet company, has bought the company from the Sperry & Hutchinson Company, Bigelow Sanford officials announced today.   Terms of the sale were not disclosed, and company officials would not say which members of top management were involved.

headline: TOPAZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UNITEL VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Patents; New Way of Producing Iodine for Industry
abstract: The Cetus Corporation, a large genetic engineering company in Berkeley, Calif., received a patent this week for a method of producing iodine.

headline: DOW CUTS LOSING STREAK AT 8
abstract: A last-minute burst of buying catapulted the Dow Jones industrial average into the win column yesterday after eight successive losing sessions.   The Dow, which seesawed most of the day, closed at 954.15, up 4.85 points. The key indicator had plunged 9.89 points Monday.  The stock market actually ended mixed yesterday with declines outnumbering advances, 819 to 695, while 394 issues were unchanged.  The New York Stock Exchange Index rose 0.40 point as volume mushroomed to 53.6 million shares from 44.6 million shares the day before.

headline: U.S., REACTING TO RAIDS, PUTS OFF ANNOUNCEMENT ON ISRAELI F-16'S
abstract: The Reagan Administration today postponed a planned announcement that the United States was resuming delivery of F-16 fighter-bombers to Israel.   At the same time, without directly criticizing Israel, the Adminstration called for a cease-fire in the warfare across the Israeli-Lebanese border.   The Administration's actions followed air strikes early today by Israeli jets against what Israel said were Palestine Liberation Organization facilities in Beirut and targets in southern Lebanon.  The air action in Lebanon was the most severe since Israeli troops moved into the southern part of the country in 1978 and was the fifth Israeli raid in a week against Palestinian targets in Lebanon.

headline: TEXT OF STATEMENT ON NAMIBIA BY FIVE WESTERN COUNTRIES
abstract: Following is a joint statement issued today by the Foreign Ministers of Canada, France, West Germany, Britain and the United States after their meeting on South-West Africa at the United States Mission: Special to the New York Times   UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24 - Following is a joint statement issued today by the Foreign Ministers of Canada, France, West Germany, Britain and the United States after their meeting on South-West Africa at the United States Mission:   The Foreign Ministers of Canada, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, the United Kingdom, and United States met in New York on 24 September to review the progress made in their search for an early settlement of the Namibian question.   The ministers noted that there have been extensive discussions with interested African governments and the Organization of African Unity. The ministers also noted that discussions had taken place between the United States Government and the South African Government and that there had been a recent exchange of messages between the Five and South Africa. It is therefore now possible to identify more clearly the issues involved and a process for their resolution which would lead to implementation of Security Council Resolution 435.

headline: Patents; Device Rapidly Deflates A Balloon or Airship
abstract: Deflation equipment patented this week for the RCA Corporation permits a balloon or airship to be rapidly collapsed after landing.  The equipment also prevents loss of the craft if a high wind breaks the mooring.

headline: Market Place; THE CHALLENGE FACING KDT
abstract: KDT INDUSTRIES is attempting to restore a major acquisition to profitability. Some who are familiar with the company's past efforts at salvage expect another success, though KDT itself is ailing at present.   Sol Kittay is guiding the effort for the former King's Department Stores chain and has a compelling interest in its success. Mr.  Kittay, who is chairman and president of the company, has controlled KDT ever since he bought 12 percent of its shares in late 1979.   It was Mr. Kittay himself who last year sold to KDT the lagging discounters that make up the acquisition - Barkers department stores and Franklin, a chain of women's and children's apparel stores. The price: $60 million.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: A Libyan diplomat said today that his country was seeking help from the Soviet bloc because it expects an invasion by Israel and Egypt with support from the United States.   Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has spent as much as $10 billion on Soviet arms since coming to power in a coup in 1969, but has insisted that he wants to remain free of any military alliance.

headline: 5 NATIONS PRESS NAMIBIA ACTION
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and the foreign ministers of four other Western nations have agreed on the urgent need for action to make South-West Africa independent. But Mark MacGuigan, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, said today that he was not optimistic about an early solution.   Mr. MacGuigan, who made his comment in an interview, met yesterday with Mr. Haig, Lord Carrington of Britain, Claude Cheysson of France and Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany. The five ministers, who are under considerable pressure from African nations to settle the issue, took time from the seven-nation economic meeting to discuss the status of the territory, which is now under the control of South Africa.

headline: BRITISH PRESS CHIDES MRS. REAGAN ON PROTOCOL
abstract: Nancy Reagan is finding it difficult to charm the British press.  This morning, only 24 hours after she arrived in London to attend Wednesday's royal wedding, both popular and quality newspapers mocked her in prominently displayed stories. Much was made of the fact that the First Lady has decided neither to curtsy nor to bow to Queen Elizabeth II when she goes to Buckingham Palace but to shake hands.   In April, when the Prince of Wales visited the United States, he was greeted at the airport in Washington with a curtsy from the chief of protocol, Lenore Annenberg. Hundreds of protests followed on the ground that 1776 and all that had made it most inappropriate for Americans to show subservience to British royalty.

headline: Hospital Corp.  To Sell 18 Units
abstract: The Hospital Corporation of America, the world's largest manager of hospital operations, said it has agreed to sell 18 nursing homes to a California company for $46 million.

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: * Buitoni Foods Corporation to Chester Gore for two of its divisions, Perugina Chocolates and Confections Inc., and Carlyle Importers Inc.   * Lady Arrow, a division of the Cluett Peabody Company, to AC&R Advertising.

headline: Business Conditions; HOW HIGH THE RATE?
abstract: West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's comment in Ottawa last week that real interest rates - calculated by deducting the rate of inflation from the nominal interest rate - are at their highest levels in Germany ''since the birth of Jesus Christ'' may be accurate. As far as the United States is concerned, however, Schmidt's estimate was off by roughly 1,940 years.   ''Believe it or not, real interest rates in the United States have been this high or higher before,'' says Edward S. Hyman Jr., senior vice president and economist at Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc., a brokerage firm. Credit conditions in 1920, 1921 and 1930, he said, pushed real interest rates at least as high as those reached during the first two quarters this year - 9.3 and 14 percent, respectively. During the past 30 years, real rates have tended to range between 2 and 3 percent.

headline: Soviet Oil Output
abstract: Oil and gas production in the Soviet Union was slightly ahead of schedule during the first eight months of this year, Pravda reported today.

headline: OM BOMBAY'S SIDEWALKS DREAMS OF LIFE IN A SLUM
abstract: Nearly one week after a municipal force of several thousand began smashing their huts and plastic tents and driving them out into monsoon rains, the sidewalk dwellers are drifting back to stake out their bits of pavement along a busy thoroughfare in the central Bombay neighborhood of Dadar.   So far, only one family has found the courage to construct a shelter of tar paper and plastic along the one-mile stretch. The rest of the thousands who are coming back are camping in the open with the pots and pans and cloth they were able to rescue in the raid, an attempt by the authorities to force them out of the street.   Some of the returned sidewalk dwellers are sleeping in train stations or with friends whose huts were saved from demolition by a last-minute court order. But in the daytime they come back to occupy the few square feet of pavement that for many had been their home for as long as 25 years. The demolition plan was postponed until mid-October, when the monsoon rains are expected to end.

headline: Market Place; Technology Sector Tested
abstract: technology stocks appear vulnerable, following their spectacular performance of the last two years. In a similar vein, he advised clients this week: ''The key to success in 1981 will be avoiding the big losers.''   Lately, some high-tech favorites have taken substantial tumbles in the market. Prime Computer, for example, showed the best performance of any issue on the New York Stock Exchange in 1980 when its shares soared 273 percent in value. But last week the surprise departure of the company's chief executive officer, Kenneth G. Fisher, raised concern on Wall Street, including worries that other key management personnel might join him in a possible new venture. As a result, Prime Computer's stock dropped that week by a jarring 8 1/8 points, to 28.

headline: Quake Shakes Japan's North
abstract: A moderate earthquake shook the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido today but there were no reports of damage or casualties, the Meteorological Agency reported.

headline: BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: Advertising; Ale-8-One Ad Drive Questioned   WITH fear and trembling the agency people show their new ad campaign to the annual sales meeting of the client bottlers, or dealers, or distributors, or franchise operators (depending on who's telling the story) and instead of greeting it with stony-faced reserve, as the ad people had been expecting, they leap to their feet, a cheering enthusiastic mob.   The product in this frequently told tale changes, but the story is always the same, and the agency people are always awed by the power of their communications.   Until the other day, that is. The teller was James R. Weller, senior vice president and creative director of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners of California in Los Angeles.

headline: New Airline Selects Campbell-Mithun
abstract: Air Chicago, a new airline scheduled to begin service Oct. 1, has appointed Campbell-Mithun/Chicago as its advertising agency.

headline: DOW CLIMBS BY 8.56, TO 862.44
abstract: The New York and American Stock Exchanges reopened normally yesterday after Wednesday's power failure caused an early closing and, afterward, equity prices rose briskly. Strong groups included energy, airline, brokerage, mining, defense, utility and semiconductor issues. The Dow Jones industrial average, scoring its best advance in five weeks, climbed 8.56 points, to 862.44. Gainers on the Big Board outnumbered declines by almost a 3-to-1 ratio .

headline: U.S.-Soviet Arms Talks End
abstract: The United States-Soviet panel that oversees the 1972 strategic arms agreements today ended its 19th periodic review session, which began May 27. The next session of what is known as the Standing Consultative Commission is to be held later this year.

headline: British Jobless at 2.85 Million
abstract: Britain's unemployment, considered a factor in the country's recent rioting, rose in July for the 14th consecutive month, to 2.85 million persons, or 11.8 percent of the work force, the Government reported today.   Unemployment has more than doubled since the Conservative Party, led by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, came to power in May 1979.

headline: MOBIL'S NET UP CITIES SERVICE OFF
abstract: The Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest industrial company, yesterday reported that second-quarter earnings rose 2 percent, while the Cities Service Company announced a 15.5 percent decline.   The earnings of both oil companies were of particular interest to Wall Street because both are involved in intense takeover battles.  Mobil is dueling with Seagram and Du Pont for control of Conoco Inc.  Cities Service is trying to parry what it believes is an attempt by the Nu-West Group, of Calgary, Alberta, to strip Cities Service of its Canadian assets. Nu-West has already purchased 7.2 percent of Cities Service's outstanding shares.

headline: SWANK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Credit market optimism over lower interest rates has given way to concern about a possible rebound in money costs. Analysts now think the recent two-point drop in short-term rates marks the end of their decline, while long-term rates could set new records as the Treasury is forced to enter a market lacking buyers. (Page D1.)

headline: Advertising; AMAX CORPORATE ADS BEING HANDLED BY GREY
abstract: Now that its work is already appearing, it can be disclosed that Grey Advertising has become the corporate agency for Amax Inc., the diversified minerals and energy company.

headline: CONDEC CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MARRIOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 19
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CONGRESS TAKES A LONG HARD LOOK AT FOREIGNN AID
abstract: Foreign aid legislation, rarely if ever politically popular in Congress, appears to be stalled in the House of Representatives with no chance of passage before the new fiscal year begins next week.   In the Senate, with its Republican majority, the Reagan Administration has lost a battle to have restrictions on aid to El Salvador removed from the $5.8 billion foreign aid bill. It has yet to face contests over policies on Argentina, Angola and Pakistan.   Legislators, aides and State Department officials say that, at a time of domestic economic strains and budget cuts affecting social programs, it is even harder than usual to argue a case for foreign expenditures.

headline: 44 SENATORS ARE SAID TO SPONSOR A RESOLUTION AGAINST AWACS SALE
abstract: Forty-four senators have agreed so far to co-sponsor a resolution aimed at vetoing President Reagan's proposal to sell five Awacs planes and other military equipment to Saudi Arabia, according to Senate staff assistants.   Fourteen senators who signed the resolution are Republicans, according to several sources, and this development brought a wave of optimism to opponents of the arms sale. If that many Republicans deserted Mr. Reagan on the issue, only 37 of the Senate's 47 Democrats would be needed to achieve a majority against the proposal - a goal that some senators now think may be feasible.

headline: Pravda Raising Its Price
abstract: Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, is increasing its price by a third. A back-page announcement today said the price of the standard six-page issue would go up from 3 kopecks to 4 kopecks (3.9 to 5.3 cents) in January because of higher prices for newsprint. The eight-page edition, published at least once each week, will rise from 4 to 5 kopecks.

headline: Business Conditions; APPLIANCES SURVIVE
abstract: Although a recent sharp downturn in production could signal worse times ahead, important determinants of demand for major household appliances - high interest rates and a sagging housing industry - do not seem to have had much impact on deliveries.   Through July, shipments of 16 major household items like refrigerators, dishwashers and electric ranges totaled 2.6 million units, up 7.5 percent from a year ago, the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers reports.

headline: MCDONALD'S IN A LICENSE FIGHT IN PARIS
abstract: The McDonald's Corporation, which for years has profited handsomely by selling hamburgers and french fries overseas, is now squabbling over one of its most lucrative foreign fast-food operations.   Raymond Dayan, a French businessmen, has filed a $500 million suit in Chancery Court in Chicago charging that McDonald's was trying illegally to cancel the franchise on the 15 McDonald's restaurants he operates in Paris and prevent him from opening 151 others that were part of the agreement. He would still be able to keep the restaurants already opened, but under another name.   As Mr. Dayan and his attorneys tell it, McDonald's underestimated the potential success of the Paris operations and licensed the franchises at only 1 percent of the gross sales, instead of the usual 5 to 10 percent for its foreign licenses. Mr. Dayan said he suspected that the 1 percent license was one of the reasons that the company was attempting to void his franchise agreement.

headline: WHY DETROIT'S SLUMP PERSISTS
abstract: The American auto industry had only modest hopes for 1981, after a disastrous year in which the domestic producers lost more than $4 billion. Sales, they said, would increase to 10 million cars from 8.9 million in 1980.   Even that goal has been unattainable so far this year, and analysts are now saying that the industry will be lucky to sell more than 9 million cars. The only time when sales exceeded 10 million on an annual basis was in February and March, when profit-sapping rebates were in effect.

headline: Issue and Debate; CURBING BRIBERY ABROAD
abstract: Four years ago, Congress spoke out in a seemingly clear voice against bribery of foreign officials by American companies when it passed the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.  The legislation, which came after yearlong hearings, also called for public companies to keep accurate records, a requirement that at the time also seemed simple and reasonable.   Now a lot of businessmen and their political supporters say the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act is not so clear and needs to be amended so that its violations are more narrowly defined. These complaints have grown louder since Ronald Reagan's election as President, and his Administration favors changing the law. Bill Brock, United States trade representative, will testify on the matter at a Senate hearing tomorrow.

headline: GLOBAL PARLEY IN CANADA IS NOT ALL SMOOTH GOING
abstract: A cooperative effort by some 130 scientists from 53 countries to find ways to limit the arms race and reduce international tensions has run into some tensions of its own.   Even before the 31st Pugwash Conference, named after the little Nova Scotia town where the series began in 1957, opened its sessions in this mountain resort Friday, the organizers protested a decision by the Canadian Government to bar two Soviet delegates. The Department of External Affairs cited security reasons for its refusal to grant the two men visas.

headline: China's Army Chief Calls For Loyalty to Party
abstract: Chief of Staff Yang Dezhi has called on China's armed forces to uphold the leadership of the Communist Party and follow its orders, remarks apparently aimed at diehard Maoists in the ranks.

headline: Disney Name Rights Sold
abstract: Walt Disney Productions, which has been paying a royalty to a Disney family corporation, Retlaw Enterprises Inc., for use of the Disney name, said it had acquired full rights to the name for $46.2 million.   The agreement, subject to approval of shareholders of Walt Disney Productions, based in Burbank, includes the rights to the name, likeness and portrait of the late Walt Disney, and all outstanding common stock in Retlaw.

headline: ANGOLA ASKS U.N. MEETING ON THE SOUTH AFRICAN RAID
abstract: Angola called today for an urgent Security Council meeting to demand the immediate withdrawal of South African troops from that country.   The move could have important diplomatic implications, diplomats here say, by illuminating the split between the United States and its allies. France and Britain have condemned South Africa's incursion into Angola, which began on Monday. In contrast, Washington has carefully avoided singling out the South Africans and has said violence in the region has to be seen ''in its full context.''

headline: Iowa Beef Merger Backed by Holders
abstract: The $800 million acquisition of Iowa Beef Processors Inc. by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation was approved by shareholders of the two companies.

headline: BANI-SADR SAYS HE'LL STAY IN PARIS UNTIL IRAN TAKES DEMOCRATIC PATH
abstract: The deposed President of Iran, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, was granted political asylum in France today after a dramatic night flight from Teheran in a hijacked Iranian plane.   Looking gaunt and tired, the former Iranian leader, who was without his mustache, told reporters: ''I will be staying in France until the people of Iran follow the path of democracy.''   Although his extradition was immediately demanded by the Iranian Government, Mr. Bani-Sadr, 48 years old, will be permitted to stay in France so long as he refrains from political activity. He signed an agreement to that effect before leaving the military airfield at Evreux, near Paris, where his plane landed at 4:30 A.M. today.

headline: TIMERMAN CHALLENGING REPORTS ON PRISON TAPES
abstract: Jacobo Timerman, the former Argentine newspaper publisher who was held for two and a half years by Argentina's military rulers, yesterday dismissed reports that tape recordings of a session with his jailers had called into question how complete his account of his arrest and detention had been. Mr. Timerman said that the reports seemed to distort his account and constituted a trial of his case by the press.   In one of the tapes, Mr. Timerman can be heard saying that he expected his arrest because of his connections with David Graiver, an Argentine banker alleged to have been the money manager of a group of leftist guerrillas called the Montoneros.   Mr. Timerman said yesterday in a telephone interview from his home in Tel Aviv that he did not believe his arrest had anything to do with his relationship with Mr. Graiver.   In his book, ''Prisoner Without a Name, Cell Without a Number,'' Mr. Timerman states that he was arrested in April 1977 because his newspaper, La Opinion, had been publishing the names of people who had disappeared and were evidently being held and killed by units of the military. The book, published two months ago, also portrays some of his captors as anti-Semitic. Mr. Timerman stated in his book that he believed that one of the reasons he was tortured after his arrest was that he is Jewish.

headline: GULF ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Bonn Says a Soviet Spy May Have Tank Plans
abstract: The West German authorities said today that they were investigating a suspected Soviet espionage operation in which a Soviet diplomat may have obtained top-secret plans to the West German Leopard 2 tank.   The officials said that the Soviet diplomat was under surveillance and that two West Germans had been picked up and later released.  Government suspicions of a spy ring were disclosed after a Hamburg newspaper, Bild Zeitung, said the Soviet diplomat, who was assigned to the embassy in Bonn, obtained the tank plans.

headline: U.S. TO AID SAVINGS INDUSTRY
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation today announced a program to acquire low-interest, long-term mortgages now held by the nation's thrift industry and convert them into securities that the thrifts could use to raise cash more easily.    Philip R. Brinkerhoff, the mortgage corporation's president, said the aim was to convert $2 billion of such mortgages this year and up to $20 billion by the end of 1982, thereby providing an important source of liquidity for beleaguered savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks.   Mr. Brinkerhoff said the program had already been put into effect on a test basis and will be operating full scale by next month.   The savings banks and savings and loans, collectively known as thrifts, hold some $600 billion of mortgages, the bulk of the $800 billion mortgage debt outstanding. More than 90 percent of the total mortgage debt was written to yield 12 1/2 percent or less, compared with current interest rates of about 17 percent that thrifts must pay to acquire funds.

headline: ALAN PATON, AT 78, STILL GOADS HIS BELOVED COUNTRY
abstract: Suddenly Alan Paton is 78 years old.  The fact occasions surprise, since his voice has not been trailing off in South Africa. A well-turned Paton polemic, mixing moral reflection and salty advice to white politicians and others who seem ill disposed to heed it, is still apt to show up in the local press, injecting a little incandescence into gray columns of ritualistic debate.   Now, after a hiatus of 28 years, the author of ''Cry, the Beloved Country'' is waiting with all the anxiety and hopes of a literary unknown for the publication of his first novel since ''Too Late the Phalarope.'' There were seven books after that - including ''Towards the Mountain,'' the first volume of an autobiography published last year - but it seemed likely that his second novel, written at the age of 50, would be his last. He had even ceased to be thought of as a practicing novelist, but Mr. Paton is now inclined to think that his third novel, due in September, could prove to be the first in a trilogy.

headline: Market Place; Colonial Penn: What Next?
abstract: A WHILE back, Colonial Penn Group looked like a hot takeover candidate. The company wrote much of the personal insurance purchased by older Americans, and its largest market, a lucrative one, was the accident and health business of individuals over age 55.   The company did not have to peddle these policies by costly doorto-door methods. It sold them by mail through the American Association of Retired People, the largest organization of its kind.

headline: More Banks Cut Prime to 19 1/2%
abstract: Most of the nation's major banks reduced their prime lending rate by one-half percentage point yesterday, to 19 1/2 percent, falling into line with an industrywide rollback started on Monday by New York's Chase Manhattan Bank.   Citibank of New York, the nation's second-largest commercial bank, led the major banks cutting their prime rates yesterday, and was later followed by Bank of America, in San Francisco, the nation's largest bank.

headline: WICKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FRENCH INDUSTRY ATTACKS PLAN
abstract: Reaction to the new Socialist French Government's nationalization program, outlined yesterday by Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy, was sharply divided today. Predictably, employers condemned the plan, while the major unions applauded it.   The strongest criticism came from the the national employers organization, which is already being pressed to accept a shorter workweek and a higher minimum wage. Its director, Francois Ceyrac, called the Socialist plan ''useless, costly and dangerous.''

headline: Product Introductions In Summer Slump
abstract: New-product introductions suffered the usual summer slump last month, according to the New Product News newsletter published by Dancer Fitzgerald Sample.

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 28, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
abstract: Meets on a complaint by Angola against South Africa at 3 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology for Develop- ment - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Paper Ad Revenues Up 21.6% in July
abstract: July advertising revenues for the nation's newspapers were up 21.6 percent, to $1.4 billion, over the same month last year, according to estimates by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau.   National advertising was the hottest category with a 29.8 gain, to about $220.3 million; classified gained 20.9 percent, to $464.4 million, and retail gained 19.9 percent, to $750.1 million.

headline: THOMAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHINESE PREMIER IN MALAYSIA
abstract: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China arrived in Malaysia today on the second leg of a Southeast Asian tour.  Mr Zhao, who flew here from Manila, is scheduled to leave for Singapore on Tuesday and he will also visit Thailand.

headline: Hong Kong to Restrict Water To 16 Hours a Day Next Week
abstract: The Government announced today that water would be available only 16 hours a day for Hong Kong's five million residents beginning Oct. 8.

headline: Massey Completes Engine Plant Sale
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the Canadian farm equipment maker, said it had completed the sale of its Canton, Ohio, diesel engine plant that has been closed since December 1979.

headline: Patents; Re-usable X-Ray Tube Said to Cut Radiation
abstract: Prof. Robert S. Ledley of the Georgetown University Medical Center here was awarded Patent 4,281,269 this week for a re-usable medical X-ray tube that generates a large number of rays in relatively short time. He said he believed that the device would make images significantly sharper and reduce the radiation dose to the patient.

headline: Belgian Market Aide Is Killed by His Wife
abstract: Fernand Spaak, chief aide to the president of the Common Market and a member of one of Belgium's most influential political families, was shot to death by his wife, who then electrocuted herself in the bathtub of their apartment here, the police said today.   The authorities refused to speculate on the motives for what they described as a murder and a suicide, and they refused to divulge more details.

headline: U.S. Studies Canada Trade
abstract: The Office of the United States Trade Representative said today that it has begun steps that might eventually lead to American trade retaliation against Canadian investment policies.   An official of the agency, which is part of the Executive Office of the President, reported that it has begun a formal investigation to determine whether United States-Canadian trade is affected adversely by Canada's Foreign Investment Review Agency.

headline: BUSH PLEGES U.S. SUPPORT FOR THE PHILIPPINES
abstract: Vice President Bush raised a toast to President Ferdinand E. Marcos today on the inauguration of his new six-year term and pledged full United States commitment and support to this country and its non-Communist neighbors.   In a statement he read to the press after a meeting with President Marcos, the Vice President said it was the intention of the new Administration in Washington ''to improve relations with the Philippines, take into consideration the importance of Asean, and make everybody recognize we have not diminished our interest in this area.'' Mr. Bush was referring to the non-Communist group known as the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean.   Earlier, after a luncheon given in his honor at the Presidential palace, Mr. Bush raised his wine glass to President Marcos and cited the President's adherence to democratic principles and processes.  ''Our country has deep commitments to the Philippines. We will not leave you in isolation,'' Mr. Bush said.

headline: RAMPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Vornado Loss Sharply Wider
abstract: Vornado Inc., o perator of the Two Guys discount department store chain, report ed yesterday that it had a loss of $10.3 million in the second fiscal quarter of 1981, ended Aug. 1, more than nine times theloss of $1.1 million recorded in the similar 1980 quarter.   Sales fell 12.8 percent, to $131.3 million from $150.6 million.  The company, based in Garfield, N.J., recently sold its last seven food markets, which were operated in its discount department stores.

headline: NUCOR STEEL MILL BEGINS SHIPMENTS
abstract: The Nucor Corporation said that its small steel mill here began shipping steel to market this week.  The $90 million plant, which uses scrap as its basic raw material, will produce about 400,000 tons of recycled steel annually when it reaches full capacity in about a year, a company spokesman said.

headline: It's Time for Ricoh To Get Better Known
abstract: Having decided on aggressive marketing of its quartz analog watch in the highly competitive American market, Ricoh, the Japanese manufacturer, must first get its name known among consumers. To do that it has turned for help to Quasimodo to carry the ball.   On television, radio, magazines and point-of-sale posters, the fabled bell ringer who is the Hunchback of Notre Dame will be delivering such messages from his tower suite as ''Not just another pretty face'' or ''Thanks to Ricoh accuracy, I have more time to hang around.''

headline: Patents; A PITCHING TARGET THAT RETURNS THE BALL
abstract: A wine salesman who has devoted his spare time for a dozen years to training young baseball players was granted a patent this week for a pitching target that returns the ball.

headline: The U.N. Today; Sept. 29, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: NEW AIRLINE BATTLE IN TEXAS
abstract: The battle that is about to begin in the skies of Texas probably will not be as bitter as the tough, mean slugging matches that took place between the state's airlines during the 1970's. But it ought to be a lot more fun, based as it partly is on style and sex appeal.   A decade ago, Braniff International and Texas International Airlines, then the big boys on the block, nearly knocked out little Southwest Airlines, their sassy new low-fare, frequent-trip intrastate rival, before the fight was fairly started.   As it celebrates its 10th anniversary this summer, Southwest has not only survived its competitors' lawsuits and price cutting, but has also triumphed. That success has attracted new competition, and Southwest, a leader among the growing group of cut-rate regional carriers, is itself being challenged by a new upstart Texas airline - Muse Air.

headline: INCOME UP BY 1.1% IN AUGUST
abstract: Americans' personal income in August rose more than a full percentage point for the second consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today.   Analysts saw the 1.1 percent income gain - and a 1.4 percent rise in personal consumption spending - as signs that many people are feeling relatively little pain from the high interest rates that have crippled such big industries as housing and auto production.   In fact, Theodore Torda, Commerce Department economist, said, about one-fourth of the month's $26.9 billion increase in personal income was a result of gains in interest income.

headline: Excerpts from encyclical, page D26.
abstract: Pope John Paul II declared today, in the third encyclical of his pontificate, that labor unions were ''an indispensable element'' of modern industrialized society and a vehicle ''for the struggle for social justice.''   He warned, however, that they must ''not be subjected to the decision of political parties or have close links with them.'' Otherwise, he said, they could ''easily lose contact with their specific role, which is to secure the just rights of workers within the framework of the common good of the whole of society.''   The encyclical, or circular letter to Roman Catholic bishops, runs to 30,000 words and is entitled ''Laborem Exercens.'' It has been given the English title ''On Human Work'' by the Vatican.

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 27, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology for Develop- ment - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Memorex Confirms Merger Discussions
abstract: The Memorex Corporation, confirming widespread speculation, said yesterday that it has been holding discussions with several unidentified partners over the past several months aimed at combining part or all of its assets with another company.   The company, a major manufacturer of data storage equipment and audio tapes, declined to identify the parties with whom it has been talking. But a spokesman for the Storage Technology Corporation, responding to an question, said that Storage had recently held talks with Memorex.

headline: Economic Scene; TAX PATTERNS: THE NEW LOOK
abstract: CONGRESS has given the President his smashing tax victory. The frenetic contest in the House of Representatives dramatized the importance of the tax bill, but the Reagan fiscal victory had already been secured no matter whose bill won. For the Democratic bill, had it passed, would have given the President almost everything he wanted.   Mr. Reagan was certainly right in asserting that he had made converts, if grudging ones, of virtually all the Democrats. In the final hours of the debate, the President reminded them that when he first proposed his heavy tax cuts during the campaign and immediately after the election, the Democrats said tax-cutting was out of the question because it would be ''wildly inflationary.''

headline: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: E.E.C. Threat On Canada
abstract: The European Economic Community might take ''countervailing action'' against Canada because it is holding its energy prices far below world levels, community officials said here today.   Wilhelm Haferkamp, the community's commissioner for external relations, told an audience of businessmen and government representatives that, should European companies suffer by competing against Canadian exports ''benefiting from artificially low energy prices, we might be forced to apply safeguard measures.''

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 10, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Seminar on relations that exist be- tween human rights, peace and devel- opment - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARAFAT SAYS SAUDI PLAN COULD LEAD TO LASTING MIDEAST PEACE
abstract: Yasir Arafat said today that a Saudi Arabian proposal calling for Israel to withdraw to its 1967 borders offered ''a good beginning for a lasting peace in the Middle East.''   But Mr. Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said in an interview that he saw little indication that either the United States or Israel had any inclination to consider the plan offered last week by Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia.   ''I am sorry to say I haven't had any official signals from the American Administration,'' Mr. Arafat said.  The Saudi plan calls for, among other things, Israel's withdrawal from the Arab land it has occupied since 1967 and elimination of its settlements there, the right of Palestinians to repatriation or compensation, and the establishment of an independent Palestinian state with Jerusalem as its capital.

headline: U.S. FARM PRODUCTIVITY MAY BE LEVELING OFF
abstract: A WORLD TO FEED Fifth article of a series appearing periodically   EMERSON, Neb. - Melvin Fischer has been living on the same piece of land here in eastern Nebraska for 46 years, and the living has been pretty good.   He and his wife, Margaret, have sent four children to college, with one to go. And they have acquired the usual accoutrements of prosperous American life, including that extra sign of the farmer: a side yard of machinery that looks like a John Deere sales lot.   Viewed from a different perspective, however, Mr. Fischer is not doing so well. He is paying so much more for nearly everything - land, fuel, pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers and seed corn - that he has to wring a lot more production out of the land just to stay even.

headline: Nissan, Toyota Sales Off
abstract: Japan's two largest auto makers said today that exports and domestic sales fell in July from a year earlier, because of the sluggish Japanese economy and restraints on shipments to the United States and other countries.   Exports by the Toyota Motor Company, Japan's leading auto maker, fell 7.7 percent in the month, to 149,343 units.

headline: Blood-Sucking Insects Target of a Repellent
abstract: Repellents effective against blood-sucking insects have been invented for the Department of Agriculture by Terence P. McGovern and Carl E. Schreck, who got patent 4,291,041 this week.

headline: HAIG, REVIEWING POLICY ON SOVIET, SAYS U.S. SEEKS FAIR AGREEMENTS
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., asserting that the Reagan Administration's military buildup would encourage Soviet moderation, said today that the United States sought fair agreements with Moscow that recognized legitimate interests on both sides.   In the Administration's most extensive discussion to date of its relations with the Soviet Union, Mr. Haig went be- Excerpts from Haig speech, page A4. yond the attacks on Soviet behavior that had marked his earlier speeches with an offer for cooperation if Moscow showed ''restraint and reciprocity.''   ''What in turn do we offer the Sovi@ets?'' he said. ''We offer a reduction in the tensions that are so costly to both our societies.  We offer diplomatic alternatives to the pursuit of violent change. We offer fair and balanced agreements on arms control. And we offer the possibility of Western trade and technology.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Medical International, Beverly Hills, Calif., said Dr.  John H. Moxle y 3d, former Assistant Secretary of Defense for Health Services, had joined the company as vice president, st rate gic planning.   * Excalibur Technologies Corporation, Albuquerque, N.M., has elected to its board John W. Turner, founder of Eppler, Guerin & Turner, members of the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Occidental Notes' Rating Is Raised
abstract: The Standard and Poor's Corporation said it had raised the ratings of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's 11 percent notes due 1982 to BBB+ from BBB. It also said the rating of all outstanding preferred stock had been raised to BBB-from BB.

headline: Rebels Report Seizing A Salvadoran Garrison
abstract: A clandestine guerrilla radio station said today that rebel forces had overrun a National Guard garrison in the town of Perquin, 122 miles northeast of San Salvador.

headline: NEW ZEALAND'S PLAN: REPROCESS U.S. BUTTER
abstract: Millions of tons of surplus American butter sold to New Zealand on Wednesday probably will not be used as a table spread because it is not good enough to eat that way, a New Zealand Government official said today.   The sale of the 220 million pounds of Government-owned butter for $155 million, or about 70 cents a pound, was approved on the condition that it not be resold to the Soviet Union.   Tony Cranston, commercial minister at the New Zealand embassy, said the New Zealand Dairy Board bought the butter to forestall its sale on the international market, which could have depressed prices drastically.

headline: ALLIED STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; France to Help Iraqis Rebuild Nuclear Center
abstract: France agreed in principle today to help Iraq rebuild the nuclear reactor complex destroyed by Israeli bombers in June, a French Government source said.   The source, who declined to be identified, said the pledge was given by President Francois Mitterrand to the Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister, Tarik Aziz, at a private Elysee Palace meeting.   The French Government, while approving the request to rebuild the $360 million Osirak reactor bombed June 7, will make sure the new plant cannot be diverted to military use, the source said.

headline: BOARDS MUST RESIST
abstract: I N their article, ''When Shareholders Become the Victims'' (July 12), Frank H. Easterbrook and Daniel R. Fischel argued that ''acquiescence'' should govern the directors and management of a company that becomes the target of a tender offer, effectively prohibiting any resistance to the offer. This would be a drastic change from the current law, called the business judgment rule, which requires the directors of a target company to evaluate the offer in good faith and determine whether it is in the best interest of the company's shareholders. Such a suggestion strikes me as very unwise and very undesirable.   In a April Harvard Law Review article by the two professors, from which their Times article was adapted, the key economic principles they set forth to support their proposed passivity rule are the following:   * Takeovers improve the economy by moving assets to more efficient management.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: HUTTON UP 5 ON MERGER RUMORS
abstract: The E.F. Hutton Group's stock jumped 5 points, to 41 1/2, yesterday, fueling speculation that the Wall Street brokerage firm was the target of a takeover attempt. However, company officials said they could not explain the activity in the stock.

headline: Steel Imports Are Debated
abstract: The American steel industry says it is ''intensely concerned'' with the recent level of imports, but a group representing foreign mills called the complaints far-fetched.   Imports in July were 1.66 million tons, about the same as in June but 54 percent higher than the figure of 1.08 million for July 1980, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported.

headline: BEFORE PLANE BATTLE, LIBYA ASSAILED U.S. OVER ITS MANEUVERS
abstract: The Libyan press agency said Tuesday that American naval maneuvers in the Gulf of Sidra had exposed ''the nature and reality of American aggressive intentions'' against Libya.   The broadcast by the Jamahiriya News Agency was made hours before the reported battle between two Navy jets and two Soviet-built Libyan fighters over the Gulf early yesterday.

headline: Oxford's Net Doubles
abstract: Oxford Industries, an apparel maker, said today that earnings doubled in the first quarter, ended Aug. 28, to $3.7 million, or $1.29 a share, from $1.7 million, or 54 cents, a year earlier.

headline: HYDRAULIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CREDIT MARKETS
abstract: Interest Rates Move Up Again   Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday as traders concluded tha t the recent decline in short-term rates had run out of steam for the moment. At the same time, the Treasury's heavy fourthquarter borrowing needs loomed larger than ever.   In the short-term market, the turnaround in rates was linked to a Federal Reserve move to temporarily drain credit from the banking system by arranging short-term sales of securities. The Fed's move was a sign, analysts said, that the Fed had gone as far as it wanted in supplying additional reserves to the banking system.

headline: Pope Cancels French Visit
abstract: The Vatican has told the French episcopate that Pope John Paul II will not be able to attend the eucharistic congress in Lourdes July 21, a church spokesman said today. The Pope is recovering in a Rome hospital from a virus possibly transmitted through blood he received during surgery for wounds suffered in an assassination attempt May 13.

headline: BEGIN ASSERTS P.L.O. VIOLATES CEASE-FIRE
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin contended today that Palestinian forces had deployed 18 Soviet-made artillery pieces in Lebanon since the cease-fire took effect July 24, but he said that Israel would take no action against the batteries as long as they remained silent.   Interviewed in his Jerusalem office a day after his meeting with President Anwar el-Sadat in Alexandria, Mr. Begin appeared relaxed and calm, discussing a range of issues without any of the passionate arguments that have marked most of his public statements in recent months.   He expressed regret over the killing of civilians in the Israeli bombing of Beirut last month, calling it ''a tragedy.'' But he defended the attack, which was aimed at Palestinian headquarters in the Lebanese capital, as having been decisive in pushing the Palestine Liberation Organization to agree to a cease-fire along the Israeli border.

headline: APPLAUSE FOR THE 'INCENTIVE' STOCK OPTION
abstract: FOR business executives, one of the most far-reaching provisions of the tax legislation just enacted is the creation of a new compensation tool, the ''incentive'' stock option. It is being welcomed as the reincarnation of a familiar friend.   ''It's like the old qualified stock option but even better,'' George R. Ince, a tax manager with the accounting firm of Ernst & Whinney, enthused.   ''It's the Lone Ranger coming to the rescue of executives,'' agreed W. Donald Gough, a partner in Sibson & Company, the Princeton, N.J., employee benefit consulting firm.

headline: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS
abstract: Producer prices rose at a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in July, indicating a continued easing in inflation. The Government said the increase would have been the lowest since last fall save for a surge in prices for pork.   Tax and budget cuts, among the most sweeping economic measures since the New Deal, were signed into law by President Reagan.

headline: LEADING INDICATORS DROP 1.3%
abstract: An important gauge of future economic strength fell sharply in June for the second month in a row, but private and Government economists differed on whether the decline meant that a recession was on the way.   The Government's index of leading indicators, which is designed to forecast coming economic trends, dropped 1.3 percent in June after falling 1.5 percent the month before, the Commerce Department reported today.   Theodore Torda, an analyst at the Commerce Department, said the index's ''recent behavior is consistent with our view that there will be no early end to the business slowdown.'' But, he added, ''It would be premature to say that behavior would signal a recession.''

headline: PRESIDENT ADDS TO CONCESSIONS IN TAX-CUT BILL
abstract: The Reagan Administration, openly offering tax concessions to win votes in the House of Representatives, today introduced still another version of its three-year tax-relief bill that included future automatic ''indexing'' of tax brackets to offset inflation.   With voting in the House scheduled for next Wednesday, President Reagan and Vice President Bush exhorted House Republicans at a rally to stick by their President and party.   Mr. Bush, acknowledging that Republicans might ''have reservations'' about some provisions in the Administration bill, said they should vote for it anyway because ''it is important that the President be perceived as moving the country forward.'' Countered by Rostenkowski   In a counterthrust a few hours later, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the Democratic chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, contended that the Democratic bill would give more tax relief to ''the working poor.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Medical International Inc. said it had completed the acquisition of Brookwood Health Services Inc.   * Brent Petroleum Industries Ltd. agreed to purchase Beta Well Service Ltd. and Custom Drilling Ltd., both of Leduc, Alberta, for a total of $30 million.   * Conductron Corp. signed a letter of intent to acquire Middleburg Corp. for about 200,000 common shares of Conductron.

headline: WARSAW PACT'S SOVIET COMMANDER HOLDS TALKS WITH POLISH PREMIER
abstract: The Soviet commander in chief of Warsaw Pact forces was reported today to have met here with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish Prime Minister, apparently in an effort to stiffen the Polish Government's resolve to deal with spreading protests over food shortages.   Coming at a time when Soviet forces have been conducting amphibious maneuvers in the Baltic Sea, the talks were seen as an attempt to persuade Solidarity, the independent labor union, to reduce the unrest.   The meeting between Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov, the Warsaw Pact commander, and General Jaruzelski, who is also the Defense Minister, was announced by the Polish press agency. It coincided with a stepped-up barrage by both the Soviet and the Polish press against the union.

headline: Dow Chemical Expands in Spain
abstract: The Dow Chemical Company's Spanish subsidiary, Dow Chemical Iberica S.A., has purchased a 350,000-tonsa-year ethylene cracker from state-owned Empresa Nacional del Petroleo S.A., or Enpetrol, a Dow spokesman said.

headline: West Germany Tries Woman Linked to Killing by Terrorists
abstract: @Sieglinde Hofmann, accused of being a member of the outlawed Red Army Faction, went on trial today for the attempted kidnapping of Jurgen Ponto, a banker who was killed by terrorists in 1977.   Miss Hofmann, 36 years old, was charged in Superior Court with membership in a terrorist organization and attempted kidnapping for ransom. She is accused of helping the Red Army Faction, also known as the Baader-Meinhof gang, in the kidnapping attempt in which Mr. Ponto was shot when he apparently resisted.

headline: Soviet Said to Explode Nuclear Device in Siberia
abstract: The Soviet Union detonated its most powerful underground nuclear explosion of the year today, the Swedish Seismological Institute reported.

headline: 9-Digit ZIP Plan Put Off
abstract: The Postal Service today withdrew its request for an incentive plan that has been considered vital for success of its nine-digit ZIP code proposal.   Because of Congressional opposition to the plan to expand ZIP codes from the current five digits, the agency said it was ''temporarily'' deferring the request.

headline: Energy Watch
abstract: Supplies of crude oil declined sharply to 393.5 million barrels from 402.3 million in what experts termed an inventory adjustment.

headline: More Germans Jobless
abstract: Unemployment in West Germany rose to 1.29 million last month, the highest August figure in 29 years, the Government said today. The total, 5.5 percent of the work force, was up 43,000 from July. The nation's weak economy was blamed.

headline: Business People; ABC'S TOP TEAM OF 3 ALL SIGNING ON AGAIN
abstract: The American Broadcasting Companies announced yesterday that its top three executives - Leonard H. Goldenson, chairman and chief executive officer; Elton H. Rule, president, and Frederick S. Pierce, executive vice president - had signed new four-year contracts.   ''What can I say?'' said Fred Anschel, who follows ABC for Dean Witter Reynolds. ''It comes as absolutely no surprise. This team has been running the company for some time, although I wonder if ABC couldn't use some new blood.''

headline: Quebec Party Worries Bank
abstract: Several major Canadian banks, including the Bank of Montreal, may move their head offices from Montreal to Calgary or Toronto, partly as a result of the Parti Quebecois language policy, the chairman of the Bank of Montreal said in an interview published today.   The official, William Mulholland, told the daily La Presse that a bank must be able to rely on easy access to certain services that had become more difficult to obtain in Montreal following an exodus by several businesses after the first election victory by the Parti Quebecois in 1976.

headline: K MART SLIPS 4.1%
abstract: The J.C. Penney Company, the nation's largest retailer after Sears, Roebuck & Company and the K mart Corporation, reported yesterday that earnings in the second fiscal quarter ended Aug. 1 had quadrupled as sales increased 8.2 percent. It cited better price margins and lower interest expense.   Penney said that net income in the latest three months soared to $44 million, or 63 cents a share, from $11 million, or 15 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales rose to $2.63 billion from $2.43 billion.

headline: SCHLITZ BOARD APPROVES HEILEMAN TAKEOVER BID
abstract: The board of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company yesterday approved a definitive $494 million merger agreement with the G. Heileman Brewing Company, rejecting a $588 million offer from the Pabst Brewing Company.   A spokesman representing Pabst said, however, that the company ''wasn't throwing in the towel.'' ''We're expressing disapproval, but we're not pulling out,''the spokesman said. ''We are frustrated and quite disappointed by the action of the Schlitz board. However, he would not comment further on what course of action Pabst would now take, but said the board's decision ''narrows the opportunties Pabst has.''

headline: NIAGARA FRONTIER SERVICES reports earnings for Yr to June 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A U.S. 'HARD-LINER' WILL GO TO ISRAEL
abstract: The State Department confirmed today that a high-ranking official would be traveling to Israel soon for talks with the Begin Government, and there were indications that the talks would center on the question of future use of American weapons in Israeli military operations. The department said that its counselor, Robert C. McFarlane, would be ''visiting Israel for the next several days'' in what a statement called ''the context of ongoing exchanges with the Government of Israel.''   Mr. McFarlane is regarded by American and Israeli diplomats as perhaps the leading exponent in the State Department of a hard line toward Israel's June 7 raid on an Iraqi nuclear reactor near Baghdad. The Israelis used F-16 fighter-bombers for the mission.

headline: Fluor Expects Reduced Net
abstract: The acquisition of the St.  Joe Minerals Corporation by the Fluor Corporation will reduce Fluor's 1981 earnings by an undetermined amount, the chairman, J. Robert Fluor, told a special shareholders meeting.   The merger, which is now effective, was approved earlier by shareholders of both companies.  Mr. Fluor did not disclose the size of the anticipated cost but said Fluor earnings for the year ending Oct. 31 will exceed 1980's $131.9 million, or $2.73 a share. He said St. Joe's 1981 earnings will be essentially the same as last year's $117.1 million, or $2.60 a share.

headline: Esso Italiana Spending
abstract: Esso Italiana will invest about $550 million in the next three years, largely in its refining operations, an Esso spokesman said here today. From 1981 to 1984 the company plans to concentrate its spending on projects that include the development of energy-saving and antipollution systems, with about one-quarter of the total investment to be spent on marketing, the spokesman added.

headline: STSC INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LIKE THE DOW, EARNINGS ARE TUMBLING
abstract: P RICES are n ot the only thing falling in the stock market. Corporateearnings esti mates - the engine that typically pulls equity prices along - have also been heading downhill and prospects seem to favor afurther slide .   ''We are entering a period when earnings predictability, along with the credibility of profit estimates by Wall Street, will go by the board for the next several months,'' Stewart J. Pillette, associate research director for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said.  ''Essentially, that's because the chaos in th e fixed-income market will leave the domestic economy staggering. I don't anticipate any growth at all in the economy through the firs t quarter of 1982.''

headline: THE MAN BEHIND THE SOUL OF A NEW MACHINE
abstract: quarters-high partitions to a 13-by-10-foot cinderblock cubicle that is the workplace of the computer industry's latest living legend.   Mr. West's is not the typical story of a high-tech entrepreneur who made it big in electronics or data processing. He is, instead, an engineering middle manager, one who masterminded the development of a complex new family of Data General computers and did so in phenomenally short time while under extreme competitive pressure.   Similar feats occur frequently in high-tech industries, especially in computers, where product life can at times be measured in months.  But Mr. West's achievement was especially ambitious. It might have gone unnoticed were it not for a new book that has documented the story, ''The Soul of a New Machine,'' by Tracy Kidder.

headline: 2 Airbus Orders
abstract: Airbus I ndustrie, the European aircraft con sortium financed by the Governments of Britain, France and West Germa n, said today that Egypt's international airline, Egyptair, had converted two options for A300-200 series aircraft into firm orders . The company said the planes will be delivered in the spring of 198 3 and will be powered by the General Electric Company's CF6-50C2 en gines. The value of the accord was not disclosed, but the series-200 Airbus typica lly sells for about $30 million when spare parts are included.

headline: Buckingham Palace Arrest
abstract: A 17-year-old British youth carrying an air rifle was arrested outside Buckingham Palace today, the police said. A Scotland Yard spokesman said a search of the young man's clothing had produced the ''offensive weapon.'' The youth was held for questioning, the police said.

headline: FACTORY USE DECLINED TO 79.6% DURING JUNE
abstract: Manufacturers operated at 79.6 percent of capacity in June, a half-point decline from May and the biggest onemonth drop since last July, the Federal Reserve Board said today.   The new report was ''totally consistent'' with a weak economy, said David Cross, senior economist at Chase Econometrics.

headline: PRISONER BEATINGS REPORTED IN SEOUL
abstract: Law enforcement authorities have been beating political prisoners and suspects in an attempt to repress dissent, according to relatives of prisoners and Christian activists here and abroad.   The use of violence against people suspected of Communist leanings takes place in detention centers and is routine, according to the sources.   Government spokesmen, questioned about the beatings, said a ''policy of reconciliation'' went into effect this year. They did not specifically deny that interrogators were using violence.

headline: Fuqua Sells I ts Lano Unit
abstract: Fuqua Industries Inc. said it had sold its Lano Corporation subsidiary for $69 million i n cash and notes and that it would post an after-tax loss of about $15 million on the transaction. Separately, the company announce d that J.B. Fuqua, chairman, had sold his 16.9 percent interest in the Cyprus Corporation for an undisclosed amount.

headline: Flagship Accepts Royal Trustco Bid
abstract: The executive committee of Flagship Banks Inc., Florida's fifth-largest bank holding company, has approved in principle a $290 million (United States) acquisition offer by Royal Trustco Ltd., Canada's largest trust company group, officials of the two concerns said today.   When united with Royal Trustco's wholly owned Royal Trust Bank Corporation of Miami, the merged institution would have combined assets of about $2.9 billion (United States), 110 banking offices and would rank as the fourth-largest bank holding company in Florida.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA GENERAL ASSERTS RAIDS INTO ANGOLA DISRUPT INSURGENTS
abstract: West Africa, July 30 - The commander of South African forces in this disupted territory said today that their assaults into southern Angola this month had shattered the command structure of two of the three regional headquarters of the insurgent South-West Africa People's Organization and forced the insurgents to regroup 30 to 35 miles from the border.   Maj. Gen. Charles Lloyd denied reports from the Angolan capital of Luanda that his troops had occupied seven small towns in the region, but he said that strikes across the border against insurgent bases were ''a continual process.''   ''We are going across and coming back,'' he said. ''We don't occupy towns.''

headline: SOUTH AFRICA BURNS A BLACK CAMPSITE AND BARS U.S. VISITORS
abstract: The South African police raided a black squatter camp at dawn today, a few hours before it was to be visited by an American Congressional delegation, and set on fire its flimsy shelters of plastic sheeting and tree branches.   The five-member delegation was later turned back at a police roadblock when it tried to visit the camp, which was on bare ground between a black township called Nyanga and a shantytown known as Crossroads. Later Representative Shirley Chisholm, Democrat of Brooklyn, broke into tears at an airport news conference, saying she was deeply concerned by ''what had been done to black mothers and children.''   The nameless squatter camp came into existence after a series of police raids last month on Nyanga and Langa townships that resulted in the eviction of more than a thousand blacks, many of them women, who had come to Cape Town in search of work or to live with husbands on migrant labor contracts, even though they lacked official permits to be in the area. Most were from impoverished rural areas of Transkei, a black state that was proclaimed independent five years ago.

headline: COBALT STILL BLUE
abstract: The Reagan Administration's decision to beef up stockpiles of strategic metals quickened the pulses of some cobalt traders earlier this year. They felt that rising demand from the government might pinch supplies, and send prices back toward levels reached in the late 1970's, when cobalt was selling for around $50 a pound.

headline: OIL STOCKS STAR IN DULL MARKET
abstract: Feverish trading in oil shares, particularly those involved in takeovers or those rumored to be targets, dominated an otherwise lackluster and trendless market yesterday. Conoco again led in volume as Seagram moved to outbid Du Pont's offer for the oil company and rose a further 7 points, to 84 3/8, on 1.7 million shares.   Texasgulf, the object of takeover maneuver by a French oil company, was second most active on nearly 1.2 million shares and closed up a half point, at 54 1/2. Next on the active list with trading volume of roughly 500,000 shares each were Cities Service, Mobil Oil, Marathon Oil, Texaco and Union Oil of California, which have been mentioned as being involved in aggressive or passive takeover moves. Except for Marathon, which rose 3 points, these shares closed unchanged or gained a fraction.

headline: FIRST CONTINENTAL REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT T reports earnings for Qtr to Aug
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Live TV Coverage Set For Wedding Today
abstract: Channels 2, 4, 7, 11 and 13 are providing coverage of the wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer.  Live coverage from London begins at 4:30 A.M., New York time, on Channels 4 and 11, and at 5 A.M. on Channels 2 and 7.

headline: Avon Halts Talks With Cooper
abstract: Avon Products Inc. withdrew its proposal for a business combination with Cooper Laboratories, which was announced only last Tuesday, Cooper said.   The merger talks, which began several weeks ago, were ''fairly active, and then they stopped,'' said Joseph A. Dornig Jr., Cooper's vice president and secretary.

headline: TAX BILL DEADLINE MINIMIZED
abstract: House Democrats said today that tax relief could go into effect on Oct. 1, even if Congress missed President Reagan's Aug. 1 deadline for passage of a tax bill.   In a new tactic, aides to Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said that a cut in tax rates could become effective as of Oct. 1 although the reduction in withholding taxes might not begin until later. In that event, the aides said, taxpayers would get refund checks upon filing their tax returns next spring.   Meanwhile, the Administration and Mr. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat, both turned a cold shoulder to a suggestion by Senator Bob Dole, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, that a compromise tax bill could be fashioned. Mr. Dole, a Republican from Kansas, suggested that the Republicans would go along with the Democratic preference for giving extra tax relief to those with incomes below $50,000 a year if the Democrats would agree to a 25 percent, threeyear tax-rate cut instead of just 15 percent over two years.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: Iron Shipments Increase
abstract: Great Lakes iron ore shipment tonnage increased by 36 percent in August over shipments in August 1980, the American Iron Ore Association said today. The association reported August shipments at 10.7 million tons, compared with 7.93 million tons a year ago. Shipments from January through August from 11 United States and Canadian ports totaled 50.2 million tons, compared with 44.7 million tons during the first eight months of 1980, the association said.

headline: G.T.E. Unit Seeks Satellite Channel
abstract: The G.T.E. Satellite Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to lease space on Canada's Anik B satellite to serve customers in the United States, until its own satellites are launched in 1984.   If approved by the commission, the proposal would provide some unexpectedly early competition for companies like Satellite Business Systems, which began operating an advanced satellite system for business customers earlier this year.   G.T.E. Satellite, which now shares with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company a three-satellite system devoted to handling longdistance telephone calls, said in its application that the channel it proposed to lease from Telesat Canada would provide the same type of high-speed data transmission service offered by Sattelite Business Systems. G.T.E. said it would pay about $18,400 a month for the service,

headline: CONWED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Japan-Brazil Pact
abstract: Japan is expected soon to pledge cooperation in a project to develop the Amazon River Basin, which Brazil estimates will cost more than $30 billion, Foreign Ministry officials said today. The International Trade and Industry Minister, Rokusuke Tanaka, and the Foreign Minister, Sunao Sonoda, will visit Brazil soon and convey Japan's readiness to cooperate in the project to develop iron ore, copper, manganese and nickel resources as well as to develop agriculture and forestry, and to build railways and ports, the officials said.

headline: Chief of Yugoslav Region Is Out in Apparent Purge
abstract: The President of Yugoslavia's Autonomous Province of Kosovo stepped down today in an apparent purge linked to riots by ethnic Albanians in the region in March and April.

headline: Bank Merger Talks End
abstract: The American City Bank and the United Overseas Bank of Singapore announced that they had ''mutually agreed'' to break off merger talks.

headline: Colombian Pipeline Set
abstract: Colombia will invest $300 million in the construction of a 156-mile pipeline from its oilfields at Aranca and Casanare to the port of Barrancabemeja, the Mines Minister, Carlos Rodado Noriega, said. He added that oil reserves in the area, close to the Venezuelan border, were estimated at 80 million barrels.

headline: SHOPPING CENTERS, SHOWING AGE, SEEKING NEW LOOK
abstract: T HE Gardiner Manor Mall is a 22-year-old, rather large shopping center in Bay Shore, L.I., 30 miles east of New York City. A driver set out last week to find it and on his first pass along Sunrise Highway, he overshot the turnoff, unmarked because of laws against road signs, by two miles.   Until two years ago, the Gardiner mall fit what had become the usual shape of most centers, a simple open group of stores, including Sears, Gertz and several smaller outlets. It had been losing shoppers to bigger, newer centers nearby. So its owners then renovated it into a more appealing all-weather, air-conditioned, enclosed mall.
