That helped the center's merchants a bit - there are now 41 - but business is hardly bustling. On weekdays, shoppers are scarce. Few well-known national retail chains, considered vital to luring new business to a mal l, have opened there, and it's still hard to find.   ''The access isn't so hot,'' said Ike Pardo, manager of the L.& D.  apparel store. But, he added, since the renovation, ''Business has been pretty good. It's starting to be a good year.''

headline: BRITAIN PLANS TO STUDY BASIC ROOTS OF UNREST
abstract: The British Government announced today that it would make an official study of ways to solve the problems of the inner cities that have led to almost two weeks of rioting.   William Whitelaw, the Home Secretary, said in the House of Commons that Michael Heseltine, the Environment Secretary and temporary Minister for Inner Cities, would go to Liverpool's Toxteth district Monday with other senior officials to lead a new inquiry into ways of solving the problems of that area and other troubled inner cities.   Mr. Whitelaw also said in the packed House of Commons that inquiries would be held on a police raid in the Brixton area of London last night that led to renewed disturbances and into injuries caused by the police use of tear gas in Toxteth.   The actions, announced during a tumultuous debate in the House of Commons, fell far short of widespread demands for new programs aimed at inner city problems, and reflected Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's determination to avoid changing her economic program.

headline: FEDERAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. BACKS SYNTHETIC FUEL PLANTS
abstract: President Reagan, stepping in to resolve a bitter policy dispute within his Administration, gave his approval today for $3.1 billion in Government loan guarantees for two synthetic fuel plants to be built in Colorado and North Dakota.   The decision marked the second time in a week that the President overrode objections from Budget Director David A. Stockman on the issue of synthetic fuel development. Without these loan guarantees it was considered doubtful that the two projects, initiated during the Carter Administration, could be completed.

headline: ROCKWELL NET UP BY 14.4%
abstract: The Rockwell International Corporation, citing increases in its aerospace business earnings and interest income, said today that its profit for the quarter ending June 30 rose 14.4 percent from the same period in 1980 on virtually unchanged sales.   The diversified research and aerospace concern said it earned $84.2 million, or $1.11 a share, on sales of $1.78 billion in the period, compared with earnings of $73.6 million, or 98 cents a share, on sales of $1.78 billion a year earlier.

headline: Disney to Issue Its First Debt
abstract: Walt Disney Productions, the California-based entertainment concern and theme park operator, is raising $100 million with a five-year Eurobond, its first public debt issue anywhere, the lead manager, Morgan Stanley International, said today.

headline: ACF Increases Bid For Ladish Shares
abstract: The contest for control of the Ladish Company intensified yesterday when ACF Industries raised its previous tender offer for all of Ladish's common shares.   ACF, a diversified manufacturer based in New York, said it would offer $3,000 a share in cash, or 64 shares of ACF, for each share of Ladish subject to a maximum on the cash portion of the offer. The total indicated value of the offer is about $324 million.

headline: MANUFACTURER SEES BIG PROFITS IN SMALL ROBOTS
abstract: After working on robot technology for 22 years at the General Electric Company, Ralph Mosher left in 1971 to form Robotics Inc. and began producing heavy industrial robots. He sold about a dozen before running into financing problems and the 1974-75 recession.   At that point, he switched to making a device to seal auto engine gaskets. Sales have been booming and now he plans to pump some of the profits back into robots and carve out his own special niche in the market. Specifically, he is developing a line of inexpensive, benchassembly robots that he hopes to introduce in 1982.

headline: HONEYWELL TO INVEST $9 MILLION IN FRANCE
abstract: Despite the threat of a French Government takeover of one of its major investments, Honeywell Inc., the computer concern, said today that its board of directors had approved a $9 million capital investment in its wholly owned French subsidiary, Honeywell S.A.   Honeywell also said that it had reached agreement in principle with Imetal, a French metals holding company, for Honeywell S.A. to purchase Cometa, a Grenoble-based affiliate of Imetal.   The Compagnie Internationale Pour l'Informatique CII-Honeywell Bull, a French computer company of which Honeywell owns 47 percent, was one of the companies named in the Socialist Government's nationalization plans.

headline: Chronology of Prices
abstract: Following is a chronology of the major pricing decisions taken by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and its individual members over the past three years that have led to the current wide range of OPEC prices. All prices are for 42-gallon barrels.   Dec. 31, 1978: OPEC announces a four-stage price increase to lift the base price from $12.70 to $14.54 by Oct.1, 1979.

headline: WALDHEIM SAYS HE WOULD WELCOME A THIRD TERM
abstract: Kurt Waldheim, the Austrian diplomat who has run the United Nations bureaucracy for 10 years, said today that he would welcome an unprecedented third term as Secretary General.   His announcement was an anticlimax to most diplomats. Mr. Waldheim and his aides have been vigorously if discreetly campaigning for months to keep the Secretary General in his $158,340-a-year post.   Mr. Waldheim, who has carefully avoided giving offense to either the United States or the Soviet Union, is expected by many dipl omats to win another five-year term. But this is fa r from certain because African countries have thrown their support t o Salim Ahmed Salim, Foreign Minister of Tanzania and former presi dent of the General Assembly.

headline: TIME INC. TO TEST NEW CABLE SERVICE
abstract: Time Inc. announced plans to use San Diego as a test ground for a new service that will transmit 4,000 to 5,000 pages of news and information to cable subscribers over a number of channels.

headline: Marathon Well's Flow
abstract: Marathon Oil (U.K.) Ltd., the British unit of Marathon Oil, said that a test well in the Brae area of the North Sea yielded 3,624 barrels of crude oil and 26.1 million cubic feet of natural gas daily from a depth of 12,000 feet. Marathon also said that the well yielded 4,582 barrels a day of crude and 15.1 million cubic feet of gas at about 12,550 feet.

headline: Sinatra Sues On Cassettes
abstract: Frank Sinatra and Liza Minnelli have joined in a multimilliondollar suit against a company that they say is selling video cassettes of their performances without authorization.

headline: KOPPERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Savings Unit Has to Merge
abstract: The Government today took another savings and loan association off its list of troubled financial institutions, forcing it to merge with a stronger partner to form the largest thrift institution in South Dakota.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Motors Corporation, Detroit, has elected Jose J.  Dedeurwaerder to the new post of executive vice president.   * American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Long Lines Department has elected Alexander C. Stark Jr. executive vice president of network operations.

headline: Plessey Profit Up
abstract: Plessey Inc., a London-based technology company, reported yesterday that its net income in the first fi scal quarter, ended July 3, rose 34.1 percent, to $29.9 million, or $1 .24 per American Depositary Receipt, from $22.3 million, or 93 cents an A.D.R., a yearearlier.

headline: Copper Mines Close in Chile
abstract: About 5,000 small copper mining companies have ceased operations in this country as a result of the lowest world copper prices in Chilean mining history, the National Mining Society said today.   Another 200 medium-size mining operations have also closed, Manuel Feliu, president of the National Mining Society, said.

headline: ZAMBIA DEFERS COURT ACTION ON AIDE LINKED TO THE C.I.A.
abstract: A Zambian Foreign Ministry official accused of spying for the United States was ordered today to remain in jail while prosecutors completed paper work for court proceedings, the official Zambia News Agency reported.   Magistrate Noah Kabamba allowed a prosecution adjournment application in the case of Webster Kayi Lumbwe but said that if the papers were not received by July 28 he would deal with the case.   Mr. Lumbwe, a political officer on the ministry's Africa desk, is accused of passing information that might injure state security to the Central Intelligence Agency between January 1979 and last April 30.

headline: Petrie to Acquire Hartfield Stores
abstract: The Petrie Stores Corporation, the nation's second-largest chain of women's apparel specialty shops, and Hartfield-Zodys Inc., a diversified retailer based in Los Angeles, said they had reached an agreement for Petrie to acquire the 68-store Hartfield junior apparel chain for $10 million in cash.   Petrie had 690 stores with total sales of $447 million in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31.

headline: Bolivia Frees a Jailed Priest; 27 Prisoners Facing Release
abstract: Bolivia last night released the Rev. Leonidas Sanchez, the first of 28 political prisoners the junta promised yesterday to free.

headline: PLASTIC BATTERY IS GOAL OF NEW PROJECT AT ALLIED
abstract: The Allied Corporation yesterday announced licensing arrangements and a development program that it hopes will lead to the marketing of the first plastic battery by the end of this decade. The technology involved could represent the most significant advance in batteries since development of the lead-acid battery a century ago, the company said at a news conference in New York.   Allied said that research at the University of Pennsylvania and in the company's own laboratories indicated that a rechargeable plastic battery could be both more powerful and longer-lasting than a comparable lead-acid battery, the type widely used today. Plastic b atteries als o appear to offer weight and size advantages.

headline: Ford Rebates On Trucks Set
abstract: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it has begun offering cash rebates of $500-$700 to buyers of the company's light trucks.

headline: A BEIRUT TRIUMPH: REOPENING OF ROAD
abstract: A bulldozer came under sniper fire today as it moved up to clear a road between the Moslem and Christian sectors of the capital. The road had been closed for at least three months.   A woman on the Moslem side was wounded before a cease-fire was arranged and the bulldozing of the war debris was completed.  A huge mound of red-brown dirt had been heaped across the road several blocks into the Moslem side to keep any unwary motorist from straying into the dangerous area. As if to acknowledge the uncertainty of the situation, the bulldozer cleared the dirt from only one lane.

headline: Net Off 5.2% At Winn-Dixie
abstract: Winn-Dixie Stores Inc. reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1981 ended June 24 dipped 5.2 percent, to $22.1 million, or 86 cents a share, from $23.3 million, or 88 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Japan and South Korea, neighbors that have not been on close terms in recent years, held their first high-level meeting since 1978 last week, but the conference was something less than an outstanding success.   The Koreans asked for $6 billion in economic aid from Japan to finance a new five-year development plan that is due to start in 1982. The Japanese were offered a vastly expanded role in South Korea, if they chose it.   They did not; only small increases in the current aid of $83 million a year are contemplated. Their decision to rebuff the aid request says a good deal about Japan today, not only in its relations with South Korea but in its foreign policy as a whole.

headline: Abu Dhabi Oil Output
abstract: Oil production in Abu Dhabi totaled 109.3 million barrels in the first quarter of this year, down 12.3 percent from the same 1980 period, the official Emirates News Agency said today. The report gave no reason for the lower production.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Ogilvy & Mather has decided to put its West Coast operation - Los Angeles and San Francisco - under the leadership of a single person, Hal Riney, who has been named to the new position of executive vice president-west and also to the overall board.   That leaves an opening for Alan P. Mooney, formerly of New York, to become managing director of the San Francisco office.  In Los Angeles, Gerard P. Smith Jr. has become managing director, replacing Bourne G. Morris, who is going to ''relocate to Nevada'' but remain a consultant to the agency.

headline: INSILCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Article 022844 -- No Title
abstract: Foremost-McKesson Inc. said it had been served with a $6 million lawsuit filed in New York Supreme Court arising from its repurchase of nearly 1.6 million of its common shares last May from the Sharon Steel Corporation.   The suit, filed by Isidore L. Gordon of New York City, contends that the company and its directors wasted corporate assets in repurchasing the shares at a cost of $65.2 million.

headline: Advertising; Tracking Cash Flow At Ogilvy
abstract: FOR Graham Phillips, who has just been named managing director of Ogilvy & Mather in New York, managing the cash position of the agency is one of his most important functions.   And that means keeping close tabs on accounts receivable at a time when, despite optimistic comments from some agency sources, late pay is a major industry problem.   So seriously does Mr. Phillips take the situation that in a few cases of chronic late payment, he has been charging clients interest, certainly a rare occasion in a business where ''the client is always right.''   ''We are agents, not a bank,'' he said strongly during an interview yesterday on the occasion of his promotion.  Ad agencies are, after all, money conduits between their clients and the media, as well as suppliers, photographers, printers and the like.

headline: Penn Central Unit Gets Rig Orders
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation said that its Marathon Manufacturing I nc. unit had been awarded $326 million in contracts to build eight o ffshore oil and gas mobile drilling rigs for the Rowan Companies.

headline: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Pemex to Raise;
abstract: The Mexican state-controlled oil concern, Petroleos Mexicanos, is to raise $500 million in a six-year finance package that combines aspects of both a credit facility and a bond issue, the lead manager, the European Banking Company, said today.   Under the terms of the package, the company, known as Pemex, will issue the $500 million in the form of six-month notes at an interest spread of one-eighth of 1 percent over London inter-bank offered rates.

headline: A.& P. PLANNING TO SHUT DOWN 16 OF 74 FOOD-DISCOUNT STORES
abstract: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said yesterday that it would close 16 of its 74 Plus food-discount stores this month in an effort to reverse the continuing unprofitability of that year-old division.   A.& P., confirming food trade reports that it would close more than 20 percent of its Plus stores, said that 10 units in the metropolitan New York area would be terminated and six in the Philadelphia and Baltimore areas. All have been unprofitable, a company spokesman said.   Loss-ridden A.& P., more than 50 percent owned by the Tengelmann Group of West Germany, sought to offset a reduced sales trend in its regular stores by opening the chain of limited-assortment Plus stores modeled on similar Tengelmann stores in Europe. But, according to A.& P. and industry sources, the absence of such consumer services as coupon redemption, check cashing and advertising, as well as such practices as Sunday closings and too many private-brand products, worked against the concept.

headline: U.S. CLERICS OPTIMISTIC ON CHINA
abstract: The leader of a group of American clergymen who recently returned from a two-week visit to China said yesterday that the delegation felt hopeful about the apparent relaxation of Government restrictions on religious freedom there.   Rabbi Arthur Schneier, senior rabbi of the Park East Synagogue and president of the Appeal of Conscience Foundation, which sponsored the interfaith visit, sounded the note of cautious optimism in a news conference about the trip.   ''What we are witnessing,'' the four clergymen said in a joint statement, ''is not just a loosening up of some of the tight restrictions imposed on any public exercise of religion but an implementation of a decision to facilitate positively the public reemergence of religion in Chinese life.''

headline: CANADIAN FLAVOR IN DENVER'S BOOM
abstract: When Michael J. Brenneman looks out the windows of his office suite on the 23d floor of a downtown Denver skyscraper, the view makes him feel right at home.   Mr. Brenneman, the Canadian-born manager of the Colorado office for Knowlton Realty Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, is not only directly across from the glittering glass office tower of Great West Life Assurance Company of Winnipeg, Manitoba, but the block under construction below his window is being developed by Oxford Development Group Ltd. of Toronto, which plans a 60-story skyscraper for the site.   Indeed, even the building in which Mr. Brenneman has his office was built with money raised by Cadillac Fairview Corporation Ltd., a huge Toronto-based development concern more than a third of which is controlled by Bronfman family interests.   ''Canadian investors love Denver,'' said Mr. Brenneman, whose company has funneled tens of millions of dollars in Canadian funds into the Denver real estate market in the past two years.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA HOLDS 5 SUSPECTS IN DEATH OF NEW YORK LAWYER
abstract: Five men have been arrested as suspects in the murder last month of an American tourist, ending an intensive manhunt, a police spokesman said today.   Catherine Julia Tobin, a 29-year-old New York lawyer and graduate of Rutgers Law School, was found July 29 stabbed to death in a muddy canefield near the resort village of Amanzimtoti. She had been scheduled to fly back to the United States two days later after a scuba diving vacation.

headline: SPLITTING U.S. INDUSTRIES
abstract: When he visits one of the plants owned by U.S. Industries, said Gordon A. Walker, the 53-year-old chairman and chief executive officer, he always walks through the factory. ''Having come up through the manufacturing route, I think it's important to take its tempo,'' he added.

headline: Funding Plan For Britain
abstract: The Confederation of British Industry today urged the Conservative Government to stimulate Britain's economy with an $11 billion package of measures designed to reduce unemployment.   The group said the measures, spread over four years, would reduce the number of hard-core unemployed to 2.25 million by 1985; otherwise, the group said, the figure would increase to more than 3 million.

headline: WELL TESTS GO ON, ESSO UNIT SAYS
abstract: Esso Resources Canada Ltd., a unit of Imperial Oil Ltd., denied published reports that its test well in the Beaufort Sea was flowing at a rate of 8,000 barrels a day.   In denying the report, which caused a flurry of excitement in Canadian markets and oil circles, Esso said that it had been testing the well since May, but that "no definitive calculations of the maximum producing capacity of the zones have been made nor can the size of the discovery be determined without the drilling of further wells."

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Belk Stores Services, Charlotte, N.C., has named Robert N.  Wildrick vice president and general manager of its New York buying office.   * C.I.T. Corporation and the C.I.T. Leasing Corporation, operating units of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation, have elected Chester C.  Goss chairman and Leon G. Pappas president.   * Corroon & Black Corporation has named Frank House Jr. president and chief executive officer of Corroon & Black, Engel-House Insurance Inc.

headline: C.A.B. BACKS TEXAS AIR IN ITS BID FOR CONTINENTAL
abstract: Texas International Airlines won a round today in its fight to take over Continental Air Lines, as the Civil Aeronautics Board instructed its staff to draw up an order approving the proposed acquisition.   The action dealt a blow to Continental's efforts to thwart Texas International by selling newly issued shares to an employees' association, through an Employees Stock Option Plan that would then assume control of the airline, but spokesmen for Continental and the employees association said that the effort was not dead.   ''We'll never quit,'' said Chuck Cheeld, a Continental pilot and adviser to the employees' association . ''We'll fight this thing to the very end,''

headline: FROM OPERA TO BOLSHOI: ARTHUR A HARTMAN
abstract: Each week, Le Nouvel Observateur chooses a luminary of the Parisian intellectual or artistic world to set out his or her choices among the cultural events of the succeeding week.  One week last   May it chose Arthur A.  Hartman.  That the newspaper, a pillar of the French left, should pick the American Ambassador to tell Parisian intellectuals what to go see or hear was nothing short of remarkable. Not since Benjamin Franklin has an American envoy to France been given such public recognition for his culture.

headline: India Seeks Record Loan
abstract: India is seeking a record $4 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund to help pay its soaring oil bills, I.M.F. officials said today.

headline: CHARLES RIVER BREEDING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DANKER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Reagan May Nominate Adviser as Paris Envoy
abstract: President Reagan was reported today to be considering Evan G. Galbraith, a 53-year-old investment banker, for the post of Ambassador to France. The White House indicated that an announcement might come tomorrow in Santa Barbara, Calif., where the President is vacationing.

headline: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CONTROLLED FRENZY IN THE PIT
abstract: Randy Warsager, a trader at the New York Mercantile Exchange, makes many of his business deals in less than 30 seconds. If they take longer than that, Mr. Warsager gets nervous, particularly since he receives no salary and has no clients or partners.   ''You don't sit and wait,'' said Mr. Warsager, speaking of the heating oil contracts he buys and sells at a furious pace in the Mercantile Exchange's heating oil pit. ''Everybody here understands obliteration.''

headline: Union Refuses to Halt Strike in Sierra Leone
abstract: Leaders of Sierra Leone's first general strike met with the Government today and vowed to continue the walkout despite a promise by authorities to stabilize rice prices.   The strike, which began yesterday, has brought Freetown and other major towns of this small diamond-producing West African nation to a virtual standstill.

headline: ADVANCE THIRD IN ROW
abstract: A decline in short-term interest rates and a brisk rally in bond prices kept the stock market's three-day recovery alive yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 10.37 points, to 872.81.   High interest rates have rocked stock prices since mid-June, analysts noted, so that any sign of easing rates brings subdued cheers on Wall Street.   ''It's still too early to tell whether we're seeing more than a technical rally in the wake of the prolonged market slump,'' said William M. LeFevre, investment strategist at Purcell, Graham & Company.   Technical rally or not, for the second consecutive day the New York Stock Exchange produced more than 1,100 advances and fewer than 400 declines.

headline: EX-NEW YORKER GETS LIFE FOR CRIMES IN NAZI CAMP
abstract: West Germany's last major Nazi war crimes trial, which spanned five and a half years, ended today with the conviction of eight former guards of the Maidanek camp, including a former resident of Maspeth, Queens.   Seven of the nine defendants were found guilty of complicity to murder at the camp near Lublin, Poland, where 250,000 inmates died.  Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan, who was convicted of murder, received a life sentence. Mrs. Ryan, 61 years old, is married to an American and lived in Maspeth until she was stripped of her American citizenship in 1971 and deported in 1973.   Her husband, Russell Ryan, who attended most of the trial proceedings, said today: ''American Jews demand these trials, and this is what happens.''

headline: BETHLEHEM STEEL SOARS BY 80%
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the country's second-largest steel maker after the United States Steel Corporation, reported yesterday that higher steel product shipments helped net income in the second quarter of 1981 to soar 80 percent, as sales expanded 18.8 percent.   The Bethlehem, Pa., concern said that net income in the latest three months jumped to $77.6 million, or $1.78 a share, from $43.1 million, or 98 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

headline: Soviet Wheat Imports
abstract: Official trade figures released today showed that the Soviet Union almost doubled the value of its wheat imports last year, to the equivalent of $2.35 billion from $1.26 billion the year before.  importing $1.96 billion worth of oil, up from $1.2 billion.

headline: Indian Minister Blames U.S.  In the Worsening of Relations
abstract: Foreign Minister Narasimha Rao told Parliament today that relations with the United States had descended into a ''temporary phase of bitterness'' over India's refusal to accept an American diplomat and Washington's retaliation.

headline: NEW ROLE IN INVESTING FOR QUEBEC
abstract: When the shareholders of Domtar Inc., Canada's second-largest forest products company, picked up their morning newspapers last Wednesday, they discovered that the Province of Quebec owned nearly half of the company's common shares.   Representatives of the two provincial agencies that together now hold a 42 percent block of Domtar stock - the Caisse de Depot et Placement and the Societe Generale de Financement -also announced that they had told Domtar's management the day before that they expected proportionate representation on its board and executive committee.   The event brought into focus a trend that has worried some investors ever since the province announced last year that Caisse de Depot, which manages $13 billion (Canadian) worth of assets for the province's pension and insurance plans, would take a more active role in Quebec's economic development. New Role for the Caisse   To some observers, the move last week comfirmed suspicions that Caisse de Depot had become a potent new tool for the Quebec government in its attempt to influence the behavior of big business in the province.

headline: RISE BELOW RIVALS
abstract: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would increase the price of its 1982 models an average of 4.8 percent, or $430 a car, which is less than its domestic competitors.   The General Motors Corporation last month said it would increase its prices 5.8 percent, or $617 a car, and the Chrysler Corporation has notified its dealers that its increase might be as much as 7.7 percent.   The average price for a 1982 Ford automobile, according to the company, will be $9,600.

headline: KUWAIT OIL SALE DIP CITED
abstract: Kuwait's crude oil exports have dropped to their lowest level in a decade, the daily Al Watan reported today.  Quoting ''reliable'' sources, the newspaper said the country's oil exports fell over the past three months to an average of 900,000 barrels daily.

headline: SENATOR BAKER ENDORSES PROPOSED SAUDI DEAL
abstract: President Reagan today won the support of Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate Republican leader, for his proposal to sell radar planes to Saudi Arabia, but other members of Congress were critical.   Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, the ranking Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee, said he would co-sponsor a resolution of disapproval for the sale of the five planes, known as Awacs, when Congress returns from its summer recess on Sept. 9.   ''Inevitably, I fear, providing this equipment to Saudi Arabia will impel Israel to ask for more equipment from us and thus the already dangerous arms race in the Middle East will escalate,'' Senator Pell said. The Awacs are part of an $8.5 billion arms package that the Administraton announced yesterday.

headline: Detroit Edison Issue
abstract: The Detroit Edison Company won state Public Service Commission approval today for a $1.9 billion debt issue, the utility's largest ever.

headline: Advertising; Selling Via the Movies
abstract: AMONG the performers in ''Honky Tonk Freeway,'' which opens at movie theaters tomorrow, will be Cheerios, Budweiser and Quaker State Motor Oil. Those are some of the placements made by Associated Film Promotions, a Los Angeles-based company that says it is the leader in the business of getting clients' products on the big screen.   Founded four years ago by Robert Kovoloff, 44 years old, who remains the sole owner, A.F.P. promises clients, such as Anheuser-Busch, General Mills and Beatrice Foods, ''positive visibility'' or, as they used to say, a chance to get into the movies. The basic idea is to put that bottle of Michelob into the hands of, say, Clint Eastwood (as in ''Any Which Way You Can''), or to get that Gatorade cooler within reasonable proximity of Alan Alda and Carol Burnett (as in ''Four Seasons'').

headline: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Saudis Said To Cut Flow
abstract: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest exporter of crude oil, has carried out its promise to reduce production by about 1 million barrels a day, industry sources said here today.   People connected with the Arabian American Oil Company, the consortium of oil companies operating in Saudi Arabia, said the Ministry of Petroleum and Minerals had issued instructions to cut back on oil pumping, starting today.

headline: Emery Jet Fleet
abstract: Emery Air Freight, an air-freight forwarder concern, said it would buy 12 Boeing 727's for its domestic fleet from Northwest Airlines.

headline: Monsanto Faces 2d Suit
abstract: A $1.35 billion suit has been filed against the Monsanto Company on behalf of 43 former employees and survivors of former employees, contending that workers at a chemical plant were knowingly exposed to toxic substances that cause long-term health problems.   The suit was filed in Federal District Court here.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: New York Times March 1 1981 143 Lines P:810301; HOW SAUDI ARABIA MIXES WELFARE AND FREE ENTERPRISE; RIYADH, Saudi Arabia
abstract: SAUDI ARABIA's economy is an odd hybrid, a melange of social welfare programs grafted onto a system dominated by free enterprise.  On one level, Saudi Arabia takes care of its own, But on another, the policy, which also includes severe economic discrimination against foreigners, leaves some Saudis fabulously wealthy, others moderately well-to-do and unskilled guest workers almost universally poor.   In the sandy outskirts of this capital city, for example, high-walled compounds containing luxurious, often marble-clad villas, have sprung up. Downtown, Saudi families remain crammed into 20-year-old apartments above the city's shops. Tents and sheds dot the city's vast undeveloped blocks.

headline: Advertising; EPSTEIN RABOY NAMES PRESIDENT
abstract: Mitchell J. Epstein and Richard H. Raboy, founders of Epstein Raboy Advertising and both copywriters, have filled their president's office, vacant since Joseph P. Foran left with his 11 kids to run an inn in Maine a year and a half ago.   The new man is Myron B. Poloner, who is 38 years old.

headline: GRAINGER, W W, INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MOBUTU ENDURES AS SYMBOL AND PERVASIVE FORCE
abstract: The newspapers usually carry a frontpage picture of him and an item about what the Guide is doing.  His portrait hangs in every office, invariably depicting him wearing a leopardskin cap and holding a carved swagger stick - two articles that have become the symbols of his power.   Sometimes his aides wear enameled badges bearing his portrait in the lapels of suits modeled on the presidential mode of dress. His voice comes over the radio, reciting slogans like an incantation.

headline: Shell Plans to Sell Its Canadian Unit
abstract: The Shell Oil Company said today it planned to sell its Canadian unit to Husky Oil of Calgary, Alberta, for $360 million, in American funds.   It said that, through the transaction, Husky would acquire all of Shell Explorer of Calgary's holdings in offshore oil and gas leases and permits in Canada, as well as interests in oil sands in Alberta.

headline: TREASURY FINANCING KEEPS DEPUTY BUSY
abstract: There was a heavy calendar of Federal financings last week and no one was busier seeing them through than Mark E. Stalnecker, the 30-year-old Deputy Assistant Secretary-designate of the Treasury, specializing in Federal finance. The regular three- and six-month bill auctions were held on Monday, three- ,10- and 30-year refundings were completed on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday and one-year bills were sold on Friday.

headline: Reader Comment; A JOB FOR CONGRESS
abstract: I AM disappointed that Paul MacAvoy, who has had the opportunity to observe government first-hand, did not give closer attention to the institutional roles and responsibilities involved than he reflects in his article on the Supreme Court decision in the cotton dust case, ''The Indecisive Cotton Dust Decision'' (July 5).   I view the Court's decision as fundamental and far-reaching in its implications. The Court concluded that the responsibility to define the limits of a regulatory agency's mandate and the standards it is to apply in discharging it rests with the instrumentality which created it, namely the Congress of the United States.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Pad and Paper Company, Holyoke, Mass., announced that Francis J. Guiliano, chairman and chief executive officer, was assuming the additional title of president. Henry A. Fifield, formerly president, becomes vice chairman; Robert B. Antrasian, executive vice president-corporate, and Frank M. McHugh, executive vice president and general manager of the Ampad group.   * Baxter Travenol Laboratories, Deerfield, Ill., has elected Wayne G. Custead vice president of research and development.

headline: VENDO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GERMANS COVET GENE TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Alert to American advances in genetic engineering, West Germany's chemical giants are scrambling for access to United States expertise in an effort some industry analysts say could parallel Europe's drive in the 1970's for American computer technology.   They are pouring money into American basic research, and, industry executives say, they are watching the new little companies that have sprung up in genetic research with an eye toward possible acquisitions.   In May, Hoechst, West Germany's and the world's second-biggest chemical group, after BASF, also of West Germany, said it was giving the Massachusetts General Hospital, which is affiliated with the Harvard Medical School, a 10-year, $50 million grant for research in molecular biology in exchange for a claim to patents and licenses for applications.   Last October, Bayer, No.3 worldwide, gave the Massachusetts Institute of Technology a five-year, $300,000 gift for a professorship in biotechnology. Unlike Hoechst, Bayer said it had no formal agreement for the transfer of results, but the endowment is expected to give Bayer some benefit from M.I.T.'s research.

headline: LABORITES TO SETTLE BITTER FIGHT TODAY
abstract: A bitter and divisive struggle for the deputy leadership of the Labor Party, which could result in a takeover by the extreme l eft, will be decided tomorrow on the first day of the party's annua l conference at the seaside resort of Brighton.   The principal contenders are Denis Healey, the present deputy leader and a moderate former Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Tony Benn, a former peer and former Cabinet member who has emerged as the leader of party elements that favor unilateral nuclear disarmament, the restriction or closure of American bases in Britain, the abolition of the House of Lords and a sweeping program of further nationalization.   A third candidate, John Silkin, appears to have failed in his bid to present himself as a unifier between two extreme points of view.  The contest has been going on for months and has so preoccupied the party that it has failed to capitalize on the unpopularity of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Government. Michael Foot, the Labor leader, has said the contentiousness that the contest symbolizes threatens to destroy the party, which has won five of the 11 elections held in Britain since World War II.

headline: SHOOT-OUT ON SEVENTH AVENUE
abstract: T HE man who makes Jordache leather vests was there. So was the man who makes Jordache boys' swimwear. The man for Jordache hosiery. The man for Jordache fake furs. The man for Jordache sunglasses. The man for Jordache children's coats.   The occasion was a recent party to introduce Jordache's 30-plus licensees to Stanley Schwarz, the man hired to take charge of the jeans company's lucrative and fast-growing licensing operation.   The licensees paid their respects to the label - in their own fashion: ''We had a great steak, but we needed some sizzle,'' said Sam Shaskan, president of Casual Time, a children's wear manufacturer. ''Jordache gave us the sizzle.''

headline: U.S. AID FOR THRIFT UNITS POSES QUESTIONS OF NEED
abstract: Savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks, which have provided most of the money for the $700 billion of home mortgages outstanding in the nation, are reporting record outflows of deposits and mounting losses from operations.   The net deposit withdrawals from the 4,700 savings and loan associations totaled $5.3 billion in the first four months of this year. Savers drew down their deposits by $4.2 billion from the 460 mutual savings banks over the same period. Meanwhile, the combined operating losses of the savings and loan associations and savings banks, which together make up what is known as the thrift industry, already exceed $1 billion so far this year.   When a major company or an important industry runs into such difficulty, it often seeks aid from the Federal Government. The Reagan Administration, after a bitter internal debate, recently agreed to help the loss-ridden domestic automobile industry with protection against Japanese imports. The Carter Administration agreed to help the Chrysler Corporation with emergency loan guarantees not unlike the ones adopted under President Nixon to aid the Lockheed Corporation. Now the thrift institutions, which are to home ownership what Henry Ford was to an afforable, mass-produced car, are asking for special Government aid as well.

headline: Marketing Official Gets Post With Tonka Toy
abstract: Anticipating an expansion of its sales of toys and other children's products, the Tonka Corporation has hired J. William Petty, 49, a veteran consumer products marketing executive, as president of its toy division, effective tomorrow. The position, with responsibility for the portion of the company encompassing more than 90 percent of overall volume last year, has not been filled since 1978.

headline: U.S. and India Discuss Rift Over Nuclear Fuel
abstract: A high-level United States delegation met today with Indian officials to discuss the deadlocked issue of nuclear cooperation. Neither side seemed hopeful of a breakthrough.

headline: Oneida's 'Product Mix' Praised by New Chief
abstract: At Oneida Ltd., the big manufacturer of stainless steel tableware and other items, a member of the Noyes family has long run the company. Now Pierrepont T. Noyes, the 67-year-old grandson of John Humphrey Noyes, who founded the Oneida Community, the predecessor of the corporation, as a religious commune in 1848, is retiring on Oct.  1 as chairman and chief executive officer, to be succeeded by John L. Marcellus Jr., 58.

headline: Krugerrand Sales Down
abstract: International sales of the Krugerrand gold coin fell to 407,680 ounces in August from 1981's monthly peak of 447,080 sold in July, but were sharply above the 273,500 ounces sold in August 1980, the International Gold Corporation said today. The company, the gold marketing arm of the South African Government, said in a statement that sales for the year to date total 2.3 million ounces, against 1.7 million in the same 1980 period.

headline: Zia Leaves for Saudi Visit
abstract: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan left today for a three-day private visit to Saudi Arabia that could include talks with King Khalid on sales of United States arms to the two countries.

headline: Advertising; John Blair Expanding Cents-Off Coupon Area
abstract: John Blair Marketing, which knows its way around a cents-off coupon, is next going to be offering the package-goods crowd a way of reaching 18 million households whose inhabitants have an average of 4.1 members and an average annual income of $26,500.   The program, called Prime Families Direct, will be a mailed 8-by-11-inch insert; a full-page outside will cost $17 a thousand and an inside page $15 a thousand. Blair plucked its names out of 150 to 250 lists that were selected from the 21,000 available in the marketplace.

headline: Southland Up 8 1/4 On News of Merger
abstract: The Southland Royalty Company, which disclosed on Monday that it was a willing target in what could become an estimated $2 billion takeover, surged 8 1/4 points in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to close at $34 a share. The Fort Worth-based oil and gas company said it was holding exploratory merger talks with a limited number of companies.   Southland did not identify any of the companies, but Wall Street sources said ''the whole club'' would be interested, including Mobil, Gulf, Texaco, Standard Oil of California, Arco, Phillips and Getty.  The First Boston Corporation, acting on behalf of Southland, was understood to be sending data to these and other companies.

headline: ADDING POWER AT A. &P.
abstract: James W. Wood, the veteran supermarket executive who was named chairman and chief executive officer of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company last year, has added the office of president to his string of titles and consolidated his power at the loss-ridden chain.   Mr. Wood, a 51-year-old Briton who was formerly chief executive of Grand Union, the ninth-largest supermarket chain in the United States, said that he would work directly with A.&P.'s operations and merchandising chiefs in the future. ''When I came here, A.& P. was comprised of separate divisions,'' he said. ''My style is to integrate to a much greater degree.''

headline: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Weinberger Leaves London
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, who ended a three-day visit to London today and departed for Washington, said the question of deploying neutron weapons in Europe had not been discussed in his talks with British officials. Mr.Weinberger said, however, that if the United States decided to deploy the neutron weapon it would seek permission from its allies.

headline: ALPINE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: G.& W. Increases Two Stock Stakes
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that it had increased its holdings of stock in both the Brunswick Corporation and the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company for investment purposes.   The disclosures, in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, followed similar earlier announcements that the diversified New York-based company had increased its stake in the stock of J.P. Stevens & Company, the General Tire and Rubber Company, Munsingwear Inc. and Cluett, Peabody & Company.

headline: Tin Price Rollback At National Steel
abstract: The National Steel Corporation said it was withdrawing an earlier announced 6 percent increase in the base price of tin mill products, virtually completing the industry's rollback of a price increase announced only two weeks ago. The United States Steel Corporation, the country's largest steel producer, made a similar move on Tuesday.

headline: Business Digest
abstract: Friday, July 24, 1981 Companies   Joseph E. Seagram & Sons increased its bid for Conoco yesterday to $92 a share, or $4.1 billion, for a 51 percent interest in the nation's ninth-largest oil company. Seagram, Du Pont and Mobil, competing bidders for Conoco, have all set deadlines to accept stock in response to their offers. With Seagram's deadline coming first on midnight last Wednesday, Wall Street professionals flooded Seagram with an estimated 25 million shares. (D1.)   The Washington Star, a 128-year-old daily, will cease publication on Aug.7, Time Inc. said. Time, the Star's owner for the past three and a half years, said the paper was losing about $20 million a year and that its 25 percent share of the Washington-area advertising market was not improving. (A1.)

headline: CHRYSLER OVERTIME
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said it would have only one of its four operating assembly plants working overtime next week after more than two consecutive months of extensive overtime production. The company said its Belvidere, Ill., plant, which builds the subcompact Omni-Horizon models, will operate two nine-hour daily shifts in its 19th consecutive week of overtime. Chrysler, whose sales for the year are up 23 percent over the disastrous levels of 1980, gave no reason for the cutback in overtime.

headline: Company Seeking More Phibro Seats
abstract: The Minerals and Resources Corporation, a Bermuda-based holding company, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it wanted to increase its representation on the Phibro Corporation's board.   Minerals and Resources, the principal shareholders of which are the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa, Charter Consolidated Ltd. and De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., owns about 18.5 million shares, or about 30 percent, of Phibro.

headline: U.S., JAPAN, EUROPE SET SPECIAL FORUM ON TRADE TENSIONS
abstract: The United States, the European Common Market and Japan have worked out a special early-warning arrangement to tackle trade and investment issues before they erupt into major international disputes, a high-ranking Administration official said today.   Leaders of the three parties agreed that their trade representatives would meet as trouble-shooters - for the first time - and try to defuse problems. Although temporary accords now govern trade in autos and steel, those issues could flare up again. And trade officials cited trade in synthetic fibers, data processing equipment and insurance services as areas of potential trouble that the three-way talks might deal with.

headline: U.S. VETOES REBUKE TO SOUTH AFRICANS
abstract: The United States, in a break with its allies, tonight vetoed a Security Council resolution strongly criticizing South Africa for its raid into Angola.   France voted with 12 other Council members to rebuke the South Africans while Britain abstained.  The 13-to-1 result with the single abstention was said by diplomats here to Text of vetoed resolution, page A4. have underscored the growing split between the United States and its four Western partners on issues in southern Africa.

headline: REMARKS BY SOVIET DELEGATE ARE RECEIVED WITH RELIEVED APPLAUSE
abstract: The head of the Soviet delegation to the Polish party congress said today that Moscow was confident that the Polish Communists would overcome their economic and political crisis through their own efforts. But he maintained that the Soviet Union could not be indifferent to the plight of its ''friends and allies.''   Viktor V. Grishin, a middle-ranking member of the ruling Politburo, said the delegates were all familiar with the letter in which the Soviet leaders had stated their anxiety over the course of events in Poland.

headline: Around the World; POPE STAYING IN HOSPITAL UNTIL SECOND OPERATION
abstract: Pope John Paul II will stay in the hospital until after his recovery from a second operation on his intestines that will probably take place next month, the Pope's doctors said today, dispelling rumors that he may be about to return to the Vatican.   Dr. Emilio Tresalti, medical director of the Gemelli Hospital, said the second operation could be be carried out only after the patient had fully recovered from his virus infection of the last few weeks.

headline: Indian Oil Contract
abstract: The Indian Government signed a fouryear consultancy contract with a French oil company today to increase oil production from the country's west coast offshore fields. Compagnie Fran,caise des Petroles will provide technology and industrial experience to raise oil output from the fields to 380,000 barrels a day by 1984-85 from about 160,000 barrels now, an Indian official said. He said the company's payment would likely be less than $50 million.

headline: Credit Markets; 10-YEAR U.S. NOTES SET MARK
abstract: The Treasury sold new 14 7/8 percent 10-year notes yesterday at an average yield of 14.98 percent - a record for that maturity and one that seemed to attract more buying interest as the day wore on.   This week's Treasury financing has highlighted the ambivalence that pervades the credit markets, where record yields continue to attract some investors and speculators but have not yet attracted enough buyers to sustain a move to lower yields and higher prices.   One result has often been wide price swings, as speculative positioning by securities firms easily outweighs the modest noteand bond-buying programs of portfolio managers. Another Record Forecast   In the case of the new 10-year notes, securities dealers pushed prices lower early in the day but then reversed direction during the afternoon when prices rose, and the yield on the new issue fell to about 14.86 percent. Last May, the Treasury sold 10-year 14 1/2 percent notes at an average rate of 14.56 percent.

headline: Nobel Laureate Given Pension by Argentina
abstract: After a delay of nearly five months, the military Government has granted Adolfo Perez Esquivel, last year's Nobel Peace Prize winner, the lifetime pension to which he is entitled by law, his son said yesterday.   Leonardo Perez Esquivel, national coordinator of his father's Service for Peace and Justice, said that his father was informed yesterday by the Social Action Ministry that the pension had been approved retroactive to May, when he applied for it, not to last October, when he won the prize.

headline: AVON AND COOPER HOLD MERGER TALKS
abstract: As part of a continuing diversification drive intended to spur earnings growth, Avon Products, the cosmetics company, disclosed yesterday that it was involved in talks with Cooper Laboratories, a leading producer of medical and dental products, about a possible business combination.   Avon's announcement followed an earlier release from Cooper, which acknowledged it was holding merger discussions but did not identify the other company.   Cooper's disclosure was prompted by rumors that developed Monday and pushed up the price of its stock 2 1/4 points. After Avon's announcement yesterday, the price of Cooper shares rose 5 5/8 more, closing at 33 5/8.

headline: IN THE ONCE-MIGHTY ROYAL NAVY, A SENSE OF DESPAIR
abstract: The Royal Navy, starting next year, will send a squadron built around an aircraft carrier to the Indian and South Atlantic Oceans as a potential reinforcement for American forces in those areas.   At the same time, however, Britain will reduce the number of destroyers and frigates assigned to NATO from 59 to what the British Defense Secretary, John Nott, said would be ''about 50.''   The burden of compensating NATO for the nine British surface ships is expected to fall chiefly on the United States at a singularly inopportune moment. For although the Reagan Administration's military budget envisions an expansion of the surface fleet, the ships are unlikely to be available for three more years at the soonest.

headline: PENNWALT'S TROUBLES IN NICARAGUA
abstract: Nicaragua's Sandinist revolution is two years old, but for Robert P. Ogden, vice president of chemicals for the Pennwalt Corporation, the smoke is only now beginning to clear.   Mr. Ogden is one of two Pennwalt representatives on the board of Electroquimica Pennwalt, known as El Pesa, a chlorine and caustic soda plant in Managua that is 40-percent owned by the Philadelphiabased concern.   Since the overthrow of Anastasio Somoza Debayle, the former President, El Pesa has been controlled by the Government of the Sandinist Liberation Front.   For a company thrust into the awkward position of minority business partner with a revolutionary Government, the going has not been easy. For instance, despite Pennwalt's technical expertise and the Government's commitment to maintain a mixed economy for its nation, the Government has until recently kept Pennwalt managers and technicians away from the plant.

headline: BOLT BERANEK & NEWMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RELIANCE ABANDONS MOTOR PLAN
abstract: The books were closed yesterday on an unusually controversial technology failure when the Reliance Electric Company announced that it was abandoning efforts to develop energy-saving motor controls based on a device invented in 1979 by its parent, the Exxon Corporation.   In March, Exxon announced that its original design had proven uneconomical and that Reliance was working on an alternative approach. ''The results since then have not been encouraging,'' Reliance said yesterday in its brief announcement of a decision reached last week to terminate the program.

headline: Business People; HIRSCHFILED NAMED CHAIRMAN OF FOX
abstract: Following a nearly two-year power struggle at the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, Alan J. Hirschfield, 45 years old, has been named chairman and chief executive officer by Marvin Davis, the Denver oil man who purchased the company last spring and took it private.   Mr. Hirschfield, who had been vice chairman and chief operating officer, replaces Dennis C. Stanfill, who resigned June 30 after Mr.  Davis refused to let him dismiss a studio executive and protege of Mr. Hirschfield over the issue of $1,000 of disputed expenses.

headline: ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY SALES AND PROFITS AT 282 COMPANIES
abstract: Revenues

headline: MID- AUGUST AUTO SALES UP BY 20.3%
abstract: Sales of new cars by the nation's Big Three auto makers, spurred by industrywide rebate and incentive programs, increased 20.3 percent in mid-August over the comparable 1980 period, the manufacturers reported today.   ''It was specifically a reflection of the number and generosity of the campaigns,'' said Maryann Keller, an auto industry analyst with Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins & Company. She predicted that sales would drop in September when the incentive plans end.   The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation reported sales of 194,836 units for the Aug.  11-20 sales period, compared with 161,889 units sold in mid-August of 1980, when sales were at their lowest level in 13 years.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Alba-Waldensian Inc. said it has been advised that 5.6 percent of its shares have been purchased by Shamrock Associates of Far Hills, N.J.   * American Ship Building Co. said it received a $73 million contract from Moore McCormack Lines, a subsidiary of Moore McCormack Resources, to lengthen and increase the cargo capacity of four C-4 cargo liner vessels.   * Bendix Corp.'s Texas Pipe Building Co. subsidiary was awarded a $40 million pipe fabrication order by Lummus Co. for the American Natural Gas Co. coal gasifacation project.   * Dorchester Gas Corp. signed a letter of intent to sell fourmillion tons of coal a year to Japan.

headline: Yet Another Magazine For the Wealthy
abstract: There is no longer such a group as the idle rich.

headline: MOBIL SAYS ITS BID MEETS U.S. CRITERIA
abstract: The Mobil Corporation, anticipating a major antitrust investigation of its $7.7 billion offer to buy Conoco Inc., yesterday vigorously defended its bold takeover move for the nation's ninth-largest oil company as one that ''meets existing merger guidelines of the Department of Justice.''   But Ralph E. Bailey, chairman of Conoco, said that the Mobil bid ''raises substantial antitrust and other public policy issues of national importance, which will require intensive examination and which make the acquisition of Conoco by Mobil subject to serious question.'' He said, however, that he would not respond to the Mobil offer until Conoco directors reviewed it early next week.   Moreover, less than a week ago, without naming any of the companies interested in Conoco, William Baxter, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, signaled that all big bidders would face a tough fight.

headline: BERKSHIRE GAS CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Beneficial to Sell Spiegel
abstract: The Beneficial Corporation, the nation's largest consumer loan company, announced yesterday that it had reached agreement to sell its Spiegel Inc. catalogue subsidiary to a West German merchandising concern for more than $50 million.   Beneficial said it expected the sale of Spiegel to the Otto Versand catalogue company of Hamburg, West Germany, to create a book loss of approximately $40 million in 1981, after tax adjustments.   Otto Versand is one of the largest catalogue merchandisers in the world, with sales in West Germany, France and the Netherlands totaling nearly $2 billion in 1980.

headline: 2.5% STAKE IN HUTTON PURCHASED
abstract: The E.F. Hutton Group said yesterday that during April and May the Transamerica Corporation, which owns one of the nation's largest insurance companies, bought 2.5 percent, or 400,000, of its outstanding shares.   Asked whether Transamerica intended to increase its position in the brokerage firm, William McClave, director of corporate relations, said: ''I'd just rather say that we have made the purchases as an investment and limit it to that.''   Thomas P. Lynch, vice president of E.F. Hutton, said that his contact with Transamerica indicated the company was only interested in an investment. He added that whether or not E.F. Hutton finally merged with another company would depend ''on what the offer was.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Anglo Energy Ltd. said that it had completed its acquisition of S & G Construction North Slope Enterprises Inc., Anchorage, for a total of $11 million in cash and notes.   * Anta Corp. agreed to sell three nursing homes to First Health Care Associates Ltd. of Chicago for $7.9 million.   * Energy Resources Corp. and Page Petroleum Ltd. announced the sale by Energy's Exploration joint venture and a private party of 47.5 percent of about 28,000 net acres in the A.B.O. trend area of De Baca County, N.M., to Page Petroleum Inc., a subsidiary of Page Petroleum Ltd., for $5.3 million in cash and a 25 percent reversionary interest.

headline: JAPANESE TAKING STOCK IN AMERICA
abstract: O NCE again, the Japanese are coming, and on Wall Street, it is already being called ''the friendly invasion.'' This time, instead of invading American consumer markets with their Toyotas, Sonys and Panasonics, the Japanese are bringing their money. In increasing numbers, they are coming to buy stocks on Wall Street and to wheel and deal in America's commodities pits.   For decades Japanese authorities, concerned with sheltering its economy, severely restricted the ability of Japanese to take yen out of the country. Last December, however, those stringent foreign exchange controls were substantially relaxed, and more Japanese funds are already flowing into American stock and commodity markets.   Though the total is not yet great, investment professionals in both Japan and the United States predict far-reaching effects in both countries, not only in investment circles but also in broader economic, political and diplomatic spheres. The influx of Japanese funds is not only more business for Wall Street; it is also expected to enlarge, deepen and add liquidity to American financial markets.  And in international finance, Japan's relaxing of currency controls is a kind of coming of age, elevating the yen as a major world currency and signifying Japan's willingness to expose its economy to the vagaries of world currency markets.

headline: City Business
abstract: To the Business Editor: William Norris, who suggests ''Let's Let Business Help Run the Cities'' (Sept. 13), deserves the Mirage Award for his idea.  Before business runs cities, it will have to quit running from them.

headline: DECONTROL OF INSURANCE FEES URGED
abstract: The chairman of a House small business subcommittee said today that insurance agents' fixed commissions were raising insurance costs for Americans by billions of dollars. Representative John J. LaFalce, Democrat of upstate New York and chairman of the Small Business Oversight subc ommittee, said the situation ''may very well be one of the most enduring price-fixing schemes ever perpetrated on the American publ ic.''   Representatives of the insurance industry disagreed, warning that decontrol of commissions could confuse insurance buyers and actually harm unsophisticated buyers who might end up paying more for insurance.

headline: NORWAY'S RIGHT TOPPLES LABOR GOVERNMENT
abstract: The Labor Party, which has dominated Norwegian politics for almost half a century, was defeated in parliamentary elections yesterday by a resurgent right.   Riding a tide of discontent with high taxes, 14 percent inflation and Government intrusion into every aspect of life, the Conservative Party gained almost a third of the popular vote and, with its allies, took a majority of the seats in the 155-member Parliament.   It was a striking personal triumph for Kare Willoch, the 53-yearold economist who leads the Conservatives. A proponent of ''supply side'' theories, he is expected to succeed the Labor Party's Gro Harlem Bruntland as Prime Minister in mid-October.

headline: WALLETS BUTTONED SHUT
abstract: Although some economists expect rising disposable income - the product of recent declines in the inflation rate - to generate healthier retail sales during the third quarter and thereby help forestall a recession, a recent survey suggests otherwise.   In its monthly sampling of national opinion for Advertising Age, a trade publication, Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a Chicago-based market research company, found that consumers do have more cash, but are less willing to spend it. Forty-four percent of those polled did have extra cash left over at the end of the June, the largest percentage in the last 19 months. But more than half of those surveyed chose to cut back on spending.

headline: GTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AT THE U.N., KEY MEETINGS ARE IN PRIVATE
abstract: The private meetings and informal discussions that are being held among the 121 foreign ministers and 10 heads of government gathered here for the General Asembly session are where most of the real work is going on.   Once a year, during the two-week general debate that marks the opening of the General Assembly, the foreign ministers, and occasionally a head of state, of the 156 member countries come to New York. They come nominally to present the views of their governments but more practically to confer with each other on an array of issues.

headline: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Official Approves Continental Plan
abstract: Continental Air Lines will be permitted to sell 15.4 million shares of common stock to an Employee Stock Ownership Plan, but the airline must first get shareholder and employee approval, a state official ruled today.   The sale, if completed, would turn the airline into the country's largest worker-controlled corporation.  Geraldine Green, the State Commissioner of Corporations, announced her decision at a news conference but said that she had several reservations about the fairness of the plan.

headline: Opposition to NATO in Spain
abstract: Santiago Carrillo, the Spanish Communist Party leader, said today that his party had gathered half a million signatures in favor of a referendum on whether Spain should join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The Government of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo has rejected a referendum, saying that the question would be decided by a vote in Parliament.

headline: RESPONSE BY DEMOCRATS TO PRESIDENT
abstract: Following are replies to President Reagan's tax speech by Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, as recorded by The New York Times:   O'NEILL: I, too, just watched the President of the United States, and I must agree he is a supersalesmen. He and I don't agree on his plan whatsoever. I believe in the plan of fairness. Very easy to put the question. The question is this: Do you make over $50,000 or less than $50,000? If you make over $50,000, then you're for the Republican plan because that's who it's geared for.

headline: PIONEERING INTERMAGNETICS SEEKS A NICHE
abstract: An intriguing thing happens when certain metals are cooled to extremely low temperatures. At about 415 degrees below zero Fahrenheit - close to what is called absolute zero because matter can get no colder - these metals lose all resistance to electricity.   When electricity can move without resistance, a dramatic improvement in the efficiency of energy transmission is possible. So is the creation of supermagnets.

headline: WESTERN BEEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOUTH AFRICANS SAY 240 ANGOLANS DIED IN 5-DAY INCURSION
abstract: South Africa said today that it had destroyed Angolan radar installations and killed at least 240 Angolan Government troops in its assaults this week in southern Angola.   Antiaircraft installations protecting the radar units were also knocked out, according to South African officers in the area. They declined to tell four foreign journalists who were taken yesterday into southern Angola whether the equipment destroyed had included Soviet-made SAM-3 and SAM-6 missiles that were reported to have been recently installed in southern Angola. Military Headquarters Destroyed   The journalists, who were chosen by the Defense Ministry to represent the foreign press corps here, were flown to the small town of Xangongo, about 60 miles north of the border that separates Angola from the disputed territory of South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, which South Africa administers. The local Angolan military headquarters on the town's outskirts had been destroyed by heavy air bombardment, the journalists said.

headline: Ogilvy & Mather Acquire Translator
abstract: Ogilvy & Mather International announced an interesting and unusual acquisition yesterday. In keeping with the ''International'' in its title it has bought Euramerica Translations, a six-year-old New York company that does what its name suggests - in 38 languages.

headline: ARGENTINA SAYS ITS NUCLEAR PLANTS WILL NOT COMPLY WITH SAFEGUARDS
abstract: Argentina, disappointed by the policy announced last week by the Reagan Administration to limit the spread of nuclear arms, will not put its nuclear installations under international safeguards, the head of Argentina's nuclear programs said.   The installations include a small reprocessing plant that is capable of producing the plutonium for a nuclear device, but Vice Adm. Carlos Castro Madero, a nuclear physicist who is the president of the atomic energy commission, said in an interview this week that Argentina is ''not even thinking of developing a nuclear explosive.''

headline: ROLFITE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LEBANON CHRISTIANS CLARIFY TIES TO ISRAEL
abstract: Leaders of the Christian Phalangist Party have given President Elias Sarkis a letter that is said to deal with the issue of their relations with Israel.   Syria has been demanding that the Lebanese Christians issue a declaration formally renouncing any collaboration with Israel as a precondition for further efforts by a special Arab League committee toward ending a half-dozen years of violence in this bitterly divided nation.   While Phalangists have previously resisted such demands, Bashir Gemayel, head of the party's militia force, said last night when he emerged from a 20-minute meeting with Mr. Sarkis:   ''I have come to tell the President we are ready to take any stand that may facilitate the mission of the four-power committee comprising Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the Arab League and Syria and render this mission a success.'' 'The Seven-Year Tragedy'   Reading a statement to reporters, Mr. Gemayel added: ''We, as the Lebanese resistance, are determined to put an end to the seven-year tragedy of our people at all cost and irrespective of difficulties. We have given 5,000 martyrs and are ready to give other things so this crisis may end and our honor may be preserved and our morale remain high.''

headline: HERBICIDE POSES PROBLEMS FOR U.S. AND CANADA
abstract: There are 95,000 gallons of an American-made herbicide in a warehouse across the river from here in Windsor, Ontario. The Canadians want it out of the country, but the Americans will not allow it across the river.   ''It's a good example of business and government all doing the right thing but not being able to do what has to be done when technology takes over,'' said L.A. Price, speaking for the United States Environmental Protection Agency in Was hington.

headline: Advertising; ZIFF-DAVIS PUBLISHING GETS SUBSCRIPTION LIST
abstract: Ziff-Davis Publishing has acquired the subscription list of Next magazine from the International Thomson Business Press, which terminated the publication Friday, and will apply it to its Psychology Today magazine.   International Thomson, part of the International Thomson Organization of Canada, acquired Next from Litton Industries, where it was the conglomerate's first consumer magazine.

headline: SADAT CHIDES U.S. FOR 'PASSIVITY' TOWARD SOVIET
abstract: President Anwar el-Sadat said last night that he was disturbed by the ''passivity'' of the United States towards Soviet moves in the Middle East and he again offered to provide Egyptian military facilities to the United States if they were needed.   In a late night address at Alexandria before a gathering of scholars, Mr. Sadat spoke about his trip to Washington next Tuesday, where he will meet with President Reagan for the first time.   ''I will tell President Reagan that Egypt will give the United State miliatary facilities to reach any Gulf state or Islamic country so that the Soviet involvement in Afghanistan will not be repeated,'' Mr. Sadat said.

headline: Associated Press
abstract: 6,000 RALLY AGAINST MARCOS IN MANILA: Part of the crowd that gathered yesterday in Manila's Bonifacio Park to denounce President Ferdinand E. Marcos and Filipino ties to the United States. For the first time, Government schoolteachers took part in a demonstration against Mr. Marcos. The rally was peaceful.

headline: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Georgia-Pacific
abstract: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said that it had asked the Federal Trade Commission to approve its proposed acquisition of eight corrugated container plants from a unit of the Johns-Manville Corporation. Georgia-Pacific must get approval because of a 1972 order settling a case in which the F.T.C.  challenged Georgia-Pacific's acquisition of 16 softwood plywood manufacturers in the South. Under the proposed acquisition, Georgia-Pacific will buy the plants from Manville Forest Products Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Johns-Manville, for an undisclosed price.

headline: INCUBATING INNOVATORS AT R.P.I.
abstract: INCUBATORS for fledgling industries are being provided at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., oldest of the nation's engineering schools.   Students and others who have innovative ideas and start new companies can rent space for as little as $3 a square foot yearly.  Besides gaining cheap space, the innovators can use scientific materials in the institute's library, lease computer time at low rates as needed and tap the minds of professors, sometimes for a consulting fee.   Also at hand is presumably eager labor from engineering students - either undergradutes or graduates - who might be willing to work on the projects for experience and a few dollars. Furthermore, all institute students receive 50 hours' free time yearly on computer terminals to do research, solve puzzles or anything else they wish, which gives them an added capability to take on outside research projects.

headline: Advertising; INTERPUBLIC'S NET DROPS IN QUARTER
abstract: The Interpublic Group of Companies yesterday announced its secondquarter earnings. Revenues fell 1.1 percent, to $110 million from $111.2 million in the similar period last year, and net income fell 35.3 percent, to $5.8 million from $8.95 million.

headline: SADAT SAYS SOVIET URGED HIS FOES ON
abstract: President Anwar el-Sadat said tonight that a dozen of the 1,536 people he had arrested in recent days would be charged with ''conniving'' with the Soviet Union to undermine his regime.   Mr. Sadat, in a speech of two and a half hours, also strongly justified his crackdown on religious extremists and political foes.  He appealed to the nation's youth not to be duped by religious fanatics, and said that he would no longer tolerate lax discipline in Egypt.   ''Lack of discipline in any way or form, in the streets, in the Government, in the university, in the secondary schools, in the factory, in the public sector, in the private sector, this all has ended, it has ended,'' Mr. Sadat said near the end of his televised address.

headline: DOW FALLS BY 2.57, TO 899.26
abstract: Investors concern over high interest rates and double-digit inflation sent stock prices down slightly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing below the 900 level for the first time in 13 months.   The blue-chip barometer closed off 2.57 points, to 899.26. The last time the Dow has closed below 900 was on July 11, 1980, when it finished at 891.l3.   The Dow fell 16.36 points last week and has dropped about 46 points since Aug.1, mainly, analysts say, because of apprehension over rising interest rates. High interest rates attract funds to competing forms of investment, such as money market funds, which offer high yields and low risk; raise concern about the health of business, thereby discouraging investment in stocks, and make it too costly for many investors to buy stocks on margin.

headline: Soviet Revives Call To Ban Neutron Weapon
abstract: Reacting to Washington's decision to manufacture and stockpile neutron weapons, the Soviet Union today revived its three-year-old call for an international treaty to outlaw them.   Viktor L. Israelyan, the Soviet delegate to the 40-nation disarmament conference, called for the ''immediate establishment'' of a working group to consider a draft treaty that the Soviet Union submitted in March 1978.

headline: DOW UP 2.76 IN SHORT SESSION
abstract: In a trading session shortened by 30 minutes because of a power failure, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.76 points yesterday, its first increase in a week of dropping stock prices resulting from high interest rates.   The Dow average had been declining for an hour when an explosion at Consolidated Edison's 14th Street power plant cut off power to much of the Wall Street area, forcing the New York Stock Exchange to end trading at 3:30 P.M., with the Dow average at 853.88. It had risen 5.52 points from Tuesday's close before the decline started at 2:30 P.M.   Yesterday was the first time that the exchange has had to close trading before the session officially ended because of a power blackout. The previous abbreviated session occurred last March 30, when trading ended at 3:17 P.M. after the attempted assassination of President Reagan.

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 11, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Seminar on relations that exists be- tween human rights, peace and devel- opment - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.   Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 2:15 P.M.

headline: Business People; PUROLATOR CHOOSES CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER
abstract: Frederick H. Cook, 65, has been named president and chief executive officer of Purolator Inc., the filter manufacturer that is also the world's largest courier company and one of the three biggest armored car companies in the United States. He succeeds Paul A. Cameron, 59, who has been named vice chairman.

headline: DC-9 CERTIFIED
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said that the Federal Aviation Administration has certified its DC-9 model 82 to enter commercial airline service.

headline: U.S. BARS LOAN FOR GUYANA
abstract: The Reagan Administration, in an action described as representative of a more rigorous approach to lending to the third world, today vetoed a $20 million loan to Guyana that came before the board of the Inter-American Development Bank.   R.T. McNamar, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, said the decision had been taken on ''technical economic grounds and should not be interpreted as a vote against the Government of Guyana.'' A spokesman for the Washington-based regional lending institution declined to comment on the American action.

headline: Advertising; GILETTE INTRODUCING SILKIENCE MOISTURIZER
abstract: Gillette's personal care division, in hopes of taking a bite out of Oil of Olay's position in the skin-care market, will begin this fall putting $22.6 million in promotion behind a new product called Silkience Self-Adjusting Moisturizer.   The stated consumer benefit: The product seeks out the dry skin on your face and makes it ''silky.'' The company already has a hair conditioner and two shampoos under the Silkience name that also have ''self-adjusting'' qualities.

headline: TURNOVER UP
