abstract: The stock market showed some resilience yesterday, with some prices rising slightly despite continued concern over high interest rates.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which had tumbled 39 points in the preceding six sessions mainly because of investor concern over rising interest rates, rose 1.24 points, to 882.71. On Monday, the key average plunged 10.75 points, to 881.47, its lowest close in almost 14 months.   However, in the overall market yesterday, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advancing stocks by more than an 8-to-5 ratio. Turnover on the Big Board increased to 45.1 million shares from 40.4 million shares on Monday as institutional participation expanded for the second consecutive session.

headline: The U.N. Today; Sept. 3, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets on Namibia at 3 P.M.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: * Allegheny Power System Inc. has elected Elmer B. Kaelin president of the Potomac Edison Co., a subsidiary.   * Bank of New York Co. and Bank of New York have elected to their boards Ralph E. Gomory, vice president and director of research for the International Business Machines Corp.

headline: SUN ELECTRIC GETS A NEW PRESIDENT
abstract: Keith P. Mazurek, who is 57 years old and has been in the automotive industry for many years, has joined the Sun Electric Corporation, a major manufacturer of electronic diagnostic equiment for cars and other vehicles, as president. He succeeds Frank Perna Jr., who resigned from the Chicago-based company.

headline: SADAT ASSURED OVER U.S. ROLE IN THE MIDEAST
abstract: President Reagan concluded two days of talks with President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt today by assuring him of an active American role in future Middle East diplomacy but refraining from agreeing to a specific course.   ''To be completely candid, I was a willing listener,'' Mr. Reagan told reporters as he said goodbye to Mr. Sadat at the White House.  ''We are both anxious to insure that the negotiating process stemming from the Camp David agreements will resume and succeed.''   Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said at a news conference this afternoon that Mr. Reagan and Mr. Sadat had discussed many possible negotiating options. But he said that any agreement on how to proceed had to await Mr. Reagan's meeting here next month with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel.

headline: Cities Service Discovery Well
abstract: The Cities Service Company, the nation's 18th-largest oil company and a frequent target of takeover speculation, reported a new oil discovery in a wildcat well off Palawan Island in the Philippines.   Cities Service said its Galoc-1 wildcat well flowed at an average daily rate of 1,850 barrels of good quality crude from depths between 7,338 feet and 7,364 feet.

headline: MIXED-RACE NAMIBIAN GROUP SEEKS POLITICAL ALLIES
abstract: West Africa -They speak the Afrikaans language and, when they trekked into the arid vastness of South-West Africa in the 19th century to found their own republic, they were like numerous groups of seminomadic Afrikaners trying to win their own space in Africa.   Only one thing kept them apart but it was the most important thing and it meant they could never be recognized as Afrikaners. It was race.   So they took the disparaging Afrikaans term with which the whites had always dismissed them and wore it proudly as an ethnic name. Now in this country, which is also known as Namibia, it is normal to speak of the people of mixed race called the Basters without implying any of the connotations of miscegenation and illegitimacy that still adhere to the word in colloquial Afrikaans speech.

headline: Executives
abstract: * Angeles Corporation, investment consultants, named Jerry E.  Goldress a director.   * Colgate-Palmolive Company appointed Thomas M. Casey director of purchasing.

headline: Coastal to Study Restructuring
abstract: The Coastal Corporation, a refiner and marketer of oil and natural gas and a producer of coal and chemicals, said it had retained Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., investment bankers, for consultation and advice on a possible redeployment and restructuring of the company's operations and assets.   The study would consider the possible sale or spinoff of significant parts of the company's business, Coastal said. Revenues of the company, based in Houston, were expected to increase this year.

headline: FINANCIAL LEADERS REJECT G.O.P. CHARGES
abstract: Executives of Wall Street brokerage and investment houses said yesterday that Republican leaders in Congress were mistaken in casting them as the villains perpetrating high interest rates.   The executives stressed that the huge capital markets, centered in lower Manhattan's financial district, were impossible for a small group to control because they were international, amounted to more than $4 trillion in debt and $1 trillion in equity and reacted to actions by thousands of investors.   ''It's obviously not true that Wall Street controls the markets,'' said Robert H.B. Baldwin, president of Morgan Stanley & Company. ''We make markets in thousands of investors' positions.

headline: THE TEXT OF COMMUNIQUE ISSUED AFTER THE OTTAWA CONFERENCE
abstract: The following is the official Englishlanguage version of a communique issued by the heads of state at the close of their two-day economic summit conference today: Declaration of the Ottawa Summit   1. We have met at a time of rapid change and great challenge to world economic progress and peace. Our meeting has served to reinforce the strength of our common bonds. We are conscious that economic issues reflect and affect the broader political purposes we share. In a world of interdependence, we reaffirm our common objectives and our recognition of the need to take into account the effect on others of policies we pursue. We are confident in our joint determination and ability to tackle our problems in a spirit of shared responsibility, both among ourselves and with our partners throughout the world. The Economy   2. The primary challenge we addressed at this meeting was the need to revitalize the economies of the industrial democracies, to meet the needs of our own people and strengthen world prosperity.

headline: NICARAGUA HOPES NEXT U.S. ENVOY EQUALS THE LAST
abstract: Just days before winding up an assignment here, a popular foreign Ambassador was honored recently at a private luncheon given by the junta and top Sandinist commanders. They wanted to show their appreciation for his efforts to improve relations between his Government and Nicaragua's revolutionary regime.   No one, it seemed, thought it unusual that, at a time of tense relations between Nicaragua's leftist rulers and the Reagan Administration, the guest of honor should be the United States Ambassador to Nicaragua, Lawrence A. Pezzullo.   In the two years since the Nicaraguan revolution, Mr. Pezzullo, a straight-talking, unflappable New Yorker, had earned the trust of the new Government. This trust was underscored by the warm and friendly mood at the luncheon, where, amid jokes, reminiscences and toasts, several of the young Sandinist commanders, wearing the olive-green uniforms of former guerrillas, expressed regret at the imminent departure of the tall, bespectacled diplomat sitting before them.

headline: PAN AM IN PACT TO SELL HOTELS
abstract: Pan American World Airways announced early this morning the sale of its Intercontinental Hotels subsidiary to Grand Metropolitan Ltd., the British conglomerate, for $500 million in cash. The sale is to be completed by Sept. 30.   The profitable Intercontinental chain has 97 hotels in operation or under consturction in 48 countries.  The decision to sell the prestigious chain was approved by directors at a late-night meeting at the Pan Am Building headquarters in New York.

headline: 10 Disputed Claims Resolved Favorably
abstract: During June, 10 of the 13 national advertising claims investigations conducted by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus were resolved when the advertisers were able to support the disputed claims. An unusually high percentage.

headline: BRITISH SHIP CONTRACT
abstract: Austin & Pickersgill, a shipbuilder based in northern England, said today that it had received an order worth about $85 million to build four 30,000-deadweight-ton bulk carriers for companies owned by Thomas Demseris, a Greek shipowner.The new vessels can carry 636 containers as an alternative to bulk cargoes. The vessels are to be completed by the end of 1983.

headline: Ventura Picks Up Oui
abstract: Ventura Associates, a sales promotion agency, has picked up Oui magazine, the former Playboy property, that is now being published by Laurant Publishing in New York. According to Ventura, the sales promotion budget alone will be $1.5 million.

headline: Avon's Tiffany
abstract: To the Business Editor: In reference to your article about Avon and Tiffany, ''Avon's Calling a Familiar Tune'' (Aug. 23), a few observations are in order.  The article quoted David Mitchell, chairman of Avon, saying that last year Tiffany had an outstanding year in sales, but profits were ''negatively impacted'' by the high cost of inventory.

headline: UNION OIL CO (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Talking Business with Stata of Analog Devices; Hard Choices In Electronics
abstract: Profits have evaporated this year throughout the customarily rich electronics industry. Indeed, it is the industry's worst year since 1974. This is forcing hard decisions on spending, especially on how to bolster the chronically thin ranks of engineers.   Analog Devices Inc., a maker of precision electronic components formeasurement and control devices, is a case in point. Profits dropped 48 percent in the first nine months of its fi scal year, to $3.5 million, or 39 cents a share, on $116.5 milli on in sales. Its stock price fell last week to $15.50 from a high of $28 in April.

headline: S.E.C. ACTS ON FILING METHODS
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed major changes in the way the nation's 9,000 public companies register securities and report their financial activities to the Government.   This is ''truly a dramatic and historic proposal,'' said John Shad, chairman of the S.E.C.  The changes were proposed in an effort to reduce the costs of disclosure by public companies and eliminate much of the overlapping and duplication that occurs in current corporate disclosure rules.  Companies are required to file disclosure statements with the S.E.C.  when offering securities to the public.   The package is the latest in the commission's effort to streamline its disclosure system. Other changes in the way companies report information to stockholders and the S.E.C. were adopted last year.

headline: THE QUIET COWBOY IN MR. REAGAN'S POSSE
abstract: WASHINGTON THE Reagan Cabinet's steer-roping ace doesn't much like to toot his own horn: Cowboys regard a man for what he is and what he can do, not for what he says. Their world is far from Washington, where Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige says wryly everyone would be a billionaire if people were paid by the word.   But Mr. Baldrige, a card-carrying member of the Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association - he still wins money as a ''heeler,'' the man in team roping who lassos the steer's hind legs - is the Administration's quietly influential Marlboro man. An outdoorsman in a workaholic's city, he would rather close his day in the saddle than behind a mound of paperwork. In the present Administration that bestows a special advantage. Often his fellow rider is Ronald Reagan.    But the plain-spoken Mr. Baldrige, who built Scovill Inc. into a $1 billion multinational enterprise, is playing an important role in the Reagan Administration and enunciating policy in an increasingly influential way. There are even those who say that under him, the Commerce Department, traditionally the weak sister of the Washington bureaucracy, is becoming a power base with at least the potential of becoming a real force in the Capital. Political analysts in Washington suspect that Mr. Baldrige may be building a power base to challenge Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican Senator of Connecticut, in the 1982 elections.

headline: POWER FAILURE DISRUPTS BIG BOARD AND AMEX
abstract: A power failure in the Wall Street area yesterday afternoon forced the New York and American Stock Exchanges to end trading 30 minutes early and disrupted business in the nation's financial center.   ''We're in darkness here,'' said Charles Storer, public information officer for the New York Stock Exchange at 11 Wall Street, shortly after the explosion at the Consolidated Edison Company's East 14th Street station. ''The only light is coming through the window.''   But soon after power was restored in the early evening, spokesmen for both exchanges said that trading would resume normally at 10 A.M. today. ''We don't expect any operational problems,'' said Victor Ricciardelli, a vice president of the Amex.

headline: Investing; ORION: A LOOK AT AN ASSET PLAY
abstract: S PECULATORS who like stocks with rising earnings and a rising price trend - of which there have been precious few this summer -share a familiar problem: how to get in ahead of the crowd. There is another breed of player, however, that rarely has to worry about that.   These are investors who look for asset plays. Typically, they focus on balance sheets rather than income statements, scouring the numbers for hidden values in assets. If that isn't daunting enough, the arithmetic can some times become so convol uted that it is beyond the ken of ordinary investors.

headline: G.N.P. DIP REVISED TO 2.4% RATE
abstract: The United States economy suffered an even sharper downswing during the second quarter than originally estimated, while corporate profits posted a steep decline, the Commerce Department reported today.   The gross national product, the value of the nation's goods and services, is now calculated to have declined during the April-June period at an annual rate of 2.4 percent, adjusted for inflation, a somewhat faster pace than the 1.9 percent decline initially reported four weeks ago.   Profits after taxes fell 11.3 percent, in part because of high interest rates, the report said.  The new G.N.P. figure compared with an 8.6 percent rate of gain in the first quarter - a figure reached after two upward revisions.

headline: BELL ASKS TRUST-SUI DISMISSAL
abstract: A lawyer for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company urged a judge today to dismiss the Government's antitrust suit against the world's largest corporation, describing it as a ''fraud'' and an ''outrage.''   ''It's hard to figure out what the Government means,'' said George Saunders, the lawyer, in his oral argument before United States District Judge Harold Greene. ''What the Government is doing here is an outrage against the largest corporation in the world that has contributed to the country's well-being more than any other company.''

headline: TANDYCRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PACT ON IRAN ASSETS
abstract: American and Iranian negotiators meeting near Amsterdam have at last reached tentative agreement on conditions for the transfer by the United States of more than $2 billion in oncefrozen Iranian bank deposits, an Administration official said today.   The $2 billion will be transferred to the central bank of the Netherlands tomorrow if no new snags develop, according to the official, who declined to be named. That bank would hold $1 billion in a special security account to cover possible awards against Iran by an international tribunal arbitrating American claims, and the rest of the money would go to Iran.

headline: PACCAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 3,000 Salvadoran Troops Said to Head for Battle
abstract: Witnesses estimated today that 3,000 Government troops, backed by fighter planes and helicopters, were advancing on the town of Perquin in the northeastern province of Morazan, where rebels say they have begun a major offensive.   The Defense Ministry continued to refuse all comment on fighting in the province.

headline: Europeans' Afghan Plan Is Dismissed by Tass
abstract: On the eve of a visit here by Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary, to discuss a new West European initiative on Afghanistan, the Soviet press agency Tass declared today that it was ''absolutely clear'' that the plan could not serve as a basis for discussions.   The Tass commentary did not mention Lord Carrington's visit. The European Common Market plan calls for a conference and guarantees of Afghan independence and nonalignment.

headline: ...NOR OIL STUDIES
abstract: even telling - that he chose to castigate the Ford Foundation and the Harvard energy reports and not the more traditional forecasters, who missed the future by an even wider margin.   In the 1970's almost everybody underestimated the elasticity of demand for oil and energy in general - as indeed most forecasters still do. Those with an interest in the supply side of the equation, such as the oil companies, used their overblown projections to argue that the way had to be cleared for them to increase production from conventional oil deposits and to accelerate development of unconventional supplies such as those from shale.

headline: REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT PROPERTIES reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Athlone Industries said it had repurchased 20,000 shares of its common stock in the open market for $572,500.   * Bank Securities Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of 600,000 common shares to be sold through underwriters headed by Bottcher & Company.

headline: 10 SAVED FROM ATLANTIC
abstract: A cargo ship rescued the 10 occupants of a yacht that sank in the Atlantic today, officials at the military Search and Rescue Center here said. They said the 10 were in good condition after being picked up from life rafts by the cargo ship Oldendorf.

headline: IT'S D-DAY FOR THE THRIFTY
abstract: ONLY four days to go. Anticipation mounts. Confusion abounds. To save or not to save?  Come Thursday morning, savers one and all - accountants and artists, brokers and bakers, record company executives and race car drivers, bellhops and beauty parlor magnates - can trudge over to their neighborhood bank and plunk a bit of the fruit of their labors into the first-ever, one and only All Savers certificates.   Millions of people are expected to do just that. Many economists are betting that a whopping $250 billion will be poured into the All Savers, making it one of the biggest savings events of all time, this huge river of green running from C.D.'s and money market funds and cookie jars and emptying into this reservoir newly created by Federal law. Some disbelievers insist that just $100 billion or so will trickle in; others say it will be an ocean of as much as $500 billion. Nobody really knows.   ''I happen to think it's going to be a very big deal,'' says a Citibank vice president, who, like other bankers, stands to gain if it is a very big deal.

headline: STATE NATIONAL BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PEKING SAYS FORCE MIGHT BE USED TO REUNITE TAIWAN AND MAINLAND
abstract: China may be forced to resort to ''nonpeaceful methods'' to reunify Taiwan with the mainland if the United States carries out the defense provisions of the Taiwan Relations Act by supplying new weapons, a new Chinese foreign affairs journal has warned.   The quarterly journal, Research on International Problems, said in its first issue that advancement or retrogression in relations with the United States depended on the extent to which certain ''upperclass Americans'' carried out the act in violation of American commitments to Peking.   ''The provisions in the Taiwan Relations Act, which interfere in the internal affairs of China, can only encourage Taiwanese authorities to reject peaceful talks and oppose peaceful unification,'' said the article, which was approved for publication by senior officials. ''As a result, China may be forced to resort to nonpeaceful methods to settle the Taiwan problem against its wish.''

headline: Washington Watch; Stock-Option Tax Confusion
abstract: WASHINGTON TAX legislation of any kind in recent years has quickly been dubbed a relief act for lawyers and accountants. This year's is no exception as banks and thrift institutions have found out already in marketing tax-free savings certificates.   Among the thorniest problems, specialists say, is the one regarding stock options, the right to buy shares at specified prices, granted by companies to their executives.   In greatly liberalizing benefits - mainly by changing the tax treatment to capital gains rates and levying the tax when the optioned stock is sold rather than when the option is exercised - Congress appears to have left more than the usual quota of loose ends.

headline: 3 Indicted In Fraud Case
abstract: An indictment that was unsealed in Manhattan yesterday accused the former chairman of a Costa Rican corporation of selling unregistered securities that defrauded American investors of more than $1 million.    The 16-count Federal indictment included charges against Robert W.  Slocum, the 49-year-old former chairman of International Trade Development of Costa Rica S.A.; his wife, Rita, and a business associate, Henry Ming Wong of Miami.

headline: Advertising; Addendum
abstract: * Esquire magazine increasing its advertising rates 12 percent, effective with the January issue.

headline: LABOR IS SCORNFUL OF MRS. THATCHER IN DEBATE ON RIOTS
abstract: The House of Commons erupted in a storm of bitter recrimination this afternoon after a sixth night of urban violence, with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher forced to shout to make herself heard over the taunts of critics.   Tonight, the violence resumed in two cities. In Manchester, youths attacked a police station in the Moss Side district but were driven off. Earlier, groups of youths, both whites and blacks, set a shop afire and threw rocks and bricks at officers in what the city's Chief Constable called an outbreak of ''guerrilla warfare.'' In Woolwich, in east London, rampaging youths overturned several cars and damaged shops. The police said the situation there had been brought under control within an hour. Twelve people were arrested on looting and assault charges.

headline: THOUSANDS MOURN TORRIJOS AT FUNERAL IN PANAMA
abstract: Senior military commanders and government leaders from throughout the world, along with thousands of Panamanians, attended the funeral today of Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, Panama's powerful leader for nearly 13 years.   Under the white, vaulted arches in the cavernous Metropolitan Cathedral, the head of the United States delegation, Gen. David C.  Jones, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, sat next to military officers from China.   Mrs. George Bush and other United States representatives sat in the nave with Dr. Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, vice president of Cuba's Council of State, and members of the Nicaraguan delegation headed by Sergio Ramirez Mercado, a junta member.

headline: Elf Fiber Venture
abstract: Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, the French state-owned oil concern, said it had agreed with the Union Carbide Corporation and Toray Industries of Japan to study the feasibility of building a carbon fiber plant in France to meet growing European demand. No details of the agreement were given, but Japanese sources said that Elf Aquitaine would be the largest shareholder in the factory, likely to be in southwestern France.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Express Company has elected Robert F. Smith vice chairman of its subsidiary, the American Express International Banking Corporation.   * Chemical Bank has named Alfonso Martinez-Fonts Jr. a vice president.

headline: U.S. AND INDIA PLAN MORE ATOM TALKS
abstract: The United States and India today agreed to hold at least one more series of talks on their differences over American nuclear fuel shipments. There were indications that both sides were eager to liquidate a disputed agreement on nuclear cooperation in the most amicable way possible.   As negotiators for both countries announced that a third session would be held soon in Washington, the spokesman for the Indian Foreign Ministry hinted broadly that what was being discussed were the details for scuttling the 18-year-old agreement, which provided for the shipment of enriched uranium to a power plant in Tarapur.   ''The question of resumption of supplies was not raised by either side,'' J.N. Dixit, the ministry spokesman, said in describing the two days of discussions.

headline: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Sept 5
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RESILIENCE IS SEEN FOR ECONOMY
abstract: Although interest rates are near record levels, the nation's economy appears to be resisting recession, according to a wide range of Government and private-sector economists. The economy's considerable resilience this quarter, they said, could complicate President Reagan's economic recovery program.   Leading economic forecasters predict that America's gross national product, the basic measure of the nation's output of goods and services, will register either a slight increase or only a modest decline for the three-month period of July, August and September.  Such a showing would indicate that the economy, while not surging, is much stronger than has been widely assumed.

headline: Economic Scene; The Pressure On the Fed
abstract: THE Secretary of the Treasury, Donald T. Regan, and the chairman of the Council of Ecomomic Advisers, Murray L. Weidenbaum, have both begun to suggest in their public orations that the Fed might make the money supply grow a bit faster, even if Wall Street takes fright.    Mr. Regan, as a former chairman of Merrill Lynch, clearly feels that he possesses the hard-earned right to show proper disrespect for the wisdom of Wall Street. He is complaining that the Street is so nervous it turns all news into bad news. If the money supply increased, the Street grew sick with fear over inflation; if the money supply fell, it trembled over a coming money crunch.

headline: President Nominates Deputy Patents Chief
abstract: President Reagan has nominated Donald J. Quigg, retired patent counsel of the Phillips Petroleum Company, Bartlesville, Okla., to be Deputy Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks.

headline: CONCERN OVER SIZE OF DEFICIT
abstract: Widespread fear that the budget deficit for the fiscal year 1982 may go beyond the Reagan Administration's projection has set off a rancorous debate over whether the excess spending would damage the nation's financial well-being and torpedo the President's economic program.   If the deficit of $42.5 billion forecast by the Reagan team for the year turns out to be substantially larger, investors fear that it could unleash a wave of inflation and high interest rates. Their concern that even the second round of budget cutting now being undertaken by the President will not bring the deficit much within $60 billion has been enough to send the financial markets into a tailspin.   But other people argue that the size of the deficit - whether it is $42.5 billion, $50 billion or $60 billion - will have no bearing on the success or failure of the Reagan program. At worst, they say, deficits have marginal influence in determining levels of interest and inflation, and at best they can be a stimulant to a sagging economy.

headline: Advertising; Lipton Herbal Teas Moving to SSC&B
abstract: Only one kind of Lipton tea has not had its advertising done by SSC&B, its herbal teas. However, Thomas J. Lipton Inc., the Unilever subsidiary, is rectifying that situation by removing the herbals from Della Femina, Travisano & Partners and depositing them with the other Lipton products, which probably bill around $15 million.

headline: AQUITAINE PROCEEDING ON TENDER
abstract: Despite a request from the United States asking that France delay the acquisition of Texasgulf by its Government-controlled oil company, the French concern started to make payments yesterday for Texasgulf's tendered shares.   The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, an interagency body led by the Treasury Department, had requested that the $2.87 billion tender offer from Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine be delayed until it finished a review of the takeover, which involves one of the world's largest producers of sulfur. Considered a Commercial Matter   The French Government decided not to interfere with the transaction because it was a commercial matter, according to Wall Street sources.

headline: Article 015425 -- No Title
abstract: In what was believed to be the biggest theft of cash in Britain since the Great Train Robbery, bandits ambushed an armored car today and stole more than $1.8 million meant for London banks.   The ambush occurred in the morning as an armored Securicor van drove through a heavily wooded section of a two-lane highway about 35 miles east of London.

headline: INDIA PROHIBITS STRIKES IN ASSAM
abstract: The Government imposed a six-month ban on strikes in some essential services today in the oil-producing state of Assam, an official communique said.   Services within the state have been disrupted for almost two years by unrest caused by protests against the presence of immigrants, most of them from Bangladesh.

headline: UNILEVER LTD AND UNILEVER NV reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
VW Deliveries Slip by 4%
abstract: Volkswagenwerk A.G.'s motor vehicle group deliveries fell a provisional 4 percent, to 1.2 million units, in the first half of 1981 from the first six months of 1980, the auto maker's finance director, Friederich Thomee, told the annual meeting today.   He said the fall was mainly caused by reduced sales in Brazil and West Germany.  Mr. Thomee said total 1981 group sales would not reach the 1980 total of 2.44 million because of the drastic fall in Brazilian sales, but added the group would improve its market position in the United States and Europe.

headline: Advertising; Holiday Inns Ready To Start Magazine
abstract: Inn America, an advertising-supported magazine for Holiday Inn guests, with a projected annual circulation of more than 63 million, is being prepared for publication by Holiday Inns and King Network Publications.

headline: VOLCKER APPEALS FOR SPENDING CUTS Metzenbaum
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, counseled Congress today to get on with further spending cuts as the best way to shrink the budget deficit and bring down high interest rates.   Mr. Volcker rejected suggestions by some Democratic senators that Congress raise taxes now to reduce the deficit, despite the Administration's sweeping new law lowering tax rates.  Nevertheless, he said that ultimately this course might be necessary.   ''The economy will function better at a lower level of taxes and a lower level of spending,'' the central bank chief said during three hours of testimony before the Senate Budget Committee.

headline: METROCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PACT ON POLISH DEBT DELAYED
abstract: Representatives of about 60 American banks failed yesterday to endorse an agreement that had been reached to reschedule $2.7 billion in Polish debts owed this year to foreign commercial banks. Another meeting has been scheduled for next week.   The meeting was held to vote on a compromise reached late last month between European bankers and a steering comittee of American bankers concerning how to deal with Polish debts. About 460 banks around the world are involved in the negotiations to reschedule a total of $13 billion owed over a number of years to foreign banks, including $1.7 billion to the American banks.

headline: Midsize Renault Production Begun
abstract: Renault, France's state-owned auto maker, began production of its R-9 model in Europe and said it expected worldwide production to reach 2,000 cars a day.

headline: Companies
abstract: Seagram raised its bid for Conoco to $3.8 billion in cash for 51 percent of the oil company's stock. The bid is designed to top Du Pont's offer of $7.3 billion for all of Conoco, with only $3.1 billion in cash and the rest in Du Pont shares. (Page A1.)

headline: CHICAGO FED'S NEW LEADER
abstract: The advocates of tight money have a staunch new ally on the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee in Silas Keehn, the recently appointed president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.   ''Inflation is our No.1 problem,'' Mr. Keehn said recently at a press luncheon, making his first public pronouncement since taking office on July 1. ''It's important that we deal with it while we have this opportunity. If we had faced it years ago we wouldn't be talking about it now.''

headline: CAMPBELL SOUP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: National City Ends Gray Drug Offer
abstract: National City Lines, Inc., said it had terminated its offer to purchase up to 650,000 shares of Gray Drug Stores Inc.

headline: Bonn Rejects Merger
abstract: The West German Federal Cartel Office said today that it rejected the proposed acquisition of more than 25 percent of Metallgesellschaft, the West German nonferrous metals and chemical company, by Veba, the petrochemicals and energy group that is West Germany's largest corporation in terms of sales. A Cartel Office spokesman said that after an informal examination of the proposed acquisition, the office expressed ''grave doubts'' whether the transaction could receive formal approval because of the extent to which certain market activities of both companies would benefit from the deal.

headline: Advertising; Beef Industry Council Picks Botsford Agency
abstract: The Beef Industry Council, which has its headquarters - where else? -in Chicago, has named Botsford Ketchum Advertising of San Francisco as its new agency, replacing Lee King & Partners of Chicago, which had the account for more than six years. The council has budgeted $7.8 million for advertising next year - $6 million more than was budgeted for 1981.

headline: CALIFORNIA WATER SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FAIR-TEX MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Credit Markets; PRICES RISE FOR 2-YEAR ISSUES
abstract: Prices rose slightly yesterday for corporate and Treasury issues due in two years and more. Dealers said a significant number of investors were attracted by prices that were almost at record lows.   ''The nearly 16 percent yield on new two-year Treasury notes seemed to attract buyers who wanted to hold on to the issue and not sell as soon as they could make an eighth of a point profit,'' commented Morgan Stark, senior vice president at the Chemical Bank.  The new two-year notes closed at 100 3/32 to yield 15.82 percent, up from the average price of slightly more than 99 29/32 at Wednesday's auction, where the yield was 15.92 percent.

headline: French Start Dismantling A Napoleonic System
abstract: The National Assembly voted today to withdraw most of the powers of the prefects of France's 95 departments in the first step toward dismantling the centralized political system that has dominated France since Napoleon. The Government also scrapped a plan by the previous administration to provide all residents with computerized identity cards.

headline: Personal-Safety Items
abstract: Garrity Industries, in Stamford, Conn., wants you to know that it is in a position to help you feel safer. That is why it has hired Gordon & Shortt to tell you about its products: a disposable flashlight and a purse-size tear-gas dispenser named Fight Back, which the company says is legal in 45 states. The budget, which previously went through McCurdy Inc. in New Haven, should come to $1 million.

headline: LANE BRYANT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Atomic Energy Agency Considers Ousting Israel
abstract: The International Atomic Energy Agency voted today to consider suspending Israel next year if it does not open its nuclear facilities to inspection. The agency also suspended immediately all technical aid to Israel under agency programs.

headline: WHEN UNCLE SAM IS THE BABY SITTER
abstract: A LTHOUGH the Reagan tax bill provides generous tax breaks for the wealthy, it also contains several provisions that could substantially trim taxes for the average American family. One is an easing of the marriage penalty. Another is a provision that could greatly aid many two-income households with children, but is still virtually unknown outside a tight coterie of tax experts.   That provision would permit companies to set up tax-favored ''dependent-care assistance programs'' to help pay for employee child-care expenses, a much sought-after fringe benefit now that more and more mothers are working. Effective Jan. 1, 1982, companies can set up and pay for the costs of on-site day-care centers, directly pay the outside providers of such services, or reimburse employees for the costs of home day care provided by housekeepers and babysitters.   Within certain limits, employees will not have to report the reimbursement as taxable income, just as they now do not have to report medical reimbursements. In addition, companies will be able to claim a tax deduction for their share of the bill, so long as the program is a formal written plan and is not limited to highly paid workers.

headline: Seagram Gets Conoco Shares
abstract: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc., an unsuccessful bidder for Conoco Inc. in last month's dramatic battle to take over the oil company, said it had received nearly 28 million Conoco shares by its deadline Wednesday for accepting shares offered under its $92-a-share bid.   Seagram said about 180,000 other Conoco shares that had been offered were not delivered.

headline: Toronto R ebounds Af ter Fall
abstract: Prices on the Toronto Stock Exchange bounced back to close strongly higher today after a first-hour drop that was the second-largest on record.   The exchange's broadly based composite index of 300 stocks closed with a rise of 42.96 at 1855.44, a dramatic turnaround from the first hour of trading, when it plunged 54.48 points, or 3 percent.

headline: HAIG SAYS SOVIET ARMS SHIPMENTS TO CUBA HAVE INCREASED SHARPLY
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., said today that Soviet arms shipments to Cuba had increased sharply in the last seven months. He added that there was ''solid evidence'' that some of the increased deliveries were being reshipped to Central America.   Mr. Haig said ''most of the tonnage'' of military supplies ''is believed to be earmarked for Cuba's regular armed forces and its newly created territorial militia.''

headline: Market Place; Cautious View For Analysts
abstract: ONE trade secret for economists who want to stay employed consists of two words: ''Forecast often.'' Wall Street security analysts have borrowed this strategy lately by repeatedly lowering earnings estimates for such diverse stock groups as semiconductors, lodging and forest products. Even resear ch directors at large brokerage firms are not immune to changing thei r signals on the stock market. For example, Donald I.  Trott of A.G.  Becker & Company, when interviewed in late July, offered this outlook for stock prices: ''The underlying trend is still upward, and we continue to look for a summer rally that will carry stock a verages to new highs - perhaps 1,050 to 1,070 as measured by t he Dow Jones industrials - by the end of September.''

headline: Sonny Mae Sets Bond Sale
abstract: The State of New York Mortgage Agency, known as Sonny Mae, announced plans yesterday to sell $100 million to $125 million of single-family home mortgage revenue bonds. The issue is scheduled for the last half of September through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Imperial Shutting Heavy-Oil Plant
abstract: Imperial Oil Ltd. announced today that it was suspending its $12 billion (Canadian) heavy oil production and upgrading facility at Cold Lake in western Canada because of the continuing governmental dispute over energy issues.

headline: HEALEY SCORES NARROWEST OF VICTORIES IN FIGHT WITH BENN FOR LABORITE POST
abstract: Denis Healey retained the deputy leadership of the Labor Party tonight, holding off a strong left-wing challenge by the narrowest of margins and avoiding, for the moment, what would have amounted to a takeover by extremist elements.   Mr. Healey, the former Chancellor of the Exchequer, won by only eight-tenths of 1 percent of the votes cast by an electoral college made up of La bor members of Parliament, local party organizations and the trade unions. His opponent, Tony Benn, had appeared to be thewinner after the first count, and it was only after two recounts thatMr. Healey wa s confirmed as the winner.

headline: Bernadette Devlin in France To Gain Support for I.R.A Fast
abstract: Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, the Irish nationalist, was expelled from Spain and flew to Paris today to seek support for the hunger strike in Northern Ireland.   ''We appeal to the French trade unions to place an embargo on the handling of all British goods at French ports ,'' Mrs. McAliskey told a news conference held at the Paris offices o f the Revolutionary Communist League.

headline: U.S. SAYS RUSSIANS WITHHELD DATA ON SIZE OF MANEUVERS NEAR POLAND
abstract: State Department officials said today that the Soviet Union had withheld information on the number of troops involved in military maneuvers now being conducted in the Baltic region near Poland. Under the terms of the 1975 Helsinki accord s, notification of majormilitary exercises must include information o n the strength of the forces involved. This is the first time that the Soviet Union has failed to provide such information.

headline: Federal Express Sets Jet Purchases
abstract: The Federal Express Corporation said it had signed a contract with the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company to buy 15 new jetliners for more than $300 million. The first of the 727-200F planes will be delivered to the small-package airline in July 1983 and continue on a one-a-m onth basis . Federal Express plans to use 10 of the planes itself and lease the other five to other carriers.

headline: PRESIDENT DEFENDS LIBYAN ENCOUNTER AS 'IMPRESSIVE' ACT
abstract: President Reagan today defended the reported downing of two Libyan jets and vowed to continue the policy of prompt retaliation to make American power ''impressive to the enemies of freedom.''   His public comments were his first since the incident yesterday, in which the United States said two Libyan fighters were shot down by Navy planes after firing at the Americans. Mr. Reagan said the United States had planned naval maneuvers in the Gulf of Sidra to show that this country would not honor Libya's claim that the gulf was part of its internal waters.   But Mr. Regan denied that the naval exercises about 60 nautical miles off the Libyan coast had been intended to provoke an incident or to destabilize the Government of Col. Muammar el-Q@addafi. Visit to a U.S. Carrier   ''We decided it was time to recognize what are the international waters and behave accordingly,'' Mr. Reagan said during a three-hour visit to the carrier Constellation off the California coast.   He said the destruction of the Libyan planes was an appropriate response to an attack. He also said that he was not alarmed that several hours elapsed before his staff informed him of the air battle.

headline: Pressure Seen On Yamani
abstract: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi oil minister, has come under heavy pressure from other Arab oil ministers to reduce his country's oil production, now believed to be about 10 million barrels a day, industry sources reported today.   The disagreements came during a brief meeting in Taif, a mountain resort east of Jidda, the sources added.

headline: KV PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A Look Back at Bentley
abstract: Seventeen years ago, Donald J. Bentley was vice president and general manager of Edwards Laboratories, where an oxygenator - which functions as a heart and lungs during open heart surgery - was developed. The machine was built under Mr. Bentley's direction and, as he recalled yesterday, he saw enormous potential for the product.   ''When I decided that the product should be pursued, I asked the board of directors for funding to ultimately put it on the market,'' he said. ''But they decided not to continue and I offered to buy whatever interest they had.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: IRAN ACCUSES 50 LEFTISTS OF CONSPIRING TO DESTOY THE PARLIAMENT   BUILDING TEHERAN, Iran, July 1 (Reuters) - The newly appointed leader of Iran's ruling party said today that 50 leftist guerrillas were arrested last night as they were planning to destroy the Parliament building.   The guerrillas were members of the Islamic Marxist opposition group Mujahedeen-i-Khalq, which Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini denounced yesterday as responsible for the bomb attack on Sunday that killed more than 70 high members of the dominant Islamic Republican Party.   The revolutionary leader's denunciation appeared to suggest that the leftists would be the target of an increased drive against ''counterrevolutionaries.''   Reports in Teheran newspapers said the arrests last night followed a gun battle between guerrillas and Islamic Revolutionary Guards, in which one guerrilla was killed and three were wounded.

headline: BANKAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN ENDS BAN ON SENDING ISRAEL 16 JET WARPLANE
abstract: President Reagan today lifted a 10-week-old suspension in the shipment of F-15 and F-16 jet fighters to Israel without reaching a conclusion on whether Israel had violated an agreement in using its American-made F-16's to bomb an Iraqi nuclear reactor in June.   An announcement of the release of a total of 16 planes was made here this afternoon by Secretary of State Alexander Haig statement on jets, page A6. M. Haig Jr. after a meeting this morning with Mr. Reagan, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and other members of the National Security Council. A spokesman for Mr. Haig said that the planes would be sent to Israel in a few days.   Secretary Haig said that ''it wasn't necessary to make a legal or juridical decision'' on whether Israel had violated the 1952 arms agreement with the United States. The agreement barred the use of American-made planes for purposes other than defense.

headline: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SRI LANKA TRIES TO REVIVE SAGGING TEA OUTPUT
abstract: Sri Lanka is trying to restore tea production after a drop in output during the 1970's.  Tea was first planted in Sri Lanka more than a hundred years ago and is now one of the mainstays of the economy, along with rubber, gems and tourism.   Talk of possible nationalization of the tea estates in the mid-70's led to the departure of expatriate plantation managers, a lack of investment funds and a decline in production.

headline: WILEY, JOHN, & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Commodities; Currency Futures At Age 10
abstract: WHILE the 10th anniversary of the start of trading in foreign currency futures will not be marked until next May 16, its birth took place a decade ago last Saturday. On Aug. 15, 1971, President Nixon acted to defend the dollar, then flooding the world in everincreasing volume, by imposing a 10 percent surcharge on imports, suspending the convertibility of the dollar into American gold by foreign central banks and instituting wage and price controls to combat domestic inflation.   By Dec. 18, 1971, the resultant upheaval caused a realignment of currency values that ended the system of fixed exchange rates set at the Bretton Woods, N.H., meeting in 1944. The dollar, no longer backed by gold, was, in effect, cut loose to rise or fall in the marketplace, protected only by periodic central bank interventions.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG SPEECH AT GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the speech yesterday by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the General Assembly of the United Nations, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:   International development reflects the worldwide search for economic progress, social justice and human dignity. Short of war itself, no other issue before us will affect more people, for good or ill, than this search.   We must choose today between two futures: a future of sustainable growth, an expansion of world trade, and a reduction of poverty - or a future of economic stagnation, rising protectionism, and the spread of poverty.   The poorest developing countries require long-term and generous concessional aid from developed and other developing countries to raise productivity, to broadly based education and training, improvements in health, nutrition, and better infrastructure.

headline: United Offers Travel Pass
abstract: United Airlines is offerin g a sp ecial discount pass to travelers from four Southern cities in an attempt to''stimulate air travel from those cities.''   Travelers from Memphis and Knoxville, Tenn., and Birmingham and Huntsville, Ala., can buy the pass for $398 and take up to 12 flights with it, a spokesman for United said Friday.

headline: SOVIET DISMISSES TALK BY HAIG ON ARMS CURB
abstract: The Soviet Government's press agency Tass today dismissed Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s pledge to begin arms limitations talks and said the United States was trying to hide the ''aggressive'' nature of its foreign policy.   Tass also said Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's talk of confrontation was ''inflammatory'' and ''can be qualified only as a call to war.''

headline: 3 REVOLUTIONARY GUARDS SLAIN AS IRAN GOES TO POLLS fired
abstract: Three revolutionary guards were reported slain in Teheran today as Iranian voters went to the polls to decide which of four candidates will succeed the ousted President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr.   Prime Minister Mohammad Ali Rajai, supported by the ruling Moslem clergy, seemed assured of a landslide victory after his three opponents announced their support for him, although their names apparently remained on the ballot.   The state radio said other areas of the country were calm as Iranians voted ''enthusiastically'' and in great numbers.  The broadcast, monitored here, said two of the revolutionary guards were fatally shot by leftist gunmen and that a third was killed by a bomb. It added that two civilians had been killed in another bomb explosion.

headline: MRS. THATCHER, IN LIVERPOOL, URGES UNITY
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher visited Liverpool today to appeal to the people of the riot-bruised city to unite with the police to end urban violence.   Tomatoes and rolls of toilet paper were thrown at Mrs. Thatcher as she left the Liverpool town hall.  One of the tomatoes, hurled from a crowd of protesters demanding jobs, passed within inches of the Prime Minister as she stepped into her black bulletproof Jaguar. She had spent the morning meeting with local officials and touring the run-down Toxteth area, the site of the worst single riot during 10 days of disturbances - 10 days that she described as ''the most worrying'' since she took office in 1979.

headline: JULY SALES OF HOUSES UP BY 2.4%
abstract: Sales of new single-family houses recovered a bit in July, rising a seasonally adjusted 2.4 percent despite record mortgage interest rates, the departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development reported today.   However, July's sales - at an annual rate of 420,000 units - were still 33 percent below the level of July 1980, when the housing industry was pulling out of a recession.   Industry spokesmen are just beginning to talk about an end to this year's slump, but most of them say it will be early next year before interest rates fall far enough to help sales significantly.

headline: Advertising; Newspaper Ad Revenue Up an Estimated 25%
abstract: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau has reported that daily newspaper advertising revenues were up an estimated 25 percent in May, to about $1.62 billion.   Retail gained 19.7 percent and classified showed a 29.9 increase, but it was national that was the real winner, up 33.4 percent. Jack Kauffman, president of the bureau, credited the bureau's Newsplan program under which newspapers give standardized frequency discounts for the gains in national.

headline: Funds' Assets Up $2.48 Billion
abstract: Assets in money market funds rose $2.48 billion, to $152.8 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Since Jan.1, $78.2 billion has flowed into the funds, an average of $2.2 billion a week, the institute said.

headline: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CDC in Bid For Aquitaine
abstract: CDC Petroleum Inc., a diversified energy concern partially owned by the Canadian Government, said it would offer $61.65 a share (in United States currency) for all the outstanding shares of Aquitaine Company of Canada Ltd. that it does not already own.   In response to the announcement, Aquitaine shares rose 7 5/8, to 60 3/8, in heavy trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

headline: CHARITIES FAVORED IN TAX VOTE
abstract: By a vote of 97 to 1, the Senate today approved legislation that would let taxpayers who take the standard deduction on their tax returns also claim a separate deduction for charitable contributions.   The proposal was adopted as an amendment to the pending tax-relief bill. Despite the one-sided vote for the amendment, enactment this year seems uncertain. Last week the Democratic majority on the House Ways and Means Committee voted down the proposal, which charities, churches and colleges have been sponsoring since the 1970's.

headline: The Quiet Repeal
abstract: To the Business Editor: In their comment on the quiet repeal of the corporate income tax, ''Taxing Profits: The Unseen Burden'' (Aug. 16), Norman Robertson and Ronald J. Talley make much of the fact that nonfinancial corporations last year paid taxes on some $62 billion of ''phantom profits'' - the amount of Commerce Department adjustments for underdepreciation and inventory gains. They fail to mention that this sector excluded from its taxable income some $56 billion in net interest payments, most of which is a phantom expense.   This is a curious omission for two bank economists to make. Surely they can appreciate that when their employer, the Mellon Bank, lends out money at 20 percent and the inflation rate is 10 percent, the bank's real earnings on the transaction make up only half of the interest payments it receives. The remainder is not real income, because it merely compensates the bank for the declining value of principal; reckoned in constant dollars, it is return of capital.  Without the cover of inflation, it would not be a tax-deductible expense to the borrower.

headline: South Africa Coal Plan
abstract: South Africa has raised the coal export quota to 80 million tons a year from 44 million tons, the minerals and energy affairs minister, F.W. De Klerk, told Parliament today.

headline: Ladish Accepts Armco Offer
abstract: The Ladish Company, a privately held metals concern based in Cudahy, Wis., said yesterday that its board had voted to reject a $270 million takeover offer by ACF Industries in favor of a revised $286 million stock acquisition offer from Armco Inc. Armco, the nation's fifth-largest steel producer, had earlier bid $221 million for Ladish.   The acceptance of the new Armco bid was announced jointly in Milwaukee by Victor F. Braun, Ladish chairman and chief executive officer, and Harry Holiday, chief executive officer of Armco Inc.

headline: MOZAMBIQUE PILOT DEFECTS
abstract: The pilot of a Sovietbuilt MIG-17 jet fighter of the Mozambique Air Force asked for political asylum today after his plane was intercepted over South Africa, Defense Minister Magnus Malan said.  General Malan said South African fighters intercepted the plane and the pilot indicated with hand signals that he wanted to land.

headline: SPANISH PLOTTERS STIR SOME WHAT-IFS
abstract: If Gen. Jose Juste had not been wearing combat fatigues on Feb. 23, would Spain today be a military dictatorship?  Spaniards have had the occasion to pose this and a few other unsettling what-ifs and might-have-beens of history after a summer of pretrial newspaper leaks of the testimony of soldiers involved in the unsuccessful coup in February.   But the disclosures, started by defense attorneys for some of the 32 officers accused in the plot, appear to have backfired. Instead of high-minded patriots, the defendants emerge from their pretrial depositions as incompetent and undecided plotters, unwilling finally to assume responsibility for their botched enterprise.   And, with their court-martial nearing, the principal defendants have been unable to marshal any proof for their contention that King Juan Carlos was somehow involved in the plot. The testimony makes it clear that the King was surprised by the rebellion and had a major hand in stopping it.

headline: The U.N. Today; July 15, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: International conference on Cambo- dia - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Around the World; Iran Reports Attacking Leftist Guerrillas
abstract: Iran's revolutionary guards attacked a hide-out of the leftist Mujahedeen guerrillas in suburban Teheran early today, the Teheran radio reported.

headline: COALITION RESIGNS IN BELGIUM OVER AID TO A STEEL COMPANY
abstract: Belgium's center-left coalition Cabinet resigned tonight after it was unable to resolve an internal dispute over how to finance the nation's troubled steel industry.   The Royal Palace said Prime Minister Marc Eyskens handed in the resignation of his five-month-old administration, and King Baudouin accepted it. The King asked Mr. Eyskens's Government to stay on in a caretaker capacity.

headline: TERRORISM COURTS ASSAILED IN ULSTER
abstract: The judge, resplendent in a scarlet robe, sits facing the defendant, who is guarded by two policemen. The lawyers wear curly gray wigs and starchy white dickeys, and the crier opens the trial by intoning, ''God Save the Queen!''   In short, it looks just like any other courtroom in Britain with one major exception - the jury box is always empty.  These are Northern Ireland's antiterrorism courts, where bombers and gunmen are tried, without juries.  Long an object of concern among civil libertarians, the courts are central to the Northern Ireland conflict and to the prison hunger strike in which 10 men have died since May.

headline: ROLE REVERSAL IN THE REA GAN CABINET
abstract: The two men seem to enjoy their role reversal. After a lifetime in the Army, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. displays fondness for stylishly cut, diplomatically striped suits. He delights in lecturing on the nuances of foreign policy.   Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, the career civilian, relishes slogging around military installations to watch firepower exercises, his Presidential cuff links and white shirt camouflaged beneath an infantry outfit. Always the gentleman, he apologized the other day to one G.I. after ''shooting'' the soldier in a demonstration of a new laser target system.   Mr. Weinberger is bemused by his growing reputation as Washington's leading hawk. ''I can't believe I am the heavy,'' he says with an airy laugh. ''I don't feel like the heavy.''

headline: Minnesota's Bonds Lowered
abstract: Minnesota, where state workers have gone out on strike for higher pay, had its bond ratings lowered yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.   Minnesota plans to sell $63 million in bonds next week, and analysts said the downgrading could raise the interest expense on the offering by as much $126,000 a year.

headline: OFFICIAL SAYS U.S. WILL BE NEUTRAL ON SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today that despite its opposition to South Africa's racial separation policies, it would not take sides between blacks and whites in that country or try to undermine the South African Government ''in order to curry favor elsewhere.''   In the Administration's most comprehensive statement on its southern Afri- Excerpts from speech are on page 18. ca policies, Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said the United States wanted to remain neutral between South Africa and black countries to be in a better position to pursue diplomatic solutions and to protect Western strategic and economic interests in the region.   ''We cannot and will not permit our hand to be forced to align ourselves with one side or another in these disputes,'' Mr. Crocker said to an American Legion meeting in Honolulu. The text was released in advance by the State Department. Officials said it had been cleared at the highest levels of the Administration.

headline: Bairnco Ends Bid for Ludlow
abstract: The Bairnco Corporation dropped its $90 million bid for the Ludlow Corporation after Tyco Laboratories Inc., which owns nearly 30 percent of Ludlow, increased its offer for the rest of the company.   Bairnco said in a statement that it had told Ludlow, a furniture and packaging concern based in Needham Heights, Mass., it was dropping its bid ''in view of Tyco Laboratories' subsequent proposal to acquire Ludlow.''

headline: CAMBEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GEORGES BANK START BY EXXON
abstract: The Exxon Company U.S.A. drove a steel shaft into the ocean floor off the coast of New England and became the first company to start exploratory drilling for oil and gas in the Georges Bank fishing grounds.   ''We began spudding at 1:45 A.M.,'' said Jack McDonnell, an Exxon spokesman in Florham Park, N.J. ''That's the first step for drilling.''

headline: CHILDREN'S PLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: For Airline Boredom, Plastic Slot Machines
abstract: A new concept for in-flight entertainment was added today when the first jetliner to be fitted with slot machines took off for San Francisco from Singapore.

headline: PLAYBOY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Currency Markets; DOLLAR MIXED ABROAD; GOLD PRICES OFF SLIGHTLY
abstract: The dollar was mixed on European currency exchanges yesterday, and a London dealer described trading as nervous. Gold was little changed.

headline: A MAVERICK QUITS PABST BOARD
abstract: When Irwin L. Jacobs, the 39-year old Minneapolis multimillionaire, elbowed his way onto the Pabst Brewing Company board, he was viewed as an unfriendly interloper, at best.   As owner of about 10 percent of Pabst's outstanding shares, Mr.  Jacobs, who made his fortune by buying failing or bankrupt companies, first demanded last summer that he be named chairman and that four of his associates be named directors. He settled for a lone board seat for himself.   Now, Mr. Jacobs is giving up that seat. But in doing so, he has issued heated statements indicating that his battle with the nation's third-largest brewer - behind Anheuser-Busch Inc. and the Miller Brewing Company - is far from over.

headline: SALVADORANS HELD ON COAST AS ALIENS ASK REAGAN FOR ASYLUM
abstract: A group of 150 Salvadoran refugees, some of whom had been held as illegal aliens for as long as nine months, petitioned President Reagan today for political asylum.   Until Monday, 87 of the refugees had been held in several Federal detention centers in southern California. Their release came through the efforts of several religious and political organizations.

headline: Commodities; A Strong Comeback For Silver
abstract: WHATEVER fundamental or technical factors may have provoked the remarkable rebound in silver prices this month, they have sent the metal soaring from a two-year low of $8.52 an ounce last July 31 to $9.60 at last Friday's spot (cash) quote in New York.   The advance since July 31 has been particularly impressive because many of the silver bulls of past years had become disenchanted with the metal since it broke $10 late last June. Last week alone, the believers holding silver futures saw them rise 56 cents.   Each one-cent move in silver represents $50 per contract of 5,000 ounces. On New York's Commodity Exchange, the biggest metals futures market, the minimum initial margin calls for $1,500 in cash. However, most brokers require somewhat more money.

headline: News conference excerpts, page A10.
abstract: The commander of the Sixth Fleet said today that American fighters intercepted Libyan aircraft on 45 occasions during manuevers last week, but had not fired on them until two Libyan SU-22's fired at two Navy F-14's.   The commander of the fleet, Vice Adm. William H. Rowden, also said at a news conference aboard the U.S.S. Nimitz, that the air battle Wednesday that resulted in the shooting down of the two Libyan airplanes took place slightly outside a ''designated'' area where the United States had said manuevers were taking place, but still well within international waters. The Nimitz is anchored about seven miles from here in the Bay of Naples below Mount Vesuvius.

headline: Health Officials Adopt Plan for the Americas
abstract: Health ministers from the 35 nations in the Pan American Health Organization approved a plan today aimed at insuring access to health care for all 900 million people expected to be living in the Western Hemisphere in the year 2,000.   The plan sets minimum regional health goals for life expectancy, infant mortality, immunization, drinking water, sewage disposal and extension of health services.

headline: Aqua-Chem Buyer
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company said it had agreed to sell its Aqua-Chem Inc. subsidiary to Societe Lyonnaise des Eaux et de l'Eclairage, a Paris-based company, for an undisclosed amount of cash. Completion of the sale is expected in the third quarter of 1981, the Atlanta-based company said. Aqua-Chem, with headquarters in Milwaukee, had sales of $130 million in 1980.

headline: Careers; Real Estate Appraisers In Demand
abstract: THE fine art of real estate appraising depends on the eye of the beholder, which is why two or more appraisals are often made of the same property.   With housing in a slump because of high mortgage rates, the question arises whether this is a good time to become an appraiser.  ''Yes,'' says Richard L. Bartsch, vice president, home sales division, of the Midlantic Mortgage Corporation, a unit of Midlantic, a large New Jersey bank. The corporation does relocation work for companies moving executives.

headline: Briefs
abstract: * Allied Corp. said it has purchased a one-fifth interest in Calgene Inc. The price was not disclosed.   * American Can Co. increased its loan agreements with 15 banks to $570 million from $320 million.

headline: Soviet Rescues U.S. Boat
abstract: The Soviet trawler Betelgeuse has rescued the crew of a disabled American fishing boat, the Lat Windjammer, that drifted in the Atlantic Ocean for five days without food and water, the Soviet press agency Tass said today. The trawler radioed the news to the Baltic port of Kaliningrad, Tass said.

headline: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * First Interstate Bancorp, Los Angeles, has elected to its board Warren Christopher, a former United States Deputy Secretary of State.

headline: TAIWAN'S AID TO REFUGEES GOES UNRECOGNIZED
abstract: In the flow of statistics from the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to record the number o people fleeing from Indochina, more than 12,000 men, women and children have never been taken into account.  They are the Vietnamese and ethnic Chinese form Vietnam who have made their way to Taiwan.   Because Nationalist China is no longer a member of the United Nations, the High Commissioner's headquarters in Geneva and its offices throughout Asia have chosen to ignore those refugees.

headline: ANCIENT ICE YIELDING SECRETS OF CLIMATE
abstract: An international team of scientists is reading, in six-foot cylinders of ice, the story of the snows that fell when Cro-Magnon artists were painting the images of prehistoric animals on the walls of French caves.   In a highly elaborate and sophisticated experiment, the scientists have drilled almost to the bottom of the Greenland ice sheet, extracting remnants of the snows that built the great mass of ice that bulldozed the Northern Hemisphere more than 60,000 years ago.   By yesterday afternoon they had penetrated to 6,687 feet and were drilling through ice made milky by rock ''flour,'' ground from the bedrock by the enormous burden of creeping ice. Two days earlier, at a depth of 6,455 feet, they penetrated a silty layer perhaps scraped off some summit. May Be 100,000 Years Old   Then 130 feet of clear ice was drilled before they reached the milky layer. The scientists said they expected very soon to hit bottom, where the ice may date back 100,000 years to a warm period before the last Ice Age.

headline: Around the World; AFGHAN REBELS REPORTED TO KILL 27 KARMAL AIDES
abstract: Afghan rebels have killed 27 senior members of President Babrak Karmal's National Fatherland Front since it was founded last month, a source from Kabul said today.

headline: BANK AMERICA, 2 OTHERS POST EARNINGS DECLINES
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation and the Continental Illinois Corporation yesterday reported sharply lower net operating earnings for the second quarter of 1981, compared with the second quarter in 1980.   BankAmerica Corp. The BankAmerica Corporation reported that its net operating earnings, before securities transactions, declined by 29.4 percent, to $122.5 million, or 83 cents a share, from $173.6 million, or $1.18 a share, in the second quarter of 1980.   Samuel H. Armacost, president, attributed much of the decline to a smaller profit margin between the average rate paid by BankAmerica for its funds and the average yield on its loans and investments. The margin dropped to 3.18 percent in the second quarter of 1981 from 3.30 percent in the period a year earlier.

headline: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ENVIROTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: North Korea Charges Spying
abstract: The North Korean press agency said a United States SR-71 ''spy plane'' infiltrated North Korean airspace today to commit espionage.

headline: CHICAGO OPENS C.D. TRADING
abstract: Trading opened today in domestic certificates of deposit on the Chicago Board of Trade, marking the start of an intense battle for dominance of the market.   The Board of Trade competes directly with the New York Futures Exchange, a unit of the New York Stock Exchange, where C.D. trading started two weeks ago. And the rival Chicago Mercantile Exchange will enter the market next week.

headline: f4; EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Aluminum Company of America named Marvin E. Gantz Jr. a director and vice chairman of the board. * Colgate-Palmolive Company appointed Thomas M. Casey a director.

headline: A VIETNAMESE ORPHAN TELLS OF KILLINGS AND CANNIBALISM IN 52-DAY SEA ESCARE
abstract: Dao Van Cu is a 15-year-old Vietnamese orphan whose ribs, collarbone and shoulder blades protrude from his emaciated body so sharply that one fears they will cut through his skin. His head is swathed in a large bandage, and his body is marked with angry scars.   The doctor at the refugee detention center told him that he had gained two pounds since he arrived eight days ago, which brought his weight up to 68 pounds.   When he fled Vietnam with a group of fishermen in June, he weighed nearly 100 pounds. They were at sea in a small boat for 52 days, according to the adults. Of 11 people aboard, 5 reached safety.

headline: ISRAEL TIGHTENS EMIGRE POLICY
abstract: Israel has moved to make it more difficult for Jewish emigrants arriving in Vienna from the Soviet Union to go anywhere else but Israel.   Nearly 85 percent of the emigrants reaching Vienna with visas for Israel have gone elsewhere in recent months.

headline: Patents; New Method Devised For Culturing Microbes
abstract: Corning Glass Works, Corning, N. Y., received a patent this week on a method for the continuous culturing of microbes.

headline: STRUTHERS OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: World's Fastest Train Opens French Service
abstract: The world's fastest train, looking like a jet plane without wings, raced quietly like an orange flash through the French countryside today at speeds of up to 156 miles per hour on its inaugural run from Paris to Lyons.   The bullet-nosed train made the 300-mile trip in 2 hours, 32 minutes - an hour and 12 minutes faster than a regular express and even quicker than a plane when trips to the airport are taken into account.

headline: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DEFINING AN ESTATE TAX LIMIT
abstract: ''By taxing estates heavily at death, the state marks its condemnation of the selfish millionaire's unworth life.'' - Andrew Carnegie, 1889, industrialist, multimillionaire, philanthropist, advocate of estate taxes.   ''Current estate and gift tax law imposes almost impossible burdens on the most productive sector of the economy.'' - Testimony to Congress, 1981, by Robert L. Spence, chairman of the National Committee to Preserve the Family Business.   WASHINGTON, July 5 - The problem of heeding both Mr. Carnegie and Mr. Spence is before Congress this year as it considers how much to relax the Federal tax on transfers of wealth by inheritance and giftgiving.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: * Allegheny Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company, Baltimore, has appointed James P. Sheridan vice president for manufacturing.   * Bank of New York has elected Jeannette Hobson, Santo F. Manata and Richard S. Szaro vice presidents.

headline: Weinberger on London Trip
abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W.  Weinberger will fly to London tonight for another in a series of private talks with the British Defense Minister, John Nott, Pentagon officials said. They said Mr. Weinberger would arrive in London tomorrow morning and meet Mr. Nott in the afternoon. He plans to return to Washington Sunday.

headline: PEKING IS USING A WRITER'S FAME TO CONTROL ARTS
abstract: The Communist Party chose the occasion of the centennial of the birth one of China's greatest 20th-century writers, Lu Hsun, to warn the country's writers and artists that it will brook no opposition to its rule and tolerate no criticism of its dictates.   In the party's sharpest attack on free expression and dissent since China's present leadership assumed power, Hu Yaobang, the party chairman, railed against the ''bourgeois liberalism'' and ''pernicious writing'' that he said cast doubt on the supreme virtues of communism and socialism.   The criticism by one of China's senior rulers, most Western diplomats agreed, effectively ended a yearlong debate on how much individual creativity in the arts the party would tolerate. 'Wrong Trends and Approaches'   ''How can the people of our country tolerate the wrong trends and approaches to writing just described?'' Mr. Hu said, addressing 6,000 people from cultural circles who gathered last Friday in the Great Hall of the People. ''We should all come forward to criticize and resist works of this kind as well as those who thrust them on the public, especially on young readers with little experience of life.''

headline: The U.N. Today; Sept. 21, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: Seoul Charges 7 in a Family With Spying for North Korea
abstract: Seven members of a South Korean family face charges that they were involved in providing North Korea with military and economic information through clandestine radio transmissions for the last 24 years, the Agency for National Security Planning said today.

headline: PRESIDENT OF BOLIVIA RESIGNS IN FACE OF REVOLT
abstract: Bolivia, Aug. 4 (AP) - Gen. Luis Garcia Meza, bowing to the demands of army rebels, resigned today as President and asked the military junta to govern.   In a broadcast from the presidential palace, General Garcia Meza said: ''Above any reasons of pride and vanity comes the fatherland. For this reason I have decided to turn power over to the junta of commanders.''

headline: Talking Business with Trautlein of Bethlehem Steel; For Big Steel, New Troubles
abstract: After a strong first half of steel shipments, steel executives were hoping that the trend would continue to the end of the year.  Instead, demand in recent weeks has fallen off and the companies were forced to rescind a price increase on tin plate, though they are still seeking to push through increases on other products. Last week the industry was jolted again as steel imports for July came in at a high level, accounting for about 20 percent of the domestic steel market. Donald H. Trautlein, an accountant by training, joined the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in 1977, when it was coping with a severe downturn. Three years later Mr. Trautlein, who is 55 years old, took over as chairman of Bethlehem. Here, he discusses the uncertain state of the industry as it enters another downturn.   Q. Does the downturn look modest or could it be long and severe?

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bristol-Myers Co. has elected Marion A. Klein vice presidentmarket research and Patrick F. Crossman vice president-corporate affairs.   * Corroon & Black Corp. has appointed Frank Eblen president and chief executive officer of its newly formed Corporate Energy Resources Services.

headline: BARBER-GREENE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 6
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CAUTIOUS OPTIMISM ON BONDS
abstract: The trend t oward lower short-term interest rates has aroused some cautious opti mism in the bond market.  Securities dealers are still concerned that heavy borrowing by the Government co mbined with a growing economy would mean higher interestrates, but a few suggest that the near-term outlook is for lower rates. Whethe r a rate decline can be sustained into 1982 is much disputed.

headline: CENTURY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Iran Cancels 1954 Oil Pacts
