abstract: Iran has canceled all contracts signed with multinational oil companies before the 1979 Islamic revolution, the Iranian Oil Ministry announced today.   The announcement, carried by the official Iranian press agency, said the contracts had been signed with American, British, Dutch and French companies in 1954.

headline: EXERPTS FROM VIEWS EXPRESSED BY HAIG
abstract: Following are excerpts from a transcript of an interview with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. last night:   Southern Africa We've got to dedicate ourselves -and this is the President's instructions to me - to achieving real results, and we're going to be measured in the final analysis by the nonaligned and by the frontline states on that. Not on our rhetoric, and not on our United Nations voting record. I think everyone is hostage to South Africa's willingness to make concessions or to take risks for peace.   Our burden - and it's a burden that history placed on our shoulders - is that probably the United States and our contact group friends are the only ones able to influence South African attitudes constructively in that direction, and the United States is the most important.

headline: MASSMUTUAL CORPORATE INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Scene; The Thatcher Plan's Failure
abstract: A SPECTER is haunting the Reagan Administration: Thatcherism. The riots in Liverpool this week, stemming partly from the worst unemployment Britain has experienced since the Depression of the 1930's, are grim evidence of the failure of what was once regarded as a brilliant innovation in economic policy.   When Mrs. Thatcher became Prime Minister in May 1979, she was the darling of conservatives on both sides of the Atlantic. Today, she faces a revolt in her own party and has been disowned by the Reaganites in Washington, who say she departed from and made a mess of what initially was a correct solution to the twin problems of inflation and industrial stagnation.   But was her fault one of execution or were there inherent inconsistencies and contradictions in the Thatcher program that the Reagan Administration is on the way to repeating?

headline: LOSS LEADS AM TO SELL TWO UNITS
abstract: AM International Inc. announced yesterday that it would report a loss of $175 million in the 1981 fiscal year and that it planned to sell its Addressograph and Jacquard divisions to relieve its debtladen balance sheet.   Analysts called the size of the loss surprising, but said the sale of two more divisions was consistent with the policy of Richard B.  Black, chairman, to cut away unprofitable lines to create a solid base upon which to rebuild the office equipment manufacturer. President Resigns   Mr. Black, who assumed control of AM International last February, replacing Roy L. Ash, also announced that James R. Mellor, president, had resigned, following the announcement of the 1981 losses.

headline: BRITISH AIRWAYS LOST $254 MILLION FOR YEAR
abstract: British Airways, the Government-owned airline, today reported a $254 million loss for the fiscal year ended March 31 in contrast to a $37 million profit in the 1980 fiscal year.   Sir John King, chairman of the airline, said at a news conference that the company was considering cutting unprofitable routes. He also announced plans to lay off 9,000 workers from the company's total work force of 52,500.

headline: 20 IRAN PILGRIMS AT SAUDI SHRINE REPORTED HURT IN CLASH WITH POLICE
abstract: Twenty Iranian pilgrims were reportedly injured in Medina, Saudi Arabia, today in clashes with policemen at Islam's second holiest site, the traditional burial place of Mohammed.   The fighting, which was reported by the Teheran radio, came a day after the Saudi authorities were said to have turned back about 80 Iranians at the beginning of the annual hajj, or pilgrimage, season because they were carrying portraits of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.  An Iranian state television crew was also turned away and its equipment seized, according to the radio.

headline: Army Drafts Ayer Again
abstract: The United States Army still wants N.W. Ayer. The Army Recruiting Command announced yesterday that, after considering a bid by Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, it has again chosen as its agency N.W. Ayer Inc., which has been handling its advertising since 1967.

headline: AMERICAN TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CO INC (AT& reports earnings for Qtr to Aug
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SMITHKLINE PACT
abstract: Japan's Fujisawa Pharmaceutical Company Ltd. and the Smithkline Corporation of Philadelphia have agreed to form a joint venture company in Philadelphia to develop and market pharmaceuticals in the United States, Fujisawa said.

headline: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: United American Has New System
abstract: The United American Service Corporation said that it had developed a new computer system, using an I.B.M. Displaywriter, that will be sold to banks for use by small businesses and professionals.   United American, a privately held concern based in Knoxville, Tenn., said that the new service, called Business Manager, would enable smaller businesses to perform most cash management and routine banking in their own offices 24 hours a day.

headline: Around the World; African Leaders Meet On Western Sahara War
abstract: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya opened a two-day meeting of African leaders today on the war between Morocco and guerrillas in Western Sahara.   Mr. Moi is chairman of the Organization of African Unity, which arranged the meeting to try to end the war.

headline: NATIONAL RETAIL SALES ROSE BY 0.6% IN AUGUST
abstract: Sales by the nation's retail merchants rose a modest six-tenths of 1 percent in August, a performance that did not keep pace with inflation, the Commerce Department reported today.   The department also revised its original report on July retail sales. Instead of climbing a brisk 1.3 percent in comparison with June, sales in July declined by three-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: POLAND'S PREMEIR SAYS SOME PRICES WILL RISE BY 110%
abstract: Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski told Poland's emergency Communist Party congress today that the price of food, coal, natural gas and housing would have to be increased 110 percent and that wage increases would have to end.   Coming after the congress's five days of heady experimentation with democracy, General Jaruzelski's speech, which included wide ranging remarks on the state of the nation, was a sobering and harsh reminder that the Government's primary task now was to consider the country's quickening economic, social and political crisis.   The Prime Minister's speech also came a day after Stanislaw Kania's decisive re-election as the party First Secretary and on the day that a new, politically balanced Politburo was named.   General Jaruzelski, dressed in full military uniform, read out a list of stark realities confronting the nation: threatened strikes, growing consumer shortages, crumbling law and order, declining production.

headline: MOBIL JOINS CONOCO QUEST WITH $3.92 BILLION BID
abstract: The Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil company, yesterday joined the bidding war for Conoco Inc., the ninth-largest, with a bid of $90 a share in cash for 43.5 million shares, for a total of $3.92 billion.   Mobil, which is seeking 51 percent of Conoco's outstanding shares, had been preparing for the bid this week and, according to banking sources, has negotiated $5 billion of credit to finance the offer.   Directors of Conoco, which is also the nation's second-largest coal producer, have endorsed a competing bid of $7.6 billion by E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the largest American chemical company.

headline: SAUDI ARMS SALE TO GO TO CONGRESS ON AUG. 24
abstract: A White House official said today that President Reagan would give Congress written notice on Aug. 24 of his intention to sell Saudi Arabia a $5 billion package of advanced military aircraft and aircraft equipment.   Max L. Friedersdorf, assistant to the President for Congressional affairs, made the announcement at a breakfast meeting at the headquarters of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. Other officials privately confirmed Mr. Friedersdorf's statement.

headline: ANGER OVER FOOD SPREADS IN POLAND
abstract: Wildcat strikes broke out here today to protest shortages of food and a 20 percent cut in the meat ration.  Workers in this city, Poland's second largest, conducted their third protest march this week.  In the Baltic port of Gdansk, members of the Solidarity union leadership met to discuss the spreading protests.  ''I can't believe I'm in Poland,'' a Lodz woman said as she watched a procession of 53 trucks and heavy-duty vehicles lumber down Piotrkowska Street, blasting their horns and paralyzing the city center for three hours.

headline: DOW UP BY 5.7% IN 2D QUARTER; SCHERING-PLOUGH DOWN 20.9%
abstract: The Dow Chemical Company, the country's second-largest chemical concern after E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, announced yesterday that gains by the bulk of its foreign operations caused net income in the second quarter to increase by 5.7 percent while sales climbed 21.8 percent.   The Midland, Mich., company said that earnings in the latest three months expanded to $181 million, or 96 cents a share, from $171.2 million, or 94 cents a share, in the corresponding three months of 1980. Sales widened to $3.07 billion from $2.52 billion.   Robert M. Keil, Dow's financial vice president, said that there was an upturn during the spring in economic conditions in most of the countries in which Dow operates and that both unit volume and prices also increased during the latest three months.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Applied Data Research Inc. filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 450,000 shares of Class B common stock. The underwriting will be managed by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp.

headline: Advertising; Soft Sell A Secret Document
abstract: THE latest captured document from the advertising wars is a strategic treatise about the soft-sell commercial. It was taken from a straggler who was left behind in the Hamptons after Labor Day.   Internal evidence indicates that the 15-page document was compiled in recent months by McCollum/Spielman, a communications research organization that wields influence along the jungle highway that has become known as ''Mad Ave.'' Its president is known to be Donald H.  McCollum, a former Armed Forces photographer who is a persuasive orator at industry conclaves.

headline: HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Anaconda Industries has named presidents at five operating units: Marlan T. Boultinghouse, at Anaconda American Brass; John P. Foss, Centrifugal Inc.; Richard J. Rothen, General Casting; Gerald A.  Scutt, Anaconda Metal Hose, and Harold M. Wenzel, Anaconda Magnet Wire.   * Ayco Corp. announced that Thomas H. Lynch was joining the company as senior vice president and general counsel.   * Bio-Medical Sciences has elected Joseph DeClemente executive vice president.

headline: SOME ABUSES FADE IN BOLIVIA, BUT TORTURE GOES ON
abstract: The rats running over his face still haunt him.  He is a priest who was taken from his church here two months ago by agents from the Government's Special Security Service. They took him to an interrogation center on an ordinary looking block guarded by policemen at each end in a neighborhood of expensive homes and embassies.   A muscular interrogator called Turco punched him in the kidneys, so that to lie down was painful and to urinate excruciating. That night the guards threw water on the floor, turning the straw on which he tried to sleep into ice.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: No Headline
abstract: Cuba said today that its troops in Angola would go into action if South African forces approached Cuban positions there.   An official note published in the newspaper Granma said: ''If South African columns approach lines defended by Cuban internationalist combatants, our troops, fulfilling the obligation of solidarity of our country with the sister republic of Angola, will go into action with all means available.''

headline: Briefs
abstract: * Anixter Brothers Inc. agreed to buy Automatic Equipment Development Corp. of West Haven, Conn., for about $10 million in common stock.   * Canada Wire and Cable Co., a unit of Noranda Mines Ltd., agreed to acquire Carol Cable Co. for $110 million in cash and $30 million in seven-year, 10 percent notes.   * Coastal Corp. said it will start construction in August on a $55 million program to upgrade the Wichita, Kan., refinery owned by its Derby Refining Co. unit.

headline: THE 'COMING' COLLAPSE IS ALREADY HERE
abstract: E VERY week the real estate sections of Sunday papers and Realtors' multiple listing books announce major economic news that should shock or excite millions of Americans. But no one is listening or reading between the lines. After 35 years of ever increasing home values, prices are coming down, and they are falling fast and far enough to bruise a lot of homeowners.   Everyone has become transfixed by how the ''median-priced'' house, now around $70,000, is no longer within reach of most Americans. But more significant is the death of real estate sales.

headline: De Beers Posts Drop in Profits
abstract: The world's leading diamond mining concern, the De Beers Mining Company, today announced a sharp drop in net profits for the first six months of this year, reflecting a slump in sales of precious stones in the United States and Europe.

headline: Monetarism
abstract: To the Business Editor: Jude Wanniski's article, ''The Burden of Friedman's Monetarism'' (July 26), demonstrates his lack of understanding of basic monetarist concepts. He places the proverbial cart before the horse in assuming that monetarists demand a floating dollar.

headline: Correction
abstract: A recent Personal Finance column incorrectly described the maximum contributions that self-employed persons can make to Keogh retirement plans. Currently, they can contribute $7,500 a year, or 15 percent of their first $100,000 in net income, whichever is less.

headline: Times Mirror Earnings Rise
abstract: The Times Mirror Company, owner of The Los Angeles Times and The Denver Post newspapers, said today that its second-quarter earnings rose to $38.5 million, or $1.13 a share, on revenues of $539.5 million.   In the same quarter last year, the company earned $35.8 million, or $1.05 a share, on revenues of $517.8 million.

headline: Swiss Rock Slide Kills 6
abstract: EMS, Switzerland, July 25 (AP) - Earth and rock apparently loosened by several days of heavy rains crashed down on a tent at a campsite, killing five girls and their 18-year-old leader, the police said. All the victims of last night's rock slide at the campsite about two miles outside Domat-Ems in eastern Switzerland were Swiss.

headline: LISBON'S EX-PREMIER URGED TO RETURN
abstract: Francisco Pinto Balsemao, who resigned last week as Portugal's Prime Minister, was given an overwhelming vote of confidence by the Social Democratic Party's leadership today and invited to resume the post.   The vote in the 74-member National Council, the governing body of the Social Democratic Party, the largest in Portugal's ruling coalition, was 58 to 1, with 3 abstentions and 12 delegates not voting. Mr. Balsemao resigned last Tuesday after the council gave him only a 37-to-15 vote of confidence and criticized him for not governing with enough authority.   Mr. Balsemao told the leadership after today's vote that he would announce his decision Wednesday on whether to accept the new mandate, but most political sources said they expected him to accept and continue as Prime Minister.

headline: HOUSE LEADERSHIP MAY LET TAX CUTS INCLUDE 3D YEAR
abstract: Two Southern Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee indicated today that the leadership was ready to let the House add a third year of cuts in individual income tax rates to the two-year bill being drafted by the committee.   The two Democrats, Ed Jenkins of Georgia and Ken Holland of South Carolina, have been working closely with the Ways and Means chairman, Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, to avert outright   Americans' confidence in Social Security is dwindling, and a majority expect the system to be short of funds, a Times/CBS Poll finds. Page A12. defeat of the bill when it reaches the House floor at the end of this month.

headline: POLISH AND SOVIET CHIEFS HOLD 'FRIENDLY' MEETING
abstract: Poland's Communist Party leader, Stanislaw Kania, paid a flying visit to the Crimea today for what the official press agency Tass described as a ''friendly working visit'' with the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev.   Less than 12 hours after Tass announced the arrival of Mr. Kania and Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish Prime Minister and Defense Minister, the Soviet agency issued a brief report saying that the two sides had met in the presence of aides and agreed on a communique.  Tass said the communique would be published tomorrow.   The visit, the briefest of any that a succession of Soviet-bloc leaders have paid to Mr. Brezhnev in recent weeks at his Crimean vacation retreat, came at a time when Poland's leaders have been under increasing Soviet pressure to crack down on the independent trade union Solidarity.

headline: SYRIA ENDS SIEGE OF LEBANESE TOWN, RAISING HOPE FOR AN EASING OF CRISIS
abstract: Lebanese Christian militiamen rode out of the battle-weary town of Zahle near here early today as a 91-day Syrian siege ended, bringing a glimmer of hope for the easing of the crisis over the stationing of Syrian missiles nearby.   The militiamen were taken in six gray Lebanese police buses past lines of Syrian soldiers and later turned over to Phalangist Party leaders under an agreement worked out over the last few weeks primarily by an Arab League committee consisting of Syria, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. The agreement was completed early today.   Witnesses reported that Zahle residents, tired of three months of artillery and sniper fire, tossed flowers and rice at the first of the 600 Lebanese policemen entering the city to replace the Christian Phalangists.

headline: SALVADORAN RIGHT SEEKS MORE POWER
abstract: A group of conservative Salvadoran business leaders, encouraged by what they say are clear signs of support from the Reagan Administration, have intensified a long-running campaign to change the makeup of the Government of President Jose Napoleon Duarte.   The business leaders said they wanted to name at least one additional member of the ruling junta and several Cabinet ministers.  The civilian-military junta headed by Mr. Duarte now consists of four members.   The businessmen, who include corporate executives, hotel and resort owners and the president of El Salvador's Chamber of Commerce, said the clearest signal for their effort had come in a speech in Washington last week by the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Thomas O. Enders.

headline: THE TAX LAW: TROUBLE FOR COLLECTIBLES
abstract: I NDIVIDUALS who have increasingly been placing investment-grade stamps, coins, diamonds, art works and other collectibles in their Individual Retirement Accounts and Keogh plans will not be able to do so because of a little known clause in the Reagan Administration's new tax-cut bill.   Under the new tax law, these alternative investments will be treated as ''distributions'' for income tax purposes; that is, taxed as short- or long-term gains. It is an ironic twist since the new tax law raises the amount that investors can put in I.R.A. accounts to $2,000 a year from $1,500, while doubling the limit on Keogh plans to $15,000 a year.   How the Internal Revenue Service will treat existing accounts with collectibles is still not clear. However, a Treasury official said last week that that issue would have to be resolved by Dec. 31, when the new rule goes into effect.

headline: Economic Scene
abstract: Falling stock and bond prices, persistently high interest rates, a widening budget gap and fears that worse inflation may lie ahead have forced President Reagan to reconsider his planned buildup in military spending.   Thus far the White House is talking about relatively small trims, amounting at most to $15 billion in each of the next three years. If fully carried out, those trims would still permit the Pentagon's budget to rise by $15 billion in 1982, $25 billion in 1983 and $42 billion in 1984. Beyond 1984, the costs of the military buildup would climb a lot faster - by $81 billion in 1985 and by $117.7 billion in 1986. Total miltary outlays in the next five years are scheduled to exceed $1.4 trillion.

headline: Coffee Nations Set Up Survey
abstract: The 47 coffee-growing nations in the International Coffee Organization set up a group today to survey world markets.   The group will examine world demand by type, quality and use as roasted or instant.

headline: COLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Moscow, in Retaliation, Expels British Diplomat
abstract: The Soviet Union has asked a British diplomat to leave Moscow in retaliation for the expulsion from Britain of a second secretary at the Soviet Embassy in London, the British Foreign Office said today.   Britain expelled Viktor Lazin this month because of ''activities incompatible with his status as a diplomat.'' The Foreign Office said that John Gordon, the cultural attache in Moscow, had been asked to leave in retaliation.  Mr. Gordon, 41 years old, was believed to be on vacation in Britain with his wife.

headline: Andrew Field Plan Postponed by B.P.
abstract: The British Petroleum Company said it had postponed its plans to develop the Andrew oil field in the North Sea because proposed changes in Britain's tax laws would make the project economically marginal.   B.P. had intended to submit its development plans to the Department of Energy before the end of this year, and to begin production in 1984 or 1985, with the total cost estimated at about $1.9 billion.

headline: U.N. LAW OF SEA PARLEY ENDS '81 SESSION ON CONFIDENT NOTE
abstract: A United Nations conference that has been at work for nearly eight years ended its 1981 session today by vowing to complete work at a meeting in New York next spring on a global charter governing uses of the seas' resources.   The adjournment came with the 146 nations still not assured that the United States will return to the negotiating table after having abstained from talks here and in New York earlier this year.

headline: INLAND STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: People
abstract: * Richard Chrampanis named advertising director of Co-Ed and Forecast magazines.   * Frederick W. Sturges named associate publisher in charge of national advertising for Oui magazine.

headline: People
abstract: * Jerry Calabrese named publisher of Games magazine, published by Playboy Enterprises.   * Fred Goldberg has been appointed senior vice president of domestic advertising and Lloyd Leipzig senior vice president of domestic publicity for the Orion Pictures Company.

headline: Pillsbury Net Off
abstract: The Pillsbury Company, a major producer of convenience foods and food mixes, reported yesterday that net income in the first fiscal quarter fell 12.9 percent, to $25 million, or $1.16 a share, from $28.7 million, or $1.43 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

headline: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Rise in U.S.  Drilling Seen
abstract: The Hughes Tool Company said today that it expected drilling activity in the United States to be about 35 percent higher in 1981 than in 1980.   The company, which monitors domestic drilling activity and publishes its reports, said that it did not know of any cutbacks in 1981 drilling plans despite the oil surplus, and noted that several major oil companies had used the debt markets to help finance their drilling budgets.

headline: Money Funds' Assets Increase Increase
abstract: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds climbed $3.42 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the 16th consecutive weekly increase, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. Investors a re attracted to the higher yields paid by the money funds, compar ed with other investment instruments such as six-month savings certi ficates.

headline: BONN IS NOW HELD UNLIKELY TO SELL ARMS TO SAUDI ARABIA
abstract: BONN. Sept. 24 - The West German Government has effectively dropped consideration of a Saudi Arabian order for advanced weapon systems, including the Leopard 2 tank, an authoritative source said today.   The source, who requested anonymity, said the deal had insufficient backing in both the parties of the West German Government coalition, the Social Democrats and the Free Democrats.   The Government, he said, is facing a battle over the deployment of new middle-range nuclear missiles in West Germany and feels that it would be squandering its strength to attempt to deal with a second major issue involving arms, international security and emotional public debate.

headline: 2 More Banks Set 20% Prime
abstract: The Crocker National Bank in San Francisco, the nation's 12thlargest commercial bank, and UMB Bank and Trust of New York lowered their prime lending rates yesterday to 20 percent from 20 1/2 percent, joining three other leading banks that made the move in the la st two weeks.   On Friday, the Marine Midland Bank of Buffalo, the nation's 14thlargest commercial bank, lowered its prime rate to 20 percent from 20 1/2 per cent.

headline: Poland Averts a Strike And Sets Union Talks
abstract: The Polish Government averted a strike in the city of Radom today. At the same time, it agreed to negotiate with Solidarity, the independent trade union movement, on demands for extensive television coverage of the union's first national congress next month.

headline: Anti-U.S. Rally Held in India
abstract: More than 100 members of the youth wing of the opposition Lok Dal Party demonstrated outside the United States Embassy today to protest the Reagan Administration's military policies. There was no violence and no arrests were reported.

headline: Nippon Phone, I.B.M. Set Deal
abstract: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation said it will sign a cross-licensing technology agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation, probably in Tokyo next month.   An agreement was recently reached after a year of talks.

headline: RUGBY DISPUTE SPLITS COMMONWEALTH
abstract: The issue of racism is again creating serious strains within the Commonwealth, that fragile but enduring association of countries that once made up the British Empire.   The new crisis, which is considered one of the most serious of the last decade, has arisen over a tour of New Zealand by the Springbok rugby team, South Africa's national squad. South Africa was expelled from the Commonwealth in 1961 because of its policy of apartheid, or separation of the races.   Rebuffed in its demand that the tour be canceled, the Commonwealth has retaliated by shifting a meeting of its finance ministers next month from Auckland, the largest city in New Zealand, to the Bahamas.

headline: VOLCKER SEES MORE TIGHTENING
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today outlined plans for further cutbacks in the growth of the money supply, warning that efforts to escape from high interest rates by abandoning policies of restraint would merely stir greater inflation and be self-defeating.   ''Sustained monetary restraint, by encouraging greater confidence in the price outlook, will in time help bring interest rates lower,'' he told the House Banking Committee, adding that the ''fundamentals of the situation suggest rates should be going lower.''   That they are not, he commented, reflects the depths to which inflationary expectations have been engrained in financial markets, in wage bargaining, in pricing and other economic decisions.

headline: FEARS ON ECONOMY KEEP LOMDON DOWN
abstract: Prices on the London Stock Exchange fell again today as British investors continued to worry about the state of their economy.   At one point this morning, the drop in the closely watched Financial Times index totaled 29.4 points, but an afternoon rally left the index down 17.2 points, at 457.5, the third-steepest one-day drop on record.   The decline continued a virtual free fall now totaling 96 points in two weeks that has sliced 17 percent, or $32.4 billion, off the value of listed British companies, $6.5 billion of it today alone.

headline: IRAN NAMES POLICE CHIEF AS CLASHES CONTINUE
abstract: Iran today announced the appointment of a new police chief as clashes were reported continuing between revolutionary guards and guerrillas in Teheran.   Meanwhile, former President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr issued a new appeal to the Iranian people to overthrow the Islamic Government.  ''Workers, farmers, rise and resist,'' the deposed President said in a statement from his exile home near Paris. ''Overthrow this regime which has proved more bloodthirsty than the monarchy.''

headline: PREFACE FROM U.S. BOOKLET ON SOVIET MILITARY
abstract: Following is the preface, signed by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, to the 99-page booklet titled ''Soviet Military Power'':   The Soviet armed forces today number more than 4.8 million men. For the past quarter century, we have witnessed the continuing growth of Soviet military power at a pace that shows no signs of slackening in the future.   All elements of the Soviet armed forces - the strategic rocket forces, the ground forces of the Army, the Air Force, the Navy and the air defense forces - continue to modernize with an unending flow of new weapons systems, tanks, missiles, ships, artillery and aircraft. The Soviet defense budget continues to grow to fund this force buildup, to fund the projection of Soviet power far from Soviet shores and to fund Soviet use of proxy forces to support revolutionary factions and conflict in an increasing threat to international stability.

headline: Seoul Textile Exports
abstract: South Korea exported $2.97 billion worth of textile products in the first half of this year, up 30.8 percent from a year ago, the Commerce and Industry Ministry reported today. Officials said the six-month tally accounted for 51.6 percent of this year's export target of $5.75 billion. Arrivals of letters of credit for textile exports in the January-June period amounted to $3.17 billion, up 42.5 percent from the same period of last year, the ministry said.

headline: NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MONDAY, AUGUST 10, 1981; Energy
abstract: President Reagan is being urged to decontrol prices on all domestically produced natural gas by the beginning of 1985, rather than just a portion of it. The move is expected to meet heavy Congressional opposition because of higher costs to the consumer, but it has a fair chance of gaining the President's support because of his recent budget and tax victories. (Page A1.)

headline: LLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Seoul Reports Loans
abstract: South Korea has obtained $4.5 billion in foreign loans so far this year, accounting for 58 percent of this year's annual loan target of $7.7 billion, Government officials reported today. Government economic planners have said that South Korea would have to borrow about $7.7 billion this year to help cover the nation's current account deficit and maintain a reasonable level of foreign exchange reserves.

headline: AVEMCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lucille Roberts Agency
abstract: The Lucille Roberts chain of health spas and diet centers, which has not previously had a real ad agency, now has gone to Calet, Hirsch, Kurnit & Spector - yes, the same agency that lost Old Bushmills - for both advertising and promotion. Billings could run from $1.5 million to $2 million.

headline: SALVADOR TROOPS FLY TO HONDURAS
abstract: An American-trained battalion of the Salvadoran Army landed in Honduras last week and then crossed the border back into El Salvador to attack this village.   According to some of the soldiers among the group of several hundred brought here, they landed in Honduras on Friday in an effort to surround the guerrillas in Los Filos. They said they had walked for almost a full day before engaging in combat with the guerrilla forces that occupied the village. Supported by mortars and heavy artillery, the soldiers said, they fought for nearly two days before they chased the guerrillas off of the mountain on which the village sits.

headline: REPUBLIC GYPSUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 1980 SLUMP TERMED SHORTEST ON RECORD
abstract: The economic decline that began in January 1980 bottomed out just seven months later, making it the shortest recession on record, according to the National Bureau of Economic Research.   The nonprofit research group's Business Cycle Dating Committee, composed of seven academic economists, is widely considered the most authoritative voice on the existence, timing and duration of recessions. Its business-cycle chronology dates back to 1854, and since 1961 its business-cycle evaluations have been adopted as official by the Department of Commerce.

headline: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Warner Amex Sued on Lease
abstract: The competition for leasing rights to scarce satellite microwave transmission channels in the pay television industry has led to a $28 million suit for breach of contract against the Warner Amex Satellite Entertainment Corporation.   Rainbow Communications Inc. of Laguna Hills, Calif., filed the action in the Federal District Court in Manhattan late Friday against Warner Amex, a pay television partnership formed in 1979 by Warner Communications Inc. and the American Express Company.

headline: TALK WITH HAIG ENDS BEGIN'S U.S. VISIT
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Secretary of State Alexander M.  -81/A/ / /WM Haig Jr. held a last-minute meeting at Kennedy International Airport last evening before the Israeli leader flew home after a 10-day visit to the United States.   Israeli officials said the meeting, sandwiched between a trip by Mr. Begin to Plains, Ga., and his departure for Israel, took place at Mr. Haig's request. Also present at the private conference in the King David Lounge of El Al Airlines was the Israeli Ambassador to the United Nations, Yehuda Blum. Neither side would disclose any of the substance of the talks.

headline: PROUD BRITISH 'HURRAH!' RESOUNDS IN LAGOS, TOO
abstract: The sky was low and dark and heavy with rain that came and left the Union Jack limp on the flagpole against a backdrop of palms. The awning that spread across the lawn from the veranda, like a marquee, got soggy, too, but not the spirit of Britons far from home.   ''It's great, isn't it?'' said a woman wearing a tunic made from a Union Jack, with red, white and blue ribbons in her hair and a red, white and blue parasol and with children wearing top hats of plastic in the same colors.   ''I wish I was there,'' said another woman, a British diplomat's wife in a striped dress. ''I wonder what the weather's like in London.''

headline: Short-Term Rates Move Up; Bond Buyers Still Scarce
abstract: The credit markets stabilized yesterday but remained extremely nervous as long-term interest rates fell slightly, while short-term rates moved higher.   In the bond market, investor demand continues to be very weak, even though there was enough buying at yesterday's near record low prices to raise prices slightly by the end of the day. Many analysts continue to expect that tax cuts and defense spending later this year will fuel inflation and credit demands, and therefore keep bond yields from declining.   The high interest rates available in the money markets, where 18 percent returns are common for issues due in a few months or less, is another reason for scant investor demand for long-term bonds.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Athlone Industries Inc. said it had purch ased 10,000 shares of its own common stock in the open market for $ 257,500.   * Apex Oil Co. said it had received a total of 6,334,293 shares of Clark Oil and Refining Corp. under its recently expired tender offer.

headline: Singapore Parts Deal
abstract: Singapore signed an agreement today enabling it to export locally made aircraft components to the United States. Under the agreement, Singapore-made aircraft parts certified by the director of civil aviation here will be accepted by the United States Federal Aviation Administration, the Trade and Industry Minister, Tony Tan, said at the signing ceremony.

headline: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1981; The Economy
abstract: President Reagan ordered his Cabinet officers to make $75 billion in budget cuts for fiscal years 1983 and 1984. He also called on them and the Wall Street financial community not to lose faith in his economic recovery program. (Page A1.) The Administration has drafted a budget resolution that includes further cuts in education and other programs for next year. (D6.)   Wall Street executives said Congressional G.O.P. leaders were wrong in casting the financial community as the villain behind high interest rates, rejecting the idea that a small group controls interest rates. The executives also were skeptical that threatened credit controls or a tax on interest income would be imposed. (D6.)

headline: Auto Layoffs Drop in Week
abstract: The number of temporary layoffs in the United States auto industry dropped sharply this week, but indefinite layoffs were virtually unchanged as domestic auto makers scheduled a 2.3 percent increase in production, according to industry reports released today.   The five major domestic car makers said they had 47,365 workers on temporary layoff, down from 54,625 last week, but open-ended layoffs were up only slightly, to 159,400, from last week's 159,240.

headline: TOCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HOUSE PANEL VOTES RELIEF ON OIL TAX
abstract: The heavily Democratic Ways and Means Committee completed its draft of a tax bill early today with a decision to give the oil industry billions of dollars of relief from the ''windfall profits'' tax.   The Democratic bill, tailored to win the support on the House floor of Southern Democrats who voted with President Reagan on the budget, was promptly denounced by the President in a talk to out-oftown editors and reporters. Conditional Cut Opposed   Mr. Reagan particularly attacked the feature of the Democratic bill that would make a third round of cuts in individual tax rates in 1984 contingent on realization of the President's economic forecast for 1983. Mr. Reagan called that element ''holding the people's tax reduction hostage to future economic events.''   In the Senate, meanwhile, the Democrats forced Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, the floor manager of the Administration tax bill, to agree to withdraw an oil amendment in exchange for a Democratic commitment to end debate on the tax bill by 3 P.M. next Wednesday and to limit debate on 92 pending amendments.

headline: Steel Output Up
abstract: Steel production rose to 2.32 million tons last week, up 1.9 percent from the previous week's 2.28 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

headline: CITIZENS' MOVEMENT BACKING TRUDEAU ON OIL
abstract: A citizens' movement has sprung up in Canada to support the Government's drive to end foreign domination of the oil and gas industry, and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has hailed it as a movement ''of great importance for our policies.''   Representatives of the movement met with the Prime Minister and the Energy Minister, Marc Lalonde, at lunch last month and, in one of the strongest attacks heard in recent times against foreign economic interests, warned them among other things that ''a strong separatist movement in western Canada may well be encouraged in the future by foreign-controlled oil companies.''   The warning was contained in an open letter to Mr. Trudeau that urged him to accelerate the policy set down last October that would reduce ownership by foreign interests of oil and gas production in Canada from about 70 percent to at least 50 percent by 1990. ''We believe this goal is far too modest,'' the letter said.

headline: CAYMAN DISMISSAL OVER MUIR
abstract: The Cayman Island Reinsurance Corporation said yesterday that an executive committee had dismissed Michael C. Scott, Cayman's chief executive, because of the possibility that he had misled the directors in transactions involving John Muir & Company, a securities firm in the process of liquidation.   John Muir underwrote the public offering of Cayman Island Reinsurance in December 1980.  A letter advising shareholders of Mr. Scott's dismissal said that the company was investigating whether Mr. Scott had given Muir permission to invest Cayman's funds in other securities that Muir underwrote.

headline: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: XEROX NET IS UP 7.5%
abstract: The Xerox Corporation reported a 7.5 percent rise in earnings for the second quarter on a 10.1 percent increase in revenues.  The company said that its earnings in the first half were reduced substantially by currency exchange rates but that the decline was offset by a lower effective tax rate overseas.

headline: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: British Car Output Off
abstract: British car production in June fell to 92,000 units from 96,000 last year, but was above the strikedepressed figure of 52,000 units in May, according to industry department figures released today.

headline: BONN AND PARIS AGREE TO OPPOSE U.S. RATE POLICY
abstract: West Germany and France agreed today to join in opposing United States economic and monetary policies at the sevennation economic summit meeting that begins in Ottawa next week.   The decision was announced by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and President Francois Mitterrand at the end of the first conference of the German and French leaders since the election of the new Socialist Government in France in May.   Both France and Germany are worried that continued high interest rates in the United States will add to Western Europe's already serious problems of inflation and unemployment. The two leaders acknowledged that they have little hope of changing America's monetarist policies, but they plan to plead their case strenuously to President Reagan at Ottawa.

headline: Patents; DEVICE OVERRIDES ERRORS IN HELICOPTER CONTROL
abstract: A helicopter control system designed to eliminate abrupt, unintentional maladjustment of the control stick has been invented for the United Technologies Corporation of Hartford. It is already used on the company's S-76 commercial helicopters.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo said in an interview today that he did not fear another coup attempt despite what he acknowledged was right wing ''restlessness'' within the armed forces. ''I don't live with the fear of another coup, but with the problems posed by unemployment, the surging dollar and terrorism,'' he said.

headline: Business Forum; WHERE'S AMERICA'S OLD TEAM SPIRIT?
abstract: W HEN Americans think about the reasons for their economic success, the Lone Ranger rides high in the saddle. The wilderness was conquered by individual settlers who pushed West. Our pantheon of economic gods - Henry Ford, Thomas Edison, Edwin Land - has room only for individual entrepreneurs. Supply-side economics preaches that the country will return to economic greatness if America unchains its individual entrepreneurs.   Yet, America is in the process of being economically surpassed by countries, such as Japan, that de-emphasize individual achievements to emphasize teamwork and group loyalty. The World Bank now places us sixth among the world's countries in providing a high standard of living. The United States has the dubious distinction of being the only country in the industrial world where productivity has been falling for the past three years.

headline: Canada Firm on Policy
abstract: A Canadian policy of promoting domestic control of its foreign-dominated oil industry cannot be stopped by threats of a United States ban on Canadian takeovers of American oil companies, Canada's Ambassador, Peter Towe, said today. He told a gas industry luncheon that a suggested Congressional moratorium on Canadian purchases of American companies would be ''highly discriminatory.''

headline: U.S. POLICY INCREASES TRADE WITH CHINA
abstract: China has replaced the Soviet Union as the most active Communist trading partner of the United States under new policies linking political behavior with more favorable trade relations, President Reagan told Congress today.   One reason for the contraction of exchanges with the Soviet Union was the American curtailment of grain shipments and suspension of sales of high technology and strategic goods after the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan in December 1979.   The grain sanctions were lifted last April 24, and today the Agriculture Department reported that the Russians had purchased 400,000 tons of American corn. This lifts to 850,000 tons the amount of grain they have bought from American farmers since April.

headline: CAPSULE HOTELS CATCH ON WITH THE JAPANESE
abstract: In some of Japan's most up-to-date hotels, a guest turns off his color television set, switches on the radio for bedtime music, sets his built-in digital alarm clock for the morning, folds his arms behind his head and looks at the ceiling waiting for sleep.   If he stretches his arms upward, he will touch the ceiling; if sideward, he will reach both walls. The room door is at his feet and his head may touch the facing wall. For a bit over $12 he has earned the right to spend a night in the latest of human habitats, something the Japanese call a kapusuru hoteru. The word is taken from English: capsule hotel.

headline: Blaze at a Kuwait Oil Refinery Is Extinguished After a Week
abstract: Firemen today extinguished a Kuwaiti oil tank blaze that had raged for almost a week and closed one of Kuwait's two refineries, a Government spokesman said.

headline: CURTAILING ARCING ON COLOR TV
abstract: WASHINGTON VIEWERS of color television have been troubled by electric flashes in the picture tubes. A cathode ray tube invented by an RCA scientist substantially suppresses the flashing, or arcing, and is being manufactured by the company.

headline: PRODUCERS' PRICES UP BY 0.4% IN JULY AS INCREASE SLOWS
abstract: The Government's Producer Price Index for finished goods, a rough measure of the level of inflation consumers will face in the future, edged up by only four-tenths of 1 percent in July, despite a large increase in the price of food, the Labor Department reported today.   This was a slightly better outcome than many economists had expected, and appeared to extend the gains that the United States has made against inflation during the last year.   In another report, the Federal Reserve Board said that the nation's factories and mines increased their production by threetenths of 1 percent last month. The rise, much of which was attributed to a rebound in coal output after the miners' strike, came despite forecasts that the American economy was entering a recession. (Page 29.)

headline: DATASCOPE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Law of Sea Treaty Is Delayed a Year
abstract: The Law of the Sea Conference, now in its ninth year, today postponed action on a proposed treaty to give the Reagan Administration time to formulate its policy on the pact.   Despite an effort by the Soviet bloc to complete action on the treaty in this session, as planned a year ago, the conference set a ''final decision-making session'' for next year in New York.

headline: Lilco Unit's Chief
abstract: Solar energy for residential use on Long Island is very much in the plans of the Long Island Lighting Company. The company has established an unregulated subsidiary, Lilco Energy Systems Inc., to market energy conservation and renewable resource equipment and has appointed Edward N. Baumann, 54, as its president.

headline: Film Makers' Magazine, Moving Image, Planned
abstract: There has been an explosion of magazines about videoland, but none, really, specifically for the video maker. Enter Moving Image, a magazine for video and film makers, that will be published by Sheptow Publishing, San Francisco.

headline: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: France Ends Mexico Oil
abstract: France's state-owned oil company, Total, said yesterday that it had suspended its Mexican crude oil purchases because of Mexico's decision to raise prices by $2 a barrel on July 1. But Mexico said it had not yet increased its prices.

headline: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HUDSON'S BAY SET TO BUY AMOCO UNIT
abstract: The Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company of Calgary said it has agreed to buy a controlling interest in the Cyprus Anvil Mining Corporation of Vancouver for $212.4 million (Canadian) from the Amoco Minerals Company, a unit of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).   The Canadian dollar is worth about 81.6 cents in United States currency.  The agreement was seen as yet another example of how Canadian Government policies are encouraging the takeover by Canadian companies of foreign-owned concerns in Canada,   The Calgary company said it would pay $44.25 for each of 4.8 million Cyprus Anvil shares in the 63 percent control block held by Amoco Minerals and later would make a similar offer for the remaining publicly owned shares. At the offering price, the indicated value of the purchase would be $127.4 million.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: SECRET CHINA PAPERS SELL FOREIGNERS ADS
abstract: Eager to earn foreign exchange at every opportunity, the Chinese Government has begun selling advertising space to foreign companies in one of its secret foreign-trade publications.   For $6,000, foreign advertisers can now buy a full-page black-andwhite advertisement in a biweekly newspaper so confidential that they are not allowed to read it. They will get a proof sheet of their ad but will have to take Peking's word that it actually appeared.

headline: Article 250036 -- No Title
abstract: The nation's savings and loan associations had a record $3.5 billion net outflow of savings in July, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.   The net worth of the federally insured savings and loan associations tumbled $536 million last month, the sharpest fall in recent years, to $30.1 billion, according to a bank board spokesman.  Net worth is the excess of assets over liabilities.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: * American Invsco Corporation, Chicago, has named Irene Gouletas D'Agnese executive vice president for financial management and administration.   * Autodynamics Inc., Neptune, N.J., a producer of computer-based training systems, has elected Donn Q. Powers vice president of finance.

headline: A PLAN TO AID THRIFT UNITS
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today proposed to allow its 12 regional banks to pay interest on the demand deposits of member savings and loan associations.   The bank board, the prime regulator of federally insured savings and loan associations, offers those institutions a broad range of financial services ''but has been prohibited by regulation from paying interest on demand deposit accounts,'' the announcement said.

headline: LURIA, L, & SONS reports earnings for Yr to Jan 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PIZZA TIME THEATRE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PACIFIC GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOODYEAR AND UNIROYAL GAIN
abstract: Two of the nation's major rubber companies yesterday reported substantial second-quarter profit gains, which they attributed in part to an improved tire market compared with last year.   The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest tire manufacturer, said that its second-quarter profit rose 58.2 percent, to $68.2 million, or 94 cents a share, from $43.1 million, or 59 cents a share, in the 1980 second quarter.

headline: Washington Watch; Antitrust Sign Is Glimpsed
abstract: WASHINGTON THE Justice Department has given its first signals of the way it intends to enforce antitrust policy under the doctrine of Attorney General William French Smith that bigness is not necessarily bad.   Intervening in the contest for control of Conoco Inc., the antitrust division under Assistant Attorney General William F. Baxter has given what amounts to pre-clearance to acquisition by E.I du Pont de Nemours & Company.   Apparently the Justice Department considers the merger an anticompetitive situation only in the joint venture in petrochemicals that Conoco manages with the Monsanto Company in Chocolate Bayou, Tex., meaning that some change in ownership of that facility will be necessary.   And in requesting additional information from the Mobil Corporation on the competitive implications of a Mobil takeover of Conoco, the antitrust division is responding to expressions of concern by a number of legislators over the concentration of corporate ownership.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: MOBIL PLANS TO SELL GAS FIELD OUTPUT
abstract: The Mobil Corporation said it has reached an agreement to sell its 50 percent share of natural gas produced from the Beryl Field in the North Sea to the British Gas Corporation, the state-run gas utility.

headline: Coffee Frost Damage Gauged
abstract: The Brazilian frost of last month will probably reduce next year's coffee harvest in the state of Sao Paulo by about 50 percent, the Agriculture Department said today.   According to a field survey by the United States agricultural counselor in Brasilia, the July 20-21 frost damaged as much as 50 to 60 percent of the 900 million coffee trees in Sao Paulo.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Aeroflex Laboratories Inc., Plainview, L.I., has appointed Arthur J. Hendler executive vice president.   * Capital Air, formerly called Capital International Airways, has elected John B. Wilkes vice president and general counsel; Larry G.  Anderson vice president-sales, and W. Mitchell Givens treasurer.

headline: Nissan Price Rise
abstract: Nissan U.S.A., distributor of Datsun and Nissan vehicles in the United States, said it would raise prices on 1982 Datsun cars and trucks by an average of 4.6 percent from 1981 prices. The increase amounts to an average of $378 a car, Nissan said. The lowest-priced Datsun, the 210, will carry a base price of $4,799 for 1982 and the standard Datsun truck will cost a minimum of $6,149, the company said.

headline: JOHNSON & JOHNSON FRAUD SUIT
abstract: Did the maker of America's most popular pain-killing pills buy up an innovative electronic pain-killing device in order to stifle the product's development and thereby protect its own drug business?   That question lies at the heart of a court battle between Johnson & Johnson and three inventors from Minnesota who sold their young company and its electronic pain reliever to the health care giant seven years ago.   Last July a Federal jury in Minneapolis ruled that Johnson & Johnson had fraudulently bought the electronic painkilling product in order to quietly suppress the device and head off new competition for its drug business. The court ordered the New Brunswick, N.J., company to pay $170.4 million in damages and antitrust fines. According to Judge Miles Lord of the United States District Court in Minneapolis, the evidence before the jury indicated that Johnson & Johnson had engaged in fraud of ''the most extreme and culpable nature.''

headline: energywatch
abstract: SEPT. 4, 1981 Crude oil inventories dropped 4.9 million barrels to 371.7 million barrels, mainly because of reduced imports. Summer driving was lower than normal, causing gasoline supplies to rise 4.4 million barrels to 241.5 million barrels. Distillate stocks continued to increase in advance of the winter heating season, rising 2.8 million barrels to 207.1 million barrels.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: CANADA ACTS TO CURB AMERICAN ACQUISITIONS
abstract: The Canadian Government reacted today to the dramatic weakening of its currency by moving to reduce ''substantially'' Canadian takeovers of American companies.   Finance Minister Allen J. MacEachan met with the representatives of seven major Canadian banks and asked them to reduce their lending for foreign takeovers. He told reporters that the bank officials had responded favorably to what they termed ''timely action.''   Mr. MacEachan said the actual and anticipated outflow of Canadian dollars into United States funds for buying companies had ''put downward pressure on the exchange rate.'' At the close of trade in New York the Canadian dollar stood at 81.83 United States cents.

headline: PRIME RATE IS CUT BY SOME BIG BANKS
abstract: A number of leading banks reduced their prime lending rates another notch yesterday, to 19 1/2 percent fro m 20 percent, and some bankers predicted tha t interest rates might finally be headed downward for the first tim e in months.   Analysts said that most other major banks were likely to move their prime rates to the new 19 1/2 level today. It would be the second half-point drop in the prime rate in the last 10 days.   Still cautious in their new optimism, the bankers based their forecasts of interest rate drops on signs that the Federal Reserve System had eased credit curbs somewhat and that the economy might be entering a recession - a view bolstered on Friday by a Commerce Department report that the gross national product would be ''flat to slightly down'' in the current third quarter.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: * AM International, Los Angeles, has elected Jerry O. Williams a senior vice president.   * Berkeley Federal Savings and Loan Association, Milburn, N.J., has elected Gilbert Raff chairman.

headline: Strike Banned At Railroad
abstract: A judge today blocked any further strike action by employees of Burlington Northern Inc. Federal District Judge Bernard M. Decker issued an injunction against the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen.   The railroad's car builders, repairmen and inspectors staged a wildcat strike June 26.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG'S SPEECH ON ADMINISTRATION'S POLICY ON ARMS CONTROL
abstract: Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the Foreign Policy Association at the New York Hilton Hotel:   Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the Foreign Policy Association at the New York Hilton Hotel   Arms control can be only one element in a comprehensive structure of defense and foreign policy designed to reduce the risks of war. It cannot be the political centerpiece or the crucial barometer of U.S.-Soviet relationships, burdening arms control with a crushing political weight. It can hardly address such issues as the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, the Iran-Iraq war, the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia, the Libyan invasion of Chad or the Cuban intervention in Africa and Latin America.   Our first principle is that our arms control efforts will be an instrument of, not a replacement for, a coherent allied security policy.   There is little prospect of agreements with the Soviet Union that will help solve such a basic security problem as the vulnerability of our land-based missiles until we demonstrate that we have the will and capacity to solve them without arms control, should that be necessary.

headline: FRENCH SOCIALISTS PRESSING TAKEOVER OF SOME INDUSTRY
abstract: In an eagerly awaited speech before the French National Assembly, Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy today outlined the new Socialist Government's economic program.It centers on the nationalization of major corporations in the steel and militarysupply industries and some banks, the creation of 210,000 civil service jobs and reduction of the workweek.   Much of the Socialist program had been disclosed previously, either during the presidential campaign or in the weeks since the Socialist accession to power. Some political analysts in France and elsewhere, however, thought that, once in control, the new Government would modify its campaign positions.

headline: Mothers' Manual
abstract: John H. Boyd has become the new publisher of Mothers' Manual, replacing Henry B. Kratz, who died last month. The six-times-a-year publication is now at a 900,000 circulation, distributed through obstetricians and sent directly to new mothers at home.

headline: PANAMA'S MILITARY TRIES TO PICK UP TORRIJOS REINS
abstract: Less than a month after the death of Brig.  Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, Panama's military high command has moved quickly to fill the political vacuum left by the death of the strongman who had ruled the country 13 years.   Although Aristides Royo has been confirmed in his largely administrative role as President, the 10 senior officers of the National Guard, the country's only armed force, have begun to project themselves as the ultimate political authority here.   In recent days, the new commander of the 9,000-member guard, Col.  Florencio Florez Aguilar, a little-known figure until General Torrijos's death in a plane crash July 31, has made several muchpublicized trips around the country, but he is believed to have little ambition to dominate the political scene and has been coordinating closely with the nine lieutenant colonels who comprise the guard's general staff.   Significantly, by inviting proponents and critics of a $2 billion copper development project to argue their case before them last week, the general staff officers assumed responsibility for deciding perhaps the most nettlesome political issue facing the country today. In the meantime, they named the chief of staff, Lieut. Col. Ruben Dario Paredes, to study the project.

headline: OCCIDENTAL MAKES BID FOR ZAPATA
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation is offering $754 million in stock for the Zapata Corporation, a major oil services company, Zapata disclosed in Houston yesterday.   Wall Street sources close to both companies said they had heard that Zapata told Occidental it was ''not for sale.'' Others close to the situation, however, insisted that such talk was just part of the bargaining process.   Asked if the proposal was friendly, Armand Hammer, chairman of Occidental, said in a telephone interview: ''Yes, absolutely. I would not be a party to an unfriendly merger with anybody.''

headline: HIGH-RISE IS PLANNED AT SLOANE'S
abstract: The Porterfield Corporation, which on Wednesday purchased a portion of the W.&J. Sloane store building on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, plans to transform that structure into a high-rise, multipurpose building with offices on top of a scaled-down Sloane store, it was disclosed yesterday.   Jack Farber, chairman of the City Stores Company and of its subsidiary, the 29-store Sloane's chain, said that Porterfield had purchased, for $10.5 million, 14,000 square feet of ground space and a total of 80,000 square feet over all. Sloane's owns the 200,000-square-foot building and rents an additional 80,000 square feet in three small buildings behind the Fifth Avenue store between 37th and 38th Streets.

headline: AWACS PROTECTED SADAT, U.S. AFFIRMS
abstract: The United States provided President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt with the one-day use of an American Awacs surveillance plane for his protection during a trip he made to Khartoum, the Sudan, on May 25, the State Department said today.   Alan D. Romberg, a department spokesman, in effect confirmed what Mr. Sadat said in a television interview yesterday. Mr. Sadat said he had asked for use of the aircraft, which was ''borrowed'' for the day from the four stationed in Saudi Arabia. Officials said it was possible that some of the other planes might have been used interchangeably during the course of the day.   Mr. Sadat was concerned, department officials said, that Libya might try to shoot down his Boeing 707. The department said the Awacs were provided without charge by the United States; no costs were disclosed.

headline: Canada Bank Bond
abstract: The National Bank of Canada is raising $40 million (United States currency) through a 6.6-year Eur obond, thelead manager, Manufacturers Hanover Ltd., said here today. The interest rate coupon on the issue is 16.50 percent semiannually, Manufacturers Hanover added, and will yield 17.06 percent annually priced at par .

headline: PRESLEY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JAPANESE HIGHLY SATISFIED WITH OTTAWA PARLEY
abstract: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki returned over the weekend from the Ottawa meeting of the leading industrial democracies without any public comment on its results, but senior officials reflected a sense of deep satisfaction.   What has inspired this sentiment within the upper reaches of the administration is not any sense of accomplishment but rather contentment that nothing happened to mar Japan's relations with the United States and Western Europe. Briefing the Japanese press on his return, Foreign Minister Sunao Sonoda emphasized that Japan had not been required to take on any new obligations.

headline: Talking Business with Wolf of
abstract: Peter Wolf Associates Buying Land: The Dangers   There seems to be a deeply ingrained assumption among Americans that land values have no place to go but up, and the last few years' experience with inflation has done little to discourage the sentiment. Peter Wolf, a consultant on land planning and land-asset management, estimates that over the past five years well-situated raw land of all types in America increased in value by 8 percent to 12 percent a year, or just ahead of inflation.   This is a good record, but as Mr. Wolf writes in a new book, ''Land in America,'' it is hardly enough to justify enthusiastic land speculation. Indeed, Mr. Wolf, whose firm is Peter Wolf Associates in New York City, believes that purchasing unimproved land may be one of the worst things an investor could do today. In his view, most people in this country have no idea how risky the purchase of undeveloped land has become.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The bonds of compromise, opportunism and West German prosperity that have held the governing coalition of Social Democrats and Free Democrats together for more than 11 years are pulling apart.   It has become a political cliche in Bonn for editorial writers to say that the coalition will not last until the next elections in 1984 - these days, half the stories in West German newspapers seem to be headlined, ''The Beginning of the End'' - but the reality is that growing elements in both parties no longer have the formula or a very intense commitment to maintain the association.   After a month of intracoalition bickering over a new budget and over how the cou ntry should deal with the eco nomic stagnation that last month produced the highest unemployment figures in 29 years, theargument took on a new shrillness over the we ekend.   Willy Brandt, the chairman of the Social Democratic Party, said he ''wouldn't put his hand in the fire'' and swear that the coalition would last. His voice cracking with emotion, he told a group of party members: ''We've been leaned on. It's gone to the limit of what Social Democratic self-respect allows! When it's necessary, it will be clear for everybody who is responsible in this!''

headline: British Gas To Sell Stores
abstract: In another move to return profitable parts of Britain's nationalized industries to private ownership, the Government today ordered the state-owned British Gas Corporation to sell the 900 appliance stores it owns. The shops, which sell stoves and other gas appliances, have annual sales of about $376 million and employ about 33,000.

headline: Applied Devices Facing Delisting
abstract: The Applied Devices Corporation, a defense contractor specializing in electronic instruments systems, said it would consent to the proposed delisting of its common stock by the American Stock Exchange.   The company, which lost $3.1 million in the first nine months of its 1981 fiscal year, said it had not met American Stock Exchange requirements for continued listing for ''some period of time.''

headline: PANDICK PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NU-WEST IN TALKS ON CITIES SERVICE
abstract: Nu-West Group Ltd. of Canada, the owner of a 7.2 percent block of stock in the Cities Service Company, disclosed yesterday that it was discussing the ''possible acquisition'' of all or part of its Cities Service stake by the Mesa Petroleum Company or by other companies, including Cities Service itself.   The Nu-West statement said that officials of Nu-West and Cities Service had also discussed a variety of matters on a preliminary basis in the last month. These matters, Nu-West said, included Cities Service's oil and gas operations in Canada and Nu-West's investment in Cities Service stock.   Despite the careful wording, the implication seemed clear that the Mesa discussions involved cash while the Cities Service talks dealt with some arrangement for Cities Service to retrieve its stock and Nu-West to get in return either cash or Cities Service's oil and gas properties in Canada.

headline: Patents; ELECTROLYSIS DEPOSITS METALS ON INERT SURFACES
abstract: A process for the electrolytic deposition of metals, conceived after research at Columbia University, was patented this week. Patent 4,279,711 was granted to Paul F. Duby, professor of chemical metallurgy at the university; Jack A. Scott, a graduate student, and Paul H. Vining, a former student and now a process engineer for Mansfield Carbon Products Inc. of Nashville.

headline: Athens Protests Charge By Hungary's Embassy
abstract: The Greek Government protested to the Hungarian Embassy today over a charge by the embassy that Athens tried to put pressure on a Budapest professor who had sought asylum in Greece but then changed his mind and was flown home.   The Hungarian Ambassador, diplomatic sources said, was summoned to the Foreign Ministry to explain his embassy's statement that Kalma Szabo, 41 years old, ''suffered a physical and psychological ordeal'' in Greece.

headline: Bauxite Mining Suit Dismissed
abstract: A Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit seeking to halt bauxite mining in Western Australia by subsidiaries of the Aluminum Company of America and the Reynolds Metals Company.

headline: Unilever Earnings Rise 42.7%
abstract: The Unilever Group, the mammoth British-Dutch food and industrial products company, reported yesterday that combined earnings in the second quarter of 1981 increased 42.7 percent, while combined sales advanced 12.9 percent.   Unilever is divided into Unilever in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, and Unilever of London.

headline: A FAST-FOOD BATTLE WITH THE TACO TASTE
abstract: Mexican fast-food restaurants, which offer an alternative to hamburgers, french fries and milkshakes, are in the midst of a tough battle for control of the California market.   Once the exclusive domain of Taco Bell Inc., the industry leader, smaller chains have grabbed a significant share of the nation's largest market for tacos, burritos and tostadas.   ''To say the least, the competition between the leaders, Taco Bell and Del Taco, is very intense,'' said Robert Wisely, a partner in Restaurant Research Associates. ''In many markets such as southern California, they're neck and neck.''

headline: Economic Scene; Why Don't Rates Drop?
abstract: THE chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Murray L.  Weidenbaum, has changed his description of the American economy from ''soggy'' to ''spongy.'' Half a year ago, Mr. Weidenbaum was presumably calling the economy ''soggy'' in the sense defined by The American Dollar Dictionary, published in 1949, as ''damp and heavy'' or as ''thoroughly wet'' (the Federal Reserve having excessively liquified the system).   It seems unlikely that he was using ''soggy'' in its secondary sense of ''dull and stupid,'' a meaning he might have applied to the Carter Administration but surely not to his own, despite his differences with other Reaganite economic advisers.   However, far from exhibiting sogginess, the economy in the first quarter showed remarkable springiness. Real gross national product climbed at an annual rate of 8.6 percent. So the economy is regarded by Mr. Weidenbaum as no longer resembling a wet bog but a springy sponge, which you can temporarily depress but which will bounce back as soon as you take off the pressure.

headline: JULY INCOME SURGED 1.6% AND SPENDING ROSE 1.2%
abstract: Americans' personal income surged 1.6 percent in July, the largest gain in a year, the Commerce Department reported today. It cited rising employment and a midyear increase in Social Security payments.   Analysts inside and outside the Government saw favorable implications for the overall economy in both the income gain and in a 1.2 percent increase in personal spending by Americans in July, which the department also reported.   But they were not ready to declare an end to the sluggish conditions that have plagued the economy for the last six months or so.

headline: POLAND'S AIRLINE STRUCK ON ISSUE OF WORKER RULE
abstract: In a second sucessive day of token strikes, 6,000 employees of the state-owned airline stopped work for four hours this morning in a dispute over the employees' demand that they be allowed to elect their own general manager.   The protest, which was believed to be the first strike affecting civil aviation in the Soviet bloc, caused a cancellation by the airline, LOT, of eight domestic flights and delays or cancellations of 14 international flights, according to organizers of the strike.   The action, coming after a one-hour walkout by 40,000 dock workers yesterday, raised fears that labor unrest might be starting up again, at a time when the Communist Party is preparing for an emergency congress next week to consider changes in the party's statutes, leadership and policies. 3 Dissidents Ordered Rearrested   In another development, the Supreme Court ordered the rearrest of three anti-Communist dissidents who are being tried on charges of plotting violent overthrow of the country's constitutional system.  The three, along with a fourth man, also on trial but at liberty because of ill health, belong to a right-wing organization called the Confederation of Independent Poland.

headline: U.P.I. REPORTER IN SOUTH AFRICA IS CHARGED FOR RIOTS ARTICLE
abstract: A United Press International reporter has been charged under South Africa's defense act with writing an article ''calculated to alarm or depress members of the public.''   The South African authorities said yesterday that Nat Gibson, U.P.I.'s chief correspondent for southern Africa, violated the defense act when he reported 14 months ago that troops were deployed to protect an auto plant against rioting black workers.

headline: FRUEHAUF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CITYTRUST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONGRESS STARTING IN WARSAW TODAY
abstract: The Soviet Union and its allies today sent middle-ranking delegations to attend a special congress of the Polish Communist Party that opens tomorrow.   The congress, the first that is not predictable in every way, is being convened to come up with policies and leadership to surmount the crisis that has hobbled Poland for a year.   The Soviet delegation that arrived today is headed by Viktor V. Grishin, the party leader of Moscow city who is a member of the ruling Politburo. The 66-year-old Mr. Grishin, who headed the Soviet trade unions from 1956 to 1967, is not a leading figure in the Kremlin, but neither is he insignificant.

headline: 4 KILLED AND 100 INJURED IN CENTRAL AFRICAN BLAST
abstract: Four people, including a French citizen, were killed and about 100 others were injured last night when a bomb exploded at a crowded movie theater in the Central African Republic capital of Bangui, reports reaching Paris said today.   French paratroops, who have been in the country since 1979 when a coup toppled Jean-Bedel Bokassa after he proclaimed himself emperor, were called out to patrol Bangui's streets after the explosion last night, the reports said.   Diplomatic sources reached by telephone in Bangui described the bombing as a ''single terrorist action, quite possibly politically motivated.''

headline: Laker Airways Picks 3 Agencies for America
abstract: In a smaller but interesting development, Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, a J.Walter Thompson subsidiary, has been named the New York area agency for Laker Airways Skytrain Service.

headline: Associated Press
abstract: CAR BOMB KILLS 15 PEOPLE: Pedestrians looking at damage caused by car that exploded near Zrariyeh, Lebanon.

headline: Semiconductor Plans Shutdowns
abstract: Blaming a worldwide slump in demand for computer ''chips,'' the National Semiconductor Corporation announced a second round of shutdowns at its United States and Scotland operations.

headline: WEINBERGER HOPES TO PUBLICIZE SOVIET MISSILE DATA
abstract: With the Soviet Union apparently deploying its new medium-range SS-20 nuclear missiles at a rapid pace, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has become involved in a dispute with intelligence agencies over publicizing evidence of the deployment, according to Administration officials.   Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. asserted in a speech in New York yesterday that the Soviet Union already had 750 nuclear warheads deployed on the SS-20's, which was considerably more than previously known, and said that ''the pace of the Soviet buildup is increasing.''   The Administration officials here said that the Soviet Union had deployed 235 to 250 missile launchers, which supported Mr. Haig's statement since each missile can carry three warheads. Two-thirds of the launchers are aimed at Western Europe and a third at China or other targets in Asia, the officials said. Japanese officials noted today, according to press reports from Tokyo, that SS-20's could reach any target in Japan.

headline: SALVADOR CHIEF ARRIVES IN U.S. TODAY
