abstract: The head of El Salvador's ruling junta, Jose Napoleon Duarte, is to arrive here tomorrow for what his aides say will be a week of lobbying Congress and the American people for the Salvadoran Government's position in the conflict with rebel forces.  Mr. Duarte is scheduled to meet with President Reagan on Monday.   The Salvadoran leader will appear before the United Nations General Assembly on Sept. 29.  Mr. Duarte's aides say that the purpose of the trip is not primarily to ask for increased United States assistance. The State Department has said on several occasions, however, that the subject of aid to El Salvador is a matter under discussion. El Salvador is receiving $126 million in economic aid and $35 million in military assistance this year. Proposed economic and military aid for the next year is $75 million and $26 million respectively.

headline: Around the World; British-French Meeting Ends on a Positive Note
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand of France and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today ended two days of talks that they described as ''excellent'' and ''fruitful'' despite some continued differences, particularly on economic policies.   Speaking at a joint news conference, Mrs. Thatcher said, ''The talks were excellent, and the atmosphere was very friendly and constructive.''

headline: ISRAEL DEBATES HOW BEST TO RESPOND TO SAUDI PLAN
abstract: A Saudi Arabian statement on terms for a Middle East peace has been rejected by a broad spectrum of Israeli politicians and news organizations. But it has prompted a debate on how the Saudi comments should be handled because a portion of them implies tacit acceptance of the existence of the state of Israel.   What has been termed in some quarters here ''the Saudi peace initiative'' is expected to be debated in the Cabinet on Sunday when Prime Minister Menachem Begin returns from vacation. But many Israeli politicians, excluding the Prime Minister, have already replied to the statement, issued several days ago to the official Saudi press agency by Crown Prince Fahd.

headline: OUTLET CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ALBERTO-CULVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KHOMEINI SAYS U.S. 'LACKEYS' KILLED HIS AIDE
abstract: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini today characterized the assassination of his personal representative in Tabriz as the work of United States ''lackeys'' and vowed that ''the people would take revenge,'' the Teheran radio reported.   The radio report also said Ayatollah Khomeini had removed Col.  Javad Fakuri as commander of the air force and replaced him with the deputy commander, Col. Mohammed Moinpur. There was no explanation for the action.

headline: Bonn Video Deal Halted
abstract: The West German newspaper and publishing concern Axel Springer, has broken off negotiations with Sony Deutschland on a planned joint video venture that was to start in September, a Sony Deutschland spokesman said today.

headline: F.T.C. DROPS TRUST SUIT AGAINST 8 OIL CONCERNS
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission today dropped its broad antitrust case against the nation's eight major oil companies, saying further proceedings in the eight-year-old case "are not in the public interest."   The case has made little progress since the commission issued the complaint in 1973, charging "collusive action" by the companies .  F.T.C. lawyers said in June that the trial co uld not begin for at least three years.   "While the length or complexity of litigation does not in itself constitute a basis for dismissal, the circumstances of this proceeding, including the limited progress of litigation, call for this result," the F.T.C. said.

headline: THEIR VALUE PUT AT $2 MILLION
abstract: MARSEILLE, France, July 8 (UPI) The police raided a heroin laboratory today and seized morphine base for heroin that they said was worth $2 million.   The police were aided by American narcotics agents based here, they said. At a modest villa near this Mediterranean port, they seized 37.4 pounds of morphine base, the largest such cache taken in France since February 1978, when 88 pounds was found in a house here.

headline: 2 Senators Caution Moscow Against Intervening in Poland
abstract: Two visiting members of the United States Senate warned the Soviet Union today that military intervention in Poland would further damage relations with the West.   ''I think we made it clear that any kind of military action in Poland would have a very sharp reaction in the West, perhaps greater than was the case with Afghanistan,'' said Senator Charles McC.

headline: NEW VIOLENCE HITS 10 ENGLISH CITIES BUT IS LESS SERIOUS
abstract: Scattered violence erupted again yesterday in London and nine other cities after the worst night of riots and looting since the turmoil in England began nine days ago.   The new violence began only hours after Friday night's rioting had died down. The police said yesterday's disturbances were less serious than those the day before.   In the east London district of Walthamstow, the scene of street fighting Friday night and early yesterday, a memorial service for four members of an Asian family who died in an arson-caused fire turned into a rampage involving 500 youths.

headline: FRANCE URGING ITS CITIZENS TO LEAVE IRAN
abstract: France today advised its citizens living in Iran to ''return quickly,'' and it recalled its ambassador in Teheran for consultations.   A spokesman for President Francois Mitterrand said the announcement covering about 140 French citizens in Iran had been prompted by demonstrations in front of the French Embassy in Teheran protesting France's granting of political asylum to Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, the former Iranian President.   Shortly after the French communique was made public, Iran's Foreign Ministry announced that the French Ambassador, Guy Georgy, was being expelled. No Action on Extradition   Mr. Georgy had been asked to leave within three days, Teheran radio reported, because the French Government had failed to comply with an Iranian demand for the extradition of Mr. Bani-Sadr and Massoud Rajavi, leader of the People's Mujahedeen guerrilla group.

headline: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MASTERCARD-FIDELITY MONEY FUND DUE
abstract: In a move that could link thousands of banks and their customers to the lucrative money market funds, Mastercard International and the Fidelity Management Group said yesterday that they planned to offer a Mastercard Money Manager account.   The service, which will allow cardholders to transfer funds from a special checking account into money market funds and other investments, will be available through Mastercard's 12,000 member banks within four months, according to Russell E. Hogg, president and chief executive officer of Mastercard. Fidelity will manage the mutual funds and provide discount brokerage services.   ''No longer will banking customers need to leave their bank for high-yield flexible investments - those investments will now be available through their local bank,'' Mr. Hogg said. ''We have planned this very carefully and have designed the program to meet the S.E.C.'s approval.''

headline: BONN REPORTS 10% DROP IN MAY'S EXPORT ORDERS
abstract: The volume of export orders booked by West German industry dropped sharply in May, on a month-to-month basis, the Government reported today.   Moreover, a top Government aide said that the decline might jeopardize the fragile prospect of an export boom that could revive the troubled German economy later this year.

headline: REAGAN DISCUSSES AGENDA FOR BEGIN
abstract: President Reagan conferred at lunch today with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger on military and other questions that are expected to arise in talks starting tomorrow with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel.   Mr. Begin arrived today from New York and spent a half hour with Mr. Haig at Blair House, the official guest house, to discuss the agenda. Mr. Haig then reported to Mr. Reagan and Mr. Weinberger at lunch.   American of ficials have said that an objective of the visit is to strengthen re lations after the strains of recent months caused by Israel's usin g American-made planes in raids against Iraq's nuclear reactor and a gainst Palestine Liberation Organization headquarters inthe civilian quarters of Beirut, Lebanon.   Officials said that, unless Israel felt confident about American support, it would be difficult to gain Israel's cooperation in concluding negotiations with Egypt on Palestinian self-rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, an agreement that is sought by the United States.

headline: Commission Rejects Ban On Commercial Whaling
abstract: The International Whaling Commission rejected a ban on commercial whaling today despite conservationist arguments and a last-minute plea from President Reagan yesterday.

headline: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Du Pont Up 50.6%; Carbide Rises 29%
abstract: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical producer, reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter of 1981 increased 50.6 percent as sales rose 14.2 percent.   The Wilmington, Del., concern said that earnings in the latest three months rose to $262 million, or $1.67 a share, from $174 million, or $1.10 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales advanced to $3.93 billion from $3.44 billion.   Du Pont, a major manufacturer of textile fibers and a variety of other specialty products, said that sales and earnings in the second quarter include the results of the New England Nuclear Corporation, which became a subsidiary in April. Prior-year results have been restated accordingly.

headline: Technology; Using Plastics In Batteries
abstract: SOMETIMES technology moves forward by focusing on what a material does poorly instead of what it does well. For instance, a number of researchers have noted that plastics are poor conductors of electricity and have wondered how they might be modified to make them more electrically active.   Interest in these questions perked up considerably last year when the University of Pennsylvania filed for a patent on a plastic film, impregnated with lithium iodide, that acted like a battery when charged. Suddenly, it seemed plausible that plastics, long valued for their light weight and the ease with which they can be shaped and combined with other materials, might be useful in a whole new realm of applicatio ns now reserved for metals.

headline: Bonn Minister Is Optimistic
abstract: A new downturn in the West German economy is unlikely, and a distinct upswing can be achieved in 1982, Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff said.   In a weekend speech to businessmen, he said that the economy was idling at present, but that grounds for optimism had emerged.

headline: Caterpillar Tractor
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amended proposed public offering of $150 million of notes due in 1986.

headline: CROWDS FLOCK TO VIEW GIFTS TO ROYAL PAIR
abstract: From the stone portico of St. James's Palace this afternoon, a queue of people six abreast stretched down Marlborough Street and The Mall almost to Buckingham Palace, a 10-minute walk away. Even that horde paled in comparison to yesterday's assemblage, a 1 1/2-mile-long human pipeline that twisted back on itself twice and took up to five hours to endure.   Despite near-record 86 degree heat yesterday and a torrential storm today, an exhibition of about 1,200 wedding presents given to Prince Charles and his bride, Diana, has instantly become London's new smash tourist attraction, luring thousands of visitors and residents alike in its first two days.

headline: Earnings Slide At Beneficial
abstract: The Beneficial Corporation, a diversified financial services company, said today that its secondquarter earnings, hurt by high borrowing costs and a large foreignexchange loss, plunged 41.6 percent from last year's second quarter.   The company said its net income dropped to $13.5 million, or 41 cents a share, from $23.1 million, or 85 cents a share, in the comparable 1980 quarter.

headline: MARINDUQUE LOAN
abstract: The Marinduque Mining and Industrial Corporation of the Philippines signed a $127.2 million short-term loan to finance oil imports with a group of international banks, Chemical Bank said as agent bank. The facility is guaranteed by the Development Bank of the Philippines and carries an interest rate of 7/8 percent over the Singapore Interbank offered rate.

headline: Washington Watch; A Squeeze on Arms Makers
abstract: WASHINGTON DEFENSE procurement officers and now members of Congress are becoming increasingly worried about the financial pincers tightening around small business and the impact of this squeeze on the mammoth arms buildup being planned by the Reagan Administration.   The defense industrial base is traditionally perceived as being 75 to 100 of the largest defense contractors. But there are thousands of subcontractors, mostly small companies, that actually produce the myriad components and subassemblies of sophisticated weapons systems.    The Senate Small Business Committee is to hold hearings tomorrow to determine whether the subcontractors actually have the capability to achieve the Reagan arms goals.

headline: Grumman Net Drops 10.1%
abstract: The Grumman Corporation said today that earnings fell 10.1 percent in the second quarter ended June 30, in part because of losses related to the company's Flxible buses.   Earnings were $7.1 million, or 51 cents a share, on sales of $503.3 million, compared with $7.9 million, or 60 cents a share, on sales of $424.9 million in the similar period last year.

headline: KAISER OFF
abstract: The Westinghouse Corporation, the country's second-largest electronics equipment concern after the General Electric Company, announced yesterday that earnings in the second quarter increased 7.5 percent, as revenues increased 11.7 perecent.   The Pittsburgh-based concern said that net income in the latest three months rose to $111.8 million, or $1.31 a share, from $104 million, or $1.22 a share, in the three months a year earlier.  Revenues were up to $2.38 billion from $2.13 billion.   Westinghouse said that a gain of 11.8 percent in operating profits in the latest quarter came primarily from the corporation's Industry Products Company. Operating results of its Public Systems Company were up slightly and at its Power Systems Company they were down slightly.

headline: GAS INJECTION SET IN ANGOLA
abstract: A gas-reinjection facility costing $160 million is to be installed in an oilfield in Cabinda, Angola, to double the field's current output of 100,000 barrels of oil a day, the official Angolan news agency reported today.

headline: INTEREST RATE WAR AT SAVINGS UNITS
abstract: He sports a Hawaiian shirt and a fishing hat, and the sack of money in one hand and the wad of bills in the other have him grinning like the Cheshire cat.   This particular consumer is shown in a full-page advertisement run by the Lincoln Savings Bank that offers the public a startling 35 percent annual rate of interest until Oct. 1. But, there is a catch.  To qualify for the 35 percent interest rate, on Oct. 1 the depositor must put the money into a 12-month ''All Savers'' Certificate at Lincoln.

headline: N.& W. Profit Declines 56%
abstract: The Norfolk & Western Railway today reported a second-quarter profit of $26.2 million, or 80 cents a share, down 56 percent from $59 million, or $1.88 a share, a year before. Revenues fell 14 percent, to $351.2 million, from $406.2 million.

headline: LONG TERM RATES DECLINE SLIGHTLY
abstract: Long-term interest rates declined slightly yesterday, but not before the markets were whipsawed by wide gyrations with long-term bond prices fluctuating by more than two points.   Securities dealers agreed that the wide price swings occurred on low trading volume, and stressed that uncertainty about interest rates and the timing of Treasury auctions had caused many investors and traders to wait on the sidelines. Early in the day the Treasury announced the postponement of the regular three-month and six-month Treasury bills auction, and said the sale of 20-year bonds tomorrow and one-year bills on Thursday might also be postponed if Congress does not increase the debt ceiling.   The bellwether issue in the long-term bond market, the 13 7/8 percent Treasury bonds due 2011, traded as low as 90 5/8 when prices were declining early in the day, but then rallied to 92 3/4 by the close. At the higher price, the issue yields 14.97 percent to maturity compared with a 15.32 percent yield at the low price.

headline: OUR DOLLAR, THEIR PROBLEM-AGAIN?
abstract: LONDON Once again, the system by which the world prices its money is under fire.  For a decade now, the international financial order has evolved a system that largely leaves the price of yen, marks, francs, pounds, guilders, lire, pesos and cruzeiros to the ebb and flow of supply and demand. In many quarters, of course, this system is still heartily applauded; but increasingly there are calls for reconsideration and for a return to what in any other market would be known as price controls.   In the market for national currencies, those controls were known as fixed exchange rates, which set and sustained the ratios at which one currency was exchanged for another. For a quarter century, fixed rates were the norm of the postwar world. Then, on an August Sunday evening 10 years ago yesterday, Richard Nixon snapped the link between gold and the dollar's value, shattering the rock on which fixed rates rested and, in effect, forcing a reliance on the free market to set the price of currencies.   Now, an increasing number of experts are calling for a reexamination of that system. A great many espouse a return, to some degree or another, to the old system of controls.

headline: COLE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FOR MOTORISTS IN MOSCOW, RANK IS ALL
abstract: Fly to Moscow, catch a taxi at the airport and something curious about this society is visible right away: If power corrupts, it does so just as surely behind a steering wheel as anywhere else.   In a country that boasts of its social discipline, the roads are a jungle. The Soviet Union has its highway code, its traffic police, its radar traps and its driver's license penalties. But in the end it is power that counts: If you have it, you can get away with almost anything. If you don't, better stay in the slow lane.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS After Treasury's Refunding
abstract: The completion of the Treasury's August refunding leaves the credit markets with a host of worries that are keeping interest rates high.   Although some dealers say that speculative trading could push prices of the new 3 1/4-year, 10-year and 30-year Treasury issues higher, they warn that none of the market's fundamental problems have gone away. Analysts agree that demand for the new Treasury issues was good from foreigners, individuals and small institutions, but there is disagreement about the strength of buying by large domestic institutions. A sustainable move to lower yields will only come, they say, if large buyers step forward.

headline: Sohio Unit Drops Uranium Project
abstract: A spokesman for the Sohio Western Mining Company, a unit of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), said the concern had dropped plans for uranium exploration in the Santa Fe National Forest, although it might decide to go ahead with drilling later.   The announcement by a spokesman, Randy Walthius, followed a news conference by opponents of the drilling, who said they would take unspecified ''physical action,'' if necessary, to halt the project.

headline: Around the World; U.S. Accepts 1,100 Poles Who Stayed in Austria
abstract: The United States has accepted some 1,100 Polish emigres in the last 10 months and may allocate more money to help refugees resettle in the West, an American diplomat said today.   The diplomat, Randolph M. Bell, who is the State Department's coordinator for refugees, said the United States ''was doing everything possible within the framework of its immigration laws to ease the troubled refugee situation in this small neutral country.''   He referred to an appeal by Interior Minister Erwin Lanc of Austria, who asked the United States, Canada and Australia to increase their immigration quotas because of the influx of emigres from Poland.

headline: Carpenter Sets Steel Projects
abstract: The Carpenter Technology Corporation, a medium-sized maker of specialty steels and other metals based in Reading, Pa., said it would spend $165 million on three capital projects as part of a $400 million program to increase its production by 50 percent.   The company said that a new $112 million hot rolling mill would be installed at its Pennsylvania plant, along with a $46.4 million rotary forging machine and melting equipment.

headline: Chase Offers Equimark $125 Million Investment
abstract: In a move intended ultimately to position itself in the Pittsburgh consumer-banking market, the Chase Manhattan Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to invest $125 million in the troubled Equimark Corporation, that city's third-largest bank holding company.    Chase, in return for its infusion of capital, would receive an option to buy all the stock of Equibank, which is owned by Equimark.  ''We're not buying up a bank here; it's a healthy mutual marriage of our interests,'' said Willard C. Butcher, Chase's chairman, in an interview yesterday. If Chase eventually were to acquire Equimark, it would give the New York bank a strong position throughout the greater Pittsburgh area and the Ohio Valley, he said.

headline: ESTATE TAX CUT MAY HURT SALES OF LIFE INSURANCE
abstract: When Dr. Joseph Paris opened his practice some years ago as an obstetrician and gynecologist in the Bronx, he purchased a substantial life insurance policy to help pay estate taxes after his death.   Now the new tax law has substantially minimized Federal estate and gift taxes, so Dr. Paris plans to reduce his life insurance coverage. ''Anybody in the successful middle-income group has got to ask, 'What do I need the extra insurance for?' '' said Dr. Paris, who is 52 years old. ''We've got to cut back.''

headline: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The Club
abstract: To the Business Editor: ''Pittsburgh's Top Brass Love the Duquesne Club'' (Aug. 9) noted that the venerable institution now counts three women members.

headline: BRITAIN ANNOUNCES TOUGHER MEASURES TO COMBAT RIOTING
abstract: In a toughening counteroffensive against rioters, the British Government has decided to permit the country's traditionally unarmed police to use plastic bullets, armored vehicles and water cannon to quell disorders.   At the same time, the Home Ministry was considering the use of army camps as detention centers for those convicted of crimes stemming from the 12 days of riots. Several hundred of the thousands of people arrested are expected to be sentenced within the next few weeks, adding a new burden to an already overcrowded prison system.   The new measures were announced late last night by Edward Gardner, a Conservative member of Parliament, after he and other Conservative legislators had met with William Whitelaw, the Home Secretary.

headline: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BONN TIES MILITARY CUTS TO OTHER BUDGET PROBLEMS
abstract: West German Government officials today rejected American criticism of Bonn's plans to reduce the rate of growth of military spending next year, arguing that severe cuts in social programs would have been @unachievable without similar cuts in military spending.   In a radio interview, the chief Government spokesman, Kurt Becker, said the ''budget program contains essential cuts in welfare programs, so it was necessary overall to plan a balance within the budget.''   Another spokesman, Lothar Ruhl, said at a news conference that ''discussions among the NATO allies over the extent of their defense performance is nothing new.''

headline: People
abstract: * Lucien Kapuscinski has been elected president of Liller Neal Weltin Inc., Atlanta.

headline: SLATER ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: F.C.C. DROPS LENDING CASE
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission, reversing its earlier position and a decision by an administrative law judge, today dismissed a complaint that had accused the Household Finance Corporation of breaking the law in computing some finance charges.   The complaint was filed by the F.T.C. in 1978 under the Truth-in-Lending Act, and it was upheld a year later by the judge, Daniel H. Hanscom.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that their decision to hold naval exercises in waters claimed by Libya was intended to affirm the right of free passage in international waters and not continue to allow even the appearance of letting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi set the rules.   The possibility of an air clash, such as the one that occurred yesterday with the reported downing of two Libyan fighters, was not regarded as inevitable, nor was it considered out of the question, several officials said. But they said that because President Carter refused to allow American planes to fly over the Gulf of Sidra during similar exercises last year, there was considerable pressure from the Navy not to allow a precedent to be set.   In 1973 Colonel Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, established a line across the mouth of the Gulf of Sidra as a ''base line,'' south of which Libya claimed as its internal waters. The American officials said that almost yearly since then, American planes and warships had crossed that line. But last year, because of the crisis over the American hostages in Iran, and because of a desire not to cause unnecessary agitation in the region, Mr. Carter did not permit American air or naval craft to go farther south than three miles north of the line.

headline: VERIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WILTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GRUMMAN STUDIES BID
abstract: The Grumman Corporation, signaling that it will fight a $450 million takeover bid by the LTV Corporation of Dallas, disclosed yesterday that it was calling a board meeting to discuss the antitrust considerations of the proposed merger as well as LTV's labor relations.   Under Federal law, a target company is unable to state categorically that it will oppose a takeover without first filing extensive documentation with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Dynamics Gets NASA Official
abstract: Alan M. Lovelace, acting administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, announced today that he will leave NASA on July 11 to join the General Dynamics Corporation as vice president for science and engineering.   Mr. Lovelace has been acting head of NASA since Jan. 20, when Robert Frosch, appointed during the Carter Administration, resigned that post.

headline: 60,000 Hondurans; Protest 'Repression'
abstract: As many as 60,000 Hondurans held a demonstration here last night to protest ''repression'' by security forces. Security was tight and no incidents were reported.

headline: U.N. Welcomes Belize As Its 156th Member
abstract: The General Assembly admitted Belize to United Nations membership today in a 144-to-1 vote, with only Guatemala opposed.

headline: ANGOLA CHARGES NEW DRIVE BY THE SOUTH AFRICAN FORCES
abstract: Angolan officials charged here today that South African troops had begun a new drive deep into southern Angola east of the area where the South African raid began on Aug.  24.   This statement was denounced in Pretoria by a South African military spokesman as ''ridiculous propaganda.'' He said it was ''obviously aimed'' at the special session of the United Nations General Assembly that opened today at the request of African nations.

headline: HIGBEE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Other Business; ANOTHER ONSLAUGHT IN BEER
abstract: Here comes Miller again.  In the hotly competitive world of beer, Anheuser-Busch, the brewing industry's leader, has managed to hold its lead against Miller's remarkable surge. One Bud advantage has been its broader product line, most notably, Michelob, its entry at the upper or ''superpremium'' end, which accounts for about 7 percent of all beer sold.

headline: Guatemala Gunmen Seize Cabinet Official
abstract: Unidentified gunmen kidnapped the Guatemalan Health Minister, Dr. Roquelino Recinos Mendez, tonight as he drove on a highway south of the capital, a government communique said.

headline: THRIFT INDUSTRY CREDIT SOUGHT
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has asked the Federal Reserve Board to revise conditions for access to its discount, or lending, window to provide ailing thrift institutions with what could be an important source of back-up credit.   Richard T. Pratt, chairman of the bank board, which regulates savings and loan associations, pressed for the change in a letter dated July 10 to Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman.   Mr. Pratt wrote that the existing requirement that the savings and loan associations first exhaust credit available from the Federal Home Loan Bank System before borrowing from the Fed ''needs reevaluation and is not appropriate at this time.''

headline: FIRST CHARTER FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OUTLOOK STILL UNCERTAIN FOR LAW-OF-SEA TALKS
abstract: The United Nations Law of the Sea conference, the most ambitious treaty-making effort ever undertaken by the world body, reconvenes here Monday with no assurance that it can escape the doldrums into which it was plunged by the advent of the Reagan Administration.   The Reagan Administration's decision to undertake a ''sweeping review'' of the tentative accords, which were reached last year after seven years of complex bargaining by as many as 163 nations, threw off stride the attempt to conclude the treaty this year.   While Washington studied the 440 draft articles prepared for the many-sided treaty, which would regulate use of the oceans and their resources, the conference mostly marked time at the seven-week session it held in New York last spring.   On the eve of the reconvening of the talks for another four- or five-week round, the conference's Secretary General, Bernardo Zuleta of Colombia, told reporters that he expected the United States to play a ''more positive role'' than at the spring session.

headline: FRENCH ACQUISITION
abstract: Saint-Gobain-Pont-a-Mousson S.A. said today that it would take control of Logabax S.A., the French office computer company, which is now in the hands of a receiver. Italy's Olivetti S.p.A., in which S.G.P.M. has a 30 percent stake, will hold 65 percent of the capital of a new company, Ste Nouvelle Logabax, and an S.G.P.M. subsidiary, Cie des Machines Bull, will hold the remaining 35 percent, it said. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed.

headline: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Bang for Business...
abstract: Analysts are not expecting big things from business as a direct result of the Administration's triumph last week. More generous depreciation schedules will be welcome, says Lawrence Chimerine, chief economist at Chase Econometrics, and consumer spending should rise as a result of individual tax cuts. But economic growth is likely to be far below Administration pro- jections, and budget deficits far higher, he predicts. The combination will keep interest rates high and temper investment enthusiasm. Continuing high rates of interest will not only make external financing difficult, but will keep the dollar strong, Mr. Chimerine expects, hurting exports and jeopardizing industries vulnerable to imports. Since fighting inflation seems to be Mr. Reagan's first priority, Robert Gough of Data Resources, Inc. doubts the Administration would be greatly concerned if investment showed only modest growth over the next few years. At present, he predicts the tax cuts will boost fixed investment 5 percent next year and 7 percent in 1983. ...And Worse Ahead?   Unless these tax cuts beget further budget cuts, the Administration's program could come unglued. If it does, business could be in for tough sledding in the 1980s. The Administration has pledged more cuts of up to $44 billion annually to achieve a balanced budget by 1984.

headline: ASBESTOS SUBSTITUTE SOUGHT
abstract: The Interior Department expects domestic use of the sometimes deadly mineral asbestos to remain steady, and it expects use elsewhere to grow at an average rate of 4.5 percent through the year 2000.   These projections have been made partly in the belief that the hazards of asbestos are finally well enough understood to prevent further dangerous exposure to asbestos fibers.   Inhalation of asbestos in past decades has caused tens of thousands of cancer deaths so far and is likely to result in 200,000 more cancer deaths over the next 20 years, according to medical experts at Mount Sinai Hospital Environmental Sciences Laboratory. It has also caused thousands of other workers to suffer asbestosis, a chronic and disabling respiratory disease that is occasionally fatal.

headline: THE U.N. TODAY
abstract: Sept. 8, 1981 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets on Nambibia at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Prospects
abstract: At The Crossr oads   As Congress awaits what is likely to be an additional $16 billion to $20 billion in proposed budget cuts, conflicting economic signals are likely to make debate about what should and should not be done even more difficult.   Upward revisions in G.N.P. data for the second quarter, and a flash report of only modest decline in the third, suggest the economy has not fallen into recession. Personal incomes are rising, along with consumption expenditures. And short-term interest rates are trending downward, bringing some relief to the credit markets.

headline: TELEPHONE RATES GOING UP RAPIDLY
abstract: Rates charged for many telephone services are being increased dramatically as a result of major changes occurring in the telephone industry.   In the last three months, large corporate users of phone lines have been hit by a series of rate increases totaling 40 percent or more, and there are indications that consumers may soon be seeing similar increases.   In Texas the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company, which won a statewide rate increase in February, has requested another one that would double the minimum monthly charge for phone service in some cities.   The New York Telephone Company wants to nearly double the charge for installing a phone to $108.10 and to raise pay phone rates to 25 cents.   ''There really has been in the last 12 months a greater disruption in telephone rates than in the entire history of the industry,'' said Steven G. Chrust, a telephone industry analyst with Sanford C.  Bernstein & Company.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: No Higher Bid By Occidental
abstract: Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, said that Occidental had ''no intention'' of increasing its $36-ashare stock offer to buy the Zapata Corporation, a Houston oil services company. Zapata shares fell in heavy trading by $3.625 a share, to $30, on the news.

headline: Business Digest; THURSDAY, AUGUST 27, 1981; International
abstract: Nigeria, the No. 2 supplier of oil to the U.S., will cut its price by $4 to $36 a barrel. The cutback may be the first of several by OPEC members in the face of a worldwide oil glut. If other African producers follow Nigeria's lead, analysts said, American gasoline prices might be reduced as much as 3 cents a gallon. (Page A1.)   Japan, in a reversal, will require produce from California to be fumigated. The decision, a blow to the state, came as the spread of the fruit fly infestation to Los Angeles County was confirmed. (A1.)

headline: PEKING ASSESSMENT ASSERTS MAO MADE ERRORS AS LEADER
abstract: The Chinese Communist Party said today that Mao Zedong, the man who led it to power and ruled China for 27 years, had been a brilliant revolutionary who turned into a blundering national leader.   The party said that his contributions ''far outweigh'' his mistakes, but that both were monumental.  Mao, who was long regarded as a godlike figure beyond criticism, came under attack in a 35,000-word statement Excerpts from statement, page A12. for his role in starting the Cultural Revolution, a 10-year period of social turmoil that ended with his death in 1976.

headline: Timberland Suit
abstract: The Timberland Company said it had sued the Stride Rite Corporation, Uniroyal Inc., and the Sperry Topsider Company, on charges of making false patent claims for Sperry Topsider boating shoes. The suit says the defendants have continued to claim in advertising that Sperry Topsider shoes are patented although the patents expired 20 years ago. The suit seeks an injunction to prohibit this advertising as well as damages to Timberland, as a competitor of Topsiders, for profits on sales lost as a result of the advertising.

headline: NEW ISSUES SLOWED BY HIGH PRICES
abstract: The volume of new corporate and tax-exempt bond issues remains modest as high interest rates discourage many borrowers.  Among the scheduled issues is an unusual offering by the Alaska Housing Finance Corporation, which is selling $150 million of mortgage revenue bonds evenly divided between maturities in 1991 and 2001. Interest on the bonds is subject to Federal income tax even though the corporation is a state authority and has previously sold tax-exempt bonds not subject to Federal income tax.

headline: Patents; CRYSTAL IN LENS REACTS MORE PROMPTLY TO LIGHT
abstract: A New York eye specialist has invented a spectacle lens made of a layer of liquid crystal between a pair of identically curved sheets of glass or plastic. Visibility through the lens is electrically controlled according to the intensity of ambient light.

headline: Novo Net Up 96.8% in Half
abstract: Novo Industri, the world's leading producer of enzymes and the second-largest producer of insulin after Eli Lilly & Company, has reported that net income in the first half of 1981 soared 96.8 percent on an increase in sales of 48.7 percent.   The Copenhagen-based biotechnology concern, which has two subsidiaries in the United States and is about one-third owned by investors in this country, said that earnings in the first half widened to $18.7 million, or 97 cents a share, from $9.5 million, or 55 cents a share, in the first half of 1980.

headline: SALVADOR REBELS GAIN NEW SUPPORT
abstract: Mexico and France recognized El Salvador's guerrilla-led opposition today as a ''representative political force.''   The joint declaration, handed this morning to the current president of the United Nations Security Council, Jorge Illueca of Panama, runs counter to the Reagan Administration's policy. Washington seeks the military defeat of the guerrillas and urges democratic opposition parties to take part in elections for a constitutional assembly scheduled for next March.  The United States was not mentioned by name in the statement.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH HAIG ON MIDEAST
abstract: Following are excerpts from a Stat e Department transcript of an interview with Se cretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in which he discussed t he Middle East:   Q. Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel will be visiting next week. What kind of a role do you see for the United States over the next several months in negotiations between Israel and Egypt?   A. Let's answer the question by talking about the visit itself and how the visit will or will not contribute to that. Clearly, we had discussions during the Sadat visit on the Middle East peace process, and it was clear then that President Sadat is anxious to get on with both phases of the Camp David structure. We've had in the meantime an announced meeting to go on with that process on Sept. 23 at the ministerial level - that's the autonomy talks.   So with respect to Mr. Begin's visit, we are very anxious to hear how he views this process, particularly with respect to the autonomy talks.

headline: OIL ENTITLEMENT PROGRAM IN TURMOIL
abstract: A number of oil companies might be asked to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to cover the ''disappearance'' of low-priced oil from the Government entitlements program in its final months.   The result, according to industry officials, means that companies that were supposed to benefit from the program - through subsidies paid by larger oil companies - will end up owing money instead.   The situation, the subject of several current lawsuits involving oil companies and the Department of Energy, which has administered the system, arises from a huge reclassification of price-controlled ''old'' oil during the months just before and just after last November's general election.   The ''disa ppearance'' of the oil has alread y been the subject of atleast one Congressional investigation. It app arently was reclassified to another category of higher-pr iced petroleum not subject to entitlements.

headline: Heavy Metal Magazine To Increase Advertising
abstract: Now that there has been a successful ''Heavy Metal'' movie and a successful ''Heavy Metal'' record album, Leonard Mogel, publisher and editor of Heavy Metal magazine, has decided to go after advertising seriously.

headline: Foreign Bribe Curb Altered
abstract: The Senate Banking Committee voted 11-4 today for changes in the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, eliminating what sponsors called excessive rules imposed on American exporters.   The sponsors of the bill said that the revised act would still retain strong legal sanctions against bribery of foreign officials by American companies.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Norman B. Levy, a longtime film industry sales executive, has in recent years been closely associated with Alan J. Hirschfield, first at Columbia Pictures Industries and since January 1980, at the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation. Now, a month after Mr. Hirschfield was promoted to chairman and chief executive officer of Fox by Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman who purchased the company last spring, Mr.  Levy has been appointed to Mr. Hirschfield's former post of vice chairman. The changes follow the resignation of Dennis C. Stanfill as chairman and chief executive officer late in June after a dispute with Mr. Davis. C. Joseph LaBonte continues as president.

headline: POLISH CHIEF SAYS DISORDERS COULD BRING 'TRAGEDY'
abstract: Stanislaw Kania, the Polish party leader, said today that further street demonstrations could lead a national tragedy.   In a short speech at the first meeting of the Communist Party's new Central Committee, Mr. Kania said, ''Polish streets are no longer peaceful,'' and he called this a ''qualitatively new element'' in the political upheaval.   ''We must find a way to make Polish streets peaceful,'' he said.  ''The logic of the development of this situation could lead us to the greatest national tragedy.''

headline: Rise in Supply Of Gasoline
abstract: Gasoline supplies in the United States increased last week, running counter to the usual summer decline for the second week in a row, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday.   For the week ended Friday, gasoline inventories rose to 237.1 million barrels, compared with 236.5 million the previous Friday and 258.6 million at the comparable date last year, the industry group said.

headline: Around the World; Elections in Greece Are Set for Oct. 18
abstract: The President of Greece today dissolved Parliament and set Oct. 18 as the date for elections.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Abbott Laboratgries, Chicago, has elected Laurence R. Lee senior vice president, administration; Lael F. Johnson vice president and general counsel; John C. Kane corporate vice president, chemical and agricultural products, and James G. Andress corporate vice president, planning and development.   * Abex Corporation, a subsidiary of IC Industries, has elected to its board Harold R. Logan, executive vice president of W.R. Grace & Company.   * ADE Corporation, Newton, Mass., has appointed Michael Kaminsky Jr. vice president operations.

headline: Occidental in Italian Venture
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation and Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, the Italian national energy corporation, announced the formation of a joint chemical and coal company, to be called Enoxy, that would be capitalized at $1.05 billion.   Enoxy initially will control some 60 chemical plants in Sicily, Sardinia and northeast Italy, a spokesman said, and will also control four coal mines in Kentucky and West Virginia now operated by Occidental's Island Creek Coal Company unit, he said.

headline: GAF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Geer, DuBois Adds Anso IV Carpet
abstract: Geer, DuBois Advertising, the same agency that gave us the delightful Peek Freans cookies advertising, have now produced some carpet advertising that doesn't just lie there.   Actually the client is the Allied Corporation's Fibers and Plastics Company and the assignment is to promote Anso IV nylon carpet fiber.

headline: 9.22 DROP PUTS DOW AT 967.66
abstract: With short-term interest rates moving higher again, stock prices continued to drop yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average, posting its seventh loss in eight trading sessions, retreated 9.22 points, to 967.66.   Exactly two weeks earlier, the Dow finished at 1,006.56, only to slip below 1,000 in a string of generally moderate, but persistent, declines. Yesterday's closing was the lowest since May 11 at 963.44.The Dow ended last year at 963.99.

headline: CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: President Style
abstract: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''Hail to the Chief, as Executive'' (Aug. 30): Ronald Hoff may be dazzled by Mr. Reagan's managerial style but we don't have to be. Let us take some of his points in turn:   ''Let your people know what you stand for.'' - Mr. Reagan's policies have been a welter of confusion, especially in foreign and military affairs where violent oratory, prodigious waste of the nation's resources and reversal of signals have been constantly present. No definition of security has emerged and in energy, for example, security has diminished.

headline: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EGYPT COAXES NILE FARMERS TO 'INVADE' THE DESERT
abstract: The official talk in this remote, peaceful desert oasis has a harsh military ring. People speak about ''invading the desert,'' ''attacking the land'' and obtaining ''food security.''   The words are those used by President Anwar el-Sadat when he speaks, as he often does, of his Green Revolution and of Egypt's need to establish new communities in the desert to ease the strain on the fertile but overfarmed and overpopulated Nile valley and delta.   The facts that move Mr. Sadat to emphasize land reclamation and development are compelling. Only 4 percent of Egypt's land is cultivated, and practically all of the farm land is in the Nile valley and delta, where more than 95 percent of the nation's 42 million people live without much elbow room.

headline: EX-GUERRILLAS REMINISCE AT THE KING DAVID HOTEL
abstract: A few of the Jewish guerrillas who blew up the King David Hotel in 1946 came back to the King David yesterday evening - this time to sip champagne, reminisce and mix their pride and sorrow at the events of 35 years ago. Even now, in middle age, they had a stony toughness in their eyes.   The man who set the fuses was there. The woman who made three futile telephone calls of warning was there. The man who brought the explosives into Jerusalem, the man who guarded a key corridor, the man who was drinking quietly in the bar, were there. But their commander, Menachem Begin, now Prime Minister of Israel, did not attend. He had been invited and had apparently vacillated all week, and finally did not appear.

headline: M.I.T. Wants Closer Ties with Business
abstract: There are s igns on all sides that industry's involvement in university re search is growing. With this growth has come a spate of articles expr essing interest, raising questions, voicing concern.   None has gone so far as to suggest that American corporations, by financing university research, have targeted the universities for takeovers. Still, some blunt questions are being asked about the university-industry relationship - questions that ask, in effect, whether access to university laboratories is for sale to the highest bidder, who might then control the research, and, ultimately, reap unmerited profits through preferential licensing of patents.

headline: G.E. PLANS TO SHUT FLAT IRON PLANT
abstract: The General Electric Company said it plans to close its 77-year-old flat iron plant here, putting about 1,000 employees out of work, because it is phasing out its metal irons in favor of plastic bodied irons.   Plant workers were told that G.E. will halt production in the United States of metal irons and close the plant, about 45 miles east of Los Angeles, by next February.

headline: DIOR HOPING TO FIND A NEW PARTNER
abstract: Christian Dior, for the last decade at the financial mercy of two ailing conglomerates, is hoping to find a new partner that will allow it greater freedom in its business ventures.   ''We want a stable investor who will let us grow as we want,'' said Jacques Rouet, the chairman of Dior, in the company's gray-and-white headquarters on the elegant Avenue Montaigne. ''I have no preference who takes over.''   Tarnished by a new wave of bankruptcy and scandals in its beleaguered parent companies, Dior is now making a vigorous effort to improve its image. Two weeks ago the couture house severed its links with family members of Agache-Willot, the troubled textile and retailing company. Dior is a subsidiary of Boussac-Saint-Freres, a textile concern that was bankrupt in 1978 when it was purchased by Agache-Willot.

headline: PRESIDENT WARNED O N HIGH RATES
abstract: President Reagan's senior economic advisers have warned him that continuing high interest rates could cut deeply into the economy across a broad front, weakening the economic expansion forecast for 1982 and driving unemployment higher.   At a White House meeting yesterday with Cabinet-rank officials, Mr. Reagan was told that unless interest rates came down soon, there could be pronounced softening of business investment plans and business inventories. The weakness in auto sales and house buying caused by high interest rates could spread to other consumer durable goods, the advisers said.   Administration officials reported the essence of the appraisal as part of a White House drive to prepare Congress for more cuts in the budget, including military spending.

headline: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GULF, SMALLEST OF THE SEVEN OIL SISTERS
abstract: FEW Companies have a historq as grand and glorious as that of the Gulf Oil Corporation. Born in the Spindletop gusher of 1901 and financed by the Mellon fortune, Gulf went on to successfully challenge the Rockefeller oil empire. In dizzying succession, it opened the world's first gasoline filling station, acquired oceans of oil beneath the deserts of the Middle East and the swamps of Venezuela, and firmly established itself as one of the leading producers, refiners and purveyors of black gold.   Gulf is now the seventh-largest oil company in the world, the seventh-biggest company in America and a member of the planet's most exclusive business sorority - the Seven Sisters of international oil. On a warm summer evening, the orange light emanating from the crown of the company's headquarters tower in downtown Pittsburgh seems to suggest power, confidence and even a trace of deserved smugness.   Appearances, however, can be deceiving. Over the last half decade, Gulf has been hammered by a political payoff scandal, a battery of lawsuits, the loss of most of its prized foreign oil, declines in domestic output, a ludicrously disadvantageous natural gas sales contract and a devastating change in energy policy by the Government in Canada, where Gulf has vast holdings. Perhaps most painful, however, has been the combination of sharply reduced consumer demand and an overabundance of refining capacity, an industrywide affliction that is stinging Gulf particularly.

headline: SAUDIS SAID TO REIMBURSE 38 TREASURY SALARIES
abstract: A high Treasury Department official said today that Saudi Arabia had reimbursed the United States Government for the salaries of 38 Treasury Department officials working on a Saudi-American commission promoting contracts and ''good business relations'' between the two countries since 1974.   But the official, Marc E. Leland, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, testified before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Government Operations that the arrangement was not illegal.

headline: GENERAL MAGNAPLATE CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ASHLAND: NEW MAN, OLD WOES
abstract: For Ashland Oil Inc., the year has been a tough one. Earnings have plummented because of the company's slumping refinery operations. Wall Street analysts have turned investors away from what they consider an inflated stock price. And Standard & Poor's and Moody's have lowered the company's bond ratings.   In an effort to turn things around, Ashland, as some industry analysts see it, has eased out its chairman and chief executive officer, Orin E. Atkins, who had guided the company for the past 17 years. The man inheriting the problems is John R. Hall, a boyish 48-year-old chemical engineer.

headline: PBS Board Receives Cluster Ad Proposal
abstract: The board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting was told last week that the proposed cluster method of broadcast advertising on pubic television could generate as much as $164 million a year for public TV and radio.   That figure comes from a study done by Browne, Bortz & Coddington, a Denver consulting firm.

headline: RIVAL DUTCH PARTIES PAINFULLY FORGE NEW COALITION
abstract: The formation of a Dutch government is a marriage ceremony by ordeal. So long, irritable and painful are the negotiations among the various parties trying to put together a coalition that, paradoxically, once formed the governments tend to last.   This, at least, is the tradition. These days, as a new coalition takes shape, the pain is evident but the paradox is in doubt.  It is three and a half stormy months since the Dutch elections, by making a series of minuscule adjustments in the balance of the parties, reduced the Christian Democratic-Liberal coalition led by Prime Minister Dries van Agt from a one-seat majority to a one-seat minority in Parliament.

headline: WHITAKER CABLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dollar, Dollar
abstract: To the Business Editor: In ''Our Dollar, Their Problem -Again?'' (Aug. 16) the Swiss are praised for their ''self-discipline'' in controlling inflation and maintaining the strength of the Swiss franc. The Swiss adapted the classical cure for inflation - tight monetary and fiscal policies which created a recession, forcing wages and prices to fall and unemployment to rise - but their success was aided by two advantages not mentioned in the article.   First, the Bretton Woods system of fixed-exchange rates led to the Swiss currency being undervalued; the Swiss franc was appreciating in the aftermath of the 1973 oil embargo. With the price of oil pegged to the dollar, the Swiss ended up with cheaper oil after 1974 since the franc went up faster than the dollar price of oil.

headline: Market Place; MANEUVERING IN CONOCO BIDS
abstract: WALL STREET professionals call it ''a free look,'' not committing investors to anything, simply ''a chance to get in line.'' As a consequence, many investors in Conoco, faced so far with multibillion-dollar takeover bids from Seagram, Du Pont and Mobil, sent some or all of their shares yesterday to Joseph E. Seagram & Sons.   The reason was not necessarily related to the price being offered by the big liquor company but because yesterday was Seagram's ''proration date,'' the last day that Seagram is obliged to accept stock for payment. However, under Federal rules, those who get in line to sell can get out of line until the ''withdrawal date,'' after which they cannot get out.

headline: Chevron Pact On Oil Prices
abstract: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - An $82.5 million settlement, the secondlargest in a Federal oil pricing complaint, has been signed between Chevron U.S.A. Inc. and the Department of Energy, both sides said today.   In agreeing to make restitution, Chevron said the pact would settle all outstanding regulatory issues.

headline: CONSUMER DEBT ROSE DURING JULY
abstract: American consumers bought $1.95 billion more on credit than they repaid in July, taking on new installment debt more slowly but also paying off old debt at a slower pace than in June, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.   Outstanding consumer debt rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7 percent - about the same as in June -the report said. New consumer debt in July was about $28.75 billion, compared with $29 billion in June, the report said.

headline: OIL OUTPUT UP 2.6% IN AUGUST
abstract: Crude oil production in the lower 48 states of the United States increased on a year-to-year basis for the third consecutive month in August, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.   The trade group said the 2.6 percent monthly rise, equal to some 228,000 barrels daily, is evidence that ''the trend in domestic crude oil production in the lower 48 states has changed significantly.''   For most of the decade of the 1970's, crude production, outside of Alaska, slipped by about 300,000 barrels a day.  The overall gain in domestic crude output, the institute said, came despite a decline in Alaskan production of 11,000 barrels a day due to production problems. The overall year-to-year gain in domestic output thus totaled 217,000 barrels daily.

headline: International
abstract: The United States trade deficit with Japan may exceed $15 billion this year, a record imbalance that is threatening to lead to new trade frictions between the two countries. The American trade representative, William E. Brock, is asking Japan for concessions.  (Page D1.)

headline: Commodities; Precious Metals in Transition
abstract: ONE of the ironies of last week's plunging prices of precious metals and financial instrument futures was that these two markets showed the most promise of reversing long downward trends.   Financial futures, which move inversely to prices of the underlying securities, were expected to benefit by signs that interest rates were easing. Precious metals analysts were also optimistic. One bull who had become a bear and has been recently edging back to his former position is James E. Sinclair, head of a major brokerage house carrying his name.

headline: BRITISH OFFICIALS SAY THEY HAVE LITTLE HOPE OF ENDING HUNGER STRIKES AT ULSTER PRISON
abstract: Two Irish Republican Army hunger strikers appeared to be approaching death tonight as British Government officials conceded that efforts to end the crisis had virtually collapsed.   ''We have now decided that we have gone about as far as we can go,'' said a spokesman for the Northern Ireland Office here. ''We are willing to make concessions, but we are not willing to give control of the Maze Prison to the prisoners.''   With six prisoners dead of self-starvation since early May and the condition of two more deteriorating rapidly, the British have come under increasing criticism from the Irish Government, Roman Catholics and, surprisingly, a key Protestant leader.

headline: Around the World; Italy's Cabinet Approves $8 Billion in Cuts for '82
abstract: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini won Cabinet approval today for a 1982 budget that cuts more than $8 billion from Government spending on health services, social security and local government.

headline: Missile Said to Explode Near Italian Cargo Plane
abstract: The authorities are investigating a report that a missile exploded near an Italian civilian cargo plane on a flight between Palermo and Rome last month, air control officials said today.   The pilot of the DC-9, Capt. Eraldo Tortatolo, reported the explosion shortly after midnight on Aug. 8 at a distance estimated at 5 to 10 miles from the plane as it approached the island of Ustica north of Sicily.

headline: SPY CASE AND TOOL INDUSTRY
abstract: The arrest on espionage charges this week of Marian Zacharski, president of the obscure Polish American Machinery Corporation in suburban Elk Grove Village, Ill., has brought unwanted notoriety to the machine tool company, whose annual revenues are $30 million. But expanding East-West trade relations may be dealt a much harsher blow.   ''We have thousands of calls from customers wanting to know what happened, and a few have canceled orders,'' said Henry Slowinski, vice president of Polish American, which is called Polamco. ''It's a difficult time for us,'' he added, ''but the charges are against Mr.  Zacharski, not against Polamco. This will pass.''

headline: IRAN REPORTS 45 MORE EXECUTIONS AS DRIVE AGAINST LEFTISTS GOES ON
abstract: Forty-five more executions were reported from Iran today as the Islamic Government continued its purge of leftist opponents.   All were put to death last night at Teheran's Evin Prison, according to Jomhuri Islami, the newspaper of the dominant Islamic Republican Party. The death sentences were carried out a day after at least 147 other dissidents were executed at the prison and in other parts of the country.

headline: Hair-Care Conflict At Ogilvy & Mather
abstract: The conflict that caused the rift between Bristol-Myers's Clairol Products division and Ogilvy & Mather, which has been handling three Condition brands, resulted from the Rave Hair Products, the account that the agency has from Chesebrough-Ponds.

headline: Around the World; I.L.O. Tells of Increase In Attacks on Teachers
abstract: An increase in violence against teachers, which has become ''ominous'' in some countries, has contributed to making stress a ''significant occupational hazard in teaching,'' according to the International Labor Organization.

headline: SOVIET ASSEMBLES WORKERS TO ASSAIL THE POLISH UNION
abstract: The Soviet Union's campaign against the Polish independent trade union, Solidarity, took a new turn today as meetings were held at factories in Moscow and elsewhere at which Solidarity was denounced for actions at its congress this week.   At Moscow's giant Zil truck and auto plant, and at similar gatherings in Leningrad and other cities, workers were assembled to approve an open letter that spoke of a bid by Solidarity for a ''counterrevolution.'' The letter, approved in Moscow, accused the Polish union of trying to provoke workers in the Soviet Union and in other Eastern-bloc nations to ''betray'' Communism.   The factory meetings were portrayed as an effort by Soviet workers to warn Poles of the dangers of backing Solidarity. But the Kremlin's underlying purpose appeared to be to arouse indignation among millions of Soviet workers as it ponders a situation that is evidently as grave now, from the Soviet standpoint, as it has been in months.

headline: Market Place; Superior Oil After the Split
abstract: THE shares of the Superior Oil Company, once the highest-priced on the Big Board, will be trading near $40 after two 5-for-1 splits in the last year and a half. The latest of these splits goes into effect next Friday. The shares closed yesterday at 186 1/2.   For the first time, the stock of this well-regarded company will be accessible to the average investor. Meanwhile, institutional investors who had hesitated to buy the somewhat illiquid shares may find Superior more interesting now.

headline: HAIG AIDE INSISTS U.S. RIGHTS POLICY IS EVENHANDED
abstract: The third-ranking official of the State Department told Congress today that the department was not planning to abolish the office of Assistant Secretary for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, a step that some officials had discussed after the rejection of President Reagan's first nominee for the post.   Walter J. Stoessel Jr., Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, also drew praise from liberals on a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee by saying that ''ours is not a policy of selective indignation.'' It is one of opposition to human rights violations ''whether by ally or adversary, friend or foe,'' he said.

headline: BONN IS REASSURED ON U.S. ARMS VIEW
abstract: President Reagan sent Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany a letter on the eve of the Ottawa meeting, forcefully confirming the United States commitment to begin arms control talks this autumn, a Government spokesman said today.   While the substance of the letter, which Mr. Schmidt received on Sunday, was not entirely new, the Chancellor has evidently brought back from Ottawa what he considers a written commitment from the Reagan Administration and strongly hopes it will help dissipate opposition to the NATO decision to deploy medium-range missiles in Europe.   Kurt Becker, the Government spokesman, said Mr. Reagan had informed Mr. Schmidt that it had been his personal decision to lay down a schedule last spring for the start of preparatory talks with the Soviet Union in September and the start of formal negotiations in November.   Mr. Becker said the President had told the Chancellor that while Soviet medium-range nuclear missiles threatened only Western Europe, the United States was determined to view them as a common threat and to take the necessary steps to diminish or eliminate it.

headline: CARS, CARS, EVERYWHERE
abstract: Consumers looking to buy a new car this summer have an unusually wide range of models to choose from. Automotive News, an industry publication, reports strong production and lagging sales in June pushed inventories of 1981 model cars to record levels as the third quarter began.

headline: GRAFFITI CLUTTERING UP THE THE TAX BILL
abstract: SENATORS and Representatives had already departed last week for their districts and the Fourth of July holiday, leaving the cool long hallways of Congress quiet. But inside the staff offices, without the fanfare of committee hearings, lawyers and economists were down to shirtsleeves, working away on the snowballing proposals to cut taxes.    What began as two proposals from the President, tax cuts for business and for individuals, attracted a plethora of other provisions as it went through the Senate Finance Committee and is attracting yet more in the House Ways and Means Committee. Its scattershot growth displeases many.   ''It's nothing but fiscal graffiti,'' said Joseph A. Pechman, an economist and tax specialist at the Brookings Institution. What the committees are doing, he said, ''is loading the bill with provisions that cost a lot of money and will not achieve the desired objectives.''

headline: GUERRILLAS BATTLE KHOMEINI BACKERS IN TEHERAN STREETS
abstract: In the fiercest display of opposition to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini yet, Mujahedeen guerrillas, some firing machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades, fought street battles with revolutionary guards throughout central Teheran for seven hours today, according to reports reaching Beirut.   What appeared to be a campaign building over the last few days against the presidential election to be held Friday grew into the most violent clashes since the revolution, according to the reports.  Some of the Mujahedeen shouted ''Khomeini will be overthrown!'' as they fought the revolutionary guards, residents of Teheran said in telephone interviews.   (The Teheran radio said ''several persons,'' including policemen, revolutionary guards and others, were killed, and 40 persons were injured, The Associated Press reported.)

headline: HARTFORD BANK TIE OPPOSED
abstract: The largest stockholder in the Hartford National Corporation, parent company of the Hartford National Bank, sent a letter today to the 8,000 other shareholders urging them not to approve a merger with the Connecticut National Bank.   The merger agreement was reached last month at a price about $15 million higher than Hartford National had originally intended to pay. The price had been bid up by two other banks that had also sought to acquire Connecticut National.

headline: NEWSPAPERS RARE IN WARSAW KIOSKS
abstract: The Polish authorities attempted to publish skeleton editions of a number of newspapers today, but distributors and vendors refused to handle them.   The Government's move came on the second day of a printer's strike called by Solidarity, the independent trade union, to protest attacks in the official press and to demand access to the media.   Trybuna Ludu, the Communist Party daily, and Zolnierz Wolnosci, the armed forces newspaper, were printed on emergency military presses on Grzybowska Street, but deliverers boycotted them and the two papers were virtually unavailable at newsstands.   In Bydgoszcz, where many printers are loyal to the old official trade union, newspapers were published fairly normally. Other regional newspapers were also reportedly produced in Katowice, Szczecin, Radom, Opole and Lublin. But distribution blockages by supporters of the Solidarity union seem to have prevented people from seeing the few newspapers that were printed.

headline: Business Digest; FRIDAY, AUGUST 21, 1981; The Economy
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board moved to provide emergency credit for financial institutions at rates as low as 14 percent. The action, welcomed by the troubled thrift industry, is meant to offer longer-term credits than the two- to three-day loans now available.  (Page D1.)   American families' real income fell 5.5 percent last year, the biggest decline in the 34 years the Government has been keeping track, the Census Bureau reported. This raised those formally classified as poor to 13 percent of the population, from 11.7 percent in 1979. (A10.)

headline: QUICKLY AND QUIETLY, MITTERRAND CHANGES FRANCE
abstract: The new Socialist Government of Francois Mitterrand has decreed and set in motion more economic and political change in France in the last two months than its predecessors of the right managed in the 23 years since the creation of the Fifth Republic.   What is more, it has done it quietly. Profound change is supposed to be conceived in profound discontent. But while much of France was at the beach, Mr. Mitterrand's Government and the country's economy have gone off in some radically new directions.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Atlantic City Electric Company announced that its board authorized the filing of a petition with the New Jersey Board of Utilities and a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 1.5 million common shares.   * Citicorp said an average rate of 17.425 percent was set at yesterday's weekly auction of its 92-day commercial paper.

headline: SLOANE SELLS PORTION OF STORE
abstract: W.& J. Sloane Inc. has agreed to sell a portion of its flagship Fifth Avenue store in Manhattan for an amount in excess of $10.5 million, the retail furniture chain and its parent company, the City Stores Company, announced yesterday. Neither the square footage being sold nor the purchaser was identified.   Under the terms of the contract, Sloane will be permitted to remain in possession of the sold portion of the building on 38th Street and Fifth Avenue for up to nine months following closing of the sale.

headline: Newfoundland Plant Studied
abstract: Petro-Canada, Canada's state-owned energy company, and Gulf Canada are considering using oil and natural gas from East Coast offshore areas and the Arctic for a petrochemical plant in eastern Canada, Petro-Canada said.

headline: Hirohito Marks Anniversary Of War's End at Tokyo Rites
abstract: Emperor Hirohito marked the 36th anniversary today of the end of World War II with a ''prayer for world peace'' in ceremonies before 6,600 people at Tokyo's Martial Arts Hall.   ''Even now, when I think of those who fell in the ranks of the last great war, or the many who perished in the ravages of that war, and their survivors, my heart is filled with pain,'' the 80-year-old Emperor said.

headline: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Results of Bid for Page
abstract: The Guthrie Corporation said today that its cash tender offer of $57.65 a share for Page Airways of Rochester had reulted in acceptances covering 1.04 million shares, or 88.3 percent of the total shares outstanding. The offer remains open until Sept. 25, it added.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Advest Inc., Hartford, has named William E. Blankenburg Jr. group vice president.   * Bank of New York has elected LeRoy M. Richey Jr. president of the mid-Hudson region.

headline: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ROBLIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to June 20
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: YOU DON'T NEED TREES TO MAKE PAPER
abstract: K ENAF is a plant, a denizen of frost-free climates and a relative of roselle, marijuana and cotton. However little known in the United States, it is used regularly in more than 20 countries like jute, for making cordage. Today, a far more ambitious future is envisaged for kenaf. It could, its advocates contend, bail the paper-making industry out of periodic shortages of trees.   So far, the kenaf is only a gleam in the eye of American experts. A group of farmers in Homestead, Fla., have been growing it for 20 years on 110 to 200 acres. (The stems are used to make bean poles.) But since 1977, the American Newspaper Publishers Association has been actively exploring kenaf. At least six newspapers, including The Wall Street Journal and The Miami Herald, have printed papers on pulp made from the plant. And a major A.N.P.A. feasibility study on kenaf's newsprint potential is due out at the end of the year.

headline: 3 IN SOUTH AFRICA DOOMED BY COURT
abstract: Three members of the outlawed African National Congress, the main underground movement opposing white rule, were sentenced today to hang for their role in a series of sabotage attempts.   As soon as the sentence was pronounced in the Supreme Court here, one of the condemned men, David Moisi, turned in the dock, forced a smile and gave the clenched-fist salute to a courtroom that was crowded with white plainclothesmen and black sympathizers of the accused in almost equal numbers.   The 25-year-old Mr. Moisi was convicted of high treason for his role in the most widely noticed of the sabotage efforts, which resulted in the explosion of fuel storage tanks 14 months ago at South Africa's coal-to-gas conversion complex at Secunda. Johannes Shabangu, 26, threw a grenade at an office of the administration board that governs the black townships near Johannesburg - it was there that two people were injured by shrapnel, the only casualties in the sabotage attempts - and Bobby Tsotsobe, 25, was involved in an assault on a police station and several bombings.

headline: ANACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NEWS CONFERENCE ABOARD THE NIMITZ
abstract: Following are excerpts from an unofficial transcript of the news conference today by Vice Adm. William H. Rowden, the Sixth Fleet Commander; Rear Adm. James E. Service, task force commander; Cmdr. Henry M. Kleemann, the commander of the fighter squadron that shot down two Libyan planes last week, and other officers, including Lieut. Jay Sumner, a radarman, aboard the Nimitz: OPENING STATEMENTS   ROWDEN: First of all, an open-ocean missile exercise is a routine U.S. Navy exercise. The open-ocean missile exercise we conducted on Aug. 18-19 had been planned for several months.

headline: MARKETS OVERSEAS REBOUND FROM PREVIOUS DAY'S SLUMP
abstract: Investors looking for bargains among stocks oversold in yesterday's dramatic plunge on many of the world's stock exchanges fueled a reversal today. Record comebacks on the London and Tokyo exchanges more than recouped the losses of Monday.   On the London exchange, where the Financial Times index of 30 industrial stocks fell 17.2 points yesterday, the index rose 23.7 points today to close at 481.2. This surge equaled the previous record for a one-day rise set July 1, 1975, and added $6.91 billion to the value of listed stocks. ''The market was overbought in the past, and what we are seeing now is a rapid unwinding of a long bull run,'' said a London broker at one of the top investment firms. He asked not to be identified.

headline: SMALL RISE HAILED
abstract: The Government's Prod ucer Price Index for finished goods, a rough measure of the level of inflation consumers will face in the future, rose only three-tent hs of 1 percent in August, the Labor Department reported today.   The small rise from July in the index, which measures price changes at the last stage of production, was partly a result of slight declines in meat and energy prices. Over all, food prices were up only two-tenths of 1 percent following a worrisome 1.5 percent July rise.   The modest August increase in the index was equal to a rise of 3.6 percent at an annual rate.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Cyanamid Company, Wayne, N.J., has named William L.  Berry president of the organic chemicals division, and Gordon D.  Sterling president of the Formica Corporation, a wholly-owned subsidiary.   * American Electric Power Service Corporation, Columbus, Ohio, has elected John F. DiLorenzo Jr. vice president and associate general counsel, and Bruce A. Beam vice president-government affairs.   * Asarco Inc. has elected to its board Harry Holiday Jr., chief executive officer of Armco Inc.

headline: Texaco Seen Preparing Cities Service Takeover
abstract: Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, is preparing to make a bid for another major oil company, banking industry sources said yesterday.
