These sources said flatly that the target was the Cities Service Company, the 20th-largest energy company, although speculation elsewhere centered on Conoco Inc., No.9.   Moving to dispel the avalanche of rumors contributing to the upward price spiral for its stock, Charles J. Waidelich, president of Cities Service, said at his headquarters in Tulsa, Okla., ''Cities Service is not engaged in any discussions or merger with Texaco Inc. or any other company, and we have no plans to do so.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: IRANIANS URGED TO BE ALERT FOR SUSPICIOUS ACTIVITY   TEHERAN, Iran, July 2 (Reuters) - Iran's leaders, seeking to prevent further violent attacks on prominent Iranians, declared today that it was the duty of all people to be alert and inform the authorities immediately of any suspicious activities.   ''From now on,'' Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said in a speech, ''all of you are members of the intelligence organization.'' A similar request for information on what people might be saying in buses, public places and even doctors' offices was made by the newspaper of the ruling Islamic Republican Party, whose headquarters was wrecked last Sunday by a bomb explosion that killed 72 leading members.   The newspaper, Jomhuri-i-Islami, also called on both the Iranian people and the authorities to ''bring under their severe control the activities of foreign journalists.''

headline: HMW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DOW GAINS SLIGHTLY, TO 928.56
abstract: Takeover stocks thundered back into popularity yesterday as Colt Industries, the session's biggest winner on Wall Street, soared more than 20 points. The Dow Jones industrial average, after plunging 34 points over the three previous trading days, rose 3.90 points, to 928.56.   This slight recovery in the Dow, reflecting gains of over 1 point each in Allied Corporation and Minnesota Mining, was at variance with the market's overall performance, as losers outpaced winners by about 3-to-2.

headline: HAIG POSTPONES DRIVE FOR SALE OF AWACS TO SAUDIS
abstract: The State Department said today that it would postpone until September the submission to Congress of a proposal to sell Saudi Arabia a package of advanced military aircraft.   The department also said no decision had yet been reached on resuming deliveries of F-16 fighter-bombers to Israel.  Meanwhile, increasingly vivid descriptions of the reasons for yesterday's forced resignation of Robert G. Neumann as Ambassador to Saudi Arabia circulated here.   One official, who declined to be identified, asserted that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had discovered clandestine, or so-called ''back-channel,'' communications between the White House national security adviser, Richard V. Allen, and Mr. Neumann in recent weeks.

headline: Scott Paper Bid
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said it had approved the Scott Paper Company's purchase of American Convenience Products Inc., a privately held, Milwaukee-based paper goods maker. Under a consent order, Scott Paper is required to seek approval of the F.T.C. to buy another company that makes paper products.

headline: Shad Assails Insider Abuse
abstract: John S.R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, urged investment bankers yesterday to ''redouble efforts'' against the abuse of insider stock trading.   He advised restricting confidential information to those who have ''a need to know.''

headline: AMERICAN SPORTS ADVISORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Mr. Exxon
abstract: To the Business Editor: It is depressing to have a reputable business leader such as Clifton C. Garvin Jr. put down solar energy as he did in your article, ''An Audience With Mr. Exxon'' (Aug. 9). In the same breath, while acknowledging that the technology of solar is simple and good, he bemoans the fact that, ''the sun's not out around here,'' and since he's getting older, he would like something about 80 degrees.

headline: Zimbabwe Planning to Close Schools Serving Only Whites
abstract: Private ''community schools,'' regarded by the Zimbabwean Government as a means of continuing whites-only education in an officially desegregated society, will be abolished at the end of the month, Education Minister Dzingai Mutumbuka announced today.

headline: U.N. PLANS PARLEY ON ENERGY SOURCES
abstract: As the Reagan Administration moves to cut back on Federal efforts to develop renewable energy sources and other alternatives to oil, the rest of the world is starting to move in the opposite direction.   Next month, the United Nations will hold a conference on new and renewable sources of energy in Nairobi, Kenya. The purpose, according to Enrique V. Iglesias, the secretary general of the conference, is to create a worldwide climate of opinion that will pave the way for accelerated development of alternatives to fossil fuels.   In a recent interview, Mr. Iglesias, a Uruguayan, said it was important for the world to begin ''to move away from oil to a new energy mix.''

headline: German Plan on Checks
abstract: West German commercial and savings banks plan to form a group to issue international traveler's checks, a spokesman for the savings bank association said today. Other details were not disclosed. The move follows failure of negotiations in Brussels yesterday between German commercial banks and Thomas Cook Ltd., aimed at developing sales of Cook's traveler's checks in Germany, the spokesman said.

headline: NATO Official Praises Move By U.S. on Neutron Warheads
abstract: The Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Joseph M.A.H. Luns, said today that the recent American decision to produce neutron warheads would increase the deterrence potential of the United States and create stability in East-West relations.   Dr. Luns told reporters that the Reagan Administration's decisions to improve the country's d efenses and modernize its armed forces would help re duce the military imbalance between NATO and the Soviet bloc.

headline: Home News Cable Service
abstract: Dow Jones & Company and Tocom Inc.  today announced plans for the first widespread use of cable television for delivering home information retrieval services.   Under the agreement, Tocom will produce 2,000 home interface terminals that will enable Dow Jones to send its news retrieval service to subscribers via two-way cable.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Bolt Technology Corp. announced an initial public offering of one million shares of its common stock at a price of $13.75 per share, to be sold through an L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin group.   * Galveston-Houston Co. announced placement of a $9.9 million principle amount of industrial development revenue bonds due 1984 with the First International Bank in Houston and the First National Bank in Dallas.

headline: Market Place; The Changes In Discounting
abstract: THE big mergers involving brokerage firms this year have seen Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc. walk down the aisle with the American Express Company, and Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. breathe ''yes'' to the Prudential Insurance Company.   But two mergers were also announced last month by discount brokers, a segment of the securities industry that began offering sharply reduced commission rates to retail clients in the 1970's. In contrast to full-service brokerage houses, such as Merrill Lynch or E.F. Hutton & Company, discounters did not provide their customers with investment research and various other amenities.   In San Francisco, Charles Schwab & Company, largest of the discounters, disclosed plans to acquire Kingsley, Boye & Southwood Inc., a Manhattan-based discount firm that also operates a specialist unit on the New York Stock Exchange. In the second match, Quick & Reilly Inc., which ranks No.2 among the estimated 125 discount houses, said it would acquire Kelly Associates Ltd.

headline: VIDEO CURB PLAN DENIED BY TOKYO
abstract: Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry today denied reports that it was planning to curb this nation's rapidly increasing exports of videotape recorders.   ''Ther will be no restriction on videotape recorder exports,'' said Kazu Kusaka, deputy director of the ministry's Americas-Oceania division, which handles trade matters with the United States. Asked about the recent reports, which appeared in several Japanese newspapers and were termed essentially accurate by a Government official yesterday, Mr. Kusaka replied, ''Some of my colleagues may have misled reporters.''   To Western economic experts here, the apparent divergence of opinion within the ministry, an agency whose officials typically hew to a single line, reflects the frenzied nature of the Japanese Government's efforts to trim its sizable and growing trade with the United States and Europe. Japan's trade surplus with the United States in 1981 is currently estimated at a record $15 billion. The Reagan Administration has warned that it expects substantial pressure later this year to take protectionist steps to limit imports from Japan.

headline: FRANCE TO LOOSEN CENTRALIZED RULE
abstract: France's new Socialist Government has approved what may be the most far-reaching of all its proposals, the decentralization of government.   The measure, called ''the rights and liberties of the communities, departments and regions,'' was described by Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy as ''the most important business of our seven-year term.'' President Francois Mitterrand had made decentralization one of the key planks in his campaign platform.   ''We must rid ourselves of what remains of Napoleon's ancien regime,'' Mr. Mauroy said recently.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM EL SALVADOR SPEECH
abstract: Following are excerpts from a speech on El Salvador today by Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, to the World Affairs Council here:   What I would like to talk about today: A political solution. For just as the conflict was Salvadoran in its origins, so its ultimate resolution must be Salvadoran.   El Salvador, however, remains a divided country. It is divided between the insurgents and a great majority that opposes the extreme left's violent methods and foreign ties. It is divided between an equally violent minority on the extreme right that seeks to return El Salvador to the domination of a small elite and a great majority that has welcomed the political and social changes of the past 18 months.

headline: CHRYSLER, UNION SET PROFIT SHARING
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers have agreed on an innovative profit-sharing plan that includes cash payments, shares of stock, discounts on cars and a lottery that will give some lucky employees company products free.   The agreement, however is subject to approval by the Chrysler Loan Review Board. In the past its members, who are Government officials, have expressed hostility toward the profit-sharing idea.

headline: BANKS' PLEA ON PARIS TAKEOVER
abstract: Sitting in the ornate room on the Rue d'Antin, where Napoleon married Josephine in 1796, Pierre Moussa, head of the Banque de Paris et des Pays Bas, regarded as one of France's most dynamic investment banks, worries about divorce.   If Francois Mitterrand, France's Socialist President, goes ahead with his commitment to nationalize all remaining French-owned privatebanks, then P aribas, as Mr. Moussa's bank is called, may well lose powerful fore ign partners and customers.   ''They are very nice about it, but they say they don't wish to have a French Government institution as a major shareholder and business partner,'' Mr. Moussa said.   As a result, Mr. Moussa is leading a campaign by France's private investment banks to persuade the country's new leaders to exempt the banks' international operations and their industrial investments from the planned takeover.

headline: METHODE ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BREZEZINSKI URGES TALKS WITH P.L.O.
abstract: Zbigniew Brzezinski, who was President Carter's national security adviser, said today that the time had come for the United States to end its boycott and ''talk to the Palestine Liberation Organization.''   In a breakfast meeting with a group of reporters, Mr. Brzezinski said he was not advocating formal negotiations or recognition of the P.L.O. as a government.   But, he said, Washington should undertake ''some form of dialogue with the P.L.O. which encourages it to be more moderate and which leads to the engagement of the P.L.O. in solving the West Bank and Gaza Strip issues.'' Young Met With P.L.O.   The only other senior member of the Carter Administration to advocate a break with the policy of not dealing with the P.L.O. was Andrew Young, who served as chief representative at the United Nations. He resigned in August 1979 after it was learned that he had met privately with the P.L.O. representative at the United Nations to discuss a possible Security Council resolution.

headline: Senior Director Quits at Bendix
abstract: The senior director of the Bendix Corporation, declaring that he had lost confidence in the conglomerate's management, has resigned from its board.   Robert W. Purcell, 69 years old, a former business consultant to the Rockefeller Family & Associates in New York and a Bendix director since 1965, announced his resignation to the company's outside directors on Wednesday night. Mr. Purcell was traveling yesterday and could not be reached for elaboration.

headline: SALVADORAN URGES TALKS TO AVOID A LONG WAR
abstract: The leader of El Salvador's leftist political opposition said yesterday that neither the guerrillas nor the United States-backed Salvadoran Army forces are capable of a military victory in the short run.   A negotiated settlement, said the opposition leader, Guillermo Manuel Ungo, was the way to avoid a prolonged war, which he said would leave tens of thousands homeless and as many as 100,000 dead.   Mr. Ungo, who is president of the Democratic Revolutionary Front, a broad-based political group allied with the five guerrilla organizations that make up the Farabundo Marti Liberation Front, spoke at a news conference yesterday in Manhattan.

headline: STANDARD REGISTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EX-IM CREDIT FOR AUSTRALIA
abstract: The Export-Import Bank said today that it will guarantee a private credit for a $63.7 million purchase of heavy duty mining equipment from Dresser Industries Inc. by an Australian company. it said Theiss Dampier Mitsui Coal, a joint venture Australian mining concern, will purchase drag lines, drills, shovels, haulers and other equipment from Dresser to develop an open coal mine in Queensland.   The purchase will be supported with a bank guarantee for a $41.4 million credit.

headline: Monsanto to Cut Nylon Production
abstract: The Monsanto Company, one of the nation's biggest producers of nylon fiber, announced it was cutting production by almost 23 percent because of slack demand for nylon for carpets.

headline: UNION COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The U.N. Today; July 1, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Development Program Governing Council - 11 A.M.   Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M.

headline: CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CURTICE-BURNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BIG I.B.M.'S LITTLE COMPUTER
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation, once slow to recognize that computers were getting smaller, is apparently determined not to make the same mistake in the emerging personal computer market.   In the 1960's, I.B.M. was slow to enter the minicomputer field, allowing upstarts, particularly the Digital Equipment Corporation, to acquire a dominant share of the market and to grow into companies with billions in annual revenue.   Yesterday I.B.M. announced that it would sell a desk-top computer for use in homes, schools and businesses, thereby staging a relatively early entry, some analysts contend, into a market now dominated by Apple Computer Inc. and Tandy Corporation's Radio Shack division.   ''I don't think they want to allow another Digital Equipment to rise through the ranks in personal computers,'' said Thomas J.  Crotty, an analyst with the Gartner Group, an investment adviser specializing in the computer field.   Although I.B.M.'s entry into the personal computer business had been expected for months, it still sent reverberations through the industry.

headline: DISNEY, WALT, PRODUCTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MITTERRAND UPHOLDS CAMP DAVID AGREEMENTS
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand of France today reiterated his full backing of the Middle East peace accords reached at Camp David, apparently dealing a severe blow to Western Europe's hopes of an independent Middle East peace initiative of its own.   At the same time, West European leaders formally opened their new campaign that calls on the Soviet Union to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan in return for internationally agreed steps to guarantee Afghanistan's neutrality and freedom from foreign interference.   ''The Russians haven't accepted our idea yet, but they haven't rejected it either, so there's a sporting chance,'' Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary and author of the plan, said at a news conference here at the end of the regular summer meeting of Common Market heads of government. Lord Carrington will fly to Moscow on Monday in an effort to persuade the Soviet leadership to back the European initiative.

headline: MELLON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Imported Car Stocks Up
abstract: Inventories of new imported cars in the hands of American dealers, importers and distributors stood at 441,000 on July 1, compared with 432,500 a month earlier, the trade paper Automotve News reported today. This level is 51 days' supply at current sales rates, compared with 48 days' supply a month earlier, it said.

headline: Khomeini Confirms Rajai As Iranian President
abstract: Mohammed Ali Rajai, Iran's new President, was confirmed in office today by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who warned him that there would be calls for his death if he ever betrayed the Islamic revolution.   Pars, the official Iranian press agency, said Government officials attended the ceremony for Mr. Rajai, who was formerly Prime Minister, at the Ayatollah's residence outside Teheran.

headline: Patents; Checking For Breast Cancer
abstract: WASHINGTON A DIAGNOSTIC instrument using ordinary light for breast examination to detect cancer or other abnormalities will be patented next week by a French engineer and manufacturer of medical equipment. The instrument, called Diagnoscope, is to be marketed in this country.

headline: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for 13 weeks to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AFTER MONTHS MARKED BY DISCORD, MADRID PARLEY SOUNDS OPTIMISTIC
abstract: After nine months of public wrangling and painstaking private negotiations, the 35-nation Madrid conference on security and cooperation in Europe has reached a decisive crossroads.    Having informally agreed to try to wind up business at the end of this month, many senior diplomats at the talks believe that they have the chance of advancing the 1975 Helsinki accords on detente and human rights, which are under review here.   An air of expectancy has suddenly filled the Palace of Congress in northern Madrid, which since November has been the site of the only sustained negotiations involving the United States, the Soviet Union and their respective allies.   ''It is not at all likely that our meeting will end on July 31 without a substantive agreement,'' Max M. Kampelman, the chief American delegate to the talks, said in an interview. ''And if that agreement is not obtainable by July 31, the conference will have to find other ways to continue deliberations at a later time.''

headline: FLEXI-VAN NAMES HEAD
abstract: The Flexi-Van Corporation, a diversified financial services concern, yesterday named Lewis Rubin, a 43-year-old financial expert, to the post of president, replacing Philip Orzeck, who will remain on the company's board. The company, which specializes in long-term leasing and short-term rentals of marine cargo containers and chassis, as well as highway trailers, called the move a switch of emphasis from sales and marketing, which is Mr. Orzeck's field, to finance, Mr. Rubin's area of expertise.

headline: SHELL FLAT
abstract: The Standard Oil Company of California yesterday reported that its second-quarter net income rose by 15.1 percent, the Shell Oil Company said its earnings were ''essentially unchanged'' and the Sun Company announced a 20.6 percent increase.   But analysts nonetheless considered the earnings sluggish. Nearly all of Socal's gain resulted from currency fluctuations, Sun benefited by an extraordinary gain equal to 45 percent of its net income, and Shell cited market conditions that severely hampered its sales.

headline: NEXT, A COMPUTER ON EVERY DESK
abstract: I T used to be that a little money and a little inventiveness would go a long way in the personal computer business. Apple Computer, it is now legend, was started by two college dropouts working in a garage. The Tandy Corporation, now one of the industry's leaders, invested just $150,000 to develop its first computer.   Now the ante is rising dramatically. The race is intensifying, and the personal computer industry is seeing an influx of participants.  In June, the Xerox Corporation became the first major officeequipment company to enter the market. Then, 11 days ago, the biggest of them all, the International Business Machines Corporation, jumped in. Other large computer and office equipment companies will likely enter the fray, and many Japanese companies are waiting in the wings.   In particular, I.B.M.'s entry erased any lingering doubts that personal computers are serious business and no place for the puny or the mere tinkerer, except around the edges of the market.

headline: F.T.C. AD RATE PACT SET, BUT COAST PAPER OBJECTS
abstract: The publisher of The Los Angeles Times agreed today not to discriminate in price for some types of advertising space, the Federal Trade Commission announced Friday. But the publisher said later he wanted to contest the agreement.   The con sent decree would settle charges mad e in 1977 that the TimesMirror Company had allowed large advertisers to pay significantly lower rates than those whose advertising volu me was smaller. It alleged that this policy hurt competition.

headline: 5 OTHERS REPORTED KILLED
abstract: President Mohammed Ali Rajai and Prime Minister Mohammed Javad Bahonar of Iran were killed yesterday when a powerful bomb exploded in the offices of the Prime Minister in central Teheran.   The Iranian state radio announced the deaths this morning. Earlier reports had described the two men, both 47 years old, as being hospitalized.   At least 5 other people were killed and 15 wounded in the explosion, the official Iranian press agency Pars reported.

headline: FLATTER DEDUCTION FOR THE GOLD WATCH HANDSHAKE
abstract: WASHINGTON An obscure addition to the new tax bill which does nothing more than increase a business deduction by $300 is being hailed in certain Congressional and business circles as a most effective way of meeting the vision of increased productivity set forth by the Reagan Administration.   The subject: the trinkets, baubles -and sometimes fine jewelry - offered by corporations to employees in recognition of length of service, salesmanship, safety or success.   Previously, a company could deduct no more than $100 for, say, the gold watch at retirement. Not enough, felt the O.C. Tanner Company, a Salt Lake City manufacturer and wholesaler claiming to be the largest American firm specializing in these ''symbolic recognition award programs.'' So Tanner called Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, who decided to do something about it.

headline: ITT Telex Plan
abstract: ITT World Communications Inc., a unit of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said it will enter the domestic telex market for the first time when it begins offering service within the state of New York on Sept. 8. The company said in a release that the new service resulted from the New York Legislature's action in July deregulating all carriers providing telegraphic services within the state. ITT World said subscribers in New York will have access to the more than 6,000 ITT teleprinter terminals in the state for a flat rate of 32 cents per minute.

headline: DATA ON ORDERS REVISED
abstract: United States manufacturers' new orders and shipments have been a bit stronger this spring than earlier reported, the Commerce Department reported today.   The figures, which also show stronger orders for last year, are part of a comprehensive revision of the Commerce Department's statistics on manufacturers' shipments, inventories and orders, taking new and better Census Bureau information into account.

headline: THE DOLLAR'S IMPACT ON PROFITS
abstract: The Ford Motor Company surprised many analysts last month when it surpassed their expectations by reporting a $60 million profit for the second quarter after six consecutive quarterly losses.   But, in fact, Ford's earnings were four times greater than that.  The surge of the American dollar against most currencies in Europe caused Ford, in keeping with a controversial American accounting rule, to subtract $174 million from profits.   The opposite occurred at the Exxon Corporation. Although its profits from operations fell by 13 percent, Exxon reported a 77 percent gain in profits from its worldwide operations by following the same accounting axiom.

headline: EASTERN CUTS CALIFORNIA FARE TO $134
abstract: Faced with a summertime travel slump, Eastern Airlines began a new fare war today when it reintroduced discount coupons, reducing the lowest one-way price on the heavily traveled New York-California route to $134.   Two of Eastern's chief competitors - American Airlines and Pan American World Airways - immediately said they would match the new fares.   ''We have and we always will remain competitive,'' said Harvey Berman, a spokesman for Pan Am in New York. ''Anything we can do to remain competitive, we will do.''

headline: AUTONUMERICS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Pacific Telephone Gets Rate Increase
abstract: Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company was granted a $610 million annual rate increase by the California Public Utilities Commission, effective Aug. 29.

headline: Goodyear Bank Merger Sought
abstract: The National City Corporation, the holding company of Cleveland's second-largest bank, said it intended to buy the Goodyear Bank of Akron, a subsidiary of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, for an undisclosed price.   The merger, already approved by the boards of directors of both companies, is subject to approval by the Federal Reserve Board in Cleveland.

headline: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
abstract: As Lebanese soldiers patrol the roads leading to Zahle, residents of that predominantly Christian town return to their homes, riddled with shells during the three-month siege by Syrian gunners.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Agency Rent-A-Car said it increased its share of Spencer Companies to 33.9 percent, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.   * Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. said it has acquired a 6.25 percent stake of Flexi-Van Corp.'s outstanding convertible preferred stock at an undisclosed price .   * Criton Corp. said it intends to tender to B.Z. Holdings Corp., a wholly owned subsidiary of Bairnco Corp., the 197,200 common shares of Lightolier Inc. which it acquired before the commencement of the tender offer of its subsidiary C.N. Development Corp., for Lightolier shares. Criton said it will receive $28 per share, or about $5.5 million for its Lightolier Holdings. Criton paid about $3.3 million for the Lightolier shares.

headline: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dynamics Net Off in Quarter
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's biggest defense contractor, announced yesterday that its second-quarter profits fell 56.3 percent and its sales gained 8.3 percent from the same period last year.   The aircraft, submarine and building materials manufacturer noted that earnings dropped to $23.8 million, or 42 cents a share, from $54.4 million, or $1 a share, in the second quarter of last year.

headline: MFY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LATE JULY AUTO SALES FALL 14.7%
abstract: New-car sales, hurt by high interest rates, fell 14.7 percent in the last 10 days of July, the nation's Big Three auto makers reported today. That pushed sales for the entire month down 8 percent from July 1980, to the lowest levels in 20 years.   Sales at the General Motors Corporation fell 21 percent in the July 21-31 period compared with the low levels of late July last year. The Ford Motor Company's sales increased 14.7 percent and the Chrysler Corporation's rose 10.1 percent.

headline: ST. REGIS PAPER
abstract: The St. Regis Paper Company announced plans to invest about $116 million in two projects. They include a $98 million conversion of its Bucksport, Me., paper mill to utilize coal and wood waste instead of fuel oil and expenditure of $18 million to rebuild a kraft paper machine as part of major expansion at the company's Pensacola, Fla., plant. The Bucksport project is expected to be completed in mid-1984 and the Pensacola project in 1983.

headline: ADDENDUM
abstract: Family Weekly, a Sunday newspaper per supplement, will increase its advertising rates 3 percent, effective Sept. 13.

headline: BERG ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: G.M. to Suspend Plant Renovation
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said that it would suspend indefinitely its planned renovation of the Broening Highway auto assembly plant here, a decision that places the future of nearly 2,000 laid-off employees in doubt. In an announcement, G.M. blamed the decision on ''changes in product planning.''

headline: Stake in Asarco
abstract: M.I.M. Holdings Ltd. has increased its stake in Asarco, Inc. to 3,922,563 shares, or 15.1 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, M.I.M. said its holdings included 280,300 shares bought on the New York Stock Exchange between Aug. 17 and Sept. 2 for an aggregate price of $11,001,248.

headline: ISRAELI JETS LEAVE 50 DEAD ON THE ROADS OF LEBANON
abstract: Israeli fighter-bombers made four raids today on two temporary bridges that had been built to replace spans destroyed in raids on the coastal road between Beirut and Tyre last week.   Rescue workers and local officials were still trying to untangle wreckage and retrieve bodies tonight, but the overall death toll appeared to be about 50.   More than 30 people were reported killed in two attacks on the road at the Litani River bridge north of Tyre and at least 18 were believed to have died in two raids farther north on a makeshift road at the Zahrani River crossing.   At an oil refinery near Zahrani, the jets set fire to the pipeline delivering crude oil from Saudi Arabia, sending up black smoke. The refinery has been closed since attacks last week, causing a gasoline shortage and a warning of possible electric power cuts in Beirut.

headline: Harvester Layoffs
abstract: The International Harvester Company said it would lay off 400 production and clerical workers here on Friday as part of a national retrenchment effort announced last week.

headline: Around the World; French Lawmakers Vote To End Death Penalty
abstract: France's Chamber of Deputies voted by a 3-to-1 majority today to abolish the death penalty after 192 years in which the guillotine has been used to execute about 4,600 people.

headline: 2 BIG BANKS CUT PRIME TO 20%
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Bank and the First National Bank of Chicago yesterday reduced their prime rates to 20 percent from 20 1/2 percent, but a Chase spokesman warned that the half-point cut was ''not necessarily an indication of where rates are going from here on out.''   Donald E. Maude, chief economist for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., said he expected other banks to match yesterday's reduction, the first since early July, but added, ''I don't think it's the beginning of a meaningful decline in the prime.''   Mr. Maude added that ''any relief on the interest rate front will have to come from weakening demand in the economy.''

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The Israeli attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor last month has revived debate in Washington over a critical question: Has the 35-year international effort to curb the spread of nuclear weapons failed?   Reagan Administration officials, key Congressmen and a wide range of nuclear policy specialists are asking themselves whether, in light of the raid and other recent developments, some new approach to the problem is required.   The question is being raised when several smaller nations either have or are on the verge of acquiring atomic weapons by clandestine means, when the safeguards imposed by the nuclear supplier nations are being criticized by those who fear the spread of nuclear arms as inadequate and when the Reagan Administration is about to announce its guidelines for curbing the spread of such weapons in the 1980's. A Topic for Ottawa   Because of the heightened concern over this Armageddon issue, as some specialists call it, it is certain to figure on the agenda next weekend when the leaders of the industrialized non-Communist world, which are the nuclear supplier nations, assemble in Ottawa for their annual economic meeting.   ''Ottawa represents an extradinory opportunity to get a grip on this problem,'' said Senator John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat who was prompted by the Israeli raid to write President Reagan urging, among other steps, an immediate moratorium on the transfer of potentially dangerous nuclear equipment and technology to sensitive areas such as the Middle East.

headline: 300 DIE AS AMAZON BOAT SINKS
abstract: An Amazon riverboat sank in the northern jungle port of Obidos today and port officials said that more than 300 people were missing and feared drowned.   Capt. Elio Palhares said in a telephone interview that 178 of the 500 people thought to have been aboard had swum to safety or been saved.

headline: PARIS ASKS U.S. AID ON POORER NATIONS
abstract: The summit meeting in Ottawa this month of the leading industrialized nations will be a failure unless President Reagan shows more sympathy for the problems of the developing world, France's new Foreign Minister, Claude Cheysson, warned today.   In particular, he appealed, in a speech, to the Reagan Administration to support plans for a new agency, to be run by the World Bank, that would reduce the oil bills of poor countries by helping them develop energy sources of their own. So far the Reagan Administration has taken a skeptical, if not hostile, attitude toward the plan.

headline: NEW HEALTH PLANS FOCUS ON 'WELLNESS'
abstract: Headache. Backache. ''Job burnout.'' Emotional problems. Whatever ails an employee, his employer is likely to feel worse when the bills have to be paid.   Americans spent more than $245 billion on health care in 1980, according to the Government's Health Care Financing Administration, and the United States Chamber of Commerce says employers paid nearly half that.   By 1983 the national health bill could equal 10 percent of the gross national product, according to a study commissioned by the Health Insurance Association of America and prepared by the former chief medical director of the United States space program, Dr.  Charles A. Berry.

headline: THETFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SEARS ROEBUCK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Tenneco Unit Has Oil Find in Tunisia
abstract: Tenneco Inc. said its Houston Oil and Minerals subsidiary had made an onshore oil discovery near Sfax, Tunisia.

headline: Blue Skies Expected For Day of Wedding
abstract: The London meteorological office, offering some news that everyone here badly wants to hear, said today that it expected warm, dry weather for next Wednesday, the day of the royal wedding.

headline: Rothmans Sees No Takeover
abstract: Rothmans, the British tobacco company, dismissed conjecture that Philip Morris of the United States would take it over in the near future.   David Nicolson, Rothmans chairman, questioned about that possibility at the company's annual meeting, said the Rembrandt group, controlled by Anton Rupert, the South African financier, was not prepared to give up a minority stake in the British company.

headline: 7,000 Goats Die on Ship
abstract: A cargo of 7,000 goats suffocated aboard a freigher after the vessel's ventilation system broke down, port authorities said today. The Panamanian-flag ship, which had picked up the goats in Bulgaria and was en route to a North African port, put into Catania after the livestock died.

headline: BRITISH SHIPBUILDERS
abstract: State-owned British Shipbuilders Ltd.  said today that its loss for the year that ended March 31 narrowed to about $85 million, from about $225 million in the previous year.  The military and civil shipbuilder said that sales for the year rose slightly, to about $1.8 billion, from $1.63 billion. It said that orders from both British and overseas companies insured that most of its large merchant yards would have work into 1983.

headline: ALLIED NOW SEEKS ALL OF GARFINCKEL
abstract: The Allied Stores Corporation, one of the nation's largest department store operators, said yesterday that a subsidiary had made a cash tender offer of $48 a share for the common stock of Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc., for a total of about $210 million.   The offer, if successful, would give Allied, which had sales last year of $2.2 billion, another highly diversified group of retail stores in New York and other cities. They include 20 Brooks Brothers, 21 Miller & Rhoads, 7 Garfinckel, 32 Ann Taylor and 100 Catherine Stout stores, plus others, with annual sales of $472 million.   The move represents an abrupt expansion of Allied's bid on July 29 to acquire only the Miller & Rhoads division of Garfinckel. It quickly brought a charge yesterday of ''an unprecedented breach of faith'' from David R. Waters, president and chief executive officer of Garfinckel, which has is based in Washington.

headline: Prudential Arvida Bid Is Confirmed
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation and the Prudential Insurance Company of America said late yesterday afternoon that discussions were under way regarding the sale of Penn Central's Arvida Corporation subsidiary, a land development concern in Boca Raton, Fla., for an undisclosed sum.   Richard Dicker, chairman and chief executive officer of Penn Central, stated that ''Prudential has expressed interest in Arvida Corporation for some time before our recent public announcement.''

headline: NATIONS STUDY NEW COFFEE QUOTA CUT
abstract: In the face of a growing world surplus that has pushed prices to a five-and-a-half-year low, the 26 consumer nations in the 70-country International Coffee Organization met today and agreed to consider a fresh cut in the annual export quota.   The organization, which represents both consuming and producing countries, has already ordered three quota cuts totaling 4.2 million bags during the crop year that ends Sept. 30.   Sources attending the organization's conference here said that the producers would ask for a cut of 1.4 million bags, each holding 132.2 pounds.

headline: AMID SPLENDOR, CHARLES WEDS DIANA
abstract: In a blaze of martial and spiritual pageantry on a glorious summer morning, the Prince of Wales took as his wife today a shy and charming member of one of the kingdom's greatest families.   The 2,500 guests inside Christopher Wren's Baroque masterpiece, St. Paul's Cathedral, the hundreds of thousands who watched the wedding party ride in magnificent horse-drawn carriages from Buckingham Palace to the cathedral and back and the 700 million television viewers around the world witnessed a fairy tale come to life: the handsome Prince Charles in naval uniform marrying the lovely 20-yearold Diana Spencer, daughter of an earl, amid the sort of splendor the modern world has all but forgotten.   All the panoply of monarchy was deployed on this, one of the great days in the history of the House of Windsor: the stirring music of Handel and Purcell and Elgar; the Household Cavalry, in their burnished breastplates and helmets with red plumes; the stately royal horses, caparisoned in silver; almost all of the reigning sovereigns of Europe, come in their finery to share in the happy occasion, and the royal bride herself, resplendent in a gown of pale ivory, with puffy sleeves and a train 25 feet long.

headline: Satellite Venture
abstract: Electrohome Ltd. of Ottawa and Microdesign Ltd. of Toronto announced that they wouls form a joint 50-50 venture, the Gensat Communications Corporation, for the production of home satellite receivers.

headline: Managing Coffee
abstract: To the Business Editor: ''Pushing the Maxwell Product at General Foods'' (Aug. 16), concerning General Foods' brand manager, John Susko, makes Maxwell House look like a sinking ship. If Mr. Susko doesn't plan to stay with his product for more than a year, then maybe he knows something his superiors don't.   Wouldn't it make more sense for General Foods to move tactical brand decisions closer to strategic coffee division decisions? Given all the recent discussion of Japanese management skills and the importance of long-term product planning, shouldn't managers be evaluated on their ability to develop and nurture long-term consumer franchises? To relieve managers of responsibility for their decisionsunder the gui se of promotion is fair in the long run to neither manager nor p roduct.  RAYMOND L. BOGGS Consultant, Consumer Electronics Division, Venture Development Corporation Wellesley, Mass., Aug. 21, 1981

headline: CRANE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HARLAND, JOHN H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DOMAN INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LOWER SAXONY VOTE RESULTS IN A SETBACK FOR SCHMIDT'S PARTY
abstract: Christian Democrats won more than 50 percent of the votes and Social Democrats suffered severe losses in municipal elections over the weekend that both parties said reflected changing national political moods. Final tallies today from the state of Lower Saxony, which elected ci ty officials for the first time in five years, showed the Ch ristian Democrats winning 50.2 percent of the statewide vote, a ga in of 2.2 percentage points, while the Social Democrats fell to 36 .9 percent, a loss of 6.6 percentage points. Chancellor Helmut Sc hmidt's Social Democrats won a majority in only one city.

headline: Daniel & Charles Gains Safety Razor Billings
abstract: Daniel & Charles has been named to handle more advertising for the American Safety Razor Company's razor brands, with billings estimated at $4 million, according to trade sources.

headline: WITH LTV A MEMORY, HE'S TAKING HIS ACT TO THE OIL PATCH
abstract: DALLAS J AMES J. LING, corporate gunslinger, sits high in his leather boardroom chair, decked out like an urban cowboy in jeans, a denim shirt, cowboy boots, a tooled leather belt inscribed ''J.J. Ling'' and a huge silver belt buckle emblazoned ''The State of Texas.''   It is a Saturday, and the business offices of this fast, glossy city are silent. But in an expansive, dark-paneled, office on the 25th floor of a gleaming corporate tower, Mr. Ling works. He's plotting a new adventure, an oil and gas exploration company, called Matrix Energy Inc., which he plans to take public later this year.  Never given to modesty, Mr. Ling claims Matrix represents a ''major breakthrough'' in energy financing and says his company will ''leapfrog'' most existing independent oil companies right into the top 100.   Hyperbole comes easily to the burly, 58-year-old Mr. Ling, and his legend endures on Wall Street, even to those too young to have experienced the go-go era of the 1960's.

headline: U.N. REVISES THE TOLL IN IRAN QUAKE TO 1,500
abstract: The United Nations has announced that the estimated death toll from the earthquake last week in southeastern Iran has been reduced sharply to 1,500.   In its initial report, the United Nations Disaster Relief Office, an agency whose competence has been questioned by an internal United Nations audit, put the number of deaths at 8,000.

headline: Market Place; Have S tocks Hit Bottom?
abstract: THE question on everyone's lips now is whether the hard-hit stock market go lower still. Unfortunately, pundits to the contrary notwithstanding, the answer is that no one knows.   Judged by the magnitude of losses in the bear market of the last three and a half months, a turnaround could be imminent. An abrupt about-face yesterday that saw a slide of more than 14 points in the Dow Jones industrials replaced by an 18.55-point gain by the market's close was encouraging. The Dow closed at 842.56.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  today delivered a good part of the foreign policy speech that Mr.  President Reagan said last week did not need to be given, and he gave it on a matter that the Administration has up to now not cared to spotlight.   The subject was arms control talks with the Soviet Union and, according to his aides, Mr. Haig's aims were threefold: to reassure the worried West Europeans once again that the Administration is serious when it says that negotiations will begin soon with Moscow on medium-range missiles in Europe; to make this reassurance more believable by tying it to a set of principles and a long-term commitment to arms control; and to rees@tablish bipartisan support for arms control by giving a commitment to the process to satisfy the liberals while stressing the limitations on what arms control can be expected to achieve to please the conservatives.   ''We know where we're going,'' said Mr. Reagan last week, ''and think it might be counterproductive to make a speech about it.'' Less than a week later, the President and his principal advisers approved this Haig speech, according to officials, amid mounting criticism that the Administration has no foreign policy and a growing belief in Western Europe that the Administration contemplates arms control only grudgingly.

headline: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COMMODITIES
abstract: Kenneth W. Monfort, president of Monfort of Colorado, the world's largest cattle feeder and, consequently, a big corn user, remarked the other day that consumers could look forward before long to ''relatively cheap meat prices.''   ''I doubt if beef, pork or poultry prices will come down much,'' he said by phone from Greeley, Colo., ''but with the inflation rate as high as it is, even if prices remain steady, that's like coming down.''   Meanwhile, Frank Perdue, chairman of Perdue Inc., the biggest poultry producer in the Northeast and another big corn user, noted that for every 40-cent-a-bushel drop in the corn price, the cost of dressed poultry falls 1 cent. Therefore, with corn prices down nearly 80 cents since last fall, dressed poultry prices are off nearly 2 cents a pound - ''a terrific amount to us,'' he said, ''but not much to the consumer.''

headline: Patents; ART WORKS IN WAX
abstract: A Maryland artist has patented a process for preparing works of art with wax.

headline: HLH PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Yr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Frank E. Grzelecki, 44 years old, will join Lenox Inc., a major producer of china, crystal and other dinnerware, as president and chief operating officer, effective Aug. 31. He will succeed John S.  Chamberlin, 53, who was named to the vacant post of chairman and who will continue as chief executive officer of the Lawrenceville, N.J., company.

headline: A SURPRISING MOVE BY N.&W.
abstract: For decades, the Norfolk & Western Railway has been the lifeblood of much of the coal region of the eastern United States, transporting the coal from the mines across mountains and rivers to markets here and abroad.   This same coal has also been the lifeblood of the N.& W., filling its cars, swelling its revenues and making the railroad, which is based in Roanoke, Va., the most profitable railroad in the country today. ''The N.& W. is the only coal pipeline in America to invest in,'' said Jack Kawa, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds.   This week, however, the N.& W. pulled a surprise move by announcing that it had purchased an 8.2 percent interest in Piedmont Aviation, a regional air carrier based in Winston-Salem, N.C., for $18.3 million. For a railroad so deeply tied to its traditional lines of business - coal and merchandise hauling - this announcement was startling. Even more surprising, however, was the N.& W.'s statement that it had made a merger overture to Piedmont this summer, which was rebuffed.

headline: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PRESIDENT AND TOP AIDE RESIGN A.& P. POSITIONS
abstract: David W. Morrow, the president of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, and Allan A. Feder, its senior executive vice president, resigned yesterday from the loss-ridden supermarket chain.   The two executives, both 49 years old, were hired by Jonathan L.  Scott, A.& P.s former chairman. Mr. Scott resigned in April 1980 and was succeeded by James Wood, who had been the chairman of the Grand Union Company.   In its announcement of the two resignations, A.& P. said that its board had accepted them ''with regret.'' A company spokesman added that the departures had been voluntary. ''Both have been thinking of leaving the company,'' he said.

headline: MURPHY, G C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VIOLENCE IN BERLIN MARKS HAIG'S VISIT
abstract: The loudspeaker truck played ''The Star-Spangled Banner,'' but it was Jimi Hendrix's moaning, mocking guitarsolo version. A girl carried an American flag, but it had the shape of a pig, its hocks and ribs, red and white stripes, its head and eyes, a mosaic of misshapen stars.   A crowd estimated by police at 30,000 and at 80,000 by its organizers took the occasion of a visit by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to protest against an America they see as increasingly warlike.   The police looked on and said later that it was probably the biggest demonstration in West Berlin since the Vietnam War. A handful of families, pensioners, people waiting for buses, watched too as the parade went past, staring, keeping quiet, moving on.

headline: Alcoa and Reynolds Off
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, reported income for the second quarter fell 45.2 percent, to $81.5 million, or $1.09 a share, from $148.8 million, or $2.08 a share, in the second quarter last year.   The decline in income came on only a slim decline on sales - to $1.3 billion from $1.29 billion a year earlier.  W.H. Krome George, the chairman and chief executive officer of Alcoa, said the company had reduced production of aluminum ingot to balance inventories ''because we anticipate lower shipments in the last half of 1981.''   Most of the aluminum companies have begun to reduce production and have resorted to some price-cutting because of the decline in demand.

headline: REAGAN AIDES CALL STRAINS WITH HAIG 'FACT OF LIFE'
abstract: White House officials say they have concluded that difficult, sometimes strained relations with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. are ''a fact of life'' in the Reagan Administration, but they emphasize that Mr. Haig has the President's full confidence.   Because of the sensitivity of the problem, various White House officials discussed Mr. Haig on the condition that they not be quoted by name. These aides said that ''frustration'' had been felt at the highest levels, including Mr. Reagan's three top deputies, James A.Baker 3d, Edwin Meese 3d and Michael K. Deaver.   The unhappiness with Mr. Haig has reportedly been a subject of recent discussion among White House aides, and it also come up increasingly in interviews with reporters.

headline: ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARMSTRONG, A J, INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Suez Canal Commences Use Of Computer Instead of Pilots
abstract: The Suez Canal entered the electronic age today, modernizing its century-old system of piloting ships through the waterway with a $17 million American-built computer network.   A spokesman for the Canal Authority said that the computerized system would replace pilots who now direct the ships by means of telephone contact with 11 stations along the 101-mile canal.

headline: American Airlines' Labor Agreement
abstract: American Airlines said that it had reached tentative agreement on a new contract covering more than 5,000 flight attendants. Terms of the agreement, reached with the Association of Professional Flight Attendants, were withheld pending presentation to the union's board of directors.

headline: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CANADIANS ATTACK PRESS MONOPOLIES
abstract: A Canadian Government commission, born out of the ''shock and trauma'' of two major newspaper closings in a single day a year ago, urged tough measures today to limit concentration of ownership and enhance the quality and independence of Canadian newspapers.   After a year of study and public hearings, the three-member commission painted a dismal picture of an industry in which quality is being sacrificed to profit and whose already ''monstrous'' concentration is likely to grow ''unless law and public policy are changed.''   The proposals ''for freeing the press in Canada,'' which include a new Canada Newspaper Act, are likely to come under strong attack, particularly from the two chains most directly involved, Thomson Newspapers and Southam Press. Both chains are now under indictment for conspiracy to lessen newspaper competition.

headline: SOVIET SEES POLAND'S ALLIANCES IMPERILED
abstract: The Soviet Union accused Poland's independent labor union today of attempting to subvert the Polish Communists' Constitution and system of alliances.   Reporting on the national convention of the Solidarity union organization in Gdansk, the Soviet Government's press agency Tass said the ''antisocialist thrust'' of the meeting was being set by counterrevolutionary groups, speakers were demanding the liquidation of the Communist system, anti-Soviet materials were being distributed and the union was urging closer ties with the West.   Most of these and other charges, made today and in a similar dispatch yesterday, have been heard before in the war of nerves between Moscow and Warsaw. The latest sallies suggested that, in Soviet eyes, the tendencies attacked in the past were being confirmed by the convention.

headline: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BOOTHE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SELF: A SURPRISING SUCCESS
abstract: Back in 1976, when Phyllis Starr Wilson was managing editor of Glamour magazine, one of Conde Nast's imposing stable of women's publications, she felt that women's magazines were not doing enough for the over-30 set. So she whipped up a prospectus for a magazine geared for women of all ages. She thought of calling it Woman or Self.   The following year, S.I. Newhouse Jr., Conde Nast's chairman, got excited about a physical fitness magazine, since fitness articles in Conde Nast magazines were much savored by readers. Ultimately, the powers decided to combine the two notions, and have Mrs. Wilson edit the result.   Thus, in late 1977, Conde Nast disclosed that it would give birth to a magazine in January 1979, its first new arrival since Glamour hit the racks 40 years before. The creation would be called Self.

headline: T.V.A. Faulted
abstract: A General Accounting Office report concluded today that the Tennessee Valley Authority, a Government-run utility, was paying too much for its coal as a result of unfavorable long-term contracts signed in the 1970's. The report by the Congressional agency faulted T.V.A. managers for choosing the two least favorable periods for coal purchases in the last decade as a time to contract for almost three-quarters of the coal the T.V.A.  purchased in the 10-year period.

headline: SADAT SAYS U.S. BUYS SOVIET ARMS IN EGYPT FOR AFGHAN REBELS
abstract: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt said last night that the United States had been buying Soviet-made arms from his country for 21 months and fl ying them to rebel forces resisting Soviet troops in Afghanistan.   In an interview from Cairo broadcast by NBC News, Mr. Sadat said he was approached by United States authorities ''the first moment'' Soviet forces moved into Afghanistan in late December 1979.   ''I opened my stores to them,'' Mr. Sadat said. The weapons, the exact nature of which was not specified, were flown from Cairo in American aircraft. Although Mr. Sadat did not reveal the destination of the flights, another Egyptian official was quoted as saying the arms went to Pakistan, which has a long border with Afghanistan.

headline: Advertising; Timex Advertising
abstract: Grey Advertising; Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn; Kenyon & Eckhardt, and Warwick, Welsh & Miller were all invited to compete for the gift advertising assignment from Timex, a $5 million piece of business that was being handled by B.B.D.O. The company decided to give it to Grey, which already was the Timex agency for all other timepiece advertising.

headline: Ex-Im Bank Loan
abstract: The United States Export-Import Bank has authorized a $14.25 million loan to partially finance an underseas telephone cable between Egypt and Greece, according to an announcement released here today. The cable will link Alexandria with Athens and is scheduled for operation early in 1984. It will be built and installed by the international operating unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for Egypt's National Telecommunications Organization and Greece's Hellenic Telecommunications Organization.

headline: Longer Hours At Chicago
abstract: The Chicago Board of Trade will probably expand its hours, but is ''no longer seriously considering a 24-hour trading day,'' its chairman, Les Rosenthal, said today.   Mr. Rosenthal, who recently visited trading centers in Europe, said traders there expressed only ''lukewarm'' interest in round-the-clock trading.

headline: Technologies' Net Up 21.6%
abstract: The United Technologies Corporation today reported earnings for the second quarter ended June 30 of $122.6 million, a 21.6 percent increase over the $100.8 million reported in the previous year's second quarter. Sales rose 19 percent, to $3.56 billion.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Adams Resources and Energy Inc., Houston, has elected to its board L.K. Herzeg, executive vice president of KSA Industries.   * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. has named William F. Farley senior vice president-finance.

headline: Jersey Casino Winnings Up
abstract: Atlantic City's eight legal casino hotels, with the help of a new gaming hall, won a record $118 million in July, the state reported today.   The casinos averaged winnings of nearly $4 million a day during July, 28 percent more than in June, the previous record month, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission reported.

headline: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Bunker Hill Closing
abstract: The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation said it would shut its Bunker Hill Company operations at Kellogg, Idaho. Bunker is a mining concern and a refiner of lead, zinc and silver. Gulf said the operations had a pretax loss of about $8 million in the first half of 1981, a reflection of continuing depressed lead, zinc and silver prices.

headline: Colt Posts Rise
abstract: Colt Industries Inc. said yesterday that it earned $32.6 million, or $2.40 a share, in the second quarter, up 11.2 percent from $29.3 million, or $2.24 a share, in the same period a year ago. Sales climbed to $624.1 million from $562.7 million.

headline: Pan Am Unit Sale
abstract: Pan American World Airways Inc. said that it had completed the sale of its Intercontinental Hotels Corporation subsidiary to Grand Metropolitan Ltd.

headline: IRANIAN SAYS SECRETARY TO PREMIER HID FATAL BOMB IN TEHERAN OFFICE
abstract: A man who worked as a secretary in the office of Prime Minister Mohammed Javad Bahonar placed the bomb that killed Mr. Bahonar and President Mohammed Ali Rajai on Aug. 30, the office of Iran's Prosecutor General said today.   The announcement came in a Teheran radio broadcast that was monitored here.  An official in the office said the secretary, Massoud Kashmiri, was killed in the explosion that wrecked the Prime Minister's office and killed six other people apart from the President and Prime Minister.

headline: Group Plans Zaire Smelter
abstract: An international consortium of eight companies plans to build an aluminum smelter in Zaire capable of producing at least 150,000 tons annually, a spokesman for the consortium said today.

headline: JUAN CARLOS SNUBS ROYAL WEDDING OVER GIBRALTAR HONEYMOON PLAN
abstract: The stately, orderly preparations for the royal wedding a week from tomorrow were disrupted tonight when the Spanish Government announced that King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia had declined their invitation to the ceremony as an act of protest.   Their decision resulted from the plan of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer to board the royal yacht Britannia at Gibraltar for a two-week honeymoon cruise in the Mediterranean after spending their first two nights as husband and wife at Broadlands, the country estate of the late Earl Mountbatten of Burma at Romsey in Hampshire.   Gibraltar, a two-square-mile enclave near the southern tip of the Iberian Peninsula, has been a British naval base and crown colony since the early 18th century and has long been a subject of dispute between the two nations. It is one of Spain's most emotional political issues, with leaders of most political parties demanding that the British withdraw.

headline: British Jobless Up to 12.4% This Month
abstract: British unemployment may be higher now than during the Great Depression, with 12.4 percent of the work force out of a job this month and grim predictions that the worst is yet to come, Government officials said today.   The Department of Employment said 2,998,789 people were unemployed in September - the highest level since detailed records began in 1948.

headline: FOES OF AWACS SALE ASSERT 51 SENATORS BACK THEIR EFFORT
abstract: Opponents of President Reagan's proposal to sell $8.5 billion worth of air warfare equipment to Saudi Arabia said today that a majority of the Senate had lined up against the sale.   The development came 11 days before formal Senate committee hearings were Texts of resolution and statements by Haig and Senators, page A10. due to begin on the sale and did not yet constitute a defeat for the President. But it did threaten the possibility of a serious political defeat for Mr. Reagan and a possible setback in United States relations with Saudi Arabia. The proposed sale would include five Awacs planes.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Astrex Inc. said it would purchase a maximum of 100,000 shares of its own stock in the open market from time to time.   * Dining Concepts International authorized an exchange of currently outstanding warrants to purchase the company's common stock at $1.25 a share for newly issued warrants entitling the holders to buy common stock at $1 a share.

headline: POPE, DUE TO LEAVE HOSPITAL, WILL CONVALESCE FOR 2 MONTHS
abstract: Pope John Paul II, on the eve of his scheduled discharge from Gemelli Hospital in Rome, faces a further convalescence of at least two months before he can resume his full, normal routine, his doctors said in telephone interviews yesterday.   Dr. Emilio Tresalti, the hospital's chief physician, said that the Pope was ready for medical discharge today but that he might not leave until tomorrow because of logistical and security factors.   The doctors said the Pope made a satisfactory recovery from the one-hour operation he underwent Aug. 5 to close a colostomy, an artificial opening in the colon portion of his large bowel that was made in the emergency operation after he was wounded in St. Peter's Square on May 13.

headline: Business Conditions; WORLD RICE SHORTFALL
abstract: Major crop losses in key countries like Japan and South Korea caused world production of rice - the grain that feeds half the world - to drop slightly last year. According to the Department of Agriculture, 377 million tons of rough rice were harvested, a drop of 2 percent from 1979.

headline: SUNFLOWER EMERGING AS A COMMODITY
abstract: Even though it is the state flower of Kansas, the sunflower has had a history of scant regard by most American farmers as nothing more than a pretty weed that grows between their fences and the highway.   But things are changing. A new hybrid variety of the robust brownand-yellow flower is becoming an interesting new source of edible oil and livestock feed.   The sunflower's new status as a farm commodity now seems assured.  There is now a Sunflower Association of America. Futures contracts in sunflowers are being traded on the Minneapolis Grain Exchange and are expected to be traded on the Chicago Board of Trade after Sept.  1. In its new farm legislation, Congress has proposed a price support program for sunflowers.

headline: Business Digest; THURSDAY, JULY 30, 1981; The Tax Vote
abstract: The House of Representatives approved the Administration's tax reduction bill by 238 to 195 in a decisive victory for President Reagan. The Senate overwhelmingly approved a similar bill earlier in the day. The bills provide for a 25 percent cut in individual income taxes over three years and several business tax reductions. (Page A1.) Congressmen said the President lobbied heavily to win their votes. (D21.)   The economic effects of the radical change in tax policy are questioned by some experts, who foresee sizable budget deficits and high interest rates. (A1.) The President's victory shows a political mastery of Congress not seen since that of President Lyndon B.  Johnson in the mid-1960's. (A1.)

headline: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Reagan and Muldoon Confer
abstract: President Reagan and Prime Minister Robert D. Muldoon of New Zealand conferred today on security in the Pacific and on relations between their countries. Both leaders said that their meeting, the first between the two men, was fruitful. Mr.  Muldoon said he had given ''no indication'' to Mr. Reagan that New Zealand could take part in a multinational peacekeeping force in Sinai after Israel withdraws next April under its peace treaty with Egypt.

headline: Elf Completes Texasgulf Bid
abstract: Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, a company two-thirds owned by the French Government, said that it has completed its $3 billion acquisition of Texasgulf Inc., a major American minerals concern and the world's biggest sulfur producer, despite a request from the United States Government to postpone the merger.   ''It's done,'' said a spokesman for the French oil concern.

headline: NATO WAR GAMES OPEN TODAY IN DENMARK
abstract: The Atlantic alliance's fall war games open officially tomorrow in Denmark, a few hundred miles from the Baltic region where the Soviet Union has just held one of its biggest exercises since World War II.   Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, will attend a ceremony at the Vaerloese air base near Copenhagen marking the start of 28 separate exercises involving 200,000 to 300,000 men from Norway to Turkey.   Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, has complained in the past about the size of Western exercises, often described by Moscow as provocative.

headline: RISES IN PRICE OF FOOD SLOW
abstract: Food prices this year are going up more slowly than expected and will probably rise less than the general inflation rate, the Agriculture Department said today.   Over all, food prices now are expected to rise 8 percent to 10 percent from 1980, the department's World Agricultural Outlook Board said.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The Philadelphia Museum of Art to Tyson Ketchum, Philadelphia.

headline: Business People; Drug Distribution Aids On New Chief's Agenda
abstract: With wholesale drug distributors developing new techniques to cope with the demands of their customers, the Southwestern Drug Corporation, one of the largest wholesalers in the Southwest, intends to develop additional services in the years ahead. And the man just chosen to lead the Dallas company - a $116 million unit of the Gulf United Corporation - in these efforts is Gene Vykukal, 52, who has been named president and chief executive officer.

headline: NIGERIA REDUCES CRUDE OIL PRICE BY $4 A BARREL
abstract: Nigeria, the No.2 exporter of oil to the United States, announced yesterday that it would lower the price of its oil by $4 a barrel in what may be the first in a series of price cuts by OPEC members in the face of a worldwide oil glut.   Although the immediate effect at American gasoline pumps is expected to be negligible, industry experts said that Nigeria's price reduction - to $36 from $40 - if matched by other African producers, could reduce gasoline prices in this country by two or three cents a gallon.   ''It is a remarkable and welcome development,'' said Walter J.  Levy, a prominent oil economist. Others May Follow   Nigeria, whose official price of $40 a barrel is one of the highest in the world, had indicated that a price cut might be necessary to regain customers that purchased oil elsewhere at lower cost.

headline: MANY QUESTIONS RAISED BY NEW PROPERTY-GAINS TAX
abstract: Whatever else may be said about it, the 10 percent gains tax on large transfers of real estate enacted by the New York State Legislature three weeks ago as part of the financial package to aid the city's transit system came suddenly and unexpectedly. When an assistant to Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink was asked where the idea originated, he said it came from the Municipal Research Institute.   The ''Institute'' is a single-room office occupied by its executive director and sole member, Daniel McCarthy, at 5 Beekman Street, near City Hall. Mr. McCarthy is a 27-year-old graduate of the State University at Stony Brook and its master's program in public management, who has worked for the city's Office of Economic Development and the Office of Management and Budget.   He left the city's service in impatience over what he considered a ''vacuum in the policy-making process,'' Mr. McCarthy said in an interview, and established himself as an independent consultant. A pleasantly voluble man with a disarming manner, he said that the idea for the gains tax was original. He presented it in a paper to the Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in May. It was picked up by Assemblyman G.  Oliver Koppell of the Bronx, he said, and Mr. Koppell brought it to the attention of Mr. Fink.

headline: HE MAKES SURE THE SHOW IS ON
abstract: ''I 'M the longest act on Broadway,'' Robert A. Boyar said somewhat immodestly the other day, ''in my 33d year as an insurance broker to the bright lights and to the stars.'' Since 1948, in fact, Mr. Boyar, who is 56, has made the slogan ''the show must go on'' a reality - more so than any producer, director, writer or even a star - as he busily arranges insurance (for all risks) for half the shows on Broadway, some productions elsewhere, plus a certain number of actors and actresses as well.   In his small offices at 217 Broadway in lower Manhattan, Mr. Boyar wheels and deals with the top names in show business, mostly by phone, although ''sometimes I make house calls.'' It is often a 7 A.M. to 10 P.M. day for him -somewhat less for his wife Margery, his administrative aide, and his staff of 12.   Mr. Boyar, who maintains that no other broker specializes to the extent he does in theatrical insurance, handled about $5 million in premiums last year, on which his agency received commissions of about 10 percent. He shares no risks with the underwriters, usually in his case the Chubb insurance group.

headline: 5 U.S. Marines Die as Copter Crashes in the Mediterranean
abstract: Five American marines were killed Thursday when the helicopter they were flying crashed into the sea in a routine night operation in the Mediterranean, the United States Navy announced today.   The cause of the accident is being investigated, according to a press statement.

headline: 3 Are Killed on Matterhorn
abstract: Three British climbers fell to their deaths Sunday on the 14,690-foot Matterhorn, the police reported today. The three, all 18 years old, were identified as Simon Smith of Nottingham and Janet Mulvaney and Stephen Creswell of Derby.

headline: Advertising; A Growing Awareness Overseas
abstract: WHEN he played polo at Princeton in the 1950's, Alexander Brody was sometimes known as Ajax, after the strapping hero of the Trojan war.  As it happens, Mr. Brody is more on the short side, but as president of Young & Rubicam International, he looms large in the overseas ad game.   That game has been revolutionized in the past quarter of a century or so, he said the other day, with important consequences for the players.''The revolution is not only in the look of the advertising, but in the trained people available in larger numbers and the change of attitude by the advertisers, making the concept of marketing part of their national tongues whilst it was a foreign tongue before,'' he said, ''and here I'm talking essentially about the developed countries, in the main about the United Kingdom, Western Europe, Japan, Australia.''

headline: INDIA CITES OIL FIND OFF BOMBAY
abstract: India has discovered a new offshore oil field close to the Bombay coast, the Government announced in Parliament today.   P.C. Sethi, the petroleum minister, said the new structure was about 22 miles east of the highly productive Bombay High field, which is about 100 miles off the northwest coast of India.   Mr. Sethi said the new field was about 50 square miles and that a production test showed an oil flow of about 1,030 barrels a day.  Further tests will be needed to estimate the total reserve and yield, Mr. Sethi added.

headline: SHAH'S NIECE LEADS MONARCHIST CAUSE
abstract: Princess Azadeh, the niece of the late Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, says that Iran can survive only if the monarchy is restored.   Only the Pahlevis can govern Iran, she maintains, and only their return could save the country from pressures from the Soviet Union and the internal chaos that, she says, must inevitably be the heritage of the current Islamic Republic.   Princess Azadeh, who is the leader of the monarchist Free Iran movement here, made these statements in an interview this week.  The Princess is the daughter of Princess Ashraf, the Shah's twin sister, who heads the monarchist movement in the United States. She is also the sister of the late Prince Mustafa Chafik, who was gunned down outside her home here in 1979, apparently by agents of the Iranian revolutionary regime.

headline: TOKYO AND SEOUL AGAIN FAIL TO AGREE ON AID
abstract: Japan and South Korea failed again yesterday to agree on a Korean request for $6 billion in economic aid over five years.   A statement made public here after a two-day meeting in Seoul on the aid request did not say whether Japan would eventually increase its aid, which is more than $80 mi llion a year, to the troubled SouthKorean econom y.   But officials here said the talks were not a complete failure. A ''last-ditch effort'' led to agreement to continue the negotiations, they said.   ''It's very significant that the two sides parted in an amicable atmosphere,'' said a high-ranking Japanese diplomat who asked not to be identified. ''The effort to build new relations with the Korean people continues.''

headline: ALLIS-CHALMERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SGL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: R.J. REYNOLDS AND F.T.E. GAIN
abstract: R.J. Reynolds Inc., the nation's leading producer of cigarettes, announced yesterday that earnings in the second quarter increased 21.1 percent, while revenues climbed 16.9 percent.   The Winston-Salem, N.C., concern said that net income in the latest three months soared to $198.2 million, or $1.82 a share, from $163.6 million, or $1.50 a share, in the corresponding three months a year earlier. Revenues increased to $2.97 billion from $2.54 billion.   ''Particularly strong gains were turned in by our energy and domestic tobacco businesses as well as a significant contribution from our foods business,'' said J. Paul Sticht, chairman and chief executive of Reynolds.

headline: Soviet Buys U.S. Grain
abstract: The Soviet Union has purchased 700,000 metric tons of American grain, half corn and half wheat, for delivery before Sept. 30, the Agriculture Department announced Friday.

headline: M.A.C. Plans Bond Offering
abstract: The Municipal Assistance Corporation intends to proceed with a bond sale later this month, despite record high interest rates, officials said after yesterday's board of directors meeting. The new issue might go on sale next week, according to M.A.C.'s board chairman, Felix Rohatyn.

headline: APPLIED POWERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MOBIL LIFTS ITS OFFER FOR CONOCO
abstract: Moving to outbid Du Pont and Seagram in the multibillion-dollar battle for Conoco Inc., the Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it was increasing its cash offer for the nation's ninth-largest oil company to $105 a share for slightly more than half of Conoco's stock.   Mobil also said it was reducing its offer for the rest to the equivalent of $85 a share in Mobil securities.
