Mobil, the nation's second-largest oil company after Exxon, valued its combined offer at $95 a share, or $8.17 billion in cash and securities for Conoco's 86 million shares.   It valued a competing offer from E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company at an average price of $84 a share, or $7.3 billion in cash and stock, but said it could not estimate the average price of a bid by Joseph E. Seagram & Sons because Seagram was seeking only 51 percent of Conoco, for which it would pay cash.

headline: TRANS-WESTERN EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Advertising; Response Mixed to Postal Plan
abstract: ADVERTISING executives reacted with cautious and limited approval yesterday to the United States Postal Service's announcement Tuesday that it was considering the sale of commercial advertising space in post offices and on postal trucks, mailboxes and other postal property and materials - but not on the front of postage stamps.   The announcement came in a notice in the Federal Register, which requested public comment by Oct. 15. Afterward the Postal Service is to publish its conclusions along with a summary of the comment. The agency has the authority to start accepting commercial advertising, which would be a reversal of a long-held policy.

headline: G. HEILEMAN OFFERS TO BUY SCHLITZ
abstract: Schlitz - the beer that made Milwaukee famous and then fell into disfavor with beer drinkers because someone changed its formula - may be swallowed by an upstart brewer that has become one of the fastest growing in the industry by selling little-known regional beers.   The G. Heileman Brewing Company of La Crosse, Wis., has offered to buy the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company for $494 million, or $17 a share, in cash and stock.   If completed, the acquisiton would make Heileman, a relative newcomer that has moved from 39th place to No.6 in 20 years, the nation's third-largest brewer, with a 16 percent share of the market, behind Anheuser-Busch (28 percent) and Miller (22 percent).

headline: MACDONALD, E F, CO reports earnings for 16 weeks to Aug 16
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Shasta Beverages Inc., Hayward, Calif., to Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago.

headline: WARSAW STREET TIE-UP ENDS AFTER TWO-HOUR STRIKE
abstract: A column of 173 bus and trucks ended a two-day blockage of a downtown street intersection here today after workers in the Polish capital had staged a two-hour strike to protest food shortages.   The peaceful dissolution of the convoy, cheered by thousands, ended a confrontation between the independent trade union and the authorities. But there were no signs that union locals planned to end their food marches.   The token Warsaw strike, the biggest since March, idled the transport system and tens of thousands of industrial workers. Health services, food processing and small shops were exempted from the strike, which was called last week.

headline: Soviet Asks Egyptians To Leave in One Week
abstract: - The Soviet Union retaliated today for the expulsion of its diplomats and advisers from Cairo by ordering Egyptian military personnel to leave Moscow within seven days, Tass, the official press agency, said.

headline: ARMS BUDGET IN SOUTH AFRICA IS BEING RAISED BY 40 PERCENT
abstract: The South African Government today increased its military spending by 40 percent in 1981-82 to counter what it described as external threats.

headline: IRANIAN WARNS FRANCE TO EXTRADITE BOAT HIJACKERS
abstract: Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, hinted today that French ships and planes might be hijacked in the Persian Gulf unless France extradited the Iranian exiles who seized an Iranian gunboat.   ''If your planes and ships are from now on pirated in the Persian Gulf and we declared support for such thefts, how can you object?'' Mr. Rafsanjani said in a speech before Parliament that was broadcast by Teheran radio and monitored here.   He said that the exiled monarchists who commandeered the gunboat Tabarzin off Spain's southern coast last Thursday and surrendered the vessel to French authorities yesterday were ''thieves wanted in their own country for prosecution.''

headline: A SETBACK FOR U.S.
abstract: The Israeli air strikes in Beirut today disrupted the Reagan Administration's plans for what it hoped would be the most intensive and productive several weeks of Middle   East diplomacy since the inauguration.  With the Israeli elections over and President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt due here in less than three weeks, the Reagan policy makers had ambitious hopes of reviving the stalled talks on Palestinian autonomy and building upon the Camp David framework. They hoped to have, with luck, some new initiatives to propose to Prime Minister Menachem Begin when the Israeli leader arrives here in early September.   Officials said that the first step in clearing the air for this diplomatic offensive was scheduled for this morning, when the State Department was to announce a formula under which the United States would resume sending F-16 jets to Israel. The shipments were suspended after the June 7 Israeli attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor.

headline: China to Pay Mitsubishi
abstract: China has agreed to compensate Japan's Mitsubishi industrial group for scrapping a $369 million contract to build a steel rolling mill at Baoshan, near Shanghai, Mitsubishi said today.

headline: LIBYAN IN BRITAIN GETS LIFE
abstract: Hosni Harhat, a Libyan airlines worker, was sentenced to life imprisonment today for attempting to kill Farag Ghesouda, another Libyan, his wife and two children by leaving a packet of poisoned peanuts in their home. The prosecution said Mr. Farhat had wanted to poison the family because they did not obey Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, when he ordered Libyans living abroad to return home.

headline: Pitney Bowes Study Ended
abstract: The Justice Department has ended a five-year antitrust investigation of Pitney Bowes Inc. and decided to take no action against the company, department officials said today.   The officials said that the department had said in a memorandum sent to Pitney Bowes that it had decided not to pursue the matter further.

headline: Briton Utilizes Solar Energy To Cross Channel by Balloon
abstract: A 37-year-old London engineer crossed the English Channel to France in less than two hours today in a hot air balloon kept aloft by solar energy.   Julian Nott, a solar energy enthusiast, said he had had ''the flight of a lifetime.'' Mr. Nott had aid from a burner to get his double-skinned balloon into the air from a field near Canterbury, southeast of London, at 7 A.M. But once he was in flight, the heat of the sun's rays kept the air warm in the balloon as he drifted to France.

headline: OHIO-SEALY MATTRESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Volvo Truck Plant Site Is Reported
abstract: Volvo of Sweden has tentatively picked Greensboro as the site for its United States truck plant if a Federal court in Ohio lets it acquire the White Motor Corporation, according to sources here.

headline: THRIFT AID PLANS DIFFER
abstract: The Reagan Administration, for the second time in several months, has rejected most of a plan developed by the nation's banking regulators to deal with short-term problems in the ailing thrift industry.   But in rejecting the proposal, which was introduced last week by Fernand J. St Germain, chairman of the House Banking Committee, the Administration said it was looking favorably on a broader, long-term proposal that would further deregulate the thrift industry, making savings banks and savings and loan associations more like commercial banks.   This longer-term plan, which would essentially broaden the lending and investment powers of thrift institutions, is being put together by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates federally chartered savings and loan associations.

headline: AFRICAN LEADERS IN LAGOS BID SOUTH AFRICANS LEAVE ANGOLA
abstract: The leaders of six African countries headed home today after issuing a communique calling on South Africa to remove its troops from Angola.

headline: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SIXTH I.R.A. HUNGER STRIKER DIES
abstract: Martin Hurson, a member of the Irish Republican Army, died early today in Maze Prison on the 45th day of his fast, Britain's Northern Ireland office said.  He was the sixth Irish nationalist prisoner to die in a bid for political prisoner status.   The prison authorities had summoned Mr. Hurson's family to his bedside in the prison hospital wing yesterday after a sudden deterioration in his condition.

headline: METROMEDIA SEEKS TV STATION
abstract: Metromedia Inc. announced yesterday that it had reached agreement to purchase what is widely regarded as one of the best television stations in the country - WCVB-TV, Channel 5, the independently owned ABC affiliate in Boston - for a record $220 million.   The agreement, which is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission, gives Metromedia both an unusually strong station in the nation's sixth-largest market and a rich source of programming. WCVB, which is owned by Boston Broadcasters Inc., produces 62 hours of original programs a week, more than any local affiliate station in the country. Many of the programs are syndicated nationally.

headline: Business Conditions; GASOLINE TAXES RISING
abstract: Although recent declines in retail gasoline prices have been welcomed by consumers, a spate of tax increases in states across the country may have erased the benefits. And the trend could spread.

headline: Japan Video Recorders
abstract: Japan surpassed the 800,000 mark in production of home videotape recorders for the first time in July, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan said Friday. July's production of 802,000 units was more than double the figure for July 1980, the group said. Exports in July totaled 642,000 units, up 110.7 percent from July 1980.

headline: PILOT IS SAID TO DEFECT FROM TAIWAN TO CHINA
abstract: A Taiwan Air Force major the Chinese say defected to the mainland was given a $433,000 reward and a position in China's Air Force today, the Peking radio reported.   Huang Che-cheng, 29 years old, wore his Chinese Air Force uniform at a rally of more than 2,000 people in Fuzhou, 150 miles northwest of the Taiwan field where he took off Saturday for the mainland, the radio said.

headline: SCRIPTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PEKING STRESSES ECONOMIC GAINS AS PARTY PRIORITY
abstract: The Chinese Communist Party has published a platform of party goals that appeal to almost everyone except people opposed to continued Communist rule of China.   The platform calls for slow but steady economic development and improvement of living standards, gradual extension of democracy under party control, a loose mix of public and private enterprise, a legal system that guarantees people's rights, a commitment to intellectual achievement, protection of religious freedom, a modernized army as the economy improves and more autonomy for ethnic minorities.   At a rally in the Great Hall of the People today, the new party chairman, Hu Yaobang, said that China would stress the role of competent managers in a new era of orderly economic development and would no longer tolerate a single all-powerful ruler like Mao Zedong. (Page A12.)

headline: DILLINGHAM CUTS
abstract: Shareholders of the Dillingham Corporation of Honolulu overwhelmingly approved a plan to liquidate the company's Hawaiian commercial property and to transfer ownership to a new limited partnership of present stockholders. The company would not estimate the value of the property to be transferred, but market sources estimate it conservatively at about $250 million, equal to about $15 a share on the roughly 16.9 million shares that will be outstanding after conversion of preferred stock and debentures.

headline: ECUADOR'S DEMOCRACY WEATHERS LOSS OF PRESIDENT
abstract: This small country of traditionally unstable politics has just gone through the national trauma of the sudden death of a popular young President and has emerged with its newly democratic form of Government intact.   ''I would even say the tragedy strengthened our democracy,'' said Gil Barragan Romero, a congressional leader.  Jaime Roldos Aguilera, 40 years old and less than two years into his five-year term, died in a plane crash May 24 as he, his wife, the Defense Minister and other aides were flying through bad weather to a border town to make a political appearance.   The shock was deeply felt in this nation of 7.5 million people that elected Mr. Roldos with more than a million votes in 1979, ending nine years of civilian and military dictatorships. Some of his more fervent followers even shouted ''assassin'' at Vice President Oswaldo Hurtado Larrea during the funeral possession in Guayaquil.

headline: P.L.O. BID SEEN AT WORLD BANK-I.M.F. TALKS
abstract: Arab members of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund have launched a drive to enable the Palestine Liberation Organization to attend the joint annual meetings as an official observer, Administration and fund officials said today.   The officials said that Mohammed Finaish of Libya, one of 22 executive directors of the I.M.F., had formally requested that the issue of observer status for the P.L.O. be added to the agenda of the Boards of Governors meetings of both institutions. The international assistance and lending organizations are scheduled to open their joint annual meeting on Sept. 29.

headline: Pemex Financing
abstract: The six-year financing package for the Mexican state oil company, Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, is almost certain to be cut to $200 million from $500 million, because of current market conditions, the European Banking Company, manager of the financing, said here today. The deal has progressed slowly since its start about one month ago, the bank added, becuase of competing Pemex borrowings, the unusual type of facilit y and the August holidays.

headline: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NEO-NAZIS ACCUSED IN LONDON RIOTS
abstract: William Whitelaw, the Home Secretary, called today for a full report on the racial violence in London last night that sent more than 60 policemen to hospitals with serious injuries and caused millions of dollars in property damage.   After more than four hours of fighting between Asian youths and white "skinheads"--so-called because they have close-cropped hair--the main business area of the Southall section of West London looked like a combat zone.   The fighting was punctuated by attacks with petroleum bombs.  The streets were littered with bricks and glass, shopfronts were shattered, burntout cars and trucks blocked several intersections and the Hambrough Tavern, on which the fighting centered, was a smoldering ruin.

headline: Around the World; 3 Cambodian Factions A gree on Coalition Pact
abstract: The Communist forces of the former Cambodian Prime Minister, Pol Pot, and representatives of two other Cambodian factions agreed today on a joint statement of intention to form a coalition government to oppose the Vietnamese occupation of their country.   The statement is to be signed tomorrow by Khieu Samphan, the present Prime Minister of the Pol Pot movement; Prince Norodom Sihanouk, who abdicated as King to become chief of state and was deposed in 1970, and Son Sann, a Prime Minister under the Prince who now commands an anti-Communist guerrilla movement.

headline: Your Money; FLUX IN SECOND MORTGAGES
abstract: ''BORROW today and pay it back with cheaper dollars'' was one of the main slogans used by banks and other financial institutions to encourage consumers to take out loans by taking second mortgages on their houses.   And many consumers apparently were persuaded. Loans on second mortgages boomed in the late 1970's and in 1980 and some consumer finance companies such as the Beneficial Corporation and Household International Inc., formerly the Household Finance Corporation, have seen their portfolios of second mortgages soar. Last year, for example, such loans at Beneficial totaled $1.1 billion, 32 percent of its total portfolio.

headline: CANADIAN NEWSPAPERS ATTACK PROPOSAL TO CURB MONOPOLIES
abstract: A confrontation between the Canadian Government and the nation's press appeared likely today following proposals for official action to curb press monopolies in Canada and raise the quality of newspapers.   The proposals were made public yesterday by a Government-appointed commission, which warned that the ''monstrous'' press concentration that now existed would grow along with a deterioration in the quality of newspapers unless legal action was taken.   The idea of a Canada Newspaper Act that would force major chains to divest themselves of some of their properties and introduce other regulations came under angry attack in the press. But James Fleming, Minister of State for Multiculturalism, indicated that the Government was prepared to act by the fall because ''the situation is serious.''

headline: Credit Markets; Treasury Note at Peak Yield; Rate Is Put At 16.14%
abstract: The Treasury's needs for new money to finance the Federal deficit helped to produce a record yield of 16.14 percent for the Government's five-year two-month note auctioned yesterday. Trading on a ''when-issued'' basis, the note had finished Wednesday at a return of 16 percent.   Sold in minimum denominations of $1,000, these notes raised $3.25 billion - all in fresh cash. The interest coupon was set at 16 1/8 percent. The yield was based on an average price of 99.733 for the notes maturing Nov. 15, 1986.

headline: ELCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INDIA BARS SENIOR U.S. DIPLOMAT, STIRRING A DISPUTE
abstract: India has refused to accept a senior American diplomat in New Delhi, touching off a dispute with the Reagan Administration.   The dispute, over the assignment of George G.B. Griffin as political counselor, the third-ranking post in the United States Embassy, has aggravated the strain in relations between the two countries, American officials said. The United States has retaliated by barring a senior Indian diplomat.   It is unusual for a government to block a foreign diplomat from taking up an assignment. Ambassadors are subject to scrutiny, but lower-ranking diplomats generally take up their posts without prior agreement. As a result, the Indians' refusal to accept Mr. Griffin is being described by State Department officials as ''unprecedented.''

headline: Mobil Obtains Payment Stay
abstract: Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan today temporarily freed the Mobil Oil Corporation from paying other refiners about $50 million under the now-defunct oil price control program.   Justice Brennan issued an emergency stay of a lower court ruling that would have allowed the Government to force Mobil to make the payments.

headline: Winchester Sold
abstract: The Olin Corporation, maker of Winchester firearms, said a group of executives from its sporting arms plant had signed an agreement to buy the troubled business.

headline: HAIG TO PRESS REAGAN TO ABANDON WEINBERGER'S AIRBORNE MX PLAN
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  plans to see President Reagan Sunday to argue against Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's plan for mounting the new MX missiles on aircraft, Administration officials said today.   The officials said that Mr. Haig regards the forthcoming decision by Mr. Reagan on new missile deployment as crucial, not only for American defenses, but for maintaining allied unity. He is reportedly prepared to argue that, in addition to military and economic considerations, abandonment of the land-based MX plan would create additional political pressures in Western Europe against the deployment of American medium-range nuclear missiles there.   Mr. Haig is expected to meet with President Reagan privately at his ranch near Santa Barbara, Calif. Mr. Reagan, Mr. Haig, Mr. Weinberger and other senior national security and political advisers will meet on Monday, and perhaps Tuesday as well, in Los Angeles to go over pending military decisions and other issues.

headline: SLIDE TO 940.54 IS SHARPEST SINCE JAN. 20
abstract: Stock market prices broke on a wide front yesterday amid mounting fears that interest rates would remain high and eventually damage the economy without achieving further success in reducing inflation.   The Dow Jones industrial average fell 18.36 points, to 940.54, in the biggest one-day decline since Jan. 20, when it fell 20.31 points. The decline brought the index closer to its lowest level of this year, 931.57, which it reached on Feb. 13.   Many investors were discouraged by President Reagan's apparent rejection of pleas for lower American interest rates made by leaders of the major industrial countries at the economic summit meeting under way in Ottawa. Industrialized nations have been adversely affected by the high United States interest rates that have caused an outflow of investment funds from their countries.

headline: ANTI-REBEL PROPAGANDA IN BOLIVIA COMES WITH AN ARGENTINE ACCENT
abstract: The 15-minute cartoon showed a cynical bear and a vulture plotting to take over a tiny, far-off country.  The bear was never identified, but its headquarters looked distinctly like the Kremlin.   The cartoon was shown on television here many times last week and there was little doubt about its message: Rebellious military units were in the employ of the Soviet Union.

headline: New Caltex Chief
abstract: The Caltex Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of William E. Tucker as its chair man and chief executive officer, succeeding James M. Voss, who has be en chairman and chief executive office since 1970. Mr. Tucker has b een president for six years. Mr. Voss will complete 35 years with t he company when he retires Nov.1. Howard V. Yergin Jr., executiv e vice president of Caltex since 1979, will succeed Mr. Tucker as president of the company.

headline: ON ISLAND IN BOLIVIA, AN INDIAN SOCIETY THRIVES
abstract: Nearing its island destination in Lake Titicaca, the crew cut the boat's engine and poled along a winding narrow channel through tall reeds. As the re e ds began to thin, several hundred Indians could be seen on a bl uff, dancing, singing and waving to greet the boat's arrival.   The village elders, old men with leathery hands and missing teeth, wearing ill-fitting suits and traditional wool caps under brimmed, Western hats, came down to the shore to welcome each visitor in a rudimentary Spanish.   These were Aymara Indians, many of whom still speak only their native tongue. Of the 5.5 million Bolivians, roughly one million are Aymara-speaking Indians, and nearly a million others are Indians who speak other dialects.

headline: Time's Profit Grows 20.9%
abstract: Time Inc., the nation's largest magazine publisher, yesterday reported second-quarter earnings of $49.2 million, or $1.60 a share, up from $41.6 million, or $1.49 a share, a year before.   Last year's second-quarter profit was before a loss of $917,000 from discontinued operations, making final net income $40.7 million, or $1.45 a share.

headline: STOCK DROPS 37 1 4
abstract: A yearlong auction for the Delhi International Oil Corporation ended yesterday without a bidder and shareholders quickly registered their disappointment with a flurry of sell orders that pushed the stock down 37 1/4 points in one day, to 77 1/4, on the American Stock Exchange on a volume of 455,200 shares.   ''We all expected something, but no one imagined that there would not be any bidders,'' said Ellen Greenspan, an arbitrage analyst at Oppenheimer & Company.   ''I think this was a case of the market price getting away from the price that potential buyers were willing to pay,'' said a source close to the negotiations for Delhi.   The company's management put Delhi, one of the nation's smaller oil companies, up for sale last year. At the time no reason was given, but analysts said that the Dallas-based concern lacked capital to explore its undeveloped acreage in Australia. The deadline for sealed bids was 5 P.M. on Monday.

headline: Your Money; New Yields For Savings
abstract: THE beleaguered thrift industry has been battling for the small investor's dollar as people desert savings institutions for alternate investment vehicles. The institutions are beginning to offer new plans. Among these was one recently offered by a New York savings bank. As with most savings plans, there are some provisions that can surprise the unwary investor.   Earlier this month, the East New York Savings Bank advertised what it calls its ''guaranteed ski-hi'' interest rate of 18 percent for 48-month certificates of deposit ranging from $2,500 to $100,000.

headline: SALE OF F-15 GEAR TO SAUDIS STUDIED
abstract: A Government committee studying the question whether the United States should agree to sell Saudi Arabia specialized bomb racks for its F-15 fighter planes is not expected to reach a decision until ''late this year or early next year,'' an official said.   Three other high-ranking officials confirmed the statement that a committee to ''review Saudi Arabia's air-to-ground requirements,'' or its need for bombing capability, had just begun work. All four officials, who spoke on condition that their names not be used, said they did not believe it was very likely that the review committee would recommend the sale of so-called multiple-ejection bomb racks to Saudi Arabia. They did not rule out this possibility, however.

headline: Other Business; PUBLISHING: HOW COLUMBIA POPPED UP FROM THE CROWD
abstract: CALI, Colombia The stone facade of the corporate headquarters of Carvajal S.A.  looks imposing enough, and the polished conference tables inside suggest there's serious business going on.   Then what are these executives doing flipping through children's books and chuckling? Possibly, celebrating the fact that they have taken the invention of another age and become the world's largest exporter of so-called ''pop-up'' books.   Pop-up books for children, which were made in Austria and Germany a century ago, are expected to generate $7 million in overseas sales for Carvajal this year. Hand-assembled south of here in Santander de Quilichao and the picturesque old highland university city of Popayan, the books come in 18 languages and are being exported at the rate of a half-million a month.

headline: Greek Cabinet Modified To Prepare for Elections
abstract: The Greek Cabinet today formally submitted its resignation and was then immediately given a mandate to form a slightly modified Cabinet to conduct next month's elections.   The only change in the new Cabinet will be the replacement of the Ministers of the Interior, Justice and Public Order and the Under Secretary of Press and Information with people equally acceptable to the Socialist opposition as a means of holding irreproachable elections.

headline: GERMANS FIND PLOT AGAINST A U.S. BASE
abstract: The police found and defused two time bombs today that had been placed on a rail spur used to carry supplies in and out of a United States air base in Frankfurt.   The bombs, each containing about 13 pounds of explosives packed into expended fire extinguishers, could have blown up a train, a police spokesman said. The spur, running from the Rhine-Main Air Base to the main Frankfurt-Mannheim rail line, is being used with particular frequency because of current NATO maneuvers in West Germany. The incident was the fifth attempted attack on American personnel and installations in West Germany since Aug. 31.

headline: PITTSBURGH'S TOP BRASS ALL LOVE THE DUQUESNE CLUB
abstract: PITTSBURGH I T is noon, and the revolving doors of the Duquesne Club spin nonstop as a seemingly endless stream of men and women spills into the small foyer. They wait for their luncheon partners under murals of cherubim engaged in pursuits that are not usually associated with the chubby nudes, but are dear to the members' hearts: golfing, fly casting, hunting. Many of the women, however, slip discreetly toward the side staircase and what is still known - despite rechristening a year ago as the Crystal Room - as the Ladies' Dining Room.   Women were permitted to join the Duquesne Club last year but, to the immense relief of its 2,500 males, it is still very much a man's world. ''After all the fuss we had, we finally wound up with three women members,'' said Gurdon F. Flagg, the club's 80-year-old secretary-treasurer, noting that few women have reached the rarefied levels appropriate to membership. The privileged few ''are all very gratified to be able to come in,'' added Mr. Flagg, who has worked at the club for 50 years.

headline: Oppenheimer Moves To Rosenfeld, Sirowitz
abstract: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson has emerged as a winner in what must have been a very creative competition for the Oppenheimer Management Corporation account, which last year billed about $2.5 million.

headline: Rouse-Trizec Pact
abstract: The Rouse Company of Columbia, Md., said it had agreed in principle to a five-year agreement under which the Trizec Corporation, a real estate holding and management concern based in Calgary, Alberta, would be permitted to increase its stake in Rouse to 20.5 percent from a current 7 percent.

headline: TRINITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THURSDAY, AUGUST 13, 1981; The Economy
abstract: A two-day logjam in trans-Atlantic air travel cleared up swiftly after Canadian air traffic controllers called off a boycott of United States flights. In return, Ottawa promised to take part in an inquiry into the controllers' contention that the strike by American controllers had created safety hazards. (Page A1.) Airline executives and many pilots say that flights during the strike, carried on under a contingency flight plan developed by the F.A.A. last year, are as safe as in normal times. (A1.)   Retail sales rose 1.3 percent in July, the Commerce Department reported. Although it was the second consecutive large monthly increase, economists did not see it as a sign of economic resurgence. Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, acknowledged in a radio interview that the nation might be in its second recession in two years. (D1.)

headline: American Express Gains
abstract: The American Express Company, aided by a strong performance from its newly acquired investment unit, said yesterday that its secondquarter profit rose 15.8 percent from a year earlier.   American Express said that it earned $132 million, or $1.42 a share, in the second quarter, compared with $114 million, or $1.27 a share, a year earlier.

headline: Commodities; Quality Is A Factor In Pricing
abstract: OF all the factors that determine wheat futures prices, quality is usually not one of them. This season, however, the quality factor has not only become an important influence on prices, but in a most bizarre way. The fact is that high protein, top-quality wheat has been selling at deep discounts compared with the lower-grade ordinary grain for the last month or so.   Last Friday, for example, the spot September wheat futures on the Minneapolis Grain Exchange, which is known as the ''protein market,'' closed at $4.22 a bushel, down 8 cents on the week. The grain traded on that small exchange is top-quality dark Northern hard spring wheat used to make pastas and bread.

headline: Heinz Net Up 26.5%
abstract: The H.J. Heinz Company reported yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 26.5 percent, to $48.2 million, from $38.1 million in the comparable period of 1980. Per-share earnings rose to $2.05 from $1.65.

headline: The Economy
abstract: New construction of single-family houses fell in August to the lowest level in more than two decades, the Commerce Department reported. It said that overall housing starts had hit the lowest rate since February 1975. High interest rates were blamed. The Federal Reserve Board said U.S. factories operated at 79.2 percent of capacity in August, the lowest level in almost a year. The reports were consistent with other indicators of a slumping economy. (Page D1.)   Americans' personal income rose 1.1 percent in August, the Commerce Department reported. About a quarter of the $26.9 billion rise came from high interest paid on investments. (D1.)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Allis-Chalmers Corp. said its credit unit had completed a $100 million, three-year revolving credit agreement with 16 U.S. banks, including Citibank as agent.   * Bovaird Supply Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed initial public offering of 2.5 million common shares, to be solely managed by Merrill Lynch.

headline: Other Business; A NEW LIGHT FROM I.B.M. AT THE CHECKOUT
abstract: When International Business Machines late last year unveiled one of the first commercial products to use holography - a supermarket checkout scanner that reads those mysterious computerized bars on merchandise -its competitors gathered 'round.   The I.B.M. scanner was special -sending out laser beams that wrap around any grocery store product to find and read the product's Universal Product Code, detecting the identifying product and manufacturer code all by itself. Ketchup bottle or potato chip bag, the scanner finds the U.P.C.   Speed, they said. Accuracy. With a normal supermarket scanner, after all, the cashier has to find the code, and place it directly over the electronic eye to get the correct reading.

headline: FAMILIES SHIFT HOMES IN AN INFLAMED ULSTER
abstract: Bridget Eccles, a Roman Catholic bricklayer's wife, always thought there would be no risk in living among Protestants. But she does not think that anymore.   ''It was one night in August when we decided we had to move,'' Mrs. Eccles explained, standing at a kitchen counter in the family's new home, in a Catholic neighborhood. ''A mob of Protestants came charging down the street shouting slogans against Catholics, and saying that there was no place for us here. All that week the Catholics on our street were getting their windows broken and slogans painted on their walls.''

headline: FUNDS' ASSETS CONTINUE CLIMB
abstract: The assets of the nation's money funds climbed $2.2 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   The steady increase in the funds reflects the continued attraction of investors to the higher yields paid by the funds, compared with such other investment instruments as six-month savings certificates.

headline: Socal, Texaco Find
abstract: The Standard Oil Company of California said today that it and Texaco Inc. have made new oil discoveries totaling 4,220 barrels daily from three discovery wells so far this year near the Duri field in central Sumatra, Indonesia.

headline: Indian Women March in Delhi To Protest Against Price Rise
abstract: Thousands of women marched through parts of this city to Parliament today to protest rising prices and lawlessness in India.   The police said more than 10,000 women had taken part in the march, organized by the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party.  Atal Behari Vajpayee, the party's president, told a rally outside Parliament that there was mounting dissatisfaction over rising living costs and a breakdown of law and order.

headline: British Auto Output Up
abstract: British car production in July is estimated to have risen sharply to a seasonally adjusted monthly average of 105,000, from 80,000 the previous month and 101,000 in July 1980, the Department of Industry said today. Output of 534,000 vehicles in the first seven months of 1981, however, was 11.7 percent below the 605,000 in the same period last year, the department said.

headline: CBS Profit Off 22.8% in Period
abstract: CBS Inc., the diversified communications concern, said yesterday that earnings in the second quarter fell 22.8 percent, to $41.9 million, or $1.50 a share, from $54.3 million, or $1.94 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose to a record $998.2 million from $971.8 million.

headline: UNITED OVERTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HOME LOAN PLAN BACKED
abstract: Federal regulators today approved a new type of home loan, combining features of existing plans, in an attempt to protect lenders while helping home buyers qualify for loans they might otherwise be unable to afford.   The action by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board will allow Federally chartered savings institutions to offer what the board calls a Graduated Payment Adjustable Mortgage Loan.

headline: HARVESTER UNIT SOLD TO CATERPILLAR
abstract: The International Harvester Company said it has completed the sale of its Solar Turbines International unit to the Caterpillar Tractor Company for about $505 million.   Officials said that because of Harvester's tax position, nearly all of the money from the sale will be available to the company and will provide increased financial flexibility.

headline: PABST JOINS THE BIDDING FOR SCHLITZ
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company yesterday entered the competition to buy the troubled Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, which last week accepted a lower offer from the G. Heileman Brewing Company.   A Pabst-Schlitz union would enhance Pabst's position as the nation's third-largest brewer, with about 17 percent of the United States beer market, up from 8.4 percent.   The proposal made by Pabst, based in Milwaukee, is valued at $588 million, through a combination of $200 million in cash and $388 million in debentures, equal to $20 a share. The debentures, bearing interest of 15.5 percent, would be convertible into Pabst common stock at $27 a share.

headline: RECORDINGS RAISE QUESTIONS ABOUT TIMERMAN'S ACCOUNT
abstract: Police tape recordings of interrogation sessions with Jacobo Timerman have raised questions about whether the former newspaper publisher fully explained the authorities' possible motives in arresting and torturing him.   Mr. Timerman has said that his 1977 arrest and subsequent torture during two and a half years in prison stemmed in large part from the fact that he is a Jew and from the alleged anti-Semitism of the Argentine Government.   Many Argentines who have survived the torture and secret jails report that Jews are often dealt extra punishment and that Nazi flags decorate some torture chambers.   On the tapes, Mr. Timerman can be heard acknowledging that he had expected his arrest because of his association with David Graiver, a fugitive financier who reportedly died the year before in a plane crash in Mexico.

headline: Economic Analysis
abstract: ''Free trade doesn't exist,'' contends Michael Samuels, who watches over international trade matters for the United States Chamber of Commerce. ''It's like infinity - you never reach it.''   Nevertheless, judging from the statements of the Reagan Administration, the removal of trade barriers to achieve free trade has a high order of priority.   Getting rid of tariffs, quotas and credit and other subsidies, along with buy-national procurement policies and other forms of trade discrimination, meshes with a Reagan conservatism that elevates the marketplace as the favored instrument for allocating resources.

headline: Mauritania Denies a Charge That 100,000 Live in Slavery
abstract: Mauritania denied today that 100,000 of its people, about 10 percent of the population, live in slavery.  A report by the London-based Anti-Slavery Society to the United Nations Human Rights Commission, which is meeting here, charged that Mauritanian Government officials kept slaves despite the fact that bondage was outlawed last year.

headline: CASTILIANS TRY TO INFUSE LIFE INTO OLD AREA
abstract: In Spanish history, Castile is a proud name.  Today it is a lament. Castile once sallied out to conquer the world.  Today it is merely a region.   As if they were playing a small joke on the past, legislators from Old Castile gathered here recently and resolved that this hill town would be their capital.   They chose Tordesillas, which has 8,000 inhabitants and a few road junctions, not because it is particularly beautiful, or convenient, or important. They chose it because legislators from Burgos did not want Valladolid to be the capital, and legislators from Valladolid were against Burgos.

headline: OFFSHORE OIL: SURPRISE DISPUTE
abstract: To hear critics tell it, the Reagan Administration will not rest contented until the entire continental shelf of the United States is littered with oil wells.   That view is perhaps predictable from the likes of environmental organizations like the Sierra Club and their champion, Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California. His state last week persuaded a Federal court to block the sale of 150,000 acres of promising oil tracts off the California coast.   Surpisingly, however, not all oilmen believe that Interior Secretary James G. Watt's plan to auction off one billion acres of offshore land over the next five years is the greatest thing since the percentage depletion allowance. Quietly, individual companies are grousing that the plan may be too much, too fast, and too different.

headline: AUSTRALIA COAL VENTURE
abstract: The four partners in the the Oaky Creek coking coal joint venture in Queensland have decided to proceed with the project, M.I.M. Holdings Ltd., the senior partner, said today. Coal should be ready for export from the 2.3-million-ton-a-year plant by 1983, the company said. M.I.M. has a 78 percent stake in the project with the rest held by Estel Delstoffen, with 9.5 percent; Italsider S.p.A., 7.5 percent, and Nacional Siderurguca S.A., with 5 percent. Financing of the project is being arranged with a group of banks led by the Bank of New South Wales, Citibank and Toronto Dominion Bank, with the First Boston Corporation as financial adviser.

headline: NEW BRITISH PARTY SHOWS STRENGTH IN FIRST ELECTION
abstract: The new Social Democratic Party, in the first electoral test of its campaign to break the power monopoly of the two major parties, scored a symbolic victory last night by coming within a hair's breadth of capturing the Warrington constituency, which had been a Labor stronghold for more than half a century.   In one of the most vital by-elections in decades, Roy Jenkins, a former Labor Home Secretary and Chancellor of the Exchequer, lost by only 1,759 votes to Douglas Hoyle, a member of the Labor Party's left wing. In May 1979, Sir Thomas Williams, now a judge, won the seat for Labor by 10,274 votes, one of the largest majorities in that general election.   Neither the most optimistic Social Democratic workers, nor the public-opinion polls, nor the leading British political commentators, had given Mr. Jenkins any chance of approaching the 42 percent of the vote that he achieved. Exultant in defeat, Mr. Jenkins said the result at Warrington, in northern England, would result in ''a Social Democratic-Liberal government with a huge majority'' if it were duplicated in a general election.

headline: Venezuela Oil Output
abstract: Crude oil production in Venezuela for the week ended Wednesday averaged 2.09 million barrels daily, the Ministry of Energy and Mines reported today.

headline: BARCO OF CALIFORNIA (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Canada Price Index Up
abstract: Canada's consumer price index rose ninetenths of 1 percent in July, down from a 1.5 percent jump in June, Statistics Canada said today. The increase left prices up 13 percent over the past 12 months, the largest gain in 30 years.

headline: ISUZU WILL SEND PARTS TO G.M. UNIT
abstract: Isuzu Motor Ltd. of Japan said that it had accepted a request by the General Motors Corporation to supply Isuzumade parts for the ''J'' car to G.M.'s Australian unit, General Motors Holden Ltd., possibly beginning next spring.   Isuzu officials said that the parts would be used for assembly of an undisclosed number of ''J'' cars by General Motors Holden.

headline: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Gauging Bids For Takeover
abstract: SOPHISTICATED valuation methods are in use throughout the investment community these days - methods that often turn up potential takeover candidates.   Such methods employed by E.F. Hutton's capital management division are said to have pinpointed the attractiveness of Conoco 18 months ago.   Peter Hagerman, one of three directors of Hutton Capital Management, explains the several steps involved in the valuations.  He said that Hutton uses 18 financial ratios to establish a ''quality index'' for each of over 600 major companies. Growth is evaluated on the basis of earnings, cash flow and sales gains, while various measures of profitability include return on capital, return on equity and the gross and net profit margins.

headline: BANK SOUTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ART'S WAY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY GROMYKO TO THE U.N.
abstract: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the speech yesterday by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union to the General Assem bly of the United Nations, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:   Following are excerpts from a transcript of the speech yesterday by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union to the General Assembly of the United Nations, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:   Mr. President, distinguished delegates, speaking from this rostrum today, I should like first of all to recall that the United Nations enjoys solid credibility with the peoples of the world as a forum whose principal objective is to serve as an effective instrument for the maintenance of peace.   It is true there are some who now try to contend that there are things more important than peace. However, it is obvious that the peoples have never authorized these leaders to say this on their behalf.   Peace is a priceless asset of all people on earth. It is a decisive prerequisite for progress in any sphere of human endeavor.  This was true in the past and it is all the more true now.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Kuwait Refinery Still Closed
abstract: One of three oil refineries in Kuwait, a Persian Gulf petroleum exporter, remained closed today as firemen fought the last of five oil tank fires that began early Thursday.  The fire broke out at the Kuwait National Petroleum Company, killing one worker.

headline: ALSANDS APPROVES FURTHER SPENDING
abstract: The Alsands consortium said today it would invest a further $20 million in its billion-dollar oil sands project in northeastern Alberta.   J.E. Czaja, president, said the group would commit funds to finish engineering work under way, but not to begin any new work, bringing investment so far to $100 million.   Mr. Czaja said Alsands would monitor the negotiations in the Federal-provincial energy dispute over the pricing of energy resources, and that, ''Should it become apparent that the dispute cannot be resolved in a timely manner, we will have no alternative but to suspend our activities.''

headline: Careers; Professors May Help Find Jobs
abstract: LADY LUCK can help a job hunter; so can employment agencies, advertisements in newspapers and trade magazines, college vocational offices and company interviews on campus.   Then there is the hidden job market - an amorphous group consisting of relatives, friends and acquaintances who can often give the job seeker information about openings or provide a welcome letter of introduction. Referrals can lead to referrals - and success.   In addition, there is a smaller but more powerful group within the hidden job market that can be tapped by smart students, either at college level or in graduate professional schools. This group consists of professors.

headline: Around the world; At Least 10 Indians Die In Hindu-Moslem Melees
abstract: At least 10 people have been killed in Hindu-Moslem clashes this week in Hyderabad, local officials say.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: The bitter takeover battle between the Nu-West Group of Calgary, Alberta, and the Cities Service Company heated up as Nu-West, the target of a Cities Services suit last year, filed a $1 billion (Canadian) counterclaim against the company and its president, Charles J. Waidelich.   Attorneys for the Nu-West Group, a real estate and natural resources concern, filed the lawsuit Monday in United States District Court in Tulsa, Okla., where Cities Service is based, contending that Cities Service and Mr. Waidelich had illegally interfered with stock sales and injured Nu-West's reputation through ''the press, their lawsuit against Nu-West, their letters to Cities Service shareholders and other methods.''

headline: TEXASGULF INQUIRY ASKED
abstract: The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation has asked the Federal Trade Commission to investigate for antitrust violations the proposed $2.8 billion aquisition of Texasgulf Inc. by Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, the French state-controlled oil concern, because the proposed merger could seriously restrict domestic supplies of phosphate fertilizers.   International Minerals is the world's biggest producer of phosphate rock, and an important supplier of fertilizers.

headline: Passwords
abstract: To the Business Editor: The article concerning computer security, ''Case of the Purloined Password'' (July 26), may have been a good piece of investigative reporting about the specific problems of one company, but it came across inaccurately as an indictment against the entire computerservices industry.   The article told how the NCSS subsidiary of Dun & Bradstreet had a serious breach of its security system.

headline: Israeli Coalition Partners Draft Policy Guidelines
abstract: The prospective partners in Israel's new governing coalition today drafted the policy guidelines Prime Minister Menachem Begin is to submit to Parliament when he seeks a vote of confidence for his new government.   The meeting of Parliament was called for Tuesday morning although several hurdles remained to be cleared before the coalition agreement is signed.

headline: MDS HEALTH GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TINY HOMELAND STRAINS A SOUTH AFRICAN POLICY
abstract: Of the 10 tribal states South Africa has established within its borders as its answer to demands for black political rights, the tiny self-governing state of Qwaqwa can be seen as the most extreme example of the determined efforts white bureaucrats have made to force social reality to conform to a political theory.   The theory, once known as ''separate development'' and still part of the guiding doctrine of South Africa, although it is seldom referred to by that name, holds that all of the 21 million blacks must be considered members of different black national states, depending on their ethnic origins.   But the theory ran into difficulties when it was applied to groups whose traditional lands bore no relation to their numbers in the modern state. South Sotho Ethnic Group   This was true, for instance, of the nearly two million South Sothos, the largest black group in the Orange Free State, who are ethnically related to the inhabitants of the internationally recognized state of Lesotho but had nothing that could reasonably be called a homeland within South Africa's borders.

headline: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Vanity Fair's Return Set
abstract: For the last 45 years, the only sign of Vanity Fair magazine, the sophisticated darling of the Roaring Twenties, was the monthly notation on the spine of Vogue that said: ''Vogue (Incorporating Vanity Fair).''   It was the Conde Nast Publications' way of protecting its copyright against the day it might resurrect Vanity Fair.

headline: Patents; Reflectors Help Night Driving
abstract: WASHINGTON JACOB RABINOW of Bethesda, Md., who has been an inventor for 40 years, got his 217th patent this week, on lane markers that reflect light back from car headlights, showing drivers where to steer at night. The little reflectors will be flush with the road surface and so will not hamper snowplows.

headline: FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THRIFT INDUSTRY REGULATORS CITE PERIL
abstract: Richard T. Pratt, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today that 80 percent of the country's 4,700 savings and loan associations are experiencing operating losses and that one-third, with assets of $200 billion, are ''not viable'' under present economic conditions and may not survive.   The disclosure, which was made before a closed session of the President's Commission on Housing last week and repeated today at a Congressional hearing, provided stark, fresh evidence of the toll that high interest rates are taking on the thrift industry.   Savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks, together known as thrift institutions, are the country's principal mortgage lenders. High interest rates, combined with competitive pressures, have forced the institutions to pay more for deposits than they earn on mortgages, many of which were contracted over past years when interest rates were lower.

headline: Failures in England
abstract: A record number of business failures, 2,296, was recorded in England and Wales in the second quarter, Dun and Bradstreet Ltd., a business information service, said today.

headline: POLISH ARCHBISHOP VOWS TO CONTINUE HIS KEY ROLE
abstract: Archbishop Jozef Glemp, offering his first public sermon since he succeeded the late Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski as Primate of Poland, said today that he was confident that the church would continue to mediate confrontations between the state and its citizens.   The Archbishop recalled that the church had intervened in the past in ''conflicts that are human affairs'' with some success, and he offered to help resolve confrontations.   ''These can be solved again by tested methods,'' he said.  The new Primate, a disciple of Cardinal Wyszynski, said at a hilltop mass attended by thousands of pilgrims that, ''Poland is like a boat on a rough sea, tossed up and down and sideways,'' with the sea calmed miraculously by Jesus.

headline: Your Money; Social Concern And Investing
abstract: THE general perception is that the average investor in stocks and bonds thinks along the lines of the old saying, ''Money isn't everything, but it's way ahead of whatever is in second place.''   And if you are not average? What if you feel that making money would be nice, but that expressing social or political concerns is an equally important factor in how you invest? What if it really matters to you that the enterprise using your money offers you some nonfinancial rewards or pleasures as well as the potential for gain?   The short answer is that you have plenty of options but that they may be difficult to locate. Professional investment services are almost exclusively geared to investors whose sole concern is enhancing wealth.

headline: TORONTO EXCHANGE ACTS TO BAR BACHE CANADA
abstract: Bache Halsey Stuart Canada Ltd., one of three foreign-owned securities dealers operating here, has been denied continued membership on the Toronto Stock Exchange, Canada's largest, as a result of the acquisition of its United States parent by the Prudential Insurance Company of America.   The cancellation would effectively force the company out of the securities business in Canada.  Bache Canada, a wholly owned subsidiary of Bache Group Inc. of New York, said the exchange's decision would be appealed at a hearing scheduled for next Tuesday and Wednesday before the Ontario Securities Commission, the overseer of the province's securities industry.

headline: CHILE FAILS TO BLOCK AMERICAN'S ELECTION IN O.A.S. RIGHTS JOB
abstract: The American lawyer who heads the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights has been elected to a second term despite an attack on him and the commission's work by the Chilean Government.   The commission, an arm of the Organization of American States that monitors human rights abuses in Latin America, unanimously re-elected Tom J. Farer as president last week when it opened a two-week session to draft reports on human rights conditions in Bolivia, Colombia and Nicaragua.

headline: POPE'S OPERATION IS CALLED SUCCESSFUL
abstract: Pope John Paul II underwent 45 minutes of surgery today to restore the normal functioning of his intestine, and doctors predicted that he would be able to leave the hospital in about 10 days.   A bulletin issued by the nine doctors who have been treating the head of the Roman Catholic Church since he was shot on May 13 said the ''operation succeeded perfectly and the patient is in good condition.''   Dr. Francesco Crucitti, who headed the team of surgeons that operated on the Pope for nearly six hours on the day of the shooting, performed today's second and final operation. As expected, it presented no major difficulties.

headline: Soviet Grain Sale
abstract: The Agriculture Department reported that private exporters have sold another 400,000 tons of American grain to the Soviet Union.

headline: Day Old Bread
abstract: To the Business Editor: I read the Personal Finance column, ''Reagan's Boon to Retirement Savings'' (Aug. 2), several times to no avail, hoping to find the little niche I fit into with the recent tax benefits. I am a retiree, single, living on a fixed civil service pension.

headline: McLain Takeover
abstract: Fleming Companies said it had reached agreement to acquire the McLain Grocery Company of Massillon, Ohio, in an exchange of stock worth $22.5 million to $24.2 million.

headline: Advertising; Crazy Horse's Campaign
abstract: A four-legged cop, a four-legged clown and a four-legged jogger are one thing, but a four-legged taxi? Well, that's carrying horse costuming a bit far.   But Park Avenue passers-by saw exactly that yesterday in front of Hunter College, as Shaw & Koulermos shot the first television commercial ever for a Russ Togs women's apparel division called - now you'll get the drift -Crazy Horse.   ''We admire clients who have the guts to go along with ideas like this,'' said Martin Shaw, chairman and creative director, as the four oddly garbed horses, carrying handsomely garbed models, slowly advanced uptown toward three movie cameras.   Among the still-camera men who were clicking away were three of the four founders of 20-year-old Crazy Horse, obviously enjoying to the hilt the new role of television advertiser. Ah, show biz.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Amax Inc. raised its estimate for proved and probable tungsten reserves at its Mactung project in Northwest Canada to 13.6 million tons from 7.7 million.   * Brascade Resources Inc., 70 percent owned by Brascan Ltd. and 30 percent owned by Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec, said that its recently expired offer for 10 million Noranda Mines common shares and 1.8 million Noranda common shares had drawn approximately 69.8 million Noranda common shares and 3.2 million preferred.

headline: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY) reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BARGAIN LOANS FROM G.M.
abstract: ALL the big auto makers have resorted to ploys to increase sagging car sales, and among the most imaginative is the one taken by the General Motors Corporation.   Through its financing subsidiary, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the company is offering a bargain loan rate to consumers who buy a new G.M. car, light-duty truck or van. But the offer is about to expire, and the rock-bottom rate of 13.8 percent will only be available to consumers who take delivery of the vehicle by the end of next Wednesday.   The reason for the offer, which was first made on July 28 and then extended on Aug. 31, was to perk up sluggish sales and help clear out the large inventory of unsold cars before the bulk of the 1982 models reach dealer showrooms. The offer is only for the purchase of new 1981 vehicles and 1982 ''J'' cars such as the Chevy Cavalier or Cadillac Cimarron.

headline: Stocks Continue to Retreat
abstract: Stocks continued to give ground yesterday in a session that failed to produce any fireworks on the takeover front - the main source of Wall Street's excitement in recent sessions.   Newmont Mining rose 3 points, to 65 3/4, after advancing 2 1/4 points Monday. The stock, according to recurring rumors in the marketplace, is a possible acquisition candidate. Newmont's convertible preferred jumped 22 1/8 points, to 200.

headline: Japan Cited On Dumping
abstract: The United States is investigating charges that high-powered microwave amplifiers and components from Japan are being ''dumped'' on the United States market, the Commerce Department said today.   Several United States manufacturers have complained that American antidumping laws are being violated because the amplifiers are being sold at prices that are either below production costs or below the prices being charged in Japan.

headline: A.M.C. Sales Incentives
abstract: The American Motors Corporation, encouraged by consumer response to the rebate programs of the Big Three auto makers, said it had begun its own summer clearance sale. The cash incentives range from $100 for some A.M.C. models to $600 for Jeep models sold by Sept. 23 and $100 to $1,000 for Renault 181 models sold by Sept. 30, the company said.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: Tren V. Bui of Portland, Ore., came as a refugee from Vietnam six years ago, and has worked since as a dimensional inspector for an industrial company.

headline: Record Cotton Use Expected
abstract: Worldwide consumption of cotton is expected to set a record of 67.5 million bales this season, the Agriculture Department reported today, with increases forecast in both American and foreign use. Last season's total consumption amounted to 65.9 million bales, the department said.

headline: HAIG APPLAUDS BEGIN AND ARABS FOR CEASE-FIRE Rashidiyeh, Lebanon (p.14)
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. sent messages of ''appreciation and thanks'' today to three of the leaders involved in achieving the cease-fire that ended 16 days of intense shelling along the @Lebanese-Israeli border, State Department officials said.   The Secretary's cables were sent to President Elias Sarkis of Lebanon, Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia. No Message to P.L.O. Chief   The officials said no message was sent to Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, which also agreed to the cease-fire that was announced yesterday. In a 1975 understanding with Israel, the United States agreed not to deal directly with the P.L.O.    With only minor violations of the 24-hour-old cease-fire reported, Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy, left the Middle East today to return to the United States and report to Mr. Reagan and Mr. Haig.

headline: People
abstract: * Maxine Paetro has joined Dancer Fitzgerald Sample as senior vice president, director of creative operations.   * Peter Noto has been named senior vice president at Shaller Rubin Associates.   * Robert P. Linderman has been named senior vice president and creative director at Cabot Advertising, Boston.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Business People; New President Named At Jordache Subsidiary
abstract: Stanley Schwarz, 41, has been named to the new post of president of Jordache Licensee Promotions Ltd. The new unit, a subsidiary of Jordache Jeans Inc., will be responsible for the 32 apparel and accessory licensees of the Jordache label and its horsehead symbol.

headline: WARSAW CUTS THE MONTHLY MEAT RATION BY 20 PERCENT
abstract: The 7.7-pound monthly meat ration for Poles was cut by 20 percent today.   Before sunrise, even before the news had reached all the city, long lines had formed.  There are lines for almost everything in Poland. Lines at kiosks for newspapers in the morning become lines for cigarettes later in the day. There are lines for bread, lines for vodka, lines for plane tickets, linoleum and detergents. Lately, lines for gasoline have meant waits of one to two hours.

headline: Fiat Plans Major Layoffs
abstract: Fiat, Italy's largest private employer, announced it would lay off 70,000 workers for one to two weeks in October because of declining auto exports.

headline: SEISCOM DELTA CHANGE
abstract: Thomas B. Portwood Jr., 56, has been elected president and chief operating officer of Seiscom Delta Inc., a seismic surveying and energy search company. He succeeds D. Gale Reese, 47, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the Houston-based corporation.

headline: WORKSHOP TO BE HELD ON ISSUE ADVERTISING
abstract: "How to make issue advertising work on television" is the topic of a workshop for agency, advertiser, public relations, utility and television professionals to be held Sept. 15 at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in New York.   Issue advertising, the art form that enshrines the advertiser's views on a particular issue - political or economic for the most part, but sometimes social - will be analyzed by John Elliott, known as Jock, Ogilvy and Mather International's board chairman, and other folk.

headline: Retired Trucker to Run Ailing Spector Red Ball
abstract: Emerson W. Swan, 67, who has three decades of experience in the trucking business, abandoned a comfortable retirement yesterday to become chairman of a faltering trucking concern, Spector Red Ball Inc.   ''Well, I've been retired three times now, and it's clear to me that I like to work more than being retired,'' Mr. Swan said in a telephone interview from the trucking company's Dallas headquarters.

headline: ISRAELI JETS DESTROY 5 BRIDGES IN LEBANON
abstract: Israel intensified its air attacks against Palestinian strongholds in southern Lebanon today and destroyed five bridges on guerrilla supply routes.   Ranging over southern Lebanon one day after guerrillas fired dozens of rockets into northern Israel, killing three persons, the Israeli pilots bombed the regional headquarters of Palestinian groups at the southern port city of Sidon and at Damur, 12 miles south of Beirut.   The Israeli military command in Tel Aviv said both guerrilla sites were destroyed.  The Israeli military commander, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan, said the destruction of the bridges across the Zahrani and Litani Rivers marked the beginning of a new phase in attacks against Palestinian guerrillas in Lebanon.

headline: FRENCHMAN SIGNS IRANIAN CAVIAR PACT
abstract: Since 1979, what is arguably the world's finest caviar has been generally unavailable in the Western world. But a former French chef, in something of a gastronomic coup, has concluded a contract with the Iranian Government that could put the delicacy back on gourmet grocery shelves in the next month.   Under terms of the caviar contract, 65 tons of the world's most expensive eggs have arrived in Basel, Switzerland, to be sold to consumers at prices ranging from $210 to $320 a pound in Paris. The prices are comparable to those for the best Russian caviar. Before the 1979 United States boycott of Iranian caviar, it sold at $150 to $260 a pound in New York.

headline: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY PAKISTANI HEROIN IS NOT LIKELY TO HURT CHANCES FOR AID
abstract: Pakistan's role as a source of heroin for international drug trafficking is not likely to become an obstacle in the coming Congressional debates on the resumption of aid to that country, according to Congressional and Administration officials.   In Congress, among drug enforcement officials and in the State Department there seems to be a belief that only through aid programs and the introduction of alternative crops in opium-g@rowing areas of Pakistan can the United States hope to influence the flow of illegal drugs.   Officials and those watching the international drug trade from both within and outside the Administration say the martial law regime of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq has been cooperative in trying to cut back the production of opium and to halt the export of the drug, either as morphine or, increasingly, heroin.   They say the situation is not analogous to that of Bolivia, where the Reagan Administration withheld aid because of the former regime's reported complicity in the illegal cocaine trade.

headline: JAPAN'S CAR SALES UP
abstract: Japan's share of the West German car market rose to 10.2 percent in the first half of 1981 from 9 percent in the first six months of 1980, the federal motor office said today.

headline: New Education Weekly To Start Sept. 8
abstract: Education Week, a weekly newspaper aimed at policymakers in the elementary and secondary education field, will be started Sept. 8 by Editorial Projects in Education, founder of The Chronicle of Higher Education.   The publication, with initial circulation nationwide of 20,000, will carry display and classified advertising.

headline: Around the World; IRAN WIDENS ITS PRESSURE ON BANI-SADR SUPPORTERS
abstract: Iran's campaign against opposition groups supporting the fugitive former President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, was widened today to include his disbanded guard corps.   The Teheran radio said that members of the corps had been ordered to turn in their weapons in five days or face prosecution.

headline: NEW HEROINES: TEEN-AGERS
abstract: These are the names of some of their heroines: Mariah, Lisa, Ellynne.  These are their problems: a first love who is seriously ill (Mariah); an awful fear of not being as beautiful as Rick Brewster's steady girlfriend (Lisa); how to hook Kip, the most gorgeous boy in the world, who already is dating cute, bouncy Merri (Ellynne).   These are the titles: ''P.S. I Love You,'' ''Flowers for Lisa,'' ''Dreams Can Come True.'' For years, paperback publishers have been minting sizable piles of money by grinding out a seemingly endless barrage of gushy, steamy romances for women.

headline: PRICES PAID FOR CROPS FALL 0.7%
abstract: Prices paid to farmers for raw products fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in July from the month before but still averaged 4.4 percent higher than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.   Lower prices for cattle, oranges, wheat, barley and hay led the decline in the price index from June, the department's Crop Reporting Board said. But this decline was partly offset by higher prices for hogs, tobacco, potatoes, broilers and lettuce.   The report also revised earlier estimates to show that overall prices remained unchanged in June. The preliminary figures, issued a month ago, showed a decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent from May.

headline: Iran Says It Bombed Iraqi Hydroelectric Plant
abstract: Iran said today that its jets had knocked out power in large areas of Iraq by bombing a hydroelectric plant in Iraq's Kurdistan region.

headline: NEWSWEEK HEAD TAKES CBS PUBLISHING POST
abstract: Peter A. Derow has resigned as chairman and president of Newsweek Inc. and will replace John S. Suhler as president of the CBS/Publishing group.   The sudden move marked the second time in four years that Mr.  Derow, 41 years old, has left the presidency of Newsweek for a high executive position at CBS Inc. In 1978, the Washington Post Company, Newsweek's parent, was able to lure Mr. Derow back to Newsweek only six months after he left it to become a senior vice president at CBS.    In Washington, Katharine Graham, chairman of the Washington Post Company, announced that Mark Edmiston, 38, an executive vice president and head of domestic business operations for Newsweek, would succeed Mr. Derow as president. Newsweek publishes the weekly news magazine, as well as a new monthly called Inside Sports, and operates video and book divisions. The post of chairman and Mr.  Derow's position on the board of directors of the Washington Post Company were not immediately filled.

headline: PEP BOYS, MANNY MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DURABLE ORDERS SLUMP 2.5%
abstract: New orders for manufacturers' durable goods fell a sharp 2.5 percent in August, the Commerce Department reported toda y. It was the first decline since January and a new signthat the econ omy, already sluggish, was weakening further.   Orders for durable goods - cars, appliances and other big items expected to last three years or more - are considered a good indicator of future industrial production, which makes up about onethird of the United States' gross national product.   The new report, which is preliminary and could be substantially revised later, showed that the seasonally adjusted value of new durable goods orders fell to $87.2 billion in August.   Orders rose 1.3 percent in July, the Commerce Departmant report said, revising that number upward from the nine-tenths of 1 percent originally estimated.

headline: NEW BRITISH PARTY IN ELECTION DEBUT
abstract: ''We were not willing to go on being the fig leaves for policies we believed to be detrimental,'' said Roy Jenkins, his voice rising with unaccustomed passion. ''So we have set out to create a great shift - a geological flux - in British politics. With your help we can imprint the name of Warrington on the history of our country.''   For the urbane and reflective Mr. Jenkins, a Home Secretary and a Chancellor of the Exchequer in Labor Governments, later president of the European Economic Community, it was a crucial moment in a most unfamiliar setting -the final rally of a furious by-election campaign in this gritty industrial borough between Liverpool and Manchester. The election, which takes place tomorrow, is perhaps the most important of its kind in Britain since the war, for it marks the electoral debut of the new Social Democratic Party.

headline: NORTHROP GETTING BIG SWISS ORDER
abstract: In an unusual contract in which the sale of tactical fighter planes is tied to Swiss use of American marketing expertise, Swiss defense officials said today that the Government would buy $335 million of the Northrop Corporation's F-5E Tiger II.   In return, Northrop pledged to obtain $140 million of business for Swiss companies in nondefense activities ranging from aerial photography to interior design to wine presses to X-ray equipment.   In the hotly competitive world aerospace market, companies are resorting to all kinds of different devices to win contracts, and Northrop is among the most original.   Clearly, American companies would prefer simply to sell planes, and governments would prefer simply to buy them. But economic realities have forced new solutions. ''It places the demand on us to be as creative in how we design aircraft sales as how we satisfy a country's requirement,'' said C. Robert Gates, international vice president of Northrop. ''We didn't get to be in as many countries as we are by being conventional.''

headline: C.D. FUTURES MARKET GROWING
abstract: Some call it a three-ring circus; others describe it as three pits. Both refer to trading in new futures contracts for bank certificates of deposit now under way on the New York Futures Exchange, the Chicago Board of Trade and the International Monetary Market.   The inability of bankers, securities dealers and investors to predict interest rates in recent years has created a ready market for financial futures, making it one of the fastest growing areas of the securities business.   High and volatile interest rates have caused more borrowers and lenders to use financial futures, of which contracts on certificates of deposit are the latest entry, to protect themselves from adverse changes of interest rates. Indeed, the rosy outlook for financial futures has attracted competitors to the market.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Citicorp said that an average rate of 17.185 percent was set at the weekly auction of 91-day Citicorp commercial paper, compared with a 17.378 percent rate last week.   * Discovery Oil Ltd. entered into an agreement with the Royal Bank and Trust Co. to effect a general line of credit in the amount of $10 million.

headline: BANK OF VIRGINIA CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FERMENTING BEER SALES
abstract: The nation's brewers entered the busy summer season under a full head of steam. Patrick A. King, a research analyst at the United States Brewers Association, says withdrawals from brewers to wholesalers through May reached an estimated 71.3 million barrels, up 2.1 percent from a year ago.

headline: Bonn's Arab Trade Up
abstract: West Germany's trade with Arab countries rose to 29.8 billion marks, or $12.2 billion, the first half of 1981, up 31.6 percent compared with the first six months of 1980, the Economics Ministry said today. The rise was due to a 28.8 percent increase in West German imports from the region, of which 91 percent was oil, and a 35.7 percent rise in its exports, it said.

headline: Advertising; Weekend Watching Of TV Shows Rises
abstract: More homes are watching weekend television than ever before, according a study by the Television Bureau of Advertising. In the last five years, the study found, weekend viewing in every time period was up by at least 10 percent, with a 27 percent increase in Sunday morning viewing and 21 percent increase in Saturday afternoon.    The study also found that men and working women watch more television on weekends - approximately four hours on the average Saturday or Sunday - than either group watches on weekdays.

headline: DUPONT: TWO STEPS CLOSER
abstract: Du Pont may win the golden apple yet. Its bid for Conoco was conditionally blessed by the Justice Department, and as of late Friday it had received tenders for 56 percent of Conoco's stock.

headline: MOSCOW SAYS MANEUVERS NEAR POLAND ARE NORMAL
abstract: The Soviet Union said today that military maneuvers scheduled to start tomorrow near Poland were routine exercises and that Western statements to the contrary were ''malicious, anti-Soviet rumors.''   A report on preparations for the maneuvers in the Government daily Izvestia did not mention Poland, but it left little doubt that the report was designed to calm Western concern that the exercises, to include the call-up of reservists, represented new pressure on Poland.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. made a new attempt today to convince the public in Western Europe that the Reagan Administration is committed to arms reduction and consultation with its allies.
