Speaking at a news conference here at the end of a three-day trip to Europe, Mr. Haig promised ''complete and total'' discussions concerning any eventual deployment of neutron weapons in alliance countries and said that under ''ideal conditions,'' Soviet-American talks on medium-range nuclear missiles beginning this fall could allow the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to scrap its deployment plans for Pershing 2 and cruise missiles.

headline: Australians Will Investigate Export of Kangaroo as Beef
abstract: The Australian Government announced today that a commission would be set up to look into the meat scandal set off by the discovery last month of horse and kangaroo meat being exported as beef.   The Primary Industry Minister, Peter J. Nixon, said in a speech to Parliament in Canberra that the commission would investigate allegations of malpractice by Government officials and meat substitution in exports from the state of Victoria.   ''The Government is determined to have all the facts of this case brought to light, to stamp out this kind of activity, to prosecute those involved and to insure that all possible measures are taken to prevent such activity from happening again,'' Mr. Nixon said.

headline: Around the World; Italy's New Government Presented to Parliament
abstract: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini presented Italy's 41st Government since World War II to Parliament today, vowing to fight terrorism, improve the economy and work to strengthen Western Europe's alliance with the United States.   He also said he would support the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's decision to build and deploy medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe while negotiating with Moscow on limitations.

headline: MRS. THATCHER SAYS I.R.A. LEADERS ARE TO BLAME FOR DEATHS
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, in a letter to four prominent American politicians, said that the responsibility for further deaths among Irish Republican Army hunger strikers ''rests firmly on the shoulders of those who are ordering these young men to commit suicide.''   At the same time, Humphrey Atkins, the highest-ranking British official in Belfast, said in an interview today that the hungerstrike tactic was losing its impact in the Roman Catholic neighborhoods of Northern Ireland and that I.R.A. ''inflexibility'' was leading to the death fasts in Belfast's Maze Prison.   ''This isn't the British Government being inflexible,'' said Mr.  Atkins, the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, in his office at Stormont Palace. ''It's the Provisional I.R.A. doing everything they bloody well can to get their way.''

headline: Storage Program
abstract: The Storage Technology Corporation, a computer maker, said that it was planning a 10-year, $55 million expansion program that would double its work force and expand its facilities here by 1.4 million square feet. The company said that the four-phase expansion, to be completed in October 1992, would increase its work force from 4,300 to 8,946. The company last month introduced a new system designed to reduce the cost of data storage while increasing the speed at which access can be gained to data.

headline: LONG ROAD, ABRUPT HALT
abstract: An ''insult to the taxpayer'' is what Sue Long calls it.''It'' is a little something included in the House tax package that would exempt the Internal Revenue Service from complying with requests under the Freedom of Information Act to release data used by the agency to choose tax returns for auditing.

headline: Japanese Bond Issue
abstract: The Murata Manufacturing Company, a leading Japanese maker of ceramic condensers, said today that it would issue industrial revenue bonds worth about $6 million in the United States to raise funds for construction of production facilities. A Murata spokesman said that the State of Pennsylvania would issue the bonds on behalf of the company's wholly owned subsidiary, Erie Technology Products Ltd., based in Toronto. Another Japanese company, the Fujitec Company, an elevator maker, is reportedly negotiating with state government authorities in Ohio on the possible issuance of industrial revenue bonds.

headline: A CONFLICT WITH HAIG IS REPORTED
abstract: The resignation of Robert G. Neumann as Ambassador to Saudi Arabia was announced today, amid widespread reports that his action had been forced after a dispute with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.   Secretary Haig told reporters this morning that Mr. Neumann, who had served in his post only two months, ''has resigned for personal reasons and those reasons are for him to describe.'' David R. Gergen, a White House spokesman, said, ''I am informed that I can say he was not fired, and there have not been differences in policy.''   Mr. Neumann himself instructed a secretary to say he did not wish to speak to the press.  However, some friends and some critics of the 65-year-old foreign policy analyst said they believed that Mr. Neumann had been forced to resign after saying to one or more Senators that he believed some statements about Middle East policy made by the Secretary of State on television had been ''unfortunate.''

headline: Currency Markets; DOLLAR OFF AMID SIGNS OF SAGGING ECONOMY; The Associated Press
abstract: The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday following new reports of a weakening United States economy that bolstered hopes that interest rates may retreat from current near-record-high levels.   The price of gold rose to $411.50 a troy ounce in Europe, but wound up the day in New York at $407 an ounce, off $3.50 from Tuesday.  The dollar began the day with gains in Tokyo, rising to 235.60 yen from 233.40 yen Tuesday.  The Commerce Department reported that the gross national product fell at an annual rate of 1.9 percent in the second quarter while inflation as measured by the G.N.P, slipped to 6 percent in the second quarter from 9.8 percent in the first three months of the year.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: With the election of all 1,967 delegates to attend a special Communist Party congress in two weeks, Stanislaw Kania, the party's leader, has strengthened his position, increasing a likelihood that the gathering will reaffirm his policies of moderate change. The election process ended Monday night at a local party conference in Warsaw. Although the majority of the delegates are new and their political leanings are not totally clear, a number of known conservatives and more radical reformers were eliminated.   The middle ground - Mr. Kania's political area - seems to have emerged triumphant. This is the message read by both Polish and Western analysts as they pore over the results of scores of party conferences in the provinces and thousands of earlier elections in the basic cells.

headline: White Youths Rampage In Asian Area of London
abstract: About 200 white youths rampaged through a west London district tonight, clashing with residents of Asian origin and throwing gasoline bombs at policemen.

headline: OPEC REMAINS DIVIDED ON UNIFYING BASE PRICES
abstract: Oil ministers representing the 13 OPEC nations broke up an informal meeting in disagreement tonight over a Saudi Arabian plan for a new range of oil prices that would raise the cost of Saudi Arabian crude but roll back prices charged by several other producers.   The ministers plan to continue the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries tomorrow, after consulting with their governments.   ''The situation is fluid,'' Sobroto, Indonesia's oil minister and chairman of OPEC, told reporters afterward. ''The mountains are higher and the valleys deeper than I expected.''

headline: France Views '81 Economy
abstract: French gross domestic product is expected to rise five-tenths of 1 percent this year after a 1.1 percent increase in 1980, the Economy Ministry said today.   Improvements in the terms of trade and in the economic performance of its main trading partners could raise this French growth rate to a real 3 percent in 1982, the ministry added.

headline: DOW DOWN BY 10.56 ON RATE FEARS
abstract: Stock prices plunged yesterd ay to their lowest level in more than 15 months as investors' apprehension over high interest rates and increasing ma rgin calls continued to unsettle the market.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was off almost 16 points at 3 P.M., recovered some of its earlier losses in the last hour of trading and closed down 10.56 points, at 851.12. The closing was the lowest since the Dow ended at 843.77 on June 3, 1980. The late upswing was attributed mostly to bargain hunting.

headline: REAGAN LETTER TO CONGRESS CHIEFS REAFFIRMS SALE OF AWACS TO SAUDIS
abstract: In a letter to the leaders of both political parties in Congress, President Reagan today restated his intention to press ahead with a proposal to sell Saudi Arabia five aerial surveillance and control aircraft.   Since the Reagan Administration has never shown any signs of wavering from its decision in April to consummate the sale of Airborne Warning and Control System aircraft, known as Awacs, a Republican Senate staff member said he believed that the President's letter was meant primarily to reassure Saudi Arabia and to pass a signal to Israel's supporters in Congress.   Although Congress has never done so, a 1975 law gives it the power to block a major sale of military equipment to another nation by a joint resolution of disapproval.

headline: TUESDAY, AUGUST 11, 1981; The Economy
abstract: The F.A.A. suspended all flights to Europe from six major airports when Canadian controllers refused to handle flights into and out of the United States. A few hours later, after a new route bypassing Canadian air space had been worked out, the suspension was lifted.  (Page A1.) In the interim, however, trans-Atlantic air travel was thrown into confusion, with some flights canceled, others delayed, and still others rerouted or turned back en route. (A1.)   Overall constraints have been imposed on the airlines despite the 1978 deregulation law, industry experts said, as a result of the controllers' strike. They expect the airlines to continue operating fewer flights, dropping unprofitable routes and attracting more passengers to the remaining ones, while making less use of discount fares. (D1.)

headline: Coca-Cola Ends Aqua-Chem Sale
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company said that it has completed the previously announced sale of its Aqua-Chem unit to Societe Lyonnais des Eaux et de l'Eclairage of Paris.

headline: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: China Cuts Oil Price
abstract: China has agreed to cut the price of its exports of crude oil to Japan to $34.90 from $36.50 a barrel, officials of the Japanese Trade and Industry Ministry said today.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Can Company, Greenwich, Conn., has appointed Sal J.  Giudice to the new post of executive vice president-corporate relations.   * Caterpillar Tractor Company, Peoria, Ill., has elected John Nils Hanson as vice president.

headline: BEGIN GETS FORMAL REQUEST TO FORM NEW CABINET
abstract: President Yitzhak Navon announced today that he had decided to call upon Prime Minister Menachem Begin to form the next government of Israel.   The announcement came after two days of consultations between President Navon and the leaders of the 10 parties that won seats in Parliament in the June 30 voting. Mr. Begin said last week that he believed he could form a coalition with a one-seat majority, consisting of his Likud blod and three religious parties.   ''After these consultations,'' President Navon said, ''I arrived at the conclusion that Mr. Menachem Begin has more chances than any other candidate, at present, to form the government. I called the Prime Minister, I told him that and I asked him to see me tomorrow so I will be able to ask him to form this new government.''

headline: U.S. MOVES TO INCREASE COAL SALES
abstract: The Reagan Administration will relax stripmining rules, accelerate the deasing of Federal lands and promote dredging of harbors and rivers as part of a program to stimulate exports of United States coal, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige announced today.   The new policy, Mr. Baldrige said at a news conference, is aimed at removing ''Government impediments'' to increased coal exports in order to stimulate the domestic economy while ''helping the nation's trading partners lessen their dependence on oil supplies.''   He said that environmental regulations had slowed coal exports in the past. ''We intend to speed up that process,'' Mr. Baldrige said.  ''There will still be environmental protection, but we have to shorten the process by which coal mining and transportation is approved.''

headline: 48 INJURED IN ULSTER RIOTING AND BOMB BLASTS
abstract: At least 48 people were wounded today in bombings and rioting in northern Ireland. The violence came as Michael Devine, the 10th nationalist hunger striker to die at the Maze Prison, was buried in Londonderry.   The worst violence occurred in downtown Belfast, where a bomb exploded in a car, injuring 28 people, the police said.  Another bomb exploded outside a store in Bangor, 15 miles east of Belfast, injuring 10 people, including a policeman who tried to clear the area after a warning was telephoned to the authorities.

headline: NUCLEAR READINESS OF U.S. CRITICIZED
abstract: The General Accounting Office said today that the United States lacked the weapons and the communications to carry out the basic nuclear strategy formulated by the Carter Administration and adopted by the Reagan Administration.   In an unusually gloomy report, Congress was urged to require the Secretary of Defense to prepare and submit a plan to overcome those weaknesses when the new military budget is presented in January.   The Defense Department, however, said that it wanted to avoid such a commitment even though it agreed with much of the assessment in the yearlong study. The department said that it would report what progress had been made when the budget is submitted in January.

headline: Gypsum Stake May Be Lifted
abstract: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, a leading producer of lumber, plywood and other forest products, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it plans to increase its stake in the National Gypsum Company of Dallas, a major producer of building materials, to more than 15 percent.   Louisiana-Pacific, based in Portland, Ore., told the S.E.C. that it now holds 1,077,000, or 6.8 percent, of National Gypsum common shares.

headline: EGYPT, ISRAEL AND THE U.S. RESUME TALKS ON SELF-RULE FOR PALESTINIANS
abstract: Egypt, Israel and the United States today resumed talks aimed at finding a feasible plan for self-rule for 1.3 million Palestinian Arabs living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip.   The chief Egyptian and Israeli negotiators, Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali and Interior Minister Yosef Burg, warned against expecting a fast or dramatic breakthrough. The last round of talks broke off 16 months ago after the two sides reached an impasse on the extent of self-rule for the Palestinians.

headline: Japan Cut Cars To West in July
abstract: Japan's auto exports to the United States and Europe fell in July as a result of self-imposed restraints, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

headline: Brother of Key Informer Slain by Red Brigades
abstract: The Red Brigades, in a bid to keep arrested members of their organization from cooperating with the police, today killed the brother of Patrizio Peci, a former terrorist leader who has been an invaluable police informer for the last five months.   A piece of cardboard with the words ''Death to traitors'' was lying on the body of Roberto Peci, Patrizio's younger brother, when policemen found it in an abandoned shack on the southern outskirts of Rome.

headline: INTEREST RATE RISE TRIMS STOCK PRICES
abstract: Rising interest rates, a recurring nemesis of the stock market, sent prices tumbling on Wall Street yesterday and wiped out the entire advance that the Dow Jones industrial average had made in the first half of 1981.   Two major banks, Chase Manhattan and First National of Chicago, raised their prime lending rate by a half point, to 20 1/2 percent, while key rates went up in the money market. That was enough to send the Dow tumbling 8.47 points, to 959.19, marking its seventh straight loss.

headline: FARM EQUIPMENT SALES PITCH
abstract: ''One of the most important buyer incentive programs that we or any other agricultural equipment dealer has ever offered.'' So proclaim the advertisements that International Harvester, the country's second-largest farm equipment maker, has been running recently in farm-oriented publications.   The rest of the ad copy tells of cash rebates ranging from $500 for hay bailers to $7,000 on very large tractors, averaging 10 to 15 percent off the listed price. Or the buyer can get coupons worth up to $10,000 toward the purchase of parts or new machinery.

headline: BRASCAN IN $1.1 BILLION NORANDA ACCORD
abstract: Brascan Ltd., a holding company controlled by Edward and Peter Bronfman, all but won a bitter two-year battle yesterday to increase its stake in Noranda Mines Ltd., the Canadian mining and forest products giant.   Brascade Resources, a partly owned subsidiary of Brascan, will pay $1.1 billion in cash and stock principally to increase its holding to 37.3 percent of Noranda common stock, from its current holding of 21.5 percent. In addition, Brascade will, for the first time, have representation on the board of directors in proportion to its ownership.   The Noranda stock will be acquired in a two-stage deal, the companies announced in a statement. Noranda had been fighting for two years to try to keep Brascan from acquiring a major stake in the company.

headline: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THE WEDDING DAY ROUTE: HISTORY ALL ALONG THE WAY
abstract: The four carriage processions that will carry the royal family on the wedding day will traverse a route laden with history. Three groups of coaches will leave from Buckingham Palace.  The palace, which was built in 1703 by the Duke of Buckingham and bought by King George III in 1762, has been the ruler's home since Queen Victoria's time.

headline: MRS. KIRKPATRICK DEFENDS ARMS FOR PAKISTAN
abstract: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said here tonight that the Reagan Administration did not believe that contemplated arms sales to Pakistan posed any real threat for India. She said India had the ''fourth largest military establishment in the world.''   In an address on American foreign policy at the India International Center before a gathering made up largely of Indian diplomats and professors, she said, ''What India calls rearming of Pakistan in a way that raised tensions, we call helping Pakistan as it confronts the problem of refugees and the Soviet presence on its border.''

headline: FRANC UP ON ACTIONS BY PARIS
abstract: The French franc ros e in value against othermajor currencies today after the French Gover nment imposed new currency measures.   But monetary analysts and foreign-exchange dealers said they expected any improvement to be short-lived.  The French central bank, which last Friday spent $1.5 billion in currency markets to bolster the franc, raised its key short-term lending rate to 20 percent from 17 1/2 percent.

headline: Swiss Lift Bank Rates
abstract: The Swiss National Bank today tightened its grip on banks' liquidity in an anti-inflationary move that strengthened the Swiss franc significantly on currency exchange markets.   The central bank raised the interest rate at which it temporarily provides banks with Swiss francs in exchange for dollars to 7.5 percent from 3 percent.

headline: I.R.A. Asserts Fast Will Continue at Prison
abstract: Supporters of Irish nationalists on hunger strike in Maze Prison said today that the protest would continue despite two recent defections and reports that two of the remaining six protesters would be taken off the fast by their families.   ''The fast will go on,'' said a spokesman for Sinn Fein, the Irish Republican Army's political wing.

headline: Levi Strauss Net Off 11.7%
abstract: Levi Strauss & Company, the world's largest apparel manufacturer, reported yesterday that net income in the third fiscal quarter of 1981 ended Aug. 30 slipped 11.7 percent, to $54.6 million, or $1.32 a share, from $61.8 million, or $1.48 a share, in the three months a year earlier. Sales increased 6.7 percent, to $802.1 million, from $751.9 million.

headline: SOUTH KOREA GRANTS AMNESTY TO 1,000 FELONS AND JUVENILES
abstract: The South Korean Government announced the release today of more than 1,000 prisoners, mostly common criminals and juvenile offenders, in an amnesty to mark the 36th anniversary of Korea's liberation from Japan in 1945.   ''Those who repent and are judged capable of taking part in shaping the new era'' under President Chun Doo Hwan were being progressively released from prison in amnesties, an official statement said.   Those benefiting from this third amnesty in 1981 include 834 prisoners released on parole after sentencing on charges ranging from murder to robbery, 158 juveniles and 72 mainly political offenders, the Government said.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Computer Investor's Group Inc. announced an offer to exchange $57.50 in cash and 40 shares of a new series of its cumulative preferred stock for each $1,000 of its outstanding 5 3/4 percent convertible debentures due 1988.   * Consolidated Oil and Gas Inc. reported that about 1,160,000 of the 1.5 million common shares it had sought had been received at the expiration of its tender offer to exchange 50 shares of common stock for a unit consisting of one Series F, 11 1/2 percent debenture, due 1993, and 60 warrants to purchase common stock at $30 a share.

headline: Textile Imports Up
abstract: The Government said today that imports of textile and apparel products rose 13 percent in May from April.

headline: SAUDI AWACS DEAL PASSES $8 BILLION
abstract: The price of military equipment, including Awacs planes, that Saudi Arabia wants to buy from the United States has risen to $8.5 billion, Administration officials said today.   This is nearly $4 billion more than the rough price estimates Administration officials gave to Congressmen this spring. The increase brings the price of the arms sale, of which President Reagan will formally notify Congress on Monday, considerably closer to the $12 billion the United States paid to import crude oil from Saudi Arabia last year.   The proposed sale, which Congress can veto, is expected to cause a foreign policy debate that could turn into a major challenge to President Reagan. The price of the arms sale gives increased weight to an argument that in part it should be approved because it helps to ''recycle petrodollars.''

headline: GANNETT'S NET UP IN QUARTER
abstract: The Gannett Company, a communications group that owns more than 100 newspapers across the nation, today reported record second-quarter earnings of $46.6 million, or 86 cents a share, compared with $40.5 million, or 75 cents a share, in the 1980 quarter, after an adjustment for a 3-for-2 stock split in January.   The company said operating revenues for the three months ended June 30 climbed $41.5 million, to $349.5 million.

headline: SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Money Funds Add $3.5 Billion
abstract: The assets of the nation's money market funds grew by $3.5 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   It was one of the largest gains registered for a week this year and was part of a movement seeking the higher yields that the funds now offer compared with other investments, such as six-month certificates.

headline: CULBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Chinese Official to Visit U.S.
abstract: Foreign Minister Huang Hua of China will visit the United States in late October for talks with the Reagan Administration expected to focus on Chinese requests to buy American weapons, an Administration official said tonight. On a visit to Peking in June, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. announced an American agreement in principle to permit the sale of arms to China.

headline: Canada Prices Up by 12.8 %
abstract: Canadian consumer prices in June rose 12.8 percent above prices in June 1980, surpassing the previous record increase of 12.6 percent in April, Statistics Canada reported today.   Higher food, housing and transportation costs were largely responsible for the increase, the federal agency said, the latter two largely because of a 4.9 percent price rise in energy-related products.   Food prices, which registered a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent between early April and early May, jumped by 1.8 percent between early May and early June.

headline: SOLIDARITY BRANCHES ACCUSE MOSCOW OF INTERFERENCE
abstract: Solidarity union locals issued resolutions today characterizing last week's warning letter from the Soviet Union as interference in Polish affairs.   In apparent response, Poland's chief negotiator with the union said he did not foresee further talks between the two sides at present and accused the labor movement of transforming itself into a political opposition.   The letter, from the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party, said that anti-Sovietism in Poland was increasing and called on the Warsaw Government to do something about it.

headline: Floods Damage China Crops
abstract: Flooding has wiped out more than two million acres of wheat and soybeans in Manchuria, the New China News Agency said today. About 2,000 people were killed by summer floods throughout China. The United States Embassy said it had donated $25,000 to help flood victims in Sichuan Province, which suffered the largest number of casualties.

headline: HANSON BUYS STAKE IN GULF RESOURCES
abstract: Hanson Trust, a diversified British manufacturer and services supplier, disclosed yesterday that it has purchased 449,500 shares, or 5.04 percent, of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation.   In a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Hanson Holdings Netherlands, a unit of the British company, Hanson said it paid an average of $22.50 a share, or $10.1 million, for its stake. Gulf Resource stock climbed 1/2, to 25 3/4, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

headline: CHARTER'S LOSS WIDER IN PERIOD
abstract: The Charter Company, a broadly diversified oil company based in Jacksonville, Fla., reported yesterday that it had a loss of $27.2 million in the second quarter of 1981, sharply wider than that of $8.7 million in the second quarter of 1980.

headline: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates fell yesterday, but market participants agreed that trading was limited to speculators, with most institutional buyers waiting on the sidelines.   The bond market's rally in the last two days pushed the bellwether 13 7/8 percent Treasury bond due in 2011 from Tuesday's low of 92 18/32 to a high yesterday of 95 1/4 before it closed at 94 12/32 to yield 14.7 percent. Despite that improvement, ''the preponderance of opinion on the Street still seems to be cautious to bearish,'' said Elliott Platt, a credit market analyst at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.   One prominent concern of the marketplace continues to be the possibility that a growing economy and heavy Treasury borrowing will raise interest rates. Another is that rates are already so high they will cause some unpredictable financial calamity.

headline: BROWN-FORMAN DISTILLERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TRITON OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Some years ago Maclean's, a prominent Canadian magazine, ran a contest challenging readers to complete the phrase, ''As Canadian as ...'' The winner was, ''As   Canadian as possible under the circumstances.'' That self-putdown is also an apt description of the energy pricing agreement announced Tuesday night by two of Canada's perpetually feuding forces, the federal Government and the provincial government of Alberta, the country's chief oil producer.   The five-year agreement, which took more than a year of bitter headlines and quieter backroom bargaining to hammer out, was necessary because under Canadian law the federal Government controls the pricing of resources, but the provincial governments control the development and production of resources.   This kind of basic power split - the result of compromises forged toget four highly individual and jealous provinces to merge into one Canada in 1867 - has combined with a host of geographic, economic and political factors to produce a form of institutionalized friction that threatens to make Canada virtually ungovernable and regularly pushes this seemingly sedate nation of 21.1 million people onto the world's front pages.

headline: COMMERCE SOUTHWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNISERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Suits Follow Hyatt Mishap
abstract: Forty-six lawsuits seeking more than $1.2 billion have been filed in the aftermath of the collapse of two walkways last month at Kansas City's Hyatt Regency Hotel.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Condec Corporation is offering a reduced issue of 263,401 new common shares, at $21.75 a share, through a Drexel Burnham Lambert group.   * Linear Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of 1,036,000 common shares, to be sold thorugh an E.F. Hutton group.

headline: COMMERCIAL TRUST CO OF NJ reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JUNE RETAIL SALES UP STRONG 1.2%
abstract: Retail sales rose 1.2 percent, seasonally adjusted, in June after falling for two consecutive months, the Commerce Department reported today.   The June gain was the biggest since January's 2.1 percent. And it was solid evidence that the national economy, though still apparently far from robust, has hardly been brought to the verge of recession by near-record interest rates.

headline: AMERICAN AIR POSTS PROFITS
abstract: Despite a threatened strike by air traffic controllers, American Airlines ended the second quarter this year with net earnings of $27.8 million, or 82 cents a share, a ''dramatic'' improvement over the similar period last year when the company lost more than $30 million, the airline's chairman, Albert Casey, announced today.

headline: ALASKAN OIL EXPORT ISSUE IS REVIVED
abstract: One of the more bitter energy debates of the past decade - whether to allow the export of Alaskan oil to Japan - is again being heard in Congress and the White House.   Proponents contend that exports of Alaskan crude would result in cheaper oil prices for many American consumers who buy petroleum products refined along the Gulf Coast. In place of Alaskan oil, Gulf refiners would receive oil from Mexico, which costs less to transport.   Exports of Alaskan oil to Japan currently are banned under the Export Administration Act of 1979, which addressed possible problems of national security and was designed in part to stimulate the development of the tanker and shipping industries in the United States. Federal law requires that shipments between American ports must be made on United States ships.

headline: E.E.C. Sets Dumping Fee
abstract: The European Community Commission today announced a provisional anti-dumping duty of up to 19.9 percent on imports of the chemical phenol from the United States.   But the commission exempted the Georgia-Pacific Corporation because it was not found to be dumping, and the Dow Chemical Company because it pledged to raise its prices.

headline: SIKH SEPARATISTS HIJACK INDIAN JETLINER TO PAKISTAN
abstract: An Indian Airlines plane carrying 111 passengers and a crew of six was hijacked yesterday by five knife-wielding advocates of a separate Sikh homeland. They forced the pilot to fly to Pakistan, where security forces captured them this morning and freed the 45 hostages remaining aboard unharmed.   According to an official Pakistani announcement, ''Pakistani commandos in a daring attempt at 7:45 this morning overpowered the five hijackers of the Indian Airlines Boeing 737 and secured the release of all the passengers and crew still on board along with the hijacked aircraft. There were no casualties.''

headline: MAXCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PESSIMISM SPEEDS BRITISH STOCK SLIDE
abstract: Fear and pessimism have washed over the London Stock Exchange, causing huge declines in share prices in the last three days and widespread forecasts of still further drops to come.   ''The basic underlying confidence has disappeared,'' said Christopher Poll, a broker with Charles Stanley & Company. ''Nobody knows where this is going to stop.''   An unusual consensus is apparent among brokers and economists over the reasons for the drop: a spreading belief that Britain's days of economic austerity are far from over.

headline: MUIR ENDS BUSINESS TODAY
abstract: John Muir & Company, the controversial Wall Street brokerage firm, is ''ceasing to do business'' this morning.  In an announcement late last night, the company said that it had agreed with the New York Stock Exchange to take the move and had also ''voluntarily consented'' to the appointment of a trustee to wrap up Muir's affairs. An official of the exchange confirmed Muir's statement.

headline: Trial of Seagram Suit to Proceed
abstract: Federal District Judge James Latchum has refused to delay the trial of a lawsuit by the Seagram Company to overturn a Conoco bylaw that limits stock sales to foreign investors to 20 percent of outstanding shares. The trial is scheduled to begin on Monday.

headline: MASSEY TO END ITS REFINANCING
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the Canadian farmequipment manufacturer, said that it would begin Monday to close its $715 million refinancing program, which is designed to pull it from the edge of bankruptcy.   The cornerstone of the program, which involves 250 international loan institutions and government support, is $200 mallion in preferred shares guaranteed by the Federal and Ontario governments.

headline: REFLECTIONS ON KREMLINOLOGY IN THE SHOE BOX ERA
abstract: It may be only a footnote in the world of real estate, but a report that the entire Soviet analysis division of the Central Intelligence Agency was moving from C.I.A.  headquarters up the road about 10 miles to Vienna, Va., stirred a wave of reminiscence in Marion G. Shaw, who formerly headed the agency's Soviet internal policies branch.   She will not comment on the move from headquarters in Langley, Va., which apparently is a purely administrative housekeeping matter.  But she recalled that in the old days at the agency, before the advent ofthe Computer, she and her fellow analysts kep t their srcena about theKremlin officialdom on 3-by-5-inch file cards .  In those days the C.I.A. was housed in wartime barracks buildin gs north of the Lincoln Memorial, near the present day Kennedy Center .

headline: 2 Men Die in Ambushes In the Basque Region
abstract: Unidentified gunmen killed an army lieutenant and a Civil Guard in Spain's northern Basque region today.

headline: Cuban Council Elections Set
abstract: Nominations have been completed for Cuba's municipal council elections on Oct. 11, the newspaper Granma reported today. It said 22,726 candidates, nominated by neighborhood committees, would run for 10,660 seats on the councils, which have wide powers.

headline: Economic Scene; Reagan Goals And Labor
abstract: ORGANIZED labor will take to the streets in Washington tomorrow (called ''Solidarity Day,'' echoing Polish labor's protest, reinforced by a papal encyclical) to oppose what it sees as the antilabor and antisocial policies of the Reagan Administration.   American labor is worried that Reaganomics will spell higher unemployment and lower real wages. Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige and a host of private economists have fed those worries by warning that the economy is weakening. Just two months ago, the official forecast was for the gross national product, adjusted for inflation, to rise by 5.2 percent from the fourth quarter of this year to the fourth quarter of next year. That now looks far too optimistic. Industrial production took a sharp drop in August, and the economy appears to be on the brink of recession.

headline: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Technology; War on Waste With Microbes
abstract: CERTAIN bacteria can reduce an industrialist's hazardous waste nightmare to a manageable pile of sludge and a potentially valuable supply of methane-rich gas. The bacteria, known as anaerobic microbes, live in oxygen-less environments and feed by breaking down organic compounds like formaldehyde and acetic acid.   Unfortunately, harnessing the anaerobic microbe's quirky appetite to the nation's growing waste disposal problems has been extremely difficult. While the microbes can break down and consume a wide range of deadly organic chemicals, they do not take too well to the sudden variations in the mixture that sometimes occur in industrial waste flows.

headline: Canada Bond Rate Up
abstract: The 1981-82 issue of Canada savings bonds will pay 19.5 percent interest in the first year, the highest ever offered, and 10.5 percent for the remaining six years to maturity, the Finance Ministry announced today. The new rates will also apply to all outstanding issues of bonds.

headline: Around the World; I.R.A. MILITANTS DISCOUNT RED CROSS VISIT TO PRISON
abstract: Irish nationalist hunger strikers at Maze Prison near Belfast charged today that a Red Cross mission to the prison was a British ''pawn.'' They reiterated their call for direct negotiations with the British Government as the ''best way'' to find a solution.

headline: LANECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 6
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SLAUGHTER BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SALVADOR CITY IS SHAKEN BY SURPRISE REBEL RAID
abstract: Some of the heaviest fighting in a major city since last January's guerrilla offensive has been going on in the streets of this port city for three days.   A group of guerrillas, arriving by train, attacked a military patrol Saturday evening, according to Lieut. Colonel Ramon Antonio Morales Ruiz, commander of the army unit here. He said that altogether about 200 guerrillas had attacked the city ''by air and by land.'' They were armed with Israeli-made and Belgian-made automatic rifles as well as American-made M-16's, according to the colonel.

headline: Acton to Shift Food Operations
abstract: The Acton Corporation of Acton, Mass., said it would spin off the company's food operations into the Acton Food Corporation by the end of the year, completing a previously announced plan to divide itself into two comp anies.   Acton derives about 90 percent of its sales from food operations, which consist of distribution of food products and processing of meats.

headline: ALASKA AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 31, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
abstract: Meets on Angola's complaint against South Africa - 10 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology for Develop- ment - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad hoc committee on the drafting of an international convention against apartheid in sports - 10:30 A.M.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * CFS Continental Inc., a food services company, has named Donald W. Hansen executive vice president.

headline: STOKELY-VAN CAMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Stop Orders As Hedges
abstract: INVESTORS tempted to snap up bargains in the current disastrous stock market should consider hedging their bets with stop-loss orders. Recent history provides a reason for caution: The market fell harder in 1973 than it has so far this year, but that did not prevent the 1974 collapse.   Specifically, the market had been moving sideways before President Nixon left the White House in August 1974. Many observers thought a strong rally would greet the Presidency of Gerald Ford.

headline: Japan May Aid Refiners
abstract: Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry is studying aid for domestic oil refiners facing difficulties because of slow demand and exchange losses arising from the yen's depreciation against the dollar, ministry officials said today. The moves are expected to include raising the ceiling prices of oil products, continuing a 15 percent curtailment in refining, and purchases of crude oil and products by the Japan National Oil Corporation for a national stockpile, they said.

headline: Japan Cuts Oil Imports
abstract: Japan, with oil storage tanks filled to capacity and domestic demand declining, is cutting its crude oil import target for the 1981-82 financial year by 4.9 percent, to 4.65 million barrels a day, the Ministry for International Trade and Industry said today. The new target compares with 4.89 million barrels daily of crude oil imports in the year ended March 31, and an original goal of 4.98 million for the current year, the ministry said.

headline: Suzuki to Visit Okinawa
abstract: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki will fly to Okinawa tomorrow for a two-day visit, the first by a Japanese chief executive since the island was returned to Japan by the United States in 1972, the Kyodo News Service said today.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Citicorp said an average rate of 18.14 percent was set at the weekly auction of 91-day Citicorp commercial paper, compared with 17.185 percent last week.   * Ohio Edison Co. said its sale of $75 million of first-mortgage bonds had been postponed.

headline: TOYS-R-US CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOUTHERN PACIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RCA Americom Wins U.S. Contract
abstract: RCA Americom Communications Inc.  said it has received a $15.3 million contract from the General Services Administration to provide an additional 608 satellite circuits between six cities for Government communications.   An RCA Americom spokesman said the contract brings to more than 900 the number of circuits the company is installing for the agency. The 24-hour, seven-day circuits are to operate between Washington, San Francisco, Houston, Los Angeles, Denver and Seattle.

headline: IN LIVERPOOL, MANY BLAME THE POLICE, NOT POVERTY CONDITIONS, FOR UNREST
abstract: Eleven days after the burning and rioting began, acrid puffs still drift over the racially mixed Toxteth district. Bulldozers are leveling the rubble of about three dozen shops.   ''Business as Usual'' signs hang on the plywood shields covering the storefronts on Lodge Lane. Yet, strikingly, the prevalent emotion among blacks and whites is pride.   ''We showed them we were not going to put up with police abuse any longer,'' said Peter Bassey, a 32-year-old unemployed black who a week ago tried to explain the community's rage during a meeting with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Mr. Bassey said he does not think he got his point across.

headline: REFINEMET INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Callon's Gas Royalties
abstract: THE Callon Petroleum Company, a corporation that acts as general partner in gas royalty plans, has been offering its limited partners a premium rate of return while building gas reserves for its shareholders.   Callon uses partnership funds to purchase a portion of royalty interests owned by individual landowners who have leased their hydrocarbon rights to drilling companies. In effect, Callon eliminates the risk of total failure for the owners while the partners earn their returns out of the gas discovered on the productive properties.   The incentive for the owner is the $100,000 to $400,000 that Callon Petroleum pays for 10 to 40 percent of the owner's lease, whether gas is discovered or even whether any drilling is done.

headline: PENN CENTRAL SET TO ACQUIRE COLT
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation, a conglomerate with interests in real estate, oil and amusement parks, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Colt Industries Inc. for $100 a share, or a total of $1.4 billion in cash and stock.   ''With Colt, we are intensifying our investments and activities in the manufacturing of industrial equipment and materials,'' said Richard Dicker, chairman of Penn Central.   Before trading was suspended Monday on the New York Stock Exchange at the request of both companies, Penn Central fell 1 3/8 points, to 45 5/8 a share, and Colt rose 1 1/4 points, to 63 1/8 a share, in anticipation of the offer.

headline: NEW CARS COMING GRADUALLY
abstract: New model introduction time is rapidly approaching, the annual autumn ritual during which the automobile companies display their shiny new products, pronounce them the best ever and issue optimistic sales forecasts.   This year, though, is going to be different. The domestic industry, which is in the midst of converting to smaller, more fuel-efficient models, is simply too busy to time the delivery of new lines of cars to coincide with the traditional hoopla. The result is that new cars will be introduced gradually from the end of this month through next spring.

headline: Japan Permits Cartel
abstract: The Japanese Fair Trade Commission authorized 13 Japanese medium- and low-pressure polyethylene producers to form a cartel to hold down production for three months beginning tomorrow, commission officials said today.

headline: AIR FLORIDA SEEKING WESTERN
abstract: Air Florida, the Miami-based airline that has expanded at a rapid rate since deregulation, said yesterday that it intended to seek acquire control of Western Airlines and had already bought 9.9 percent of Western's stock   C. Edward Acker, Air Florida's chairman, said that his company had no intention of merging the two airlines but would, if the acquisition went through, maintain them as separate entities with their existing managements.   The airline said that it was asking permission of the Civil Aeronatics Board to put all purchases of Western stock in a voting trust pending the board's final decision on the acquisition of Western. It simultaneously was asking the C.A.B. for permission to buy up to 50 percent of Western's shares pending that final acquisition ruling.   The announcement said a number of factors, including market conditions, could change Air Florida's intention to go through with the plan. But Mr. Acker said that, at this junction, he hoped that the acquisition could be consummated by the end of the year.

headline: Cigarette Ad Accord Set
abstract: Three cigarette companies have agreed to pay $100,000 each in civil penalties to settle charges that they did not ''clearly and conspiciously'' display the Surgeon General's health warning in all cigarette advertising.   The consent decree, signed yesterday by a Federal District judge in New York City, came six years after the Federal Trade Commission had filed the complaint.   Philip Morris Inc., the Lorillard division of Loews Theatres Inc.  and the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation have agreed to display the warning on all advertisements and on vending machines, according to the F.T.C. In addition, billboard ads will display the warning in larger letters than in the past and in one line across the bottom of the ad, not in a box.

headline: Around the World; FRENCH ASSEMBLY MEETS ON THE SOCIALIST AGENDA
abstract: With the traditional roll of drums, the French National Assembly today opened the first session of the seventh legislature of the Fifth Republic in the Palais Bourbon on the Left Bank.   The first legislature to be dominated by the left in 23 years, the National Assembly is expected to enact some sweeping changes in French life and to do it within months, perhaps weeks.

headline: WATSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DUBLIN IS PRESSURED BY HUNGER STRIKE
abstract: The prisoners' hunger strike in Belfast is putting increasing pressure on the fragile new coalition Government in the Irish Republic.   With 10 of the nationalist prisoners now dead of starvation, and another expected to die within the next few days, the hunger strike is preoccupying the Government of Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald despite the country's pressing economic problems. A knowledgeable official in Dublin had this explanation:   ''Although FitzGerald knows that it must be Britain, not Ireland, that ultimately solves the hunger strike problem, he has to show a degree of militance so as to satisfy the hard-line elements here. But he can't be too militant, or he'll alienate the other side, as well as the British.''

headline: BRAZIL'S CHURCH AND STATE LOCKED IN A FRESH FEUD
abstract: Fourteen months after the visit of Pope John Paul II brought relative peace to relations between the politically active Brazilian church and the country's military-controlled Government, the two sides have fallen into a new angry feud.   Evidence that some church groups have been advising parishioners to support specific opposition parties in coming elections has given Government leaders the opportun ity of invokin g the Pope's own words of warning against the practice during his 12 -day visit to Brazil in July 1980.   Officials are taking church leaders to task for statements in which some bishops said they favored socialism over capitalism and viewed Cuba and Nicaragua as models for Brazil.   They also are charging priests with inciting urban squatters and rural sharecroppers in a number of violent disputes over land. Two French priests have been arrested and face possible deportation in one such incident in which four policemen were shot and wounded.

headline: PEKING IS TESTING 'LABOR DISCIPLINE'
abstract: China is again tinkering with its system of guaranteed job and income security.  For several months, China's leaders have been experimenting quietly in dozens of factories with notions that workers who do not work should be subjected to pay cuts and, if that fails, be dismissed.   These ideas were put forward last week in a front-page article in the Communist Party's official newspaper, People's Daily, which leaders often use to signal policy changes.   The newspaper reported that since April, 30 factories in Shanghai have been experimenting with forms of ''labor discipline'' in which un productive workers receive a range of warni ngs, demerits and pay cuts eventually leading to dismissal. It did not say whether any workers had actually been dismissed.

headline: Around the World; FRENCH COURT APPROVES EXTRADITION OF 3 BASQUES
abstract: A French appeals court today approved the extradition to Spain of three Basque militants.

headline: Toshiba Delays Bond
abstract: The Toshiba Corporation said today that it has decided to postpone issuing a $100 million convertible Eurobond indefinitely because of poor market conditions. Bond market sources in London said Nomura International and Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. had been planning to start the 15-year bond this week with an indicated coupon of between 5 percent and 5 1/4 percent. Also today, Daiwa Europe Ltd. in London said poor market conditions caused it to reduce to $40 million the convertible Eurobond for the Minolta Camera Company Ltd., originally $50 million.

headline: Oil Pipeline Plan Delayed
abstract: The Trans Mountain Pipe Line Company, citing a drop in worldwide petroleum demand, said today that it had shelved indefinitely its plans for an $800 million pipeline project to move Alaskan crude oil to refineries in the United States Middle West and eastern Canada.   Arnold Goulson, vice president, said the company had requested an indefinite postponement of a hearing scheduled for the end of July before the Washington State Energy Site Evaluation Council for a West Coast United States oil port and pipeline.

headline: MONSANTO NET SURGES IN QUARTER
abstract: The Monsanto Company, a diversified chemical producer, reported yesterday that it had sharply higher earnings and sales for the second quarter compared with the same period a year ago. Net income quadrupled, to $93.8 million, or $2.32 a share on a diluted basis, compared with $23.2 million, or 64 cents a share, also on a diluted basis.   At the same time sales rose almost 20 percent, to $1.86 billion, in this year's second quarter, compared with $1.55 billion in the same period a year ago.   The company noted that part of the improvement resulted from the strength of the dollar in relation to some currencies like the British pound, the Belgian franc and the Japanese yen.

headline: PENNCORP FINANCIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AS THE WEDDING DRAWS NEARER, BRITISH ARE AGOG
abstract: Barbara Cartland, the romantic novelist, isn't coming, even though she is the bride's stepgrandmother. She says she doesn't want to distract public attention. The Rev. Ian Paisley, the militant Protestant clergyman and politician, isn't coming because Basil Cardinal Hume is to deliver a prayer. President Reagan isn't coming, partly because of security problems, but his wife is.   Almost everyone else who received one of the 2,500 gold, black and white invitations (beginning with the words ''The Lord Chamberlain is commanded by the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh to invite ...'') will be in their places in St. Paul's Cathedral at 11 A.M. two weeks from tomorrow for the wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer.

headline: BELL, W, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ANATOMY OF A BEAR MARKET
abstract: In the background of a cartoon currently making the rounds is a chart showing the recent market for stocks, with a line plunging down like the slope of Mount Everest. At his desk, a stockbroker is telling a client by telephone: ''Could I call you back. I'm taking a bath.''   So, it seems, are many other investors in stocks. The unrelenting bear market of the last 10 months has pared the value of equities an average of 17 percent and has alarmed Wall Street by its increasing momentum.

headline: SOVIET NUCLEAR EDGE IN EUROPE IS REPORTED TO GROW
abstract: The International Institute for Strategic Studies warned today that the balance of nuclear forces in Europe is continuing to move in favor of the Soviet Union and reiterated its support for North Atlantic Treaty Organization plans for new weapons.    ''Modernization of nuclear forces on the Soviet side is going on across the board'' in Europe, Christopher Bertram, director of the private London research group, said at a news conference.   Otherwise, the institute contended in its annual military assessment that rapid inflation in the cost of defense-related materials was negating much of the effect of rising military budgets in both Communist and non-Communist countries.

headline: SOUTHLAND ROYALTY STUDIES TIE OR SALE
abstract: The Southland Royalty Company, a major independent oil and gas producer and exploration company based in Fort Worth, announced yesterday that it would hold ''exploratory discussions'' with a limited number of companies concerning the sale or possible merger of the company.   Southland said the First Boston Corporation would get in touch with potential buyers or merger partners on its behalf.

headline: Managua Reports Coup Plot
abstract: Leonel Poveda Sediles, an Under Secretary of Commerce, and 11 other people were arrested and accused of plotting to overthrow the Government, the Interior Ministry announced.

headline: STOCKS KEEP SINKING; MONEY SUPPLY GROWS
abstract: STOCKS FOUNDERED as Wall Street continued to express misgivings on President Reagan's economic program.  The Dow Jones industrial average closed Friday at a 15-month low of 861,68,off30.54 points on the week.   THE MONEY SUPPLY increased by $1.5 billion in the latest reporting week, the Federal Reserve said.  The increase could cause continued money tightening by the Fed.

headline: Adverising; Corporate Design Magazine
abstract: SOON after Interior Design magazine began selling on newsstands three years ago, its office began getting back subscription blanks from corporate chief executives. Since the publication was specifically and historically only for the profession, this really perked the interest of Lester Dundes, long-time publisher.   It also led to the decision by Whitney Communications to bring out its 10th publication, Corporate Design, a consumer magazine for corporate decision makers, a six-a-year publication that will bow with the January-February issue.   ''Interior Design shows professionals how it looks and why it looks that way,'' said the 67-year-old Mr. Dundes, who will also be publisher of the new magazine. ''But the businessman wants to know how it works and why it works or doesn't work.''

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: London Port Authority Plans To Shut Last Enclosed Dock
abstract: The Port of London Authority has announced that it will close the last of the enclosed Thames River docks.

headline: O.T.C. MARKET MOVING TO UNIFIED STOCK DATA
abstract: The over-the-counter stock market, that boundless arena where securites of up to 10,000 companies are traded daily by telephone rather than on the floor of an exchange, is making early steps toward combining trading information with the major stock exchanges.  The prospect is already making some securities dealers nervous.   A national market system linking the over-the-counter market with the bigger but slower growing exchanges is probably years away, but for stocks of 50 larger companies in the over-the-counter market, the changes will begin to emerge next February. Starting then, stock quotations for those 50 companies will show the opening, high, low and last price of the day's trades, along with the volume and closing bid and asked prices. Currently, only the volume and closing bid and asked prices are published.

headline: U.S. OFFICIAL, IN NICARAGUA, TIES AID TO POLICY SHIFTS
abstract: In the first high-level talks between the Reagan Administration and Nicaragua's revolutionary Government, the United States has said that any improvement in relations and resumption of economic aid depends upon a change of Nicaragua's policies in Central America.   Thomas O. Enders, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, was reported by diplomats to have told Nicaragua's junta and Sandinist commanders that the main obstacles to an improvement in relations were signs of continuing arms shipments to Salvadoran guerrillas and Nicaragua's own arms buildup, which he said was alarming other Central American nations.   In response, according to Nicaraguan officials, the Managua Government denied that it was supplying weapons to the Salvadoran left and justified its acquisition of new armaments, including some two dozen Soviet-made T-55 tanks, by pointing to increased American arms sales to the army-backed regimes in nearby El Salvador, Honduras and Guatemala. Deterioration in Relations   But despite continuing disagreement on these issues, which have brought a sharp deterioration in relations under the Reagan Administration, United States and Nicaraguan officials said that the talks had been open and frank and that they hoped the dialogue would be maintained.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Kiev in Danish Waters
abstract: The 38,000-ton aircraft carrier Kiev, the biggest vessel in the Soviet Navy, steamed north through Danish waters today, a day after the formal closing of the Soviet maneuvers. The Danish Navy reported that the Kiev was escorted by a missile-carrying frigate. The Kiev, normally stationed in the Black Sea, was amon g the first vessels to join the Soviet Baltic fleet for the nine days of air, land and sea maneuvers.

headline: Advertising; AD BUREAU ANNOUNCES A NEWSPAPER CO-OP
abstract: At the meeting of the International Advertising and Marketing Executives in Toronto yesterday, the Newspaper Advertising Bureau announced the formation of the Newspaper Co-op Network, an innovation that will allow manufacturers to fulfill the ultimate desire of the national newspaper advertiser - one order, one bill.   The program was designed by the bureau, I.N.A.M.E. and the Advertising Checking Bureau. To start with, the program will only be for dealer listing advertising initiated by the manufacturer, and for which the manufacturer is paying 100 percent.

headline: SRI LANKA DECLARES AN EMERGENCY IN ATTEMPT TO HALT ETHNIC RIOTING
abstract: Sri Lanka's President declared a nationwide state of emergency today in an attempt to halt rioting between the two major ethnic groups in the country. At least seven deaths have been reported in the last 10 days.   The state of emergency gives the army and the police sweeping powers, including the right to shoot rioters on sight and to detain suspects without judicial process.

headline: Senate Backs Heat Bill Credit
abstract: The Senate late tonight approved an amendment granting taxpayers up to $200 credit for their 1981 home heating bills.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The fourth meeting since March between President Reagan and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, held in Grand Rapids, Mich., last Thursday, appears t o have done little to dissipate what the American Ambassador here h as called ''a gathering storm'' in United States-Canadian relations.   Six months after the President's first official visit to Canada, the euphoria created by it has largely worn off and the grievances held by one side or the other seem at least as numerous as they were then.   Relations are now ''full of tensions,'' according to Mark MacGuigan, Secretary of State for External Affairs. Both the President and the Prime Minister expressed concern last week about preventing a crisis. Earlier, Paul H. Robinson Jr., the new American Ambassador, told a radio interviewer that the gathering storm can be broken up with efforts by both sides.

headline: Common Market Aides Holding Talks in Britain
abstract: Foreign Ministers of the 10 Common Market countries met today near London for two days of private talks on world political issues, including southern Africa, the Middle East, Poland and Afghanistan.   Officials said the ministers would discuss the tension in southern Africa caused by South Africa's raids into Angola and its effect on prospects for a United Nations independence settlement for South-West Africa, also known as Namibia.

headline: UNION CAMP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: New Campaigns Set For a Cigar and Wine
abstract: The Consolidated Cigar Company, a division of the Gulf and Western Corporation, is huffing and puffing in preparation for what it calls ''the biggest ad campaign in cigar history,'' beginning Sept. 21.  Nadler & Larimer is the agency for the $5 million, 12-month effort on behalf of Consolidated's new Backwoods Smokes.

headline: GARFINCKEL BROOKS BROTHERS, MILLER & RHOAD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: China to Sell Bonds in Japan
abstract: China is going ahead with plans to place its first bonds on the Japanese market and later wants to issue bonds in other currencies to raise money, the director of the China International Trust and Investment Corporation said today.   The director, Jing Shuping, said the corporation was preparing a private placement of $43 million to $65 million of medium-term bonds with a group of Japanese institutions led by Nomura Securities.

headline: Office Computer
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company has introduced a desk-top office computer, the HP 125, with prices starting at $7,500. It said the model combined functions of a personal computer, word processor, computer terminal, financial calculator and graphics work station.  The company broadened its product lines to include general-use office equipment when it introduced its first laser printer last December.

headline: CONTINENTAL COPPER & STEEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Maytag Earnings Rise
abstract: The Maytag Company, the nation's third-largest producer of home laundry equipment, today announced second-quarter earnings of $8.2 million, or 58 cents a share, up from $7.5 million, or 56 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $99.1 million from $79.1 million. The 1981 results included the operations of the Hardwick Stove Company, which Maytag acquired Jan.1.

headline: Chase Cuts Broker Rate
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it had lowered its broker loan rate to 16 1/2 percent from 17 percent, effective immediately. On Wednesday, the Continental Illinois National Bank in Chicago cut its broker rate one percentage point, to 16 percent.  Broker loan rates at major banks now range between 16 percent and 17 1/4 percent.

headline: Japan to Push E.E.C. Goods
abstract: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan directed Government offices today to promote imports from the 10-nation European Economic Community to shrink Japan's lopsided trade surplus with the Common Market, a spokesman at the Prime Minister's office said.   The spokesman said Mr. Suzuki reported to his Cabinet that on his recent trip to Europe he met repeated requests for Japan to import more, and promised leaders there that Japan would cooperate.

headline: Marchenko, a Dissident, Goes on Trial in Soviet
abstract: Anatoly Marchenko, who has spent 15 of his 43 years in prison camps and exile, went on trial today on charges of anti-Soviet agitation, the press agen cy Tass said.   Mr. Marchenko, who in 1969 wrote the book ''My Testimony,'' an account of prison camps, was arrested March 17 at his home in Karabanovo, near Vladimir.

headline: 3 East African Heads of State Call for Regional Cooperation
abstract: The Presidents of Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania, whose relations soured after the collapse of the East African Community, met in Nairobi today and agreed to work for cooperation in the region.   The three leaders, Daniel arap Moi of Kenya, Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania and Milton Obote of Uganda, discussed ways of distributing the assets and liabilities of the community, an economic and customs union that ran railways, harbors and an airline for its members.

headline: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for 12wk to June 13
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Chase Manhattan Corp. and the Chase Manhattan Bank have elected to their boards Donald H. Trautlein, chairman and chief executive officer of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.   * Control Laser Corp., Orlando, Fla., has named Robert D. Van Roijen Jr., chairman, to the additional post of chief executive officer, following the resignation of M. Lee McDaniel.

headline: Soviet Mission Visits Malta
abstract: A four-member Soviet delegation arrived here today to prepare for the opening of an embassy here. A Soviet spokesman said the visitors would look for a suitable building to house the embassy, and would meet with Maltese officials.

headline: DEFENSE STOCKS LEAD MODEST RALLY
abstract: Defense stocks, a former group favorite that ran into heavy profit-taking this year, led a modest rally on Wall Street yesterday.  The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.23 points, to 952.34, extending Thursday's advance of 7.71 points.  Volume increased to 43.5 million shares yesterday, from 41.6 million in the previous session.  For the second straight day, stock prices generally were buoyed by Congressional approval this week of President Reagan's tax-cut package.   The new tax legislation helped one market group specifically: the brokerage stocks. The proposals to reduce the maximum rate on investment income and to lower the qualifying holding period for long-term capital gains are expected to stimulate trading.

headline: VATICAN DISCLOSES $26 MILLION DEFICIT
abstract: The Vatican, in a rare public disclosure of the state of its finances, announced today that the Curia, the government of the Roman Catholic Church, would have a deficit of about $26 million this year.   The official statement today announcing the deficit for the current year and a statement in November 1979 announcing a $20 million deficit that year are described by Vatican experts as the first public disclosures of their kind. No statement was issued for the year 1980. The break with secrecy was ordered in 1979 by Pope John Paul II, who had been in office just over a year.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The war between Iran and Iraq apparently intensified today, with reports from both sides saying the principal action occurred north of the oil-producing province of Khuzistan.

headline: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Volcker Again Backs Policy
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the Fed had no plans to ease its tight monetary and credit policies that some contend have led to near-record interest rates.   Mr. Volcker said in a speech at the National Press Club that the current policy ''offers the best chance of getting interest rates lower, and, what's more important in that connec-tion, is putting them on a downward trend that can be sustained.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Westinghouse Cable Acquisition
abstract: The Westinghouse Broadcasting Company said that it had completed the acquisition of the Teleprompter Corporation, a leading cable television company, for about $650 million.

headline: BRZEZINSKI PRAISES WHITE HOUSE, URGES REAGAN-BREZHNEV MEETING
abstract: The new Administration has shown enough toughness toward the Soviet Union to warrant a meeting between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, according to Zbigniew Brzezinski.   Mr. Brzezinski, national security adviser to President Carter, suggested in an interview today that a ''low-key, consultative meeting would not be harmful.'' The summit meeting, he said, should be ''open-ended on the key issues dividing us.''   Among these issues, Mr. Brzezinski said, are the contest to develop and deploy strategic arms, ''the prejudicial consequences of the southward Soviet push to the Persian Gulf'' and ''the mutual benefits of restraint.'' He indicated that the meeting should not raise unreal expectations and ought to be more of a discussion than an effort to seal agreements.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ESKIMOS WORRIED ABOUT IMPACT OF OIL BOOM
abstract: Leaders of the 20,000 Eskimos in the Canadian Arctic say they are concerned over the impact that major oil development in the next decade will have on what is left of their people's traditional ways of life.   A key issue, according to Eskimo leaders and local government officials, is how the oil and gas industry, now discovering big fields that are expected to go into production in this decade, will affect the Eskimos' staple fish and game resources.   The officials say that young Eskimos are adjusting to modern ways with some difficulty and that older people are finding it much harder to adapt to jobs and handling money.

headline: Briefs
abstract: * American City Bank said it has had discussions with a foreign bank concerning the possible acquisition of American City Bank.   * Carrols Development Corp. said it has sold its Omnifax Computer stores to an undisclosed buyer. Terms were not made public.

headline: EXILE OF LAWYER TIED TO END OF LETELIER CASE
abstract: The dismissal of charges against Chilean security agents for involvement in the assassination of a former diplomat in Washington was due in part to the exile of a lawyer representing the diplomat's family, according to an exiled Chilean.   A United States grand jury had indicted the men for the 1976 murder of Orlando Letelier, and the Justice Department had unsuccessfully sought their extradition.   According to Jaime Barrios, who represents the interests of Chilean exiles at the United Nations, the Chilean Government action in forcing Jaime Castillo Velasco, the lawyer pursuing the investigation on behalf of the Letelier family, into exile last month effectively ended the possibility of showing that the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet may have been involved in the murder.

headline: A DASHING DELIVERY AT $99- AND UP
abstract: If you're a gentleman en route to Africa who suddenly found the need for a tuxedo from home, a bank executive with $50 million of checks sitting unproductively uncleared in Zurich, or a hustling television promoter in Britian trying to keep up the last-minute suspense on ''Who Shot J.R.?'' you have in common World Courier Service Inc.   Spawned by the same forces that nourished Federal Express, Purolator and the DHL Corporation, World Courier is the creation of James R. Berger. The problem was, and is, an increasingly unreliable and expensive mail service plus a growing business need for quick delivery, basically of documents. In 1969, Mr. Berger, then the head of his own grain brokerage firm, recognized the profit potential of a service to specialize in speedy international deliveries.

headline: TEXAS AIR'S TAKEOVER EFFORT SHIFTS TO PACIFIC ISLAND SERVICE
abstract: The bitter struggle over Texas International Airlines' bid to take over Continental Air Lines shifted today to a network of Pacific islands that are now served by Continental.   Continued air services to the American-administered islands of Micronesia has become a key issue in White House deliberations on the takeover, which has already been approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board. The final decision is to be made by President Reagan by Oct.  13.   At issue is the cred ibility of a last-minute five-year commitment by Texas Inte rnational and its parent company, Texas Air Corporation,to equal or s urpass the Continental service to Micronesia.

headline: Aminoil Seeks Sale Of Refinery Stake
abstract: Aminoil, a Houston-based subsidiary of R.J. Reynolds Industries, wants to sell its 15 percent stake in Zimbabwe's only oil refinery, according to a spokesman for the operating consortium.

headline: Du Pont of France
abstract: The E.I. Du Pont de Nemours & Company. said that its Du Pont de Nemours (France) unit has signed a letter of intent with Chargeurs Reunis Group of France to acquire the agrichemicals division of the French company's unit, Societe d'Exploration des Produit pour les Industries Chimiques. Du Pont also signed a second letter of intent with Pricel Inc., the United States unit of Chargeurs Reunis, to sell Du Pont's cellulose sponge business.

headline: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 UP 26.5%
abstract: Spurred by rebates, dealer incentives and interest rate subsidies, automobile sales by the three major domestic manufacturers increased 26.5 percent in the last 10 days of August over the comparable period in 1980.   For the entire month, the increase was 25.4 percent over August 1980, which was one of the slowest selling periods in recent history.  Analysts attributed most of the improvement to the incentives offered by the Big Three since early August. Before the sales figures were released, the Ford Motor Company said it would begin offering $500 rebates on some of its smaller cars and extend to Sept. 23 its dealer incentives on larger cars and its rebates on light trucks.  They had been set to expire on Sept. 13.

headline: WASTE IN THE PENTAGON
abstract: WASHINGTON Cutting $27 billion, or 5 percent, out of the $544 billion military budget planned for fiscal years 1983 and 1984 without slicing into military muscle ought to be easy. But political and bureaucratic obstacles are formidable. As former Defense Secretary Harold Brown once said, ''One man's waste is another man's job.''   There are at least three large contributors to waste in the military budget - the Pentagon and military services; American industry that makes the hardware, and the Congress that votes on military budgets. These are also the most resistant to changes.

headline: Around the World; WHITES BACK SMITH PARTY IN ZIMBABWE BALLOTING
abstract: The Republican Front, the party of former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia, today won the first of two by-elections reserved for whites and considered important for the future of the minority group in black-ruled Zimbabwe.   The Mazoe-Mtoko constituency was reported to have given 784 votes to the Republican Front and 476 to the new pro-Government Democratic Party of Andre Holland, who left the Smith party and ran here on a platform of white cooperation with the administration.

headline: CABLE TV PROVISIONS ACCEPTED
abstract: The cable television industry, using a telephone deregulation bill as its vehicle, succeeded today in convincing a Senate committee to accept proposals restricting the authority of local governments to regulate cable companies.   However, since most American citizens have access to TV signals over the air, the waiver provision would appear to be extremely narrow.

headline: MAGNETIC CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Home Loans Up to 16.95%
abstract: Interest rates on Americans' new home loans rose to another record in July, nearing an average of 17 percent, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.   The 16.95 percent average for fixed-rate, long-term home loans was up 0.13 percentage point from June and was the fifth monthly increase in a row.

headline: LONDON SUNDAY TIMES HALTED IN DISPUTE
abstract: The Sunday Times will not publish this weekend as a result of a new labor dispute that shattered a fragile, sevenmonth-old peace.   Times Newspapers Ltd., purchased in February by Rupert Murdoch, tonight halted all salary payments to Sunday Times staff members after the National Graphical Association, a printers' union, refused to promise not to interfere with production tomorrow.   ''It could have been avoided if we had been given a simple assurance from the N.G.A. that their members would carry out work they were paid to do and not interfere,'' Gerald Long, managing director of the company, said in a telephone interview. ''We had no choice but to suspend publication if we could not produce a paper.''

headline: A.T.& T. DIVIDES TO CONQUER
abstract: MICHAEL JONES had been a Bell telephone salesman for 10 years when the company told him last spring that he would have to prove himself again. Mr. Jones, who requested his real name not be used, was told to write a report and submit other documents showing that he knew how to organize an account, knew the Bell product line, knew the Bell marketing strategies.
