He was given less than a month to prepare the report, on his own time. A special board of crack salesmen was set up to judge his dossier and those of his co-workers.   ''I feel like it was kind of crazy to all of a sudden turn around and justify your existence,'' Mr. Jones said, who left Bell in June and now works for another telecommunications company.   The American Telephone and Telegraph Company does not think it crazy. It is requiring all 6,500 of its account executives to be certified, a test so rigorous that one of the executives in charge estimated that only 15 to 20 percent are passing on the first try.

headline: BARTER BECOMES BIG BUSINESS IN WORLD TRADE
abstract: When Levi Strauss, the world's largest maker of blue jeans, decided to expand its European operations in 1978, it began talks with the Government of Hungary. Hungary wanted to build a blue jeans plant, but did not have enough hard currency to pay for it. The solution: Hungary bought equipment and expertise from Levi Strauss, and Levi Strauss agreed to buy back a share of the production. The company now takes 60 percent of the plant's annual output, about one million pairs a year, which it sells in Europe and Africa.   Levi's barter-like agreement and variations on it, commonly called countertrades, are no longer isolated events. In fact, so many deals have been struck in the past three years that government officials, bankers and industry analysts predict such commerce will account for 20 percent or more of all international trade in the 1980's, which now totals about $3 trillion a year. Some even say that barter has already reached that level.   The companies involved are some of the biggest names - General Motors, General Electric, Pepsico and McDonnell Douglas - and the number and size of the deals are so large that many companies have set up trading subsidiaries to handle the bartering affairs.

headline: Dutch Parties Agree On a New Coalition
abstract: Leaders of three Dutch political parties reached agreement on a new left-of-center coalition Cabinet today after three and a half months of negotiations, a Government spokesman said.   Queen Beatrix will swear in the new Government tomorrow, ending four years of center-right rule in the Netherlands.

headline: RESPONSIBILITY FOR ARMS TALKS DISPUTED BY HAIG AND ROSTOW
abstract: A dispute between the State Department and the Arms Con trol and Disarmament Agency over which organization should have the chief responsibility for arms control negotiations became a public debate today.   For several weeks, aides to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Eugene V. Rostow, the arms control agency director, have been saying that their respective chiefs had the primary responsibility for negotiating with the Soviet Union and that their respective organizations would take the lead.   The State Department issued a statement late yesterday that said, ''The State Department has and will continue to take the lead in this Administration, coordinating policy required to prepare for and support the conduct of arms control negotiations.''

headline: CARTER FINDS CHINESE REASSURED BY REAGAN ON TIES
abstract: After months of ''deviation,'' the Reagan Administration appears to have succeeded in reassuring Peking that it will abide by commitments made when China and the United States established diplomatic relations, former President Jimmy Carter said today.   After three days of talks with China's leaders, Mr. Carter said he found Peking totally commited to deepening Chinese-American relations. He said he was reassured by a succession of prominent United States visitors, including Secretary of State Alexander M.  Haig Jr. in June, that President Reagan intended to adhere to agreements made during the Carter Administration.   The former President flew today to Xian to visit ancient Chin Dynasty ruins, where thousands of clay soldiers and horses are being unearthered around the tomb of Shih Huang-ti, the Chin Emperor who died in 210 B.C. In 1979, when Vice President Mondale visited the site, some Chinese explained that it was an early example of Chinese human rights because the Emperor had ordered the burial of clay statues instead of the live soldiers they represented.

headline: SCHULMAN, A, INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HOP-IN FOOD STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ABKCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN ARMS PLAN SAID TO INCLUDE 100 MX MISSILES AND 50 NEW B-1'S
abstract: Congressional sources reported tonight that President Reagan's new arms program is likely to include deployment of 100 MX mobile missiles in 1,000 silos in the West and the construction of 50 of the new B-1 bombers.   The White House refused to confirm those details, but announced tonight that ''basic decisions'' had been made on the arms program.  A program such as the one described by the Congressional sources would represent a gradual approach to building up a stronger nuclear deterrent. Administration sources say Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Defense, has been recommending this type of approach to the President.

headline: BIG RALLY CALMS TRADERS' EARLY FEARS
abstract: There were cheers, whistles, flying confetti and scattered applause at the closing bell yesterday as brokers on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange celebrated the market's resounding recovery.   ''There's a general consensus down here that they would l ike to prove Joe Gra nville wrong - and they have,'' exclaimed Ross R.  Ritchey, a fl oor broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.   But the day did not begin nearly as mirthfully, as many brokers braced for the worst.  And their fears seemed well founded, as the Dow industrial average dropped more than 15 points in early trading. However, it rallied spectacularly and closed up 18.55.

headline: Canadian Bond Sale
abstract: The Finance Department said today that it was issuing $500 million of new government bonds with maturities of two and five years. The issue is dated Oct. 15, 1981, and will be made up of notes due Oct. 15, 1983, paying 18 3/4 percent, and bonds due Oct. 1, 1986, paying 18 percent. The five-year bonds are extendable, at the holders' option, up to June 30, 1986, into bonds of an equal par value due Oct 1, 1991, paying 18 percent.

headline: U.S. REPORTS SHOOTING DOWN 2 LIBYA JETS THAT ATTACKED F-14'S OVER MEDITERRANE
abstract: The United States said today that two Navy F-14 jets shot down two Soviet-built Libyan SU-22's about 60 miles from the Libyan coast after being fired on by one of the Libyan aircraft.   The brief battle occurred in the final hours of a two-day United States Navy Transcript of Weinberger's remarks and text of U.S. protest, page A8. exercise in the southern Mediterranean and the northern part of the Gulf of Sidra, the United States said. It said the two Libyan fighters were downed by Sidewinder missiles fired by the F-14's in a one-minute dogfight over the Gulf, a broad body of water that Libya claims as part of its territorial waters but that the United States regards as international waters.   Pentagon officials said the American planes returned to the carrier Nimitz safely. A Pentagon official said that the two Libyan pilots were seen parachuting but that one of the chutes was believed to be in flames.

headline: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Petro-Lewis Gains
abstract: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, an oil and gas exploration company based in Denver, reported yesterday that net income in its fourth fiscal quarter, ended June 30, rose 31.8 percent, to $8.7 million, or 38 cents a share, from $6.6 million, or 30 cents a share, a year before. Revenues climbed 40.7 percent, to $48.4 million, from $34.4 million.

headline: ISLAMIC PARTY IS SAID TO BACK CLERGYMAN IN IRAN'S ELECTIONS
abstract: Iran's dominant Islamic Republican Party has reportedly endorsed the clergyman that leads it as its candidate for the presidency in next month's elections.   Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini had previously barred the clergy from running for President, but the party newspaper, Engelhab Islami, reported today that Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, the party's secretary general, had been chosen as its candidate in the elections of Oct. 2. This appeared to suggest that the action was taken with the tacit approval of the revolutionary leader.

headline: SHE CHARMS WITH AN EASY GRACE
abstract: When Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer posed for their engagement photograph on the steps of Buckingham Palace, she stood one step lower to make the Prince appear taller.   From her marriage today onward, Diana, now Her Royal Highness, the Princess of Wales, will permanently occupy a lower step, walking respectfully one pace behind her husband, the future King of England. In public, she will address him not as Charles but as ''Sir.''   At the age of 20 she has renounced forever spontaneity and privacy, freedom and independence, her red Mini Metro and her Chelsea apartment, past friendships and future intimacies other than those deemed appropriate for royal confidences. She looks forward to a lifetime of extreme wealth and luxury, with castles, yachts and private jets wherever she travels. She will have a minimum of one private secretary, four ladies-in-waiting, a large nursery staff when the time comes, security men, maids, valets, gardeners and a fleet of servants.

headline: Montreal Shuttle Off
abstract: Eastern Airlines yesterday announced a temporary postponement of a Montreal-New York air shuttle service that had been scheduled to start Aug. 31, citing the air controllers' strike. No new starting date was announced. Russell L. Ray, the airline's senior vice president of marketing, said that ''we must defer the start of this service pending resumption of a level of airline operations akin to that prior to the controller strike.''

headline: I.M.F. Finds Inflation Easing
abstract: The spurt of inflation that marked the world economy in 1979 and 1980 seems to be easing, but high interest rates and slower growth are causing increased unemployment and uncertainty, the International Monetary Fund said today in its annual report.   High rates are creating particular problems for poorer countries already under financial pressure from deteriorating trade positions, weak export markets and slowed growth of international relief, it said.

headline: Mitchel, Schreiber Has New President
abstract: In the world of Wall Street, there are firms that deal only with other professionals on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. One of the largest of these firms is Mitchel, Schreiber, Watts & Company.

headline: People
abstract: * Dr. Bruce Granovetter has been named senior vice president and medical director of Sudler & Hennessey, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam.   * Alan Hirsch named president of Gross & Associates, public relations.

headline: HAMMERMILL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Briefs; BRIEFS
abstract: * Dibrell Brothers Inc., a supplier and exporter of tobacco, said that it would acquire the principal assets of B.V. Tabak Export and Import Compagnie of Amsterdam for about $25 million. Tabak is an international tobacco merchant with processing and exporting operations in Brazil and Zimbabwe.   * G.D. Searle & Co. said that it was negotiating the sale of additional hospital products units, several distribution and manufacturing units in Europe and Canada and certain new product ventures. The company earlier reported a $32.5 million loss provision in the second quarter on the sale of its hospital products businesses.

headline: Business People; Division Chief Quits Associated Dry Goods
abstract: John C. Seiler, 46, son of the late Lewis P. Seiler, a longtime head of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, has resigned as chairman and chief executive officer of Stewart's, which is Associated's department store division in Louisville, Ky., effective Dec. 31. No one has been named yet to succeed him, but Robert A.  McConnell, 40, who joined Stewart's last October as president, continues in that post.   Associated operates 15 department store divisions throughout the United States, including Lord & Taylor in New York, the Caldor discount stores and the Sycamore specialty stores. Lewis Seiler, who died this year, was chief executive officer of Associated, first as president and then as chairman, from 1963 until his retirement in 1976.

headline: Emery Spending
abstract: The Emery Air Freight Corporation, a major forwarding operator, said it would add $32 million to a previously announced $63 million aircraft equipment program. The company said it would purchase an additional seven Boeing 727-100's from the Boeing Equipment Holding Company, raising to 19 the number of aircraft it has acquired this year.

headline: EUROPEANS IN PACT ON SOVIET GAS
abstract: A joint venture of West German and French companies yesterday signed the first contracts to supply compressor stations for a gas pipeline in the Soviet Union, in what is expected to be the biggest East-West trade deal ever, it was disclosed today.   A spokesman for Mannesmann, the German steel company, said today that representatives of a joint venture of Mannesmann Anlagenbau, which specializes in plant construction, and Creusot-Loire, the French steel company, had signed contracts in Dusseldorf yesterday to deliver and install 22 gas compressor stations on a pipeline that is to ship Soviet gas from Siberia to Western Europe, beginning in the mid-1980's. The spokesman, Klaus Germann, said the contracts were worth the equivalent of $956.5 million.

headline: MOSCOW DISCOUNTS AFGHANISTAN PLAN
abstract: The Soviet Union today gave a chilly reception to a Western European peace plan for Afghanistan, which was carried here by the British Foreign Secretary.   Lord Carrington, the British minister, acting on behalf of the 10 nations in the European Economic Community, said after discussions with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko that the 24-hour visit was worthwhile because the Soviet Union had not rejected the plan outright. However, by Lord Carrington's account, Mr. Gromyko gave no sign that Soviet thinking had changed to the point that a settlement was in sight.   ''The Soviet Union did not accept the proposal, but they did not say that they rejected it,'' Lord Carrington said at a news conference in the British Embassy. ''What they did say was that the plan was unrealistic in its present form, although I must say I found the arguments they advanced unconvincing.''

headline: France Car Registration
abstract: New car registrations in France fell 20.4 percent in August, to 105,040 from 132,020 in July, but were slightly higher than the 103,560 registrations in August last year, the French car makers assoc iation said. Registrations for the first eight months of 1981 totaled 1.21 million, down 4.7 percent from the similar perio d in 1980, the group said Friday.

headline: BLAST HURTS 20 AT U.S. BASE IN GERMANY
abstract: A powerful explosion went off today at the European headquarters of the United States Air Force in Ramstein, West Germany, injuring 20 people including an American general.   The office of the West German Federal Prosecutor, which was conducting an investigation, was looking into the possibility that the explosion was the result of a bomb, possibly planted by leftist terrorists.   ''We are calling this an explosion of undetermined origin,'' an Air Force spokesman, Maj. Tracy McCollister, said. ''We have not been told by the West German Government experts that the blast was caused by a bomb. We are not using that terminology.''

headline: SOUTH KOREA BUYS COAL
abstract: The Sun Eel Shipping Company of South Korea has agreed to buy more than 7 million metric tons of coal from the Usibelli coal mine over the next decade, a Usibelli spokesman said today. The value of the accord was not disclosed.

headline: AILING HOTEL REFLECTS TOGO'S ECONOMIC PLIGHT
abstract: Approaching Lome by road across themarshy plains of neighboring Ghana, the 30-story Second of February Hotel and Con ference Center suddenly appears on the horizon.   With its 52 presidential suites, an equal number of ministerial apartments, several restaurants and a 200-seat theater, it is one of the most luxurious hotels in West Africa.   It is also the linchpin in the Government's plan to make this small country a major center of tourism and international conference trade.  Weekend tourists from the economic and social turmoil of Togo's neighbors, Ghana and Nigeria, flock to Lome as an oasis in a troubled region.

headline: PRIVATE OTTAWA TALKS AS ISSUE
abstract: The seven heads of government who are to meet at the Ottawa economic summit conference next week have been asked by President Reagan to limit private meetings among themselves and to devote more time to meetings in which they are joined by their aides, Administration officials said today.   The officials said that they understood that the request, which they said was also made independently by the leaders of Japan and Italy, had been granted. As it now stands, they said, the only time the participating leaders plan to meet in private sessions will be at dinner Sunday night, the evening they arrive.

headline: JAPAN AGREES TO LET ARAFAT VISIT NEXT MONTH
abstract: The Japanese Government has agreed to allow Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to visit the country next month.   Tamio Amau, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, said this week that Mr. Arafat was expected to meet with Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki and with Foreign Minister Sunao Sonoda.   ''It seems to be quite likely he's coming here sometime in October,'' he said. But Mr. Amau said Mr. Arafat would come to Japan at the invitation of a group of members of Parliament headed by former Foreign Minister Toshio Kimura, and not as a guest of the Japanese Government.

headline: Other Business; ...AND PERRIER ASIDE, THEY CALL IT SODA
abstract: That old work horse of the neighborhood barroom, Canada Dry, has declared war on that sprightly thoroughbred of the cafe set, Perrier. In what some are calling the Great Sparkling Water Battle, the competition has become positively effervescent.   ''The first shall not always be first,'' said Nina Mosely, brand manager of Canada Dry's club soda division, pointing to her company's 30 percent gain in sparkling water sales last year. Canada Dry is owned by Norton Simon Inc.

headline: U.S. AIDE SEES BREAKTHROUGH ON NAMIBIA PLAN
abstract: Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, told a House subcommittee today that the Administration had suceeded, through continuing talks with South Africa, in reviving a ''dead'' initiative on independence for South-West Africa. He said there was now hope for a breakthrough by early next year.   Echoing remarks made by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  in an interview this month, Mr. Crocker said that South Africa was prepared to accept unconditionally a 1978 resolution of the United Nations Security Council proposing a framework for independence for the territory, which is also known as Namibia.

headline: COOK UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AMETEK'S RESEARCH INTO SOLAR ENERGY BEGINS TO PAY OFF
abstract: On the table was a portable nine-volt radio, about the size of a thick novel. It had no batteries or electric plugs to run it, only a thin film photovoltaic cell. When a cover was lifted, exposing the cell to the light in the room, the radio began to play.   Though it may appear to be a parlor trick, the conversion of light into energy has become serious business at Ametek Inc., a diversified manufacturer that is now developing solar collector panels and photovoltaic cells.

headline: BRITONS BRISTLE AT BBC'S PLANNED BUDGET CUTS
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's economic policies have inflamed passions across the land, but rarely has so much heat, drama and political intrigue been generated over so little money as in the case of a proposed cutback involving the British Broadcasting Corporation.   The issue is over whether the BBC's foreign-language broadcasts, a source of information for 70 million people, should be severely retrenched so a relatively modest $5.6 million could be contributed toward a capital refurbishment for the division, which is officially known as external services.   Late last month, Mrs. Thatcher lost a dramatic vote in the House of Lords on the cut, even after her Government went to unusual lengths to marshal support. The vote was 82 to 45.

headline: SAVINGS ADS CALLED MISLEADING
abstract: The New York City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs yesterday charged that some New York savings banks have used ''misleading'' advertisements to sell new savings certificates that will not be available to the consumer until October.   ''We believe that the recent rash of bank ads only serves to deceive and befuddle the consumer,'' Bruce Ratner, the city commissioner said.   The savings certificates are expected to bring $250 billion in deposits to financial institutions nationwide.  And to attract depositors early, some savings banks have started running ads for repurchase agreements that promise annual interest rates ranging from 20 percent to 35 percent between now and Oct. 1.

headline: FULLER, H B, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Qaddafi Warns the U.S.  On New Aerial Incursion
abstract: Col. Muammar al-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, today threatened to attack American nuclear depots in Europe if the United States again entered the Gulf of Sidra.   In a speech marking the overthrow of the monarchy in 1969, he said Libya should end its self-proclaimed neutrality and align itself with Moscow.

headline: U.S. TRADE SURPUS OFF FOR 2D QUARTER
abstract: The nation's current account - the broadest measure of financial dealings with the rest of the world - showed a $1.1 billion surplus in the second quarter of this year, down about two-thirds from the first quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.   The balance of payments should show little change the rest of the year, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said in a statement accompanying the report.   But he also said that ''a shift into a substantial deficit is likely during 1982, due to increased imports and slower export growth.''

headline: DATA PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PAULEY PETEROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Steel Outlook Called Worse
abstract: Steelmakers who earlier hoped for a strong finish in 1981 are revising their outlook as the traditional late-summer slump shows signs of lingering.   ''The picture doesn't look particularly promising,'' Joseph Wyman, an industry analyst with Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc. in New York, said today.

headline: Mitterrand's Saudi Visit Set
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand will visit Saudi Arabia September 26-28, a presidential spokesman said today. The spokesman said last month the visit would take place at the end of September but the dates had not been set.

headline: HAIG MAY ABOLISH RIGHTS JOB
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. may decide to eliminate the job of chief of the bureau for human rights, a spokesman said today.   The Reagan Administration's nominee for the vacant post, Ernest Lefever, was rejected by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the nomination was withdrawn when it became apparent last month that it would not be approved by the full Senate.

headline: TEXAS AIR ALLOWED 67% OF CONTINENTAL
abstract: The Civil Aeronautics Board today gave Texas International Airlines another boost in its nine-month effort to gain control of Continental Air Lines, ruling that the Houstonbased carrier could acquire up to 67 percent of Continental's shares outstanding.   Texas International now owns 48.5 percent of the larger Los Angeles-based carrier, but its stock remains in a holding trust that prohibits it from taking control of the airline.

headline: Japan Vehicle Output Off
abstract: Japanese vehicle production fell sharply last month from July, mainly because of a decline in exports, the Japanese Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. August prod uction of 689,200 vehicles was down 33.5 percent from July, when mo nthly production was the second largest on record, and just over 3 p ercent less than a year earlier, the association said.

headline: CONTINENTAL NAMES NEW CHIEF
abstract: George A. Warde, who joined Continental Air Lines less than two weeks ago as president and chief operating officer, was named to the added job of chief executive today at a somber meeting of the company's board. He succeeds Alvin L. Feldman, who was found dead Sunday in his office, an apparent suicide.   Robert F. Six, who had handpicked Mr. Feldman as his successor, was named to Mr. Feldman's position as chairman of the executive committee, signaling that the 74-year-old founder of Continental will be keeping a watchful eye on the transition to the management of Mr. Warde, a former president of Eastern Airlines who started as a mechanic and rose to top positions in the airline industry and in aircraft manufacturing.   Mr. Warde said that the board, at its meeting today, held out little hope for the success of an employee stock ownership plan designed to give Continental's employees control of the airline as a means of averting a takeover of the carrier by Texas International Airline.

headline: VIRGINIA ELECTRIC & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Total Solar Eclipse Darkens Part of Soviet
abstract: A total solar eclipse darkened a 4,300-milelong swath of the southern and eastern Soviet Union today and yielded extensive data about the sun's influence on the weather, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.   Scientists said this eclipse was particularly interesting because it occurred during a period of heavy sunspot activity, which occurs every 11 years.

headline: Cholera Kills 10 in Indonesia
abstract: Ten people were killed and 40 were hospitalized in a cholera outbreak in the northern city of Banda on Sumatra island, the domestic news agency Antara said today.  It said dozens more were feared dead from cholera in several nearby villages.

headline: CITINATIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRUST reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FROM 300 B.C., A STARTLING CONCEPT IN CAMERAS
abstract: In 300 B.C., Euclid blinked one eye and noticed the obvious: An image seen by one eye is slightly different from the image seen by the other. Since then, people have been interested in, even obsessed with, reproducing the three-dimensional impression obtained when the brain combines two views of an object.   In the early 1950's, interest in 3D reached its height and the craze that swept Hollywood led to about 100 movies, including ''Inferno,'' ''Creature From the Black Lagoon,'' and ''It Came from Outer Space.'' Audiences wore awkward 3D glasses and were cinematically bombarded by bats, breasts, gorillas, guns, torches, knives and scalpels. When the craze fizzled, 3D faced ignominy - until now.

headline: POST-CONOCO GUESSING GAME
abstract: The current takeover favorite is Cities Service. Its shares surged 2 1/2 points on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. But the Marathon Oil Company, with that big West Texas oil field, looks awfully enticing. And how about Union Oil of California, which is swollen with natural gas? It's probably too big to swallow, but who knows? After Conoco, anything is possible.   Du Pont's $7.57 billion takeover of Conoco Inc., the nation's ninth-largest oil company, has prompted speculation that other large oil companies might also be takeover targets. Almost everyone on Wall Street, it seems, is guessing what will be next, and stock prices are rising on the speculation, which encompasses Kerr-McGee, Superior Oil, Pennzoil, Getty and Louisiana Land and Exploration?   ''It has been the biggest game in town,'' said Robert C. LeVine, an analyst at E.F. Hutton. ''It's been the only game in town. We didn't even have baseball this summer, so we used this as the national pastime.''

headline: Nations' Credit Ratings
abstract: The United States and Japan are still good credit risks, but the creditworthiness of many other nations has slipped during the last six months, according to Institutional Investor, a magazine that rates countries for international bankers.   In its latest study, released yesterday, the New York-based periodical surveyed 100 international banks, asking them to rate each nation's creditworthiness on a scale of 0 to 100. At the top of the list was the United States, with a rating of 98.3, up one-tenth of a point from last March. At the bottom was Uganda, with a rating of 5, down 1.3 points from March.

headline: Sohio Participates In Energy Study
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said it was joining the Hampshire Energy Project, a study to determine the commercial and economic viability of converting 15,000 short tons of coal daily to 800,000 gallons of unleaded gasoline and byproducts such as mixed butanes.

headline: GREEK WOMEN GAIN IN ELECTION ROLE
abstract: Greece's women, statistically shown to be more socially and economically discriminated against than their counterparts in any other Western country, have mobilized to an extent that will make them a determining factor in next month's general elections.   Awareness of their enhanced political role has led the parties to respond to demands by the National Council of Women for the inclusion of a far larger number of women than usual as candidates in the elections. And the wives of Prime Minister George Rallis and of the Socialist opposition leader, Andreas Papandreou, are campaigning throughout the country in a bid for the female vote, which accounts for 50.5 percent of the seven million elgible voters.   About 250 female candidates, or more than 10 percent of the total, are running this time, compared with 103 in the last general election, in 1977, and 16 in 1958. Most will represent left-wing parties, reflecting the feminist complaint that their underprivileged position stems at least partly from rightist government.

headline: THE QUIET REPEAL OF THE CORPORATE INCOME TAX
abstract: WASHINGTON CORPORATE income taxes may soon be a relic, the lingering remnant of a once mighty revenue flow. President Reagan has won for business the largest tax reductions in memory, and as prodigious as they are, they are also a kind of culmination of a quieter trend, a decades-old ebbing of income taxes on business corporations. By the close of this decade, economists and tax specialists say, taxes on the profits of big business will have faded to a trickle.   The plain fact is in the numbers. Thirty years ago, Uncle Sam drew one tax dollar in four by taxing business profits; today it is one in 10 and still falling. And by realistic measures, the rate at which business is taxed has dropped by 50 percent since Harry Truman's day.

headline: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Independent Druggests' Aid
abstract: In order to combat the inroads of the large drugstore chains, which do not use their services, a number of drug wholesalers have come up with another way of helping the independent druggests, who do, by instituting a franchising concept called FamilyCare Drug Centers.   It will include programs in marketing, merchandising and buying and will be have headquarters in Dallas.

headline: POLLUTION CURBS' IMPACT ON THE ECONOMY CITED
abstract: Federal antipollution programs are adding four-tenths of a percentage point a year to the Consumer Price Index, according to a study released today by the Environmental Protection Agency.   The study, prepared by Data Resources Inc. for the agency, also shows that the spending required of industry for meeting the requirements of the clean air and water acts and other environmental laws has also stimulated employment and business investment. Data Resources is a Lexington, Mass., economic consulting firm. Serious Capital Shortfall   Meanwhile, the steel industry reported today that it would be able to clean up 96 percent of its air pollution and 98 percent of its water pollution in the next several years but that additional cleanup requirements would impose a serious capital shortfall on the industry.

headline: THRIFT UNIT TROUBLES INCREASE
abstract: At least 100 more savings and loan institutions have been added to the list of most troubled thrift institutions, which had totaled 263 at the end of May, the head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.   Meanwhile, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board told Congress that ''it would be very imprudent'' for ailing S.&L.'s to count on near-record interest rates coming down significantly in the near future to alleviate their problems.   Paul A. Volcker, head of the Federal Reserve, the nation's central bank, told the Joint Economic Committee that a rapid drop in interest rates over the next few months ''is unlikely.''

headline: U.S. Envoy Will Support More Arms to Salvador
abstract: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador said today that he will recommend, at the request of the Salvadorans, that the United States provide more arms aid after the first group of American military advisers goes home in August.

headline: The Economy
abstract: President Reagan appealed in a television address for support of his tax reduction program and accused the Democratic Congressional leadership of ''political fun and games.'' (Page A1.) Democratic leaders denounced his plan as geared to the ''wealthy of America'' and predicted victory for their own bill on the House floor. Some liberal Democrats, however, object to provisions in both bills to give tax benefits to the oil industry and commodity traders. (A1.) Text of Mr. Reagan's message. (B6.) Text of Democrats' responses.  (B7.)   House and Senate conferees reached a tentative agreement on using block grants to consolidate financing for several health care programs. The absence of an agreement on the health issue had been seen as one of the major stumbling blocks to a final accord on a $37 billion package of budget cuts. (B7.)

headline: Advertising; 2 at Bozell & Jacobs Set Out on Their Own
abstract: Kathleen Kavanagh and Joseph Genova, the co-creative directors of the New York office of Bozell & Jacobs, have quit after a year and a half, according to Miss Kavanagh, the writing half, ''to try our own wings.''

headline: NUMEX CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Allied Subsidiary's Garfinckel Stake
abstract: The Allied Stores Corporation said that its subsidiary, ASC Stores Inc., had received a total of 2,961,291 common shares of Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc. through its recently expired tender offer.   Allied, which last month announced its tender offer for Garfinckel's, also said that it had amended its agreement with the Wickes Companies of San Diego and had purchased 927,175 Garfinckel shares from Gamble-Skogmo, a Wickes subsidiary, for $50.50 a share.

headline: Finance Briefs
abstract: * Ask Computer Systems Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 1.35 million common shares, to be sold through an L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin group.   * Canadian National Railway Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell $100 million of 25-year sinking fund debentures, to be sold through a Salomon Brothers group.

headline: House Backs Tax Bill, 282-95
abstract: The House of Representatives approved the Administration's tax-relief bill today by a 3-to-1 margin and sent it to President Reagan for his signature after repelling an attempt by Northern Democrats to reopen consideration of the bill.   White House officials said that the President would sign the bill in Washington on Thursday or later in the month in California, where he will fly Thursday for a vacation.   The House vote was 282 to 95, considerably more than the two-thirds needed under the House rules to thwart the attempt to reopen the bill. That effort was led by Representative James M. Shannon, Democrat of Massachusetts. Voting with him were 93 other Democrats, largely from the upper Middle West and Northeast, and one Republican, James M. Jeffords of Vermont.

headline: SOLIDARITY PRESSING DEMANDS FOR ACCESS TO NEWS OUTLETS
abstract: The struggle for control of the Polish press intensified today when the Solidarity union movement threatened a six-day printers strike and the Communist Party leader, Stanislaw Kania, vowed that the press would not be shut down.   Union headquarters in Gdansk threatened to call another newspaper strike if it could not reach agreement with the authorities on union access to the official media.

headline: RING IN COLUMBIA KIDNAPS CHILDREN FOR SALE ABROAD
abstract: The authorities have uncovered a multimillion dollar international ring in which hundreds of poor Andean children were kidnapped or bought from their mothers and sold under forged birth certificates and adoption papers to childless couples from the United States and Europe.   A Bogota lawyer has been jailed on charges involving the smuggling abroad of 500 to 600 youngsters from Colombia and possibly 100 more from Peru. In neighboring Ecuador, officials have turned up more than a hundred questionable adoptions by Italian families.   The Colombian network is said to have included three juvenile court judges, six notaries, nurses in two maternity clinics, officials of the Government's family welfare agency, several secretaries and housewives and a Colombian consul in Spain. Among those charged in Peru is an official of the Government unit that handles international earthquake aid. The principal figure arrested so far in the Ecuadorian cases is the president of the national children's court.

headline: A NINTH HUNGER STRIKER DIES IN ULSTER
abstract: A ninth Irish nationalist hunger striker died today in Maze Prison near Belfast as pessimism deepened further over the prospects for a solution to the five-month-old dispute.   As with the others who have died since May, the death of 23-yearold Thomas G. McElwee after 62 days without food was marked by violence in Roman Catholic areas of Belfast and in Londonderry.  Firebombs and stones were thrown at policemen, and army patrols fired plastic bullets in retaliation. Several vehicles were hijacked and set on fire.

headline: Japan's Trade; Surplus Rises
abstract: Japan's world trade surplus rose 3.8 percent, to $1.53 billion in July from $1.47 billion in June, the Ministry of Finance said today. The surplus in trade with the United States rose to a record $1.35 billion.

headline: BUSINESS CARDS: A JAPANESE RITUAL
abstract: ''Your meishi is your face,'' trumpets an advertising billboard.  ''Meishi is most necessary here,'' said Akio Morita, chairman of the Sony Corporation. ''It's absolutely essential.'' ''A man without a meishi,'' Marshall R. Louis Jr., press officer in the United States Embassy, explained, ''has no identity in Japan.'' Indeed, it would be difficult to exaggerate the importance in Japan of the meishi, or name card. People in other countries do, of course, carry and exchange name cards or, as they are often called, business cards, particularly corporate executives and government officials.  But in Japan, even the bar girls have them.   Yet to note merely the prevalence of meishi-passing at all levels of commerce is to miss much of its significance in this country. The exchange of meishi is the most basic of social rituals in a nation where social ritual matters very much. It solidifies a per-sonal contact in a nation where personal contacts are the indispensible ingredient for success in any field of endeavor.

headline: Alcoa Gives; Profit Outlook
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America foresees no upturn in earnings results before the first half of next year, W.H. George Krome, chairman of the board and chief executive officer, said.   Shipments of aluminium are expected to be somewhat lower in the second half of this year compared with the same period last year, he told Zurich bankers at a presentation to mark the company's listing on Swiss stock exchanges.

headline: Israelis to Step Up Security After the Slaying of a Pilgrim
abstract: The Israeli Government said today that it would step up security for pilgrims after a terrorist explosion killed an Italian tourist and wounded 24 others in his group.

headline: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks Seen
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union may be ready to begin talks on a possible new grain agreement within two or three weeks, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today.   ''I hope that arrangements could be made somewhere toward the end of the month, but there's no date established,'' Mr. Block told a group of reporters.

headline: FRANKLIN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Research Concern Names New Chief
abstract: Norman M. Wellen, 50 years old, has been named president and chief executive officer of the Business International Corporation, a business research and information company with headquarters in New York. He succeeds Orville L. Freeman, the 62-year-old former Secretary of Agriculture, who was elected chairman.

headline: VW Unit Closes Plant
abstract: Triumph-Adler, a subsidiary of Volkswagenwerk, said today that it planned to close its factory here, resulting in the loss of some 3,000 jobs of the company's total employment of 8,700. The company, attributing the closing to a weak market for mechanical and electric typewriters, said it would concentrate on the electronic office machine sector. The company reported a loss of 79 million marks in 1980, or about $32 million.

headline: Economic Scene; HOLDING CARTER RESPONSIBLE
abstract: THE national economy stumbled during the second quarter into what may be the start of another recession, and the Reagan Administration promptly blamed the Carter Administration for the decline.   After announcing that real gross national product, which had jumped at an annual rate of 8.6 percent in the first quarter, had fallen at a rate of 1.9 percent in the second, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said, ''This setback is the result of mismanagement of economic policy during 1980.''   Is there no statute of limitations for the Carter Administration?  Is it really responsible for the renewed slump? When does the Reagan Administration assume credit or blame for the state of the national economy?   Unfortunately, there is no statute of limitations for economic crimes and misdemeanors. The Roosevelt Administration, for example, continued to indict the Hoover Administation for causing the Great Depression until World War II wiped it out.

headline: COSTA RICA ASKS TALKS ON DEBT
abstract: The Costa Rican Government has announced that it will request that a meeting be held with its principal creditors in New York later this month to seek renegotiation of its $2.4 billion foreign debt.   The decision was not surprising to foreign bankers following Costa Rica's decision last July to suspend payments of the principal on its commercial debt. Since then, Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb of New York has been advising the Government on handling its debt.

headline: 2 TOP U.S. OFFICIALS CRITICAL OF BEGIN FOR MILITARY ACTS
abstract: Two high Reagan Administration officials today criticized Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, suggesting that Israel's recent military actions had set back American diplomatic initiatives in the Middle East and had made it difficult for Washington to resume deliveries of F-16 fighter-bombers to the Israelis.   Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said that Prime Minister Begin's course ''cannot really be described as moderate at this point, and it is essential that there be some moderation.''   The White House pointedly announced that Mr. Weinberger's critical remarks, made on an early morning television program, reflected the White House's views.   Deputy Secretary of State William P. Clark told a group of reporters that Prime Minister Begin had caused ''disappointment and maybe some embarrassment'' in ordering heavy air strikes against Beirut last Friday, ''on the heels'' of a visit to Israel by the State Department counselor, Robert C. McFarlane.

headline: Bahrain Refinery
abstract: The Ras Tanura refinery of the Arabian American Oil Company, known as Aramco, has brought new naphtha and pentane-extraction installations into operation, increasing the capacity for gasoline output by as much as 10,000 barrels a day, Aramco said today. The new plant allows more low-octane products to be included in the gasoline blend, and thus increases production, it said.

headline: Muir Florida Units To Be Acquired
abstract: The four remaining John Muir & Company branch offices in Florida will be acquired by Ross Stebbins Inc., a small Wall Street retail brokerage house, and by Lawrence Monberg Jr., a salesman in Muir's Fort Lauderdale office.   The Florida branches will be operated under the name of Monberg & Company, a division of Ross Stebbins. Mr. Monberg had been hired three months ago by Muir.

headline: Bozell Selects New Executive
abstract: Hailing it as the ''greatest partnership since Max Dane met Bill Bernbach,'' G. Bruce McLaren, who has been president of Bozell & Jacobs's Atlantic division for all of seven weeks, has chosen Neal Dearling as executive vice president and executive creative director.    Like Mr. McLaren, Mr. Dearling is 37 years old and has a background in packaged goods.

headline: HE'S GETTING INTERFERENCE 1970-1981
abstract: ATLANTA W HEN broadcasting entrepreneur Ted Turner learned that Westinghouse and ABC were planning to take on his Cable News Network with a jointly-owned, faster-paced cable headline news service, his response was immediate and typically Turner. He would, he said, begin his own faster-paced cable news service, CNN II. And, he said, ''I think we're going to beat their brains out.''   Robert Edward Turner 3d, the 42-year-old self-made millionaire, owner of the Atlanta Braves, winner of the America's Cup race, frequently known to his admirers as ''The Mouth of the South,'' relishes such encounters.   From a standing start just over a year ago, he turned CNN, a venture of his Turner Broadcasting System Inc., into a household word. Turner Broadcasting, traded in the over-the-counter market but 87 percent-owned by Mr. Turner, grossed $54.6 million in 1980, small potatoes when compared with the revenues of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation ($8.5 billion) and American Broadcasting Companies Inc.  ($2.26 billion).

headline: HILLER BUYS AN OPTION ON 17% OF KAISER STEEL
abstract: A California investor acquired the option yesterday to buy 17 percent of the Ka iser Steel Corporation for $50 a share, a total of about $59 mil lion.   Stanley Hiller Jr., who purchased the option from the Kaiser Foundation, represents a group of investors who are negotiating to acquire the remainder of the 7 million outstanding shares of Kaiser Steel.   A Kaiser spokesman declined to comment on the development until the board of directors meets. She would not say whether there had already been negotiations between Mr. Hiller and Kaiser executives.

headline: REPUBLIC STEEL, GULF IN VENTURE
abstract: The Gulf Oil Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation completed their previously announced formation of a partnership to own, operate and develop Republic's coal properties on the North River tract in Fayette county, Ala., the companies said.   Gulf said it had paid Republic $120 million for a one-half interest in the North River Energy Company and will contribute at least an additional $35 million towards development of the 83,000 tract over the next five years.

headline: ENVOY WARNS OF NEUTRALISM
abstract: President Reagan's nominee as Ambassador to the Soviet Union appeared today for confirmation hearings before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and told the panel that the gravest danger in Western Europe was uninformed opposition to nuclear defenses.   The nominee, Arthur A. Hartman, a career diplomat who is currently Ambassador to France, said that another critical problem facing Europeans was a drift toward neutrality in disputes be tween Moscow and Washingto n.   Mr. Hartman said that Soviet propagandists were fueling the trend.

headline: The U.N. Today; July 16, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: International Conference on Cambo- dia - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: The U.N. Today; Sept. 10, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Eighth emergency special session meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: P.L.O. SENDS 2 NEW UNITS TO SOUTH LEBANON
abstract: Guerrilla leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization have sent two heavy weapons units into southern Lebanon to reinforce their positions.   Beirut newspapers carried photographs this morning of a column of amphibious armored cars, belonging to the mainstream Fatah organization of Yasir Arafat, headed for an undisclosed area in the south. The armored unit, a military police group known as Squad 17, had previously been deployed to guard the coast in Beirut's southern suburbs.

headline: Volkswagen Van Output to Be Cut
abstract: Volkswagenwerk said 8,000 to 9,000 workers at its Hanover van production plant will be put on reduced work schedules for 15 days beginning at the end of August.

headline: ITALY SUSPENDS ALL STOCK TRADING
abstract: Italy's new Government today closed the country's stock markets for the rest of the week in an attempt to halt an accelerating collapse of stock prices that began a month ago. It was the first such Government action since the end of World War I.   Treasury Minister Beniamino Andreatta acted this morning after regulatory authorities in Milan, the country's stock-trading center, suspended trading there yesterday when the prices of some shares fell by more than 20 percent in early morning selling. His order did not affect foreign currency or bond markets.   The decision to close the markets highlighted the difficulties that lie ahead for the new Prime Minister, Giovanni Spadolini. He was a compromise candidate for Prime Minister and, as a member of the small but influential Repubican Party, is the first non-Christian Democrat to hold the post since World War II.

headline: Funds' Assets Rise $2.5 Billion
abstract: The assets of the nation's money-market mutual funds climbed $2.5 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the 12th consecutive weekly increase, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   The trend reflects the attraction of investors to the higher yields paid by the funds, compared with other investment instruments such as six-month savings certificates.

headline: BANI-SADR, IN INTERVIEW, ASSERTS KURDS HELP HIM
abstract: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, the deposed and fugitive President of Iran, has been sheltered by rebel Kurdish tribesmen, according to an interview with him published today in Eight Days, a London-based magazine specializing in the Middle East.   The interview is the first word from Mr. Bani-Sadr since he dropped out of sight June 12 after being removed as Commander in Chief of the armed forces by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The interview, the magazine said, was conducted in Kurdistan, the mountainous area of northwestern Iran, four days later.   It is not known where Mr. Bani-Sadr is now.  Massoud Rajavi, the leader of the Mujahedeen guerrillas, organized his escape, and the Kurdish Democratic Party, which has been fighting the central Government for more than a year, helped him, the magazine said.

headline: Montgomery Ward P icks a New Chief
abstract: Stephen L. Pistner, a 49-year-old retailer who joined Montgomery Ward & Company as president about six months ago, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer of the retailing and catalogue chain. He succeeds Edward S. Donnell, 61, who will continue as chairman of Ward, the Chicago-based subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation, until he retires next March 1.   When Mr. Pistner arrived at the troubled Ward organization as a potential heir apparent to Mr. Donnell, the company had been in distress for several years, reporting the largest losses of any American retailer in recent years. In the first half of 1981, Ward lost $75 million, compared with $82 million in the first six months of the previous year. Since acquiring Ward in 1976, Mobil has given it about $355 million in interest-free loans.

headline: WEST GERMAN YOUTHS RIOT AFTER SQUATTER DIES
abstract: Youths smashed store windows and set fires in several West German cities last night and early today, causing about $1 million in damage, after a teen-ager was killed in a battle between policemen and squatters in West Berlin yesterday.   The fighting, vandalism and arson spread to a half-dozen cities and involved thousands of youths. In Frankfurt, where the police reported that passers-by were beaten by rampaging youths, damage to stores and automobiles was estimated at $250, 000.

headline: BONN SEEKS TO CUT COMMON MARKET PAYMENT
abstract: The West German Government, which is contending with a stalled economy and facing heavy budget cuts next year, said yesterday that it would seek a sharp reduction in its Common Market budget payments.   At the same time, the Government told Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher to seek formal talks in the European Economic Community on strenghtening Europe's political unity.

headline: No Headline
abstract: To the Business Editor:    In ''How the Oil Glut Is Changing Business'' (June 21), it was asserted, incorrectly, that the Consolidated Edison ''burns about 1 percent of the nation's oil.''   We don't yet have 1980 data, but 1979 will suffice.

headline: Ashland Bonds Downgraded
abstract: The ratings on Ashland Oil Company bonds were reduced yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which expressed concern over the company's profit outlook.   S.&P. lowered the rating on senior debt issues to BBB+, a notch lower than A, the former rating.

headline: Uranium Halt By Phillips
abstract: The Phillips Petroleum Company said its Phillips Uranium Corporation subsidiary was suspending operations at its Nose Rock Uranium Mine in New Mexico.   However, it does not intend to abandon the mine.

headline: Around the World; Shipyard Workers Jostle B ritish Defense Secretary
abstract: Scores of workers, angry at the prospective loss of 6,000 jobs at a naval maintenance facility here, surrounded Defense Secretary John Nott today, kicked and punched him and threw eggs and rocks in his direction until he fled.   The Ministry of Defense said that Mr. Nott was not hurt and had only been jostled.

headline: The U.N. Today; Sept. 9, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Eighth emergency special session meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 3 P.M.

headline: RATE FEARS STILL HOLD SWAY
abstract: The credit market and the stock market begin a new week facing a common foe: high interest rates. Compounding this problem, some analysts say, is the expectation that rates - in some sectors, at least - are likely to move even higher.   On Friday, the stock market reached its low for this year, with the Dow Jones industrial average tumbling 7.80 points, to 920.57.  The fixed-income market was hit even harder. Prices of existing tax-exempt securities finished at all-time lows and, correspondingly, at record yields. The same was true for certain maturities in the government market and the corporate bond market.

headline: MOBIL'S REPLY...
abstract: ''B Y virtually every traditional measure of concentration, the oil industry is considered to be competitive. In 1978, the United States oil industry four-company market shares or concentration ratios were: 28.1 percent for crude oil and condensate production, 31.4 percent for refining capacity and 29.4 percent for gasoline marketing. Last year, in the United States no single oil company had more than 9.9 percent of crude oil and condensate production, 9.21 percent of refining capacity or 7.7 percent of gasoline marketing. These market shares are well below the thresholds of antitrust concern about market power.''

headline: MUCKRAKING EDITOR A CONSTANT BARB TO MRS. GANDHI
abstract: Since the return to power of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, nothing has been as upsetting as the writings of Arun Shourie.   The 39-year-old editor, a former economist at the World Bank, is conducting an inquiry into influence-peddling and has brought one of Mrs. Gandhi's most admiring and flamboyant appointees to the brink of resignation.   Virtually alone among Indian journalists, Mr. Shourie, an editor of The Indian Express, the nation's largest circulation daily newspaper, has organized and written muckracking exposes on such scandals as the blinding by policemen of 31 suspects awaiting trial, the selling of women and the detention for years of poor people awaiting trial on minor charges. He has written about powerful and politically connected landlords who evade laws that limit holdings.

headline: BLACKS FOR PRETORIA'S PLANES
abstract: South African Airways plans to recruit black women as flight attendants, the Government has announced. The Government-owned international airline already employs black women as ground attendants at major airports, but until now flight crews have been all-white.

headline: Alfa Romeo Eurocredit
abstract: Alfa Romeo International is raising a $50 million Eurocredit, guaranteed by Societa Finanziaria Meccanica, the joint lead manager, National Westminster Bank, said today. The credit is for five years, with two and a half years' grace, at 5/8 of a percentage point above the London interbank offered rate, the bank said. The other lead manager is Fuji Bank.

headline: Social Democrats Oust West German Legislator
abstract: West Germany's governing Social Democratic Party today expelled a leftist member of Parliament who had accused Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of practicing ''secret diplomacy'' against the German people in connection with the NATO decision to deploy United States nuclear missiles in Europe.

headline: TEHERAN DELAYING ITS U.N. DELEGATION
abstract: Iran disclosed today that it had postponed the arrival of a delegation to the United Nations General Assembly after receiving a warning that the United States would not allow anyone who took part in the takeover of the American Embassy in Teheran to enter the country.   An official of the Iranian Mission to the United Nations reported the delay but said he could not confirm that the postponement was linked to the American warning. Nor could he name anyone in the Iranian delegation whose presence would have raised an objection.   There were indications, however, that among the 15-member delegation, which was to have arrived tomorrow in New York, was Ahmad Azizi, Iran's former Director of Hostage Affairs.

headline: CONOCO'S CASE AGAINST TWO BIDDERS...
abstract: C ONOCO is confronted with two unfriendly tender offers for its stock - one from Mobil involving a horizontal merger of the two major oil companies and one from Seagram, the Canadian liquor company, to take control of Conoco.   Both offers spring from the nationalistic policies of Canada, which earlier facilitated a partial tender offer by Dome Petroleum for Conoco stock. Dome's success emboldened Seagram to try the same tactics. Seagram's offer, in turn, has brought in Mobil.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The owners of an Argentine cargo plane that disappeared six days ago on a flight from Iran said today that the aircraft was forced to fly into Soviet airspace. But Jose Patetta, general manager of Transportes Aereos Rioplatenses, could offer no clues as to what happened to the plane after it entered Soviet airspace.

headline: ENDERS IN NICARAGUA FOR TALKS
abstract: A senior American official arrived here today for the first high-level talks between the United States and Nicaragua's revolutionary Government since the Reagan Administration took office.   The official, Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, met with the ruling junta as well as the critics of the regime in the church, press and private sector.

headline: Gasoline Price Leveling Seen
abstract: As competitive pressures ease, retail gas prices have apparently stopped their rate of decline and will level off, according to Dan Lundberg, publisher of the Lundberg Letter, an industry newsletter.   From March until July, the retail price of gasoline in the United States declined at a constant average of 0.81 cents each month, he said in the latest edition of his newsletter, released today.

headline: FLAGSHIP TO WEIGH ROYAL TRUSTCO BID
abstract: Flagship Banks Inc. of Miami announced today that it had resumed negotiations with Royal Trustco Ltd. of Toronto, parent of Canada's largest trust company group, on its possible takeover by the Canadian company.   If consummated, the merger, which would cost Royal Trustco $251.6 million, would create the fourth largest bank group in Florida, with assets of nearly $3 billion.

headline: Chevron Gas Well
abstract: Chevron U.S.A. said it had drilled the deepest producing well yet in the Overthrust Belt in southwestern Wyoming - a natural gas well 16,780 feet deep. The company said that the well flowed natural gas at a stabilized rate of 2.8 million cubic feet a day.

headline: India Buying U.S. Wheat
abstract: Agriculture Minister Rao Birendra Singh announced today that India would pay $293 million for wheat imported from the United States this year.

headline: AT THE CONTROLS OF PAN AM
abstract: ''I was thinking about finding a more challenging job,'' said C.  Edward Acker, ''and I asked about being the captain of the Titanic.  But they said I was years too late. So I decided to take the job of Pan Am chairman.''   With that quip Charles Edward Acker, chairman of Air Florida, explained why he had accepted an offer from the board of the foundering Pan American World Airways to assume its chairmanship Sept. 1, replacing William T. Seawell.

headline: Technology; PHONES THAT DELIVER MEMOS
abstract: PICKING up the telephone and hearing a singing telegram is a rare surprise nowadays. But in a few large companies, employees are picking up the phone and hearing talking telegrams sent by their colleagues.   A manager might pick up the phone and hear: ''This is Bill Jones.  Meet me at the airport today at 4 P.M.'' But Bill Jones would not be at the other end of the line. What the manager would hear would be an electronic reproduction of a message Bill Jones had spoken into his phone. Mr. Jones, in fact, might have dictated that call into the telephone several days earlier and programmed the telephone system to place the call at a specific time.

headline: Personal Finance; 'LOOPHOLE CERTIFICATES' AND OTHER QUERIES
abstract: T HE following are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column. Q. I recently bought a large ''loophole certificate'' and had to borrow part of the principal from the same bank to meet the required minimum. How much interest must I report on my tax return - the total amount of interest earned on the C.D. or only my net interest earnings after subtracting the interest on my loan from the bank?   A. The total amount of interest earned, according to a recent ruling by the Internal Revenue Service. It concerned a taxpayer with $5,000 who had borrowed another $5,000 from a bank to purchase a $10,000 certificate of deposit. The C.D. earned $793 when it reached maturity after six months, but the taxpayer only netted $372 after interest expenses of $421. The bank, which had to declare the interest earned by its depositors, wanted to know how much interest income it had to report to the I.R.S. on Form 1099, known as an ''information return.''

headline: Sundstrand Pact
abstract: The Sundstrand Corporation said it had entered into an agreement to acquire the Vandling Corporation of Van Nuys, Calif., for 58,950 shares of Sundstrand's common stock.

headline: People
abstract: * Thomas Gorman has been named executive vice president-marketing/ advertising for Germaine Monteil Cosmetiques.   * James F. Frawley named vice president-consumer marketing at Hunt-Wesson Foods Inc., Fullerton, Calif.

headline: Consolidated Foods Gains
abstract: The Consolidated Foods Corporation, a major food producer, said today that its profit in the fiscal fourth quarter rose 13 percent from a year earlier.

headline: 'P' Car Delay Is Reported
abstract: A cash shortage has forced the General Motors Corporation to delay introduction of its sporty ''P'' car until the autumn of 1983, according to a published report.   The two-passenger, plastic-bodied car originally was to have been introduced by G.M.'s Pontiac division in 1982, but earlier this year the introduction was postponed until the middle of the 1983 model year, the Metalworking News edi tion of American Metal Mark et reported.

headline: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Yr to Apr 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The Week in Business; LITTLE ACCORD AT THE SUMMIT
abstract: The heads of state of seven major industrial nations closed their seventh summit meeting with pledges to revitalize their economies, but no precise agreements. President Francois Mitterrand of France, right, and other European leaders charged that high American interest rates were crippling investment in their nations. President Reagan made no economic concessions, but the United States did warm up to global negotiations on north-south economic disparities.

headline: Tandy, Datapoint Link Computers
abstract: The Tandy Corporation personal computers will be able to link together in a network using technology provided by the Datapoint Corporation, the two companies announced.

headline: BEIRUT THREATENS TO ASK FOR SANCTIONS ON ISRAEL
abstract: Lebanon said today that it would seek sanctions against Israel unless the Israelis agree to halt their attacks.   Ghassan Tueni, Beirut's chief delegate here, said at a news conference that he would ask the Security Council to ''condemn Israeli aggression'' and ''resort to sanctions'' if Israel continues its attacks by air, sea and land.   Mr. Tueni did not specify the precise nature of the sanctions he might seek. The United Nations Charter provides for imposing embargoes on the shipment of commercial and military products to nations threatening peace.

headline: NEW MARKETER OF PAPAL VISIT SOUVENIRS
abstract: Mark McCormack, the head of a Cleveland business that promotes celebrities, has an impressive new client.  His company, the International Management Group, has been hired by the Roman Catholic Church in Britian as the exclusive marketer of papal souvenirs for Pope John Paul II's schedule visit to Britain in 1982.

headline: Market Place; Singer Stock Gains Backers
abstract: THE Singer Company may be a candidate for a turnaround and even a renaissance as a blue-chip company. If this should happen, the rebirth will have been a long time in the making.   Singer's founder helped invent the sewing machine in the mid-19th century. Thereafter, he began what was to become one of the world's great business successes. By World War II, the company's machines were so widely found in world markets that the name Singer was almost synonymous with sewing.

headline: Brazil Devaluation
abstract: Brazil devalued its currency, the cruzeiro, by 1.682 percent last night, to 102.18 to the United States dollar at the buyers' rate and 102.69 at the sellers' rate, effective today. This was the 23d cruzeiro devaluation of the year.

headline: Advertising; Citibank Campaign
abstract: Citibank has announced a major advertising campaign, to begin next month, for its electronic banking and cash management services for corporations and financial institutions. Advertising, which is being handled by Foote, Cone & Belding, will run in 22 national newspapers and magazines.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The emergency party congress ended today and when the votes and the tumult died down, one thing was clear - the Polish Communist Party is vastly different from what it was six days ago.   More than 90 percent of the 270 members of the full Central Committee are new. More importantly, they represent a new force - they are workers instead of party hacks. They are rooted in the provinces instead of Warsaw, and they are guided by egalitarianism and an almost populist notion of taking on the establishment.

headline: Inquirer Raises Price
abstract: The Philadelphia Inquirer is to raise the price of its Sunday edition to 75 cents from 60 cents, beginning Aug. 30, the newspaper announced today. The price of the daily Inquirer will remain at 20 cents.

headline: LASERS, FINALLY, BEGIN TO LIVE UP TO EXPECTATIONS
abstract: By BARNABY J. FEDER   Finally, very slowly but surely, the laser is living up to its billing. Sales of lasers and related equipment passed the $1 billion mark for the first time last year, according to Laser Focus, the industry's leading trade publication, and a 27 percent sales increase has been projected for this year.   It has been a rocky road to the $1 billlion level, characterized mainly by a quiet increase in the number of uses of lasers and a far cry from the eye-popping science fiction laser guns and Star Wars light saber. Thus far, the only mass- marketed consumer item that incorporates a laser is the videodisk system developed by the North American Philips Corporation and MCA Inc., which uses a laser scanner to ''read'' a pattern of depressions on the disk so that they can be translated into picture and sound.

headline: U.S. SAYS SOVIET MESSAGE IS INTERVENTION IN POLAND'S INTERNAL AFFAIRS
abstract: The United States charged today that the Soviet Union, in calling on Poli sh leaders to crack down on the Solidarity la bor movement, was intervening in Poland's domestic politics.   Alan D. Romberg, a State Department spokesman, said the Soviet message conveyed yesterday to the Polish leadership ''constitutes interference in Poland's internal affairs.''   ''We cannot accept the assertion that the Soviet Union for any reason has the right to dictate the policies of the Polish Government,'' Mr. Romberg said. This was the sharpest statement issued by Washington since the level of polemics from Moscow took on a more threatening tone.

headline: OUTLOOK BRIGHTER FOR PAKISTANI-AFGHAN TALKS
abstract: Pakistan and Afghanistan have moved closer to talks aimed at the removal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan, United Nations officials said today.   The two governments have tentatively agreed to a four-point agenda for the negotiations, if and when they begin, the officials said.  The two sides, however, are still quarreling over who should take part in the talks and how they should be conducted.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: 3 LATIN NATIONS FAULT MEXICO AND FRANCE ON SALVADOR ISSUE
abstract: Argentine diplomats said today that Argentina would join Colombia and Venezuela in issuing a statement supporting the Government of El Salvador and criticizing France and Mexico for recognizing the Salvadoran rebels as a political force.   The Argentine diplomats, in Washington for meetings between Foreign Minister Oscar Hector Camilion of Argentina and Vice President Bush and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., said they hoped that the letter supporting the Salvadoran Government would offset the international impact of the French-Mexican declaration that was issued Friday.   Mr. Camilion learned of the Colombian-Venezuelan initiative today in a phone call from Buenos Aires. It is expected that other nations will also be asked to join.

headline: NASHUA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BARD, C R, INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 UP BY 9.5%
abstract: The nation's Big Three auto makers said today that sales of their new passenger cars rose 9.5 percent in the first 10 days of September compared with the same period last year, when sales were unusually weak.   The increase, attributable mostly to extended rebate programs at the three companies, was in line with industry expectations.  September is normally a good selling month as dealers lower prices to raise money and make room for new models.   ''The sales were O.K., but not really good,'' said Arvid Jouppi, an auto analyst with Rooney, Pace Inc. ''They would be lower, of course, except for the rebates. The customer is still very wary.''

headline: BIOFUEL INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LOWER RATES ARE EXPECTED
abstract: The credit markets are waiting for the Federal Reserve to encourage lower short-term interest rates, but even those who expect such a move admit that it is far from clear whether a decline would continue through the second half of the year.   ''The vast unknowns of the Reagan economic package are still there,'' one investment banker said. ''What kind of spending and tax reductions will we get, and how are the economy and inflation going to be affected?''   In the bond markets, those questions have helped restrain buying of long-term issues so that prices have dropped for three weeks and the yield on bellwether 13 7/8 percent Treasury bonds due 2011 increased to about 13.3 percent by Friday from 12.55 percent on June 15. The issue yields less than the 13.99 percent it yielded when it was auctioned in early May, but the recent drop in prices showed that at current yields there is less demand for new long-term bonds than there is potential supply from the Treasury and corporations.

headline: KEYSTONE FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Prospects
abstract: Recession Ahead?   Until recently, while most analysts agreed that tough monetary policy would continue to hurt interest-sensitive sectors like housing and autos, they also thought high interest rates would do little more than dampen business elsewhere, resulting in sluggish growth - but growth nevertheless - the rest of the year. However, last quarter's 1.9 percent decline in economic activity may mean that a dampening has suddenly turned into recession.   Albert Sommers and Edward Yardeni, economists at the Conference Board and E.F. Hutton, respectively, find an unexpectedly large upturn in inventories particularly worrisome. Unlike a year ago, when companies anticipated recession and laid off workers early, this year producers in many sectors apparently concluded that high interest rates would not harm sales and kept workers on the job. But continued weakness in housing and construction could depress employment and weaken consumer sales.

headline: NASDAQ QUOTES INCOMPLETE
abstract: Because of the power outage in lower Manhattan, the volumes published for some NASDAQ over-the-counter quotations are incomplete. The New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange tables include consolidated trading through the early close of the New York exchanges at 3:30 P.M. and the close of trading at the regional exchanges, the last of which, the Pacific Exchange, remained open until its normal closing time of 5:30 P.M., E.D.T.

headline: MOSCOW SAYS TOXIN CHARGE MADE BY HAIG WAS A 'BIG LIE'
abstract: The Soviet Union today described as a ''big lie'' the allegation in a West Berlin speech yesterday by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that the Soviet Union has been supplying poisonous chemicals for use in warfare in Afghanistan, Cambodia and Laos.   A long article by the official press agency Tass offered Soviet readers none of the details set forth by Mr. Haig, and apart from dismissing the Secretary's charges as ''libelous and groundless,'' made no attempt to substantiate its rebuttal.   Instead, it countered with a chronicle of purported abuses by Washington, saying that ''no country in the history of international relations has used chemical weapons as extensively as the United States.'' Apart from American military practices in Vietnam, the Soviet agency said that American-manufactured chemical weapons were being used by anti-Government insurgents in Afghanistan and by the United States-backed junta in El Salvador.

headline: 6-Month Bills Rise to 14.23%; Bell Bonds Set at 15.725%
abstract: Weak investor demand for long-term bonds was amply demonstrated yesterday when underwriters announced that the New York Telephone Company's new 40-year debentures will be sold today at a yield of 15.725 percent - a record for new triple A-rated Bell System debt.   Underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation said that the $250 million of New York Telephone's 15 5/8 percent debentures due 2021 will carry a price of 99 3/8, while a companion $150 million issue of 14 5/8 percent notes due 1991 was priced at 99.357 to yield 14.75 percent.   In other credit market activity, short- and long-term interest rates were little changed in quiet secondary trading, as participants waited for signs of renewed investor interest in long-term bonds and proof that the Fed is willing to encourage lower short-term rates.  Yields were lower much of the day for both short- and long-term issues, but by the close most of the declines had been reversed.

headline: Companies
abstract: Pan Am is negotiating the sale of Intercontinental Hotels, a highly profitable subsidiary, to raise cash for its money-losing airline operation. Other measures to shore up its finances include a delay in the delivery of new jetliners and an agreement for a $200 million revolving credit conditional on union wage cuts. (Page D1.)   U.S. Steel decided to withdraw a 6 percent price increase on tin mill products set for Sept. 20 after Jones & Laughlin announced it would not raise prices until January. Analysts say tin plate demand has not been strong, as more aluminum is being used in cans. (D5.)

headline: American Express Publishing Director
abstract: Patrick Foglia has become the top ad-selling honcho for both Travel & Leisure and Food & Wine magazines.

headline: More Time on Itel Debt
abstract: The Itel Corporation said today that a Federal bankruptcy court had approved its request to extend by 60 days its deadline for filing a plan to restructure $1.3 billion of debt.

headline: Business Forum; DEREGULATION: A LETTER TO GEORGE BUSH
abstract: side effect, the resources released by tax cuts have to be put to use for more productive purposes than meeting more regulatory requirements.   Thus, the President must come forward immediately with a reform agenda.  Such a plan should concentrate on a few major regulatory programs that stand in the way of efficiency and progress. To do less would cast doubt on whether the President can carry forward his full economic program.

headline: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1981; The Economy
abstract: U.S. oil imports have dropped by one-fifth as Americans have curbed their demand for petroleum since the Reagan Administration lifted controls on oil prices in January.
