Evidence is mounting that higher crude prices may help stem the long decline in U.S. crude output.  Although the White House considers oil decontrol a major victory, some energy analysts suggested that longer-term trends may have caused the present situation. (Page A1.)

headline: Business People; FROM DART TO OLGA IN PURSUIT OF GOALS
abstract: When Thomas P. Mullaney announced his resignation in July 1980 as president and chief operating officer of Dart Industries shortly before it merged with Kraft Inc., he said that the amalgamation - which resulted in Dart & Kraft Inc. - ''makes achievement of some of my personal goals difficult.'' Now Mr. Mullaney, who is 48 years old, is setting off toward a new personal goal. Effective Sept. 28, he will become president and chief executive officer of the Olga Company in Van Nuys, Calif.

headline: Bolivian Tin Miners End Strike As Officials Pledge an Inquiry
abstract: Workers at Bolivia's major tin mines have temporarily ended an indefinite strike after the Government pledged to investigate the events that touched it off.   Some 1,400 workers at the two mines, which produce 11 tons of tin per day, began the strike last Friday to demand a Government explanation of the death of an arrested union leader, Julio Cossio Meruvia.

headline: Advertising; Big Butter Maker on The Move
abstract: IN three different areas of the country sales representatives of Land O'Lakes, the giant Middle West farm cooperative, are busy pushing products with names that are new to the 60-year-old Minneapolis-based organization.   And such activity in new brands by the country's major butter producer and marketer, is just what Everett N. Baldwin, group vice president and chief operating officer of the Foods division and onetime Procter & Gamble man, was brought in to do. This big cheese was in the Big Apple yesterday along with Delroy O. Thomas, vice president of new products and marketing services, and a fairly recent arrival from Kentucky Fried Chicken.   As far as both can recall, the only previous new product introduction in the foods group in rece nt yea rs was actually only a repackaging of the butter in the early 1970's . Hardly the kind of rush to market that is going on in the rest o f the food industry.

headline: VULCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Juliana Und ergoes Surgery
abstract: Princess Juliana of the Netherlands, who abdicated the Dutch throne last year on her 71st birthday, successfully underwent an operation today, a Government statement said. No details of the operation were given, but a Government spokesman said the illness was of a nonmalignant nature.

headline: DOME BIDS FOR REST OF OIL SHARES
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd. announced yesterday that it would bid $1.8 billion (Canadian) in preferred stock for the 47.1 percent of the shares in the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company that it did not acquire June 1 from Conoco Inc.   Spokesmen for Hudson's Bay Oil and the Hudson's Bay Company, its largest minority shareholder, called the offer ''too low.'' The bid had been expected by analysts ever since Dome won control of Hudson's Bay Oil from Conoco in June in a strategic duel that uncovered Conoco's vulnerability to a takeover. That battle encouraged Joseph E. Seagram & Sons to open a bidding war for the American oil company that ended when E.I. Du Pont de Nemours & Company won Conoco last week for a record $7.57 billion in stock and cash.

headline: FORD EARNS $60 MILLION IN QUARTER
abstract: The Ford Motor Company reported today that it had earned a profit of $60 million, or 50 cents a share, in the second quarter, in contrast to a loss of $467.9 million in the second quarter of 1980.   The size of the profit came as something of a surprise to securities analysts, who had expected the company to be about at the break-even point. It also ended six consecutive quarters of losses, totaling just over $2 billion.   ''This is a remarkable recovery from the first quarter loss of $439 million,'' said Arvid Jouppi, an auto industry analyst with John Muir & Company. ''I think it demonstrates that Ford's costcutting program has succeeded, and puts the company in a position to benefit from the sales upturn when it comes.''

headline: ARCATA BACKS $330 MILLION BID FOR ACQUISITION BY KOHLBERG
abstract: The Arcata Corporation, which produces a variety of forest products and is the nation's second-largest printing concern, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to be acquired by a new corporation to be formed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Robert & Company.   The transaction is valued at $37 a share, or a total of $330 million.  In addition to the cash payment, Arcata shareholders would retain the right to two-thirds of any net proceeds that might be realized from the company's pending $200 million claim against the United States Government for the taking of its timberlands in March 1978 to enlarge the Redwood National Park.

headline: U.S. CAUTIOUS ON GOALS IN SADAT TALK
abstract: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt arrived in Washington tonight for a visit that comes at a time when the Reagan Administration has considerable concern about the Middle East but only fragmentary ideas on what to do about promoting peace in the region.   Administration officials cautioned today against expectations of major developments arising from the visit.   The visit and a similar one by Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel next month were described as ''get-acquainted'' meetings and ''a time for listening'' to gain a better appreciation of the Egyptian and Israeli attitudes on the Palestinian self-government negotiations. The talks have been in recess since last fall.

headline: HORIZON CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Marriott Reports Gain
abstract: The Marriott Corporation, the hotel and motel chain, said today that it earned $21.8 million, or 81 cents a share, in the second quarter, up from $17.2 million, or 65 cents a share, in the same period a year ago.

headline: SOLIDARITY PLANS NEWSPAPER STRIKE IN POLAND
abstract: Polish newspaper workers today made strike preparations for a two-day shutdown of the country's presses over the issue of the Solidarity independent labor union's access to the state-run media.   In Warsaw, newspaper workers held meetings throughout the day with Solidarity leaders, while strike alerts were reported from Cracow, Szczecin, Lublin and Koszalin.   The strike call poses an awkward challenge to Poland's Communist leaders, particularly as Stanislaw Kania, the party first secretary, and Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski promised the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, three days ago that they planned ''to stop anarchy and launch an all-out battle against counterrevolution.''

headline: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 12, 1981; International
abstract: Thousands of trans-Atlantic airline passengers were stranded throughout the United States and Europe in the second day of serious disruption caused by Canadian air traffic controllers' refusal to handle flights to or from the United States. (Page A1.) The Canadian Government decided after meeting with air traffic controllers that its Eastern airspace would remain closed to all flights to or from Europe. (A1.) In Washington, the airlines enthusiastically endorsed the Administration's tough response to the strike. Secretary of Transportation Drew Lewis said that trans-Atlantic flights were using a Southern route to bypass Canadian air space. However, only four flights an hour could operate in each direction, 20 percent of the normal peak, and they were subject to delays of up to eight hours.  (A22.) Businesses dependent on trans-Atlantic freight flights reported widespread confusion, but added that time-sensitive shipments had arrived without excessive delays. (A22.)   The United States, the Common Market countries and Japan have worked out an early-warning arrangement on trade and investment issues. Representatives will meet to seek ways to defuse potential trouble in such areas as autos, steel, synthetic fibers and data processing equipment. The way for the accord was paved at last month's economic summit meeting in Ottawa. (A1.)

headline: INDIA DENIES SOVIET PROMPTED BARRING OF DIPLOMAT
abstract: A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry confirmed today that India had vetoed the posting of a senior diplomat at the United States Embassy here.   The spokesman said the Government had decided against accepting the diplomat, George G.B. Griffin, as political counselor ''after a careful evaluation of his activities during his various postings in India and the subcontinent.''   ''It is incorrect to suggest,'' the spokesman said, ''that views, information or pronouncements made by any other country played a part in India's decision.''

headline: FIRST UNITED BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UNION MILITANTS IN POLAND ATTACK LEADERS OVER GOVERNMENT ACCORD
abstract: Solidarity leaders defended themselves today against bitter accusations from the union's rank and file that the leadership had exceeded its authority in compromising with the Goverment over the right of workers to run factories.   More than two dozen of the 824 delegates at the union's national convention   Output falls, shortages worsen and worker apathy spreads as Solidarity and the Government wrangle over Poland's problems. Page D1. in Gdansk rose to denounce the compromise, some in stinging terms.  ''This union was not created to make compro mises, but to smash the totalitarian system in our country,'' Jan Rul ewski, a leading militant from Bydgoszcz, said.

headline: POLISH CHIEF PUTS 2 MORE GENERALS IN CABINET
abstract: Poland's Prime Minister shuffled his Cabinet today, dropping his deputy, who was in charge of economic affairs, and naming two more generals to Cabinet posts.   At the same time, Parliament enacted a law to preserve and govern press and cultural freedoms achieved over the last year during nationwide labor and social unrest.   Shortly before the nearly unanimous vote on the bill, about 300 workers in overalls and hard hats demonstrated at the doorway of the white stone Parliament building, demanding higher monthly meat rations.   Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski's Cabinet shakeup, which had been expected, was partly explained by a recent decision to separate Government and Communist Party responsibilities.

headline: CONSOLIDATED FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. Steps Up Afghan Aid
abstract: The United States will donate an extra $21 million to help international relief groups deal with Afghan refugees in Pakistan, a State Department spokesman announced today. The United States will spend $93 million in the current year to help the Afhgan refugees, an increase of $49 million over last year.

headline: CZECHOSLOVAKIA ALARMED BY RISE IN DIVORCES
abstract: Czechoslovakia, which has developed an extensive social system to promote family life, is now confronted with one of the highest divorce rates in the world.   A decade ago Prime Minister Lubomir Strougal warned that the country's birth rate had dropped to one of the lowest in Europe, and the Communist Party took measures to encourage families to have more children.   The state introduced a program of aid to families that amounts to about 8 percent of the national income. The program includes not only maternity leave and child-care allowances but also expansion of preschool institutions, tax relief and special loans for young couples.

headline: ARMY TROPPLES LEADER OF CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC
abstract: The army in the Central African Republic took power today from the civilian Government of President David Dacko.  The army's move came 23 months after a coup backed by the French that drove the self-styled Emperor Bokassa, a former army sergeant, into exile.   The French Foreign Minister called today's coup ''a purely Central African affair.'' France has about 1,600 troops in the former colony, but they were said to have taken no action following the peaceful coup early this morning.

headline: Forest Fires in Portugal Force Villagers to Flee
abstract: The residents of entire villages were flown to safety by helicopters today as the worst forest fires in Portugal this century ravaged densely wooded areas.

headline: Name Changed By Shearson
abstract: Shearson Loeb Rhoades, the securities firm, has changed its name to Shearson/American Express, reflecting its acquisition last June by the American Express Company.

headline: BEHIND THE OUTPOURING OF JOY, A HISTORIC MOMENT FOR BRITAIN
abstract: On a shabby street in East London, a sudden silence came over the Crown Pub this afternoon, and the lunchtime crowd turned their rapt attention to a radio that was set upon the beer-splashed bar.   Was it a crucial soccer match for which they interrupted their boisterous conversation? Election returns, or maybe even a war? No, it was a quiz in which the BBC was playing old excerpts from its accounts of previous royal weddings, with listeners asked to identify them.   ''I remember that one,'' said George Bennett, a wizened construction worker. ''It was when the Queen married Philip. That came just after our own daughter was born.''

headline: Around the World; Mail Bound for Canada Will Go Back to Senders
abstract: The Postal Service said today that mail bound for Canada and now held in the United States postal system would be returned to senders because of the Canadian postal strike.

headline: 7TH IRISH HUNGER STRIKER ENDS PROTEST IN BELFAST
abstract: Another Irish nationalist hunger striker at the Maze prison in Belfast gave up his fast tonight.  Liam McCloskey, 25 years old, who had gone without food for 55 days, became the seventh striker to give up his protest, but he was only the third to end it on his own.

headline: African Leaders Offer a Plan For the West Sahara Dispute
abstract: A seven-nation committee of the Organization of African Unity today announced a plan for a ceasefire and referendum in Western Sahara.

headline: Advertising; Bookstore Chain's Gift Package
abstract: AFTER all his years on television, Alistair Cooke wouldn't seem to need more publicity. Nevertheless, he is likely to be a prime beneficiary of Waldenbooks' lavish 1981 holiday gift catalogue. It is costing $2.5 million to put out, the bookstore chain says, with book publishers providing roughly $1.5 million.   Of the catalogue's 6.5 million copies, more than 4.3 million are to be bound into the Nov. 16 issue of Time Magazine - thereby constituting, Waldenbooks says, the largest single advertisement in bookselling history and the largest single-product advertisement ever carried in a national consumer magazine.

headline: OSHAWA GROUP LTD reports earnings for 16 weeks to Aug 8
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Quebec Eurobond Issue
abstract: The province of Quebec is raising $50 million (Canadian) through a six-year Eurobond issue, the lead manager, Societe Generale, said today.

headline: U.S. Gets Bids For Oil Leases In Atlantic
abstract: The Government said today that it received bids totaling some $561 million in its auction of prospecting rights to 285 submerged areas in the Atlantic Ocean 85 miles off the North Carolina coast - including a high bid of $103.8 million for a single tract.   In general, however, oil companies seemed less than enthusiastic about the sale. Only 54 tracts received any bids as water depths ranging to 6,000 feet apparently made oil companies reluctant to enter the bidding.

headline: IN INDIA, SIKHS RAISE A CRY FOR INDEPENDENT NATION
abstract: A 49-year-old former teacher sits cross-legged in the room he dares not leave for fear of arrest and explains passionately if seditiously how he advocates the creation of a Sikh nation to be wrenched violently from India.   The movement represented by Balbhir Singh Sandhu is quixotic and relatively small, but it is growing quickly. Several hundred activists, most of them young, have fanned out through the villages of the heavily Sikh Punjab evangelizing for independence. In Delhi they go out on graffiti raids at night and leave behind the message, ''The Sikh are a nation.''   Mr. Sandhu has sought publicity for his cause by issuing passports in the name of Khalistan, the dreamed-of Sikh homeland that translates as the Country of the Pure.

headline: TEHERAN EXILES SEIZE GUNBOAT BOUND FOR IRAN
abstract: A patrol boat sold to Iran by France was hijacked off the coast of Spain yesterday as an Iranian crew was sailing it to its new home port. An Iranian monarchist group based here took responsibility.   The 150-foot gunboat was one of three cleared for shipment 12 days ago by the French Government after President Francois Mitterrand lifted a two-year embargo that was imposed during the American hostage crisis.   The gunboat was commandeered in the Bay of Cadiz, just off the port city of Cadiz. However, details of the incident remained unclear, with the monarchist group asserting that two gunboats had been seized.

headline: Around the World; Afghans Offer Terms For Talks on Rebellion
abstract: Afghanistan announced new terms today for negotiations to end the Moslem guerrilla rebellion that led to Soviet military intervention, the Kabul radio reported.   For the first time, the Soviet-supported regime agreed to an active role for Secretary General Kurt Waldheim in eventual negotiations and dropped a condition that talks with Iran and Pakistan be held separately.

headline: FOUNDATION SELLING ASSETS WORTH OVER $1 BILLION
abstract: The MacArthur Foundation of Chicago, one of the country's wealthiest foundations, is selling its considerable assets in insurance companies and real estate. Its aim is to comply with Federal laws limiting the tax-free business ownership that is permitted private foundations.   According to experts in the investment banking community, the sale may realize $1 billion to $2 billion for the MacArthur Foundation and would consolidate its position as a financial leader in the philanthropic field, possibly second only to the Ford Foundation, which lists its assets at $2.7 billion.   ''The divestiture, which is necessitated by the Tax Reform Act of 1969, will enable us to substantially increase our grant programs,'' Gaylord Freeman, chairman of the MacArthur Foundation's finance committee, said yesterday. The act limits a foundation's ownership of a business property to a 20 percent holding.

headline: SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Other Business; 40 PERCENT A YEAR ON SAVINGS? NOT FOR LONG
abstract: Open any newspaper last week and the luggage and television sets were all but gone. Banks and savings and loan institutions were again promoting the interest they pay depositors, and the rates were extraordinary.   Midwest Federal in Minneapolis offered 20 percent; Lincoln Savings in New York, 35 percent; and Chase Manhattan, 40 percent. First Federal Savings of Philadelphia tried to top everyone off by proclaiming in big block letters ''We'll pay 1 percent higher than any similiar tax-free savings certificate plan in the Deleware Valley.''

headline: STOCKS REBOUND, PUSHING DOW UP 5.90
abstract: The stock market rallied yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at 954.15, up 5.90, regaining almost as many points as it had lost the previous day. However, much of the increase in the average was attributable to a 4 3/8-point rise in International Paper, to 48, following news about plans to sell some units.   At the same time there was some lessening of speculation in stocks of oil companies, which are the object of takeover rumors.  Volume was 49 million shares, up from 45.2 million Tuesday Malcolm O. MacLean, a broker at Bacon, Whipple & Company, commented on the rally: ''It was probably a consolidation. Silver prices were better and copper was up. Short-term interest rates were down early in the morning. There is hope that interest rates generally might come down. After all, the Administration has been jawboning them down. I think the market might rally from this point for a while.''

headline: PRATT-READ CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Scene; Investment And Inflation
abstract: INFLATION in the United States has slowed markedly in recent months.  In July, seasonally adjusted producer prices of finished goods rose only 5.5 percent at an annual rate from June and were up only 8.8 percent from a year earlier. This was in marked contrast to the 15 to 20 percent rates of increase seen in early 1980. A large part of the improved price performance reflects the worldwide oil glut and its impact on oil-related prices as well as the better-than-expected world agricultural outlook for 1981.   During the 1970's, so-called oil shocks and food-price shocks were important factors propelling the price level upward. Accordingly, it is argued that the recent improvement in inflation is only temporary; that the declines in food and oil prices cannot continue indefinitely, and that when these favorable trends reverse, the United States will return to double-digit inflation.

headline: Pan Am to Offer 2-for-1 Discounts
abstract: Pan American World Airways Inc., in an effort to increase ridership, said that it would offer two-for-one discount fares on certain overseas flights starting Sept.14.

headline: MCCORMICK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: M-G-M's Holders Vote New Shares
abstract: Shareholders of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company approved a plan to increase the company's outstanding stock and sell about $100 million worth of the new shares to M-G-M's principal stockholder, financier Kirk Kerkorian.

headline: Investment Discrepancy
abstract: American companies trying to escape high domestic interest rates may be secretly increasing their borrowings from foreign countries, a Government report that was released today indicates.   The borrowing in 1980 may have been nearly $30 billion - a record annual amount of unexplained funds coming from overseas.

headline: A SOWETO WOMAN REGAINS HER POLITICAL VOICE
abstract: Albertina Sisulu has just recovered her voice. Her problem was not medical but political, in the form of what are known in South Africa as banning orders.   Banning orders make it a crime for their recipients to speak at any kind of gathering - usually even of three persons - or ever to be quoted in print.   Mrs. Sisulu's banning orders lasted for 17 years, and were coupled with severe restrictions on her movements, even within this black township outside Johannesburg. Now she would like to tell her husband and the youngest of her three sons that she is able to speak out again on political issues, but they are in jail.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Athlone Industries announced its purchase of 10,400 shares of its own common stock in the open market for $269,100.   * Emhart Corp. said that it had signed an agreement to buy for cash Dom Sicherheitstechnik G.m.b.H. of West Germany, a maker of electronic alarm systems and locking devices, for an undisclosed sum.

Conferences Of 7 Nations Began in '75
abstract: The economic summit conference has been an annual event since 1975. Following are summaries of the six previous meetings.  Rambouillet, France, 1975 - The conferees rejected a return to fixed exchange rates while agreeing on the need for monetary stability and for international economic cooperation.

headline: 3 Killed in Jail Riot in Brazil
abstract: About 200 policemen used rifle fire, tear gas and attack dogs to break up a prison riot in this southeast Brazilian city today. Three prisoners were killed and 22 inmates and three policemen were injured, the police said.

headline: Goodrich Delays Resin Plant Work
abstract: The B.F. Goodrich Company said that it had delayed indefinitely work on a big new chemical plant in Convent, La., designed to produce polyvinyl chloride and vinyl chloride monomer, because of a drop in demand for the resins.   A Goodrich spokesman said that engineering, design and site preparation already had been completed at the facility.  He declined to disclose h ow much the project has cost to date.

headline: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Ceausescu Sees U.S. Group
abstract: President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania discussed agricultural cooperation and other international issues with a United States Congressional delegation today in Bucharest, the Rumanian press agency Agerpres reported. It said the Rumanian leader and members of the House Agriculture Committee had stressed the importance of developing agriculture, especially in the third world.

headline: The Economy
abstract: The Reagan Administration appeared ready to delay indefinitely the issue of decontrolling natural gas prices. Officials were said to have decided that Congress was too preoccupied with budget matters to take up gas decontrol now. (Page D1.)   President Reagan conferred with budget officials and worked on his television speech for tonight. He was said to be leaning against committing himself to the detailed list of $16 billion in spending reductions that his aides had said would be announced. (A1.)

headline: DENG ALLY GETS MILITARY POST
abstract: Yang Shangkun, a political ally of Deng Xiaoping, China's principal leader, has been appointed secretary general of the Communist Party's military affairs commission, the Peking radio disclosed today. The commission controls China's armed forces, nearly four million strong. Mr. Yang succeeds Geng Biao, who was made Defense Minister earlier this year.

headline: Soviet Adds U.S. Grain
abstract: The Soviet Union has added another 300,000 metric tons of American grain to its orders for delivery during the next six weeks, officials at the Agriculture Department said today.   They said the latest purchases included 150,000 tons of wheat and 150,000 tons of corn for delivery through Sept. 30, the end of the fifth year of a long-term grain agreement with the United States.

headline: BRITISH PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Weak Rates Help Lift Stocks
abstract: The stock market, buoyed by a slight decline in certain interest rates, rose modestly yesterday in accelerated trading.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, ended 5.62 points higher, at 949.30.  Advances outscored declines by a ratio of almost 9 to 5. The strongest gainers were energy stocks and interest-sensitive issues, such as those of utilities and banks.   Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange climbed to 52.6 million shares from Monday's 38.4 million shares as some of the pension funds, banks and mutual funds stepped up their participation in the market.

headline: TIMETABLE IS SET FOR NAMIBIA PACT
abstract: The United States and four other Western nations said today that after consultations with South Africa and black African nations they had developed a timetable for ''final negotiations'' on the independence of South-West Africa.   The five nations, known as the ''contact group on Namibia,'' said in a joint statement that their objective was to begin next year a three-year-old United Nations plan for the phased end of South African control of Namibia, as South-West Africa is now generally known.   Although officials from the five nations all stressed, in separate briefings for reporters, that many issues remained to be settled, they seemed to agree that momentum had been restored to the deadlocked negotiations. South Africa has administered the territory since 1920 when it was given it as a League of Nations mandate, although the United Nations withdrew the mandate in 1966.

headline: N.A.M. Sees Investing Rise
abstract: Despite continuing high interest rates, the nation's manufacturers are expected to raise spending on new investments next year because of the stimulus of the Reagan tax program, the head of the National Association of Manufacturers said today.   Alexander B. Trowbridge, the president of the trade group, said that, among manufacturers, ''there is a confidence that inflation will stabilize and be reduced and that interest rates will also tend downward.''

headline: A 10TH HUNGER STRIKER DIES IN ULSTER
abstract: Michael Devine, a 27-year-old Irish nationalist, died in the Maze Prison here this morning at the beginning of his 60th day without food.   Mr. Devine was the 10th prisoner to die in a series of hunger strikes that began last spring in an attempt to obtain special political status for Irish nationalists in the prison.   To maintain pressure on the British Government, another prisoner is expected to begin fasting within the next few days, taking Mr.  Devine's place in the protest.

headline: Goodrich Selling 4 More Segments
abstract: The B.F. Goodrich Company, the big tire and rubber products maker, is in the process of disposing of four more parts of its business in line with a strategic plan to provide more funds for high-growth areas.   The company, with headquarters in Akron, Ohio, said it had arranged to sell its Liberian rubber plantation affiliate, subject to approval by the Liberian Government, for undisclosed terms.
